book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text: Introduction: Praise be to Allah who blessed us with the Great Quran, which falsehood cannot approach from before it or from behind it; He made it—the Exalted—a lesson for those who take heed, a sufficiency for those who reflect upon its verses and ponder, and a reminder for whoever has a heart or lends a listening ear while he is heedful. Blessings and peace be upon our Chosen Prophet, and upon his family and goodly companions, and upon the followers who follow them in righteousness and emulate them in every age. To proceed: The sciences of the Islamic religion are the most noble and beneficial of sciences. These sciences are numerous and varied, and the science of Interpretation (Tafsir) is the highest of them in worth and the most elevated in status because it relates to the speech of Allah—the Exalted. Given the importance of the science of Interpretation and its status, many scholars have authored works in this field. Their methods of classification varied, and their interests multiplied. Among these scholars was Shihab al-Din Abu al-Abbas Ahmad bin Yusuf, known as Al-Samin Al-Halabi. He authored his book (Al-Durr Al-Masun fi Ulum Al-Kitab Al-Maknun / The Preserved Pearl in the Sciences of the Hidden Book), focusing therein on the linguistic and grammatical aspects of the Holy Quran. It is considered one of the most prominent references in linguistic interpretation and Quranic parsing (I'rab). He also took care to address Quranic readings, both the authentic and the anomalous. His interpretive and linguistic sources in this book were numerous, yet he did not content himself with merely transmitting from his predecessors; rather, he discusses opinions, weighs them, and provides evidence, all in a distinguished scientific style based on a disciplined methodology.
foot_note: None

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text: Among his most prominent sources was the Tafsir of Ibn Atiyyah, which occupies the third rank after the books of Abu Hayyan and Al-Zamakhshari among the sources he quoted from (1). He did not content himself with quoting him; rather, he critiqued him and debated him frequently. He declared this in the introduction of his book, where he said: "And I mentioned many of the discussions directed at Abu al-Qasim al-Zamakhshari and Abu Muhammad bin Atiyyah" (2). Most of those discussions were in the field of parsing (I'rab) and readings. Due to their abundance and scientific value, I chose them to be the subject of my Master's thesis research in Quran and its Sciences. I have tracked the places where Al-Samin quoted Ibn Atiyyah and then followed Ibn Atiyyah's statement with a statement of his own, explaining his error and refuting him, or completing a deficiency in his statement, or removing ambiguity from it, or mentioning a meaning more appropriate than Ibn Atiyyah's statement based on a method of weighing evidence. I collected those rectifications (Istidrakat), categorized them according to their subject, arranged them according to the order of the Surahs and verses in the Quran, and then studied those rectifications. * Importance of the Topic and Reasons for Selection: 1 - The method of rectification (Istidrak) is one of the approved methods for explaining and clarifying meanings, and it is among the best methods of response and correction. (3) 2 - The importance of Ibn Atiyyah's interpretation and its superior scientific value led me to choose his statements which Al-Samin critiqued as the subject of research and study. 3 - The distinctiveness of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in his discussions, the precision of his rectifications, and his adherence to a scientific style in responding to those he disagreed with.
foot_note:
1. See: The Methodology of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Interpretation in his book Al-Durr Al-Masun, by Eissa Al-Duraibi (p. 176).
2. Al-Durr Al-Masun fi Ulum Al-Kitab Al-Maknun (1: 5), Investigation by: Dr. Ahmed Al-Kharrat.
3. See: Rectifications of the Predecessors in Interpretation in the First Three Centuries, by Naif Al-Zahrani (p. 426).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text: 4 - The abundance of Al-Samin Al-Halabi's rectifications upon Ibn Atiyyah, their scientific value, and Al-Samin's moderation in his stance toward Ibn Atiyyah; at times he quotes him and supports his view, at times he refutes him, and at times he defends him against those who refuted him and seeks evidence for him. 5 - The scientific status of Al-Durr Al-Masun; it is considered a collection of the summary of many books on Quranic parsing, and it has been said of it: It is the most majestic of books on Quranic parsing (1). It also took care to mention readings, defend them, and determine their grammatical basis, just as it is considered one of the most prominent references for linguistic interpretation. 6 - The distinctiveness of Al-Samin Al-Halabi's methodology in Quranic parsing; he adheres to the apparent meaning and rejects affectation in parsing. He also relied on the Holy Quran, the Prophetic Hadith, and the speech of the Arabs in his parsing of the Quran, and he paid attention to weighing between different parsings. * Research Objectives: 1 - Clarifying Al-Samin Al-Halabi's stance regarding Ibn Atiyyah's interpretation. 2 - Collecting Al-Samin's rectifications upon Ibn Atiyyah in an independent study. 3 - Studying Al-Samin Al-Halabi's rectifications upon Ibn Atiyyah via a comparative study, and determining the most likely correct view. * Research Boundaries: The rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in "Al-Durr Al-Masun" upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic parsing, from the beginning of the Quran to its end, collecting and studying them. Excluded by this restriction are: Abu Hayyan's rectifications upon Ibn Atiyyah which Al-Samin quoted from his sheikh textually or with some modification or abbreviation (2). However, rectifications he quoted with an addition of his own to his sheikh's words, such as adding a reason for weakening Ibn Atiyyah's view that his sheikh did not mention, are included in this research.
foot_note:
1. See: Al-Itqan fi Ulum Al-Quran, by Jalal al-Din al-Suyuti (2: 447).
2. There are more than one hundred rectifications by Abu Hayyan upon Ibn Atiyyah that Al-Samin quoted from his sheikh without declaring that they were his sheikh's words.

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text: * Previous Studies: I did not find a study dedicated to collecting Al-Samin Al-Halabi's rectifications upon Ibn Atiyyah, but there are studies that dealt with some aspects related to this topic, and other studies that have no relation to my research topic. The following is a mention of the most prominent of those studies: 1 - "The Methodology of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Interpretation in his book Al-Durr Al-Masun", by Dr. Eissa Al-Duraibi. This is a thesis submitted for a Master's degree in the Department of Quran at the College of Fundamentals of Religion at Imam Muhammad bin Saud University, discussed in 1418 AH. The researcher explained in his thesis that Ibn Atiyyah's interpretation is one of the basic sources Al-Samin Al-Halabi relied upon in "Al-Durr Al-Masun." He discussed the fields in which he quoted him, his method of quoting him, and his stance on what he quotes. He also mentioned that Al-Samin took care to debate the grammarians/parsers and refute them, including Ibn Atiyyah. 2 - "Selections of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in the book Al-Durr Al-Masun: Study and Evaluation", by researcher: Muhammad Abdul Samad. This is a thesis submitted for a Master's degree in the Department of Grammar at the College of Arabic Language at Imam Muhammad bin Saud University, discussed in 1417 AH. It is a grammatical and morphological study, and it contains some of Al-Samin's grammatical rectifications upon Ibn Atiyyah. 3 - "Grammatical Directives for Anomalous Readings in (Al-Durr Al-Masun) by Al-Samin Al-Halabi, Collection and Study", by researcher: Ibrahim Salem Al-Sa'idi. This is a PhD thesis at the Islamic University, discussed in 1425 AH.

text: This study is related to my research topic in that some of Al-Samin Al-Halabi's rectifications upon Ibn Atiyyah were in the field of anomalous readings. However, it is a grammatical study relying on grammatical rules for study and weighting, unlike my study which will be interpretive, based on the rules of weighting related to readings and parsing among exegetes (Mufassireen). 4 - "Grammatical Objections of Al-Samin Al-Halabi to Al-Zamakhshari in Al-Durr Al-Masun: Collection, Study, and Evaluation", by researcher: Abdullah Al-Jafari, a Master's thesis in Grammar, Morphology, and Philology at the College of Arabic Language at Imam Muhammad bin Saud University, discussed in 1417 AH. This study, and the grammatical, morphological, and rhetorical studies to be mentioned afterwards, have no relation to my research topic. 5 - "Grammatical and Morphological Objections of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in his book (Al-Durr Al-Masun) to Abu al-Baqa al-Ukbari in his book (Al-Tibyan fi I'rab al-Quran)" by researcher: Al-Talbidi Muhammad, Master's thesis at the College of Arabic Language, Imam Muhammad bin Saud University, discussed in 1409 AH. 6 - "Objections of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun to Abu Hayyan: A Grammatical Morphological Study", by researcher: Abdullah Al-Tariqi, a PhD thesis in the College of Arabic Language at the Islamic University, discussed in 1420 AH. 7 - "Morphological Issues according to Al-Samin Al-Halabi through his two books: (Al-Durr Al-Masun and Umdat Al-Huffaz) Study and Evaluation", by researcher: Abdul Wahid Al-Harbi, Master's thesis at the College of Arabic Language - Islamic University, discussed in 1423 AH.

Index of Prophetic Hadiths. Index of Notable People (A'lam). Index of Poetry. Index of Sources and References. Index of Topics. * Research Methodology: The research is based on the inductive comparative method, according to the following: 1 - In studying the rectifications, I begin by mentioning the verse in which the rectification occurred, then I mention Ibn Atiyyah's statement, then Al-Samin's rectification upon him. Then I undertake the study of the rectification, mentioning the sayings of scholars on the issue or issues related to the rectification, explicitly stating the names of the most prominent scholars who agreed with or disagreed with Ibn Atiyyah and Al-Samin. Then I conclude with what appears to me to be the preponderant view, explaining the reason for the weighting, and I pass judgment on the rectification. 2 - I categorized the rectifications according to their subject, and arranged the rectifications in each subject according to the order of the Surahs and Verses in the Quran. 3 - Writing Quranic verses in the Othmani script, referencing them to their Surahs and mentioning their numbers.

text:
Section One
The Meaning of Rectification (Istidrak), Its Purposes, and Its Types
First Demand: The meaning of Rectification and its purposes.
First: The Meaning of Rectification:
Rectification (Istidrak) linguistically: Istidrak is the `Istif'al` form derived from (Daraka), conveying the meaning of seeking and catching up (1). Ibn Faris (2) said: "The Dal, Ra, and Kaf form a single root, which is the catching up of one thing to another and reaching it" (3). It is said: ...
foot_note:
1. See: Al-Usul fi Al-Nahw, by Ibn Al-Sarraj (3: 127), Al-Khasa'is, by Ibn Jinni (2: 155), Al-Mufassal, by Al-Zamakhshari (1: 374), Lisan Al-Arab, by Ibn Manzur, root: Daraka (10: 419), Sharh Ibn Aqil 'ala Alfiyyat Ibn Malik (4: 264), Al-Muzhir fi Ulum Al-Lughah wa Anwa'iha, by Al-Suyuti (1: 41).
2. Ahmad bin Faris bin Zakariya, Abu Al-Hussein, one of the senior Imams of language. Among his most prominent works are: Al-Sahibi fi Fiqh Al-Lughah and Maqayis Al-Lughah. He followed the methodology of Ahl Al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah. He died in Rayy in the year 395 AH. See: Nuzhat Al-Alba', by Al-Anbari (p. 235), Mu'jam Al-Udaba', by Yaqut Al-Hamawi (1: 410), Inbah Al-Ruwat, by Al-Qifti (1: 127).
3. Maqayis Al-Lughah, root: Daraka, (2: 269).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
"I reached (Adraktu) the man, an act of reaching (Idrakan): if I caught up with him" (1). And the people caught up with one another (Tadaraka): the last of them caught up with the first of them (2). And (Istadraka) what was missed and (Tadarakahu) have the same meaning (3). Al-Zamakhshari (4) said: "He rectified (Tadaraka) the error of opinion with correctness and rectified it (Istadrakahu), and he rectified his statement against him (Istadraka 'alayhi qawlahu)" (5). Al-Zubaidi (6) said: "Istadraka 'alayhi qawlahu: He corrected his mistake; and from this comes 'Al-Mustadrak 'ala Al-Sahihayn'" (7). In Al-Mu'jam Al-Wasit: "Istadraka 'alayhi al-qawl: He corrected his mistake, or completed a deficiency in it, or removed ambiguity from it" (8).
It appears from what has been mentioned that 'Istidrak' in the language has two usages:
The First: To reach one thing with another, if it attempts to catch up to it.
foot_note:
1. Jamharat Al-Lughah, by Ibn Duraid, root: Daraka, (2: 636).
2. See: Lisan Al-Arab, by Ibn Manzur, root (Daraka), (10: 419), Al-Qamus Al-Muhit, by Al-Fayruzabadi, root (Darak), (1: 938).
3. See: Al-Sahah: Taj Al-Lughah wa Sahah Al-Arabiyah, by Al-Jawhari, root: Daraka, (4: 1582).
4. Mahmoud bin Omar Al-Zamakhshari, Abu Al-Qasim, Jar Allah, an Imam in language, grammar, and literature. He was a Mu'tazilite. In Tafsir, he authored: Al-Kashshaaf 'an Haqa'iq Al-Tanzil wa 'Uyun Al-Aqawil fi Wujuh Al-Ta'wil. He died in Khwarezm in the year 538 AH. See: Nuzhat Al-Alba', by Al-Anbari (p. 290), Mu'jam Al-Udaba', by Yaqut Al-Hamawi (19: 126), Inbah Al-Ruwat, by Al-Qifti (3: 265), Tabaqat Al-Mufassirin, by Al-Suyuti (p. 120).
5. Asas Al-Balaghah, root: Daraka, (1: 285).
6. Muhammad bin Muhammad Al-Husseini Al-Zubaidi, Abu Al-Fayd, nicknamed Murtada, a scholar in language and genealogy. Among his most prominent books are: Taj Al-Arus fi Sharh Al-Qamus and Ithaf Al-Sadah Al-Muttaqin fi Sharh Ihya' Ulum Al-Din. He died of the plague in Egypt in the year 1205 AH. See: Al-A'lam by Al-Zirikli (7: 70), Hilyat Al-Bashar fi Tarikh Al-Qarn Al-Thalith 'Ashar, by Abdul Razzaq Al-Maydani (1: 1492), Tabaqat Al-Nassabin, by Bakr Abu Zaid (1: 181).
7. Taj Al-Arus, root: Daraka (27: 144).
8. See: Al-Mu'jam Al-Wasit, prepared by: The Academy of the Arabic Language, (Istadraka), (1: 281).

The Second: In such usage as their saying: "He rectified the opinion or the matter," if he amends the error or deficiency he had been negligent in (1).
Rectification (Istidrak) terminologically:
Rectification in the terminology of grammarians: Removing a misconception that arose from previous speech (2).
In the terminology of jurists (3): Repairing a defect, deficiency, or missed act that occurred in speech or action (4).
The intended meaning of Rectification (Istidrak) in this research: Correction, completion, and clarification. This is done by following the first statement with a second statement that corrects its error, completes its deficiency, or removes ambiguity from it (5).
This meaning is what was intended by the scholars who authored works in the field of Rectifications (Istidrakat) in various sciences.
foot_note:
1. See: The Kuwaiti Fiqh Encyclopedia (3: 269).

text:
The First: Refuting the statement of the one being rectified, invalidating it, and correcting his error, sometimes with an explanation of the critique's basis.
The Second: Completing a deficiency in the statement of the one being rectified, removing ambiguity from it, and directing the listener to a more appropriate meaning based on a method of weighting evidence, which is sometimes mentioned (1).
Sometimes there may be agreement on the statement but disagreement on the evidence or reasoning. For example, the rectifier might say: "And his statement—meaning the statement of the one being rectified—is correct, but the evidence is invalid," or "but the cause he mentioned is not correct," or "is not suitable as a reason for that statement," and then he follows up by mentioning the correct evidence or appropriate reasoning. This falls under correcting an error and completing it by stating its evidence or cause.
Through the purposes of rectification, we can glean some of the benefits of studying rectifications. Among the most prominent are:
1 - Knowing the most correct opinions and those most worthy of acceptance in the interpretation of the Book of Allah -the Exalted-.
2 - These rectifications highlighted the rules of weighting (Tarjih) (2) and contributed to enumerating their facets (3).
3 - Knowing the causes of error in Interpretation (4), and if those causes are known, they can be avoided (5).
foot_note:
1. See: Istidrakat Al-Salaf fi Al-Tafsir, by Naif Al-Zahrani (p. 429).
2. One of the most prominent ways to know the rules of weighting is tracking and studying the rectifications of exegetes. Among the sources for rules of weighting are books of Tafsir that focused on critiquing opinions and correcting them. See: Qawa'id Al-Tarjih 'ind Al-Mufassirin, by Hussein Al-Harbi (1: 9, 29).
3. See: Istidrakat Al-Salaf fi Al-Tafsir, by Naif Al-Zahrani (p. 433).
4. Knowing the causes of error in Tafsir is a fruit of studying rectifications, for rectification is caused by an exegete falling into error. When rectifications are studied, the causes of error become known. The causes of error in Tafsir are many, for example: Lack of knowledge of the Sunnah that explains the verses. An example of this is the opinion of Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, regarding the waiting period of the pregnant woman whose husband has died, and the disagreement of Abu Huraira and others with him. See: Sahih Al-Bukhari (6: 155), Book of Tafsir, Chapter: {And for those who are pregnant, their term is until they give birth}, Hadith (4909), and Sahih Muslim (2: 1122), Book of Divorce, Chapter: Expiry of the waiting period of the woman whose husband died and others by giving birth, Hadith (1485).
5. See: Istidrakat Al-Salaf fi Al-Tafsir, by Naif Al-Zahrani (p. 439).

Second Demand: Types of Rectifications.
Rectifications in Tafsir varied according to their subject and field, and they can be summarized into two main types:
1 - Rectifications in Transmission and Tradition (Naql and Athar).
These are rectifications that revolve around what is transmitted via tradition, and regarding the acceptance, rejection, or correction of this transmitted material. Examples include: Rectifications dealing with accepting or rejecting a Quranic reading, rectifications dealing with accepting, rejecting, or correcting some Israeliyat (Biblical narratives), and rectifications related to causes of revelation and the abrogating and abrogated verses in terms of their authenticity or lack thereof.
2 - Rectifications in Opinion and Reasoning (Ra'y and Nazar).
foot_note: None

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
These are rectifications arising from the disagreement of exegetes regarding the meaning of a verse and its interpretation, the explanation of its wording, its rulings, its parsing, and the like; a disagreement in opinion and reasoning, not in transmission and tradition.
Examples include: Rectifications in the direction/justification of readings, rectifications related to a specific exegete's opinion on the meaning of a verse, rectifications in Quranic parsing (I'rab), and rectifications in the meanings of Quranic expressions.
foot_note: None

Introduction to Ibn Atiyyah and Al-Samin Al-Halabi and Their Books on Interpretation
First Demand: Introduction to Ibn Atiyyah and His Book on Interpretation.
First: Ibn Atiyyah's Personal and Scientific Life.
- His Name, Lineage, Kunya, Birth, and Death:
He is Abdul Haq bin Ghalib bin Atiyyah Al-Muharibi, Al-Gharnati (from Granada), Abu Muhammad. He was born in the year 481 AH, and died in the fortress of Lorca (1) in the year 541 AH; it was also said: 542 AH, and said: 546 AH (2).
- His Sheikhs (Teachers):
Ibn Atiyyah studied under a group of scholars (3). The following is a mention of the most prominent among them, and what he acquired from them:
1 - Al-Hussein bin Muhammad Al-Ghassani Al-Andalusi Al-Jayyani (4), Abu Ali, the Hadith scholar and Hafiz. He was a scholar of language, parsing, poetry, and genealogy. Among his works is (Taqyid Al-Muhmal), in which he vocalized every word in the narrators of the two Sahihs that might be confusing. He died in the year 498 AH (5).

It has a fortress and a fortified stronghold. It is located in eastern Andalusia, west of Murcia and east of Almeria. The meaning of Lorca in Latin is: The Fertile Planting. - His Students:
Ibn Atiyyah was one of the senior scholars of his era, and students of knowledge were eager to benefit from his knowledge; thus many of them studied under him. The following is a mention of some of his students:
1 - Muhammad bin Khayr bin Omar bin Khalifa Al-Lamtouni Al-Ishbili, Abu Bakr, known as Ibn Khayr. The Hafiz, the Master Reciter (Mujawwid), the Reciter (Muqri'). One of the reciters and Hadith scholars famous for good precision and mastery of recording, along with his knowledge of Arabic, language, literature, and strange terms. He was prolific in narration and heard from more than one hundred individuals. Among his most famous works: Index of what he narrated from his sheikhs (Fahrasat Ibn Khayr Al-Ishbili). He died in the year 575 AH (3).

He was knowledgeable in Fiqh and its principles (Usul), advanced in theology (Ilm Al-Kalam), skilled in many sciences of the ancients such as medicine and arithmetic, and he had advancement in the science of Arabic. He died in the year 592 AH (3).

He was among those whom Allah placed affection for in the hearts of His servants, and he was among the most jealous of people for the Sunnah and its people, and the most hateful of the people of desires and innovation. Judge Ibn Atiyyah was Ash'arite in creed; he followed the methodology of the Salaf (Predecessors) in some creedal issues and differed from them in others.

The issue of the Vision; he affirmed that the servants will see their Lord on the Day of Resurrection (1). And the issue of the committer of a major sin; he holds that he will not abide eternally in the Fire (2). He also agreed with the Salaf on the issue of establishing Intercession for the disobedient monotheists (3).
He disagreed with Ahl Al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah in his interpretation (Ta'wil) of some of the Attributes of Allah Almighty. Among the attributes he interpreted metaphorically: The Attribute of Istiwa (Rising over) the Throne; he says: It is the rising of power and authority (4). He also interpreted the Attribute of the Hand for Allah the Exalted; he said: It is an expression for bestowing favors (5).
- His Jurisprudential School:
Ibn Atiyyah was Maliki in school (Madhhab), and he is one of the notables of the Maliki school (6). When interpreting verses of rulings, he presents the different jurisprudential schools without being fanatical about his own school, and he gives the opinions of Imam Malik (7) special attention (8).

He was known for his intense care for the Sunnah. He authored the book (Al-Muwatta'), in which he narrated hundreds of Hadiths arranged according to Fiqh chapters. Al-Shafi'i said of him: "If scholars are mentioned, then Malik is the star." He died in Medina in the year 179 AH. book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
- His Grammatical School:
Ibn Atiyyah was a follower of the Basran school in grammar, admiring the opinions of Sibawayh (1). He studied the books of the Basrans and their commentaries under more than one sheikh, especially the book of Sibawayh and the book Al-Jumal in Grammar (2).
Second: Introduction to Ibn Atiyyah's Interpretation.
Name of this Interpretation: Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz fi Tafsir Al-Kitab Al-Aziz (The Concise Editor in the Interpretation of the Mighty Book).
Ibn Atiyyah said about his interpretation: "I intended in it to be comprehensive, concise, and edited (Muharrar). I do not mention stories except what the verse cannot be understood without. I affirm the sayings of the scholars regarding meanings, attributed to them according to what the Righteous Predecessors (Salaf Salih), may Allah be pleased with them, received of the Book of Allah... I listed the interpretation in this commentary according to the order of the verse's words in terms of ruling, grammar, language, meaning, or reading... I intended to present all readings: the used and the anomalous, and I relied on clarifying the meanings and all possibilities of the words, all of that according to my effort and the limit of my knowledge, and with the utmost brevity and elimination of superfluous speech." (3)
Ibn Atiyyah's interpretation is considered one of the best and most just interpretations. He reviewed the works of those before him, refined them, and summarized them, and he is, with that, possessed of excellent expression (4).
foot_note:
1. See: Manhaj Ibn Atiyyah fi Tafsir Al-Quran, by Abdul Wahab Fayed (p. 154).
2. See: Fahras Ibn Atiyyah, (p. 74, 121, 128).

4. See: Al-Tashil li Ulum Al-Tanzil, by Ibn Juzayy (1: 20).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
Abu Hayyan (1) said - comparing the interpretation of Ibn Atiyyah and Al-Zamakhshari: "The book of Ibn Atiyyah is more transmitting, more comprehensive, and purer, and Al-Zamakhshari is more summarized and deeper." (2)
Ibn Khaldun (3) said: "When people returned to investigation and scrutiny, and Abu Muhammad bin Atiyyah came from the later scholars in the Maghreb, he summarized all those interpretations and sought what was closest to correctness among them. He placed that in a book circulated among the people of the Maghreb and Andalusia, excellent in its method." (4)
Ibn Atiyyah's interpretation is among the comprehensive, edited interpretations, so it deserved to be described as (Muharrar / Edited); for he edited what needed editing, and it is (Wajiz / Concise) relative to the interpretations that preceded it (5).
Ibn Atiyyah bestowed upon his interpretation from his overflowing scientific spirit what gained it precision, popularity, and acceptance, and it became the most truthful witness to its author regarding his leadership in Arabic and other various scientific aspects.

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text: In his interpretation, he mentions the verse and then interprets it with easy phrasing. He cites traditional interpretations (Tafsir al-Ma'thur) and sometimes discusses what is transmitted. He frequently cites Arabic poetry and appeals to the Arabic language when directing certain meanings. He pays great attention to grammatical structure, just as he frequently addresses readings and applies different meanings to them (1). However, Ibn Atiyyah's interpretation is criticized for interpreting some verses of Attributes according to the Ash'arite doctrine. Sheikh al-Islam said: "The interpretation of Ibn Atiyyah is closer to the Sunnah and the Group (Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah) and safer from innovation than the interpretation of Al-Zamakhshari. Had he mentioned the words of the Predecessors (Salaf) found in the traditional interpretations reported from them as they are, it would have been better and more beautiful. He often leaves what is transmitted from the Predecessors and does not relate it at all, mentioning instead what he claims to be the saying of the investigators (Muhaqqiqin)—meaning by them a faction of the theologians (Ahl al-Kalam) who established their principles using methods similar to those used by the Mu'tazila to establish their principles, even if they are closer to the Sunnah than the Mu'tazila. However, everyone due a right should be given their right, and it should be known that this is among the category of interpretation based on a [sectarian] school." (2)
foot_note:

2. Muqaddimah fi Usul Al-Tafsir (p. 37). Dr. Musa'id Al-Tayyar has good remarks on this subject in his explanation of Sheikh al-Islam's introduction (pp. 231 - 238).

Second Demand: Introduction to Al-Samin Al-Halabi and His Book on Interpretation.
First: Al-Samin Al-Halabi's Personal and Scientific Life.
- His Name, Lineage, Kunya, and Death:
Ahmad bin Yusuf bin Muhammad—and it was said Abdul Da'im—Al-Halabi, Shihab al-Din, Abu al-Abbas, known as Al-Samin. He died in the year 756 AH (1).
- His Sheikhs:
Al-Samin Al-Halabi studied under illustrious sheikhs, and they are many. Among them:
1 - Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Abdul Khaliq bin Ali Al-Sa'igh Al-Masri Al-Shafi'i, Taqi al-Din, Abu Abdullah, the Reciter. The Musnid (possessor of chains of transmission) of his era and the Sheikh of his time. He studied under a large number of sheikhs, and people traveled to him from all regions and crowded around him due to the highness of his chain of transmission (Isnad) and the abundance of his narrations. He died in the year 725 AH (2).

text:
- His Creed:
Al-Samin Al-Halabi was Ash'arite in the chapter of Names and Attributes. Among the attributes he interpreted metaphorically (did Ta'wil for):
- The Attribute of Anger (Ghadab); he said: It is Vengeance (1).
- The Attribute of Shyness (Haya); he said: It is a metaphor for abstaining or fear (2).
- The Attribute of the Shin (Saq); he said: It is a metonymy for severity (3).
He agreed with Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah in most other doctrinal issues. Among the issues in which he agreed with them:
1 - The issue of the Servants' Actions; he affirms that Allah is the Creator of the servants' actions, whether good or evil (4).
2 - The issue of the Vision; he affirms that the servants will see their Lord on the Day of Resurrection (5).

text:
- His Jurisprudential School:
Al-Samin followed the Shafi'i school. Those who wrote on the classes of Shafi'i scholars included his biography (1).
- His Grammatical School:
Al-Samin was Basran in orientation in the bulk of the grammatical opinions he established and preferred. However, he was not fanatical about his grammatical school; he would sometimes depart from the rules of the Basrans to support the Kufans (2). We see that he might prefer the Kufan opinion if the evidence supports it, which confirms Al-Samin's independence in his opinions and preferences in grammar generally and in his parsing of the Quran specifically (3).
- His Works:
Al-Samin left behind a number of valuable books, including:
1 - (Al-Tafsir Al-Kabir / The Great Interpretation): This is the one Ibn Hajar viewed, as he said in Al-Samin's biography: "He has an interpretation of the Quran in twenty volumes which I saw in his handwriting" (4). Al-Samin referred to this interpretation in more than one place in Al-Durr Al-Masun, calling it (Al-Tafsir Al-Kabir) (5).

In this book, he focused on issues of Quranic parsing and the direction of concurrent (Mutawatir) and anomalous (Shadh) readings. text:
Second: Introduction to His Book.
Name of this book: Al-Durr Al-Masun fi Ulum Al-Kitab Al-Maknun.
Al-Samin Al-Halabi authored this book intending to study the Holy Quran in terms of its parsing, the direction of its concurrent and anomalous readings, and its interpretation, relying on many sources in interpretation, Quranic parsing, readings, strange Quranic terms, grammar, and language. He collected in it the science of Parsing (I'rab), the science of Morphology (Sarf), the science of Language (Lughah), the science of Meanings (Ma'ani), and the science of Rhetoric (Bayan).
It came in the introduction of his book: The Righteous Predecessors criticized those who recite the Quran without understanding. Thus, it is more appropriate for the intelligent and wise person to inspect its sciences. He said: "And they are, after perfecting its pronunciation by recitation, five sciences: The science of Parsing, the science of Morphology, the science of Language, the science of Meanings, and the science of Rhetoric." (1)
So he gathered the aspects of these sciences, and said about this work of his: "It is the core of the speech of the people of these sciences." (2)
One of his primary purposes in this work was: Debating the exegetes, especially the grammarians/parsers among them such as Abu Hayyan, Ibn Atiyyah, and Al-Zamakhshari (3).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
It is one of the most majestic books on Quranic parsing. Al-Suyuti said of it: "It is the most majestic of them, despite the stuffing and prolixity within it" (1).
When presenting issues, Al-Samin cares about attributing opinions to their owners. He does not exit any issue until he gives it its due of research and study. He is not content with mere transmission; rather, he discusses opinions with a disciplined scientific discussion and cares about weighing between opinions (2).
He expands in his talk on grammatical and morphological issues, and his method in that is distinguished by rooting and establishing rules (3). His methodology in parsing the Quran was disciplined and distinguished by many features, most notably: Attention to meaning, and adherence to the apparent meaning in parsing (4).
He pays great attention to presenting authentic and anomalous Quranic readings attributed to their owners, directing them (explaining their grammatical validity), and defending them. He may use a reading as evidence for a specific opinion (5).
He gives special attention to Quranic vocabulary and highlights the rhetorical aspects in Quranic verses. He is distinguished by mentioning important interpretive insights regarding the interpretation of the Quran and attention to the endings of verses and other matters (6).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
Section Three
The Stance of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun Regarding the Interpretation of Ibn Atiyyah
First: The Status of Ibn Atiyyah's Interpretation with Al-Samin Al-Halabi.
Al-Samin Al-Halabi relied heavily on Ibn Atiyyah's interpretation in his book (Al-Durr Al-Masun). Dr. Ahmad Al-Kharrat placed (Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz) in the second rank among sources Al-Samin quoted from, after the interpretation of Abu Hayyan (1). Meanwhile, Dr. Eissa Al-Duraibi opined that it occupies the third rank after the interpretation (Al-Bahr Al-Muhit) by Abu Hayyan and (Al-Kashshaaf) by Al-Zamakhshari among the sources Al-Samin quoted from (2). After tracking and precise research, I concluded that Ibn Atiyyah's interpretation occupies the third rank among the sources Al-Samin quoted from (3). There is no strangeness in that; for Ibn Atiyyah's interpretation greatly influenced the exegetes after him, and they relied on it due to its distinction in editing opinions.
Al-Samin said while talking about his method in his book: "I mentioned many of the discussions directed at Abu al-Qasim al-Zamakhshari, Abu Muhammad bin Atiyyah, and Muhibb al-Din Abu al-Baqa (1), and if it was possible to answer on their behalf with something, I mentioned it." (2)

3. Where the places he quoted from Al-Zamakhshari exceed the places he quoted from Ibn Atiyyah by more than 2000 places.
1. Abdullah bin Al-Hussein bin Abdullah Al-Ukbari Al-Baghdadi, Abu Al-Baqa, Muhibb al-Din, the Imam and Scholar, the brilliant Grammarian, the Hanbali. He was knowledgeable in grammar, language, jurisprudence, inheritance laws, and theology. Among his works: (Al-Tibyan fi I'rab Al-Quran), (I'rab Al-Shawadh min Al-Qira'at), and (I'rab Al-Hadith). He died in Baghdad in the year 616 AH. See: Tarikh Baghdad (21: 104), Mu'jam Al-Udaba', by Yaqut Al-Hamawi (4: 1515), Siyar A'lam Al-Nubala (22: 91).

text:
Second: The Fields in Which Al-Samin Quoted from Ibn Atiyyah:
Al-Samin quoted from Ibn Atiyyah and benefited from him in several fields. Following is a mention of the most prominent of them with examples:
1 - Readings (Qira'at).
Al-Samin quoted from Ibn Atiyyah extensively in the field of readings, whether in transmitting them and attributing them to their readers or in judging and directing them.

This is the field in which he quoted him the most; this is because Al-Samin was concerned with grammar and parsing in his book (4).

3 - Language (Lughah).
He quotes Ibn Atiyyah in explaining the linguistic meanings of some Quranic words, such as the meaning of (Al-'Afw / Pardon) at His saying - the Exalted -: {Then We forgave you after that so that you might be grateful} [Al-Baqarah: 52]. Al-Samin said (1): "Ibn Atiyyah said: 'And Al-'Afw is covering the trace and removing the initial state of sin or otherwise, and Al-'Afw is not used in the sense of ignoring (Safh) except regarding sin'." (2)
4 - Rhetoric (Balaghah).
Al-Samin quoted some of Ibn Atiyyah's speech in the field of Quranic rhetoric.
Example: Upon discussing the simile occurring in His saying - the Exalted -: {The example of what they spend in this worldly life is like a wind containing frost which strikes the harvest of a people who have wronged themselves and destroys it} [Al Imran: 117], he said (3): "It is said that it is of the category of comparing two things to two things, so He mentioned one of the two compared items and omitted mentioning the other, then mentioned one of the two items compared to and omitted mentioning the other; for He deleted from every two that which its counterpart indicates... Ibn Atiyyah chose this and said: 'This is the pinnacle of rhetoric and inimitability'." (4)

5 - Morphology (Sarf).
The field of morphology was one of the fields in which Al-Samin quoted from Ibn Atiyyah in more than one place in his book.
Example: Upon discussing the word (Tibyan) and its morphology in His saying - the Exalted -: {And We have sent down to you the Book as clarification for all things} [An-Nahl: 89], he said (1): "It is a verbal noun (Masdar)." And Ibn Atiyyah said: "Tibyan is a noun and not a verbal noun." (2)
6 - Interpretation by Opinion (Tafsir bi al-Ra'y).
Al-Samin quoted from Ibn Atiyyah some of his interpretive reasonings.
Example: Upon explaining the meaning of His saying - the Exalted -: {So their plea when Our punishment came to them was not but that they said, "Indeed, we were wrongdoers"} [Al-A'raf: 5], he said (3): "Ibn Atiyyah said (4): 'The verse bears the meaning: Their plea which was in the state of their disbelief did not result in anything but admission'."

Third: Al-Samin's Stance on What He Quotes from Ibn Atiyyah:
1 - Quoting without comment.
He often mentions Ibn Atiyyah's opinions without approval or discussion.
Example: Upon speaking about the second (Min / from) in His saying - the Exalted -: {It is Allah who made for you the grazing animals upon which you ride, and some of them you eat} [Ghafir: 79], he said (1): "Ibn Atiyyah said: 'It is to explain the genus (classification)'." (2) He did not comment on this statement.
2 - Approving his saying and defending him.
He sometimes approves of what Ibn Atiyyah says and agrees with him.
Example: Upon his discussion of the meaning of His saying (Asbahtum / You became) in His saying - the Exalted -: {And remember the favor of Allah upon you - when you were enemies and He brought your hearts together and you became, by His favor, brothers} [Al Imran: 103], he said: Ibn Atiyyah said: "{You became} is an expression of continuity, even if the word is specific to a certain time. This word was specified for this meaning because it is the beginning of the day, and in it is the beginning of actions, so the state which a person feels within himself during it is the state he continues upon for the majority of his day" (3). book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
Chapter One: Al-Samin Al-Halabi's Rectifications upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings.
[1]: Ibn Atiyyah said regarding the direction of the reading appearing in {Yattawwafa} from His saying - the Exalted -: {Indeed, as-Safa and al-Marwah are among the symbols of Allah. So whoever makes Hajj to the House or performs 'Umrah - there is no blame upon him for walking between them} [Al-Baqarah: 158]: "Abu Al-Sammal read (1) (An Yattafa) (2). Its origin is: Yatatawwafu. The Waw moved and what was before it opened, so it was flipped into an Alif and became (Yatatafu). The Taa was assimilated into the Taa after becoming silent, according to the doctrine of those who permit assimilating the second into the first, as came in {Muddakir}. Whoever does not permit that said: The Taa was flipped into a Taa (emphatic T) then the Taa was assimilated into the Taa. There is a point of view (criticism) in this; because the original was assimilated into the augmentative, and that is weak." (3)
Al-Samin said, rectifying him: "And this which Ibn Atiyyah said contains error from two aspects. First: His claim of assimilating the second into the first, and there is no parallel for that; rather, the first is assimilated into the second. Second: That he said 'as came in {Muddakir}' (4); for it should have been said according to his saying: Mudhdhakir with a pointed Dhal. This is a poor dialect. The good dialect is with the unpointed Dal; because we flipped the Taa of 'Ifti'al' after the pointed Dhal into an unpointed Dal, so two approximants met, so we flipped the first of them to the genus of the second and assimilated." (5)
foot_note:
1. Qa'nab bin Abi Qa'nab Al-Adawi Al-Basri, Abu Al-Sammal. The Reciter. He was an Imam in Arabic, and he has an anomalous reading. He died around 160 AH. See: Mizan Al-I'tidal, by Al-Dhahabi (4: 534), Al-Wafi bil-Wafiyat, by Al-Safadi (24: 197), Ghayat Al-Nihayah fi Tabaqat Al-Qurra, by Ibn Al-Jazari (2: 27).
2. Ibn Abbas and Abu Al-Sammal read (An Yattafa) and its origin is Yatatawwafu on the measure of (Yafta'ilu). See: I'rab Al-Quran, by Al-Nahhas (1: 86), Mushkil I'rab Al-Quran, by Makki bin Abi Talib (1: 114), Tafsir Abi Hayyan (2: 67).
3. Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (1: 229).
4. In Surah Al-Qamar, Verses: 15, 17, 22, 32, 40, 51.
5. Al-Durr Al-Masun (2: 191).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
Analysis and Study of the Rectification:
Ibn Atiyyah viewed that the Taa in (Yatatafu) was assimilated into the Taa (emphatic) after becoming silent (Yattafa), meaning he sees the assimilation of the second into the first. Al-Samin opposed him in that and said: The first is assimilated into the second. This is the preponderant view, and it is Abu Hayyan's opinion as well, where he said: "The Taa (emphatic) was assimilated into the Taa after flipping it into a Taa (emphatic)." (1)
This direction has a weakness according to Ibn Atiyyah where he said: "Because the original was assimilated into the augmentative, and that is weak." This is not weak because the Taa of (Ifta'ala) is flipped into a Taa (emphatic) if preceded by a Taa (emphatic) (2), and that is obligatory (3). After flipping the Taa into a Taa (emphatic), the Taa (emphatic) is assimilated into it (4). The Arabs say in (Yattalibu) for example: Yattalibu; they substituted the Taa with a Taa (emphatic) because it is from its point of articulation, so they assimilated the Taa (emphatic) into the Taa (emphatic), and the assimilation here became obligatory due to its silence (5). The principle in Arab speech is the appearance of the original and not assimilating it into the augmentative, but in such a case they flipped the augmentative into the genus of the original and assimilated it (6).
foot_note:
1. Tafsir Abi Hayyan (2: 67).
2. See: Al-Mufassal fi San'at Al-I'rab, by Al-Zamakhshari (1: 554).
3. Flipping the Taa of Ifti'al to an approximant matching its attribute is obligatory, because if it remained with its proximity to the Taa (emphatic), it would lead either to assimilating it - and it is not assimilated into the Taa because of the Velarization (Itbaq) in the Taa which is lost by assimilation - or to manifesting it, which makes pronunciation difficult due to proximity and conflict in attributes; for the Taa is a plosive (Shadid) and the Taa (emphatic) is fricative/plosive (Rakhw - Note: classical definition varies), and also the Taa is whispered (Mahmus) and the Taa (emphatic) is voiced (Majhur), so they flipped it with the Taa (emphatic) due to its difference in voicing and laxity. See: Al-Idah fi Sharh Al-Mufassal, by Ibn Al-Hajib (2: 513).
4. See: Al-Mufassal fi San'at Al-I'rab, by Al-Zamakhshari (1: 554).
5. See: Sharh Al-Mufassal, by Ibn Yaish (5: 553).
6. See: The previous source (5: 555).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
Ibn Atiyyah exemplified the assimilation of the second into the first with {Muddakir}, and Al-Samin criticized him for that; because based on his saying, it would be necessary to say (Mudhdhakir) and not (Muddakir), and this is correct. For Ibn Atiyyah sees the assimilation of the second (the Taa) into the first (the Dhal) in (Mudhtakir) becoming (Mudhdhakir), without substitution, like his saying in (Yatatafu): by assimilating the second (the Taa) into the first (the Taa emphatic) becoming (Yattaf). Al-Samin said that (Mudhdhakir) is a poor dialect, and that the good one is with the unpointed Dal (Muddakir), its origin being (Mudhtakir), the Taa of Ifti'al was flipped into a Dal after the Dhal (Mudhdakir), so two approximants met, so the first of them (the Dhal) was flipped to the genus of the second (the Dal), and the Dal was assimilated into the Dal.
The correct view is that (Mudhdhakir) is not a poor dialect, but rather uncommon. The Taa of Ifti'al is flipped with the Dhal into a Dal obligatorily, like their saying in (Mudhtakir): (Mudhdakir). It is permissible in it, after flipping the Taa, to have two flips. One of them: Flipping the Dhal into a Dal (Muddakir) and assimilating it into the Dal that follows it, so they become in pronunciation a single doubled Dal (Muddakir). This is the condition of assimilation, because they flip the first letter to the genus of the second then assimilate it into it (1). Flipping the first to the genus of the second was permitted because the first is original and the second is augmentative, so they disliked assimilating the original into the augmentative, so they flipped the augmentative to the genus of the original and assimilated it.
The second aspect: That the Dal is flipped into a Dhal (Mudhdhakir) and assimilated, so the pronunciation becomes a pointed Dhal (Mudhdhakir) (2). Al-Farra (3) said: "And some of the Bani Asad say: Mudhdhakir." (4)
foot_note:
1. See: Sharh Al-Mufassal, by Ibn Yaish (5: 555).
2. See: The previous source, same location.
3. Yahya bin Ziyad bin Abdullah Al-Asadi, their client, Al-Kufi, Abu Zakariya, known as Al-Farra. The Scholar, the Grammarian. With his advancement in language, he was a Jurist, Theologian, knowledgeable in the days of the Arabs and their news. He has numerous works including: (Ma'ani Al-Quran) and (Al-Maqsur wa Al-Mamdud). He died in the year 207 AH. See: Tarikh Al-Ulama' Al-Nahwiyyin, by Al-Tanukhi (p. 187), Tarikh Baghdad, by Al-Baghdadi (16: 224), Siyar A'lam Al-Nubala, by Al-Dhahabi (10: 118).
4. Ma'ani Al-Quran, by Al-Farra (3: 107).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
As for assimilating the second into the first in (Mudhdhakir) according to Ibn Atiyyah's direction, it has justification from a phonetic perspective; where the second sound perishes into the first, and both are pronounced as a single sound like the first (1). This is regressive assimilation (note: text implies second into first, which usually means the first dominates, but 'progressive'/'regressive' terms can vary in translation contexts - here the text describes the outcome matching the first). (2)
Summary of the Rectification Study:
• Assimilating the first into the second is the common practice.
• (Mudhdhakir) is a dialect narrated from some Arabs but it is rare, and it has its direction.
• Assimilating the original into the augmentative is disliked in the language, except that it occurs in examples like those mentioned, where they flipped the augmentative to the genus of the original and assimilated it.

2. It is that the second sound is affected by the first. See: Al-Aswat Al-Lughawiyyah, by Ibrahim Anis (p. 109).

text:
[2]: Ibn Atiyyah said upon speaking about the readings appearing in His saying - the Exalted -: {[Fasting for] a limited number of days. So whoever among you is ill or on a journey - then an equal number of other days. And upon those who are able to do it is a ransom [substitute] of feeding a poor person} [Al-Baqarah: 184]: "Ibn Abbas read (Yattayyaqunahu) (1) with a Fatha on the Yaa, a Shadda on the Ta, and a Shadda on the open Yaa, meaning 'they undertake it with difficulty'." Then he said: "And doubling the Yaa in this word is weak." (2)
Al-Samin said, rectifying and defending this reading: "Some people rejected this reading, and Ibn Atiyyah said: 'Doubling the Yaa in this word is weak'. They only claimed the invalidity of this reading because, to them, it is from the roots with a Waw, which is Al-Tawq, so from where does the Yaa come? This reading is neither invalid nor weak, and it has a good extraction: That this reading is not from the form (Tafa'ala) such that the problem they mentioned would be necessary, but rather it is from (Tafay'ala), and the origin is: (Tataywaqa) from Al-Tawq, like (Tadayyara) and (Tahayyara) from Al-Dawaran (Rotation) and Al-Hawr, and the origin is: (Tadaywara) and (Tahaywara). So the Yaa and Waw met, and one of them was preceded by silence (Sukoon), so the Waw was flipped into a Yaa, and the Yaa was assimilated into the Yaa. So the origin was: Yatataywaqunahu, then it was assimilated after the flip. So whoever read it (Yattayyaqunahu) with Fatha on the Yaa built it for the active voice, and whoever added Damma built it for the passive voice. The reading of doubling in the Waw or Yaa bears the meaning of affectation/difficulty (Takalluf), meaning: they undertake its capability with difficulty. That is a metaphor from the Tawq (Collar) which is the necklace, as if it is in the status of a necklace on their necks." (3)
foot_note:
1. An anomalous reading, attributed to Ibn Abbas, and in another narration: (Yuttayyaqunahu) with Damma on the present tense Yaa based on the passive voice. See: Al-Muhtasib fi Tabyin Wujuh Shawadh Al-Qira'at, by Ibn Jinni (1: 118), Tafsir Al-Qurtubi (2: 287), Tafsir Abi Hayyan (2: 188), Fath Al-Qadir, by Al-Shawkani (1: 208).
2. Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (1: 252).
3. Al-Durr Al-Masun (2: 273).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
Analysis and Study of the Rectification:
Ibn Atiyyah weakened the reading with the doubled Yaa in (Yattayyaqunahu) from a linguistic perspective. Al-Samin mentioned the problem that made Ibn Atiyyah and others weaken this reading and reject it, saying that they found the coming of the Yaa in this word problematic, because to them it is from roots with a Waw, which is Al-Tawq (1). This reason was explicitly stated by Abu Bakr Al-Anbari (2) where he said: "Because the verb is taken from the Waw (Al-Tawq), so there is no meaning for flipping the Waw to a Yaa without a cause or origin." (3) Abu Ja'far Al-Nahhas (4) also explicitly stated it where he said about doubling the Yaa in this reading: "It is not permissible because the Waw is not flipped to a Yaa except for a cause." (5)

text:
Al-Samin said, explaining the soundness of the reading linguistically: "This reading is neither invalid nor weak, and it has a good extraction: That this reading is not from (Tafa'ala) such that the problem they mentioned would be necessary, but rather it is from (Tafay'ala), and the origin is: (Tataywaqa) from Al-Tawq, like (Tadayyara) and (Tahayyara) from Al-Dawaran and Al-Hawr, and the origin is: (Tadaywara) and (Tahaywara). So the Yaa and Waw met, and one of them was preceded by silence, so the Waw was flipped into a Yaa, and the Yaa was assimilated into the Yaa, so the origin was: Yatataywaqunahu, then it was assimilated after the flip" (1). Then he said: "The reading of doubling in the Waw or Yaa bears the meaning of affectation/difficulty (Takalluf), meaning: they undertake its capability with difficulty. That is a metaphor from the Tawq (Collar) which is the necklace, as if it is in the status of a necklace on their necks." (2)
A number of scholars agreed with Al-Samin in this direction, including: Ibn Jinni (3) (4), Ibn Sidah (5) (6), Al-Zamakhshari (7), Abu Al-Baqa (8), Abu Hayyan (9), and Al-Fayruzabadi (10) (11).

Al-Zamakhshari said: "And Yattayyaqunahu and Yuttayyaqunahu mean they place it around their necks (Yatatawwaqunahu), and their origin is: Yattaywaqunahu and Yatataywaqunahu, on the basis that they are from Fay'ala and Tafay'ala from Al-Tawq. So the Yaa was assimilated into the Waw after flipping it into a Yaa like their saying: Tadayyara the place (went round the place) and there is no Dayyar (dweller) in it. In it are two aspects: One of them is towards the meaning of 'Yutiqunahu' (they are able to do it). The second is 'Yukallafunahu' (they are burdened with it) or 'Yatakallafunahu' (they undertake it with difficulty) with effort and hardship from them, and they are the elders and old women." (1)
So what Al-Samin said is the preponderant view in directing the reading, and the reason for its linguistic weakness has vanished with the removal of the problem. This is one of Al-Samin's methods in defending anomalous readings; he proves the validity of the reading linguistically by removing the problem that appeared to the one who weakened the reading or rejected it, then he extracts (explains) the reading with a correct linguistic or grammatical extraction.

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
[3]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his talk about the readings occurring in His saying - the Exalted -: {The month of Ramadhan [is that] in which was revealed the Qur'an} [Al-Baqarah: 185]: "And a faction read with the assimilation (Idgham) of the Ra into the Ra. That is not necessitated by the principles; due to the meeting of two silent letters (consonants with Sukoon) in it." (1)
Al-Samin mentioned this reading attributed to its reader and defended it, saying: "And Abu Amr assimilated the Ra of {Shahr} into the Ra of {Ramadan} (2). And no attention is paid to those who considered it weak from the aspect that he combined two silent letters contrary to their limits. Ibn Atiyyah's saying: 'And that is not necessitated by the principles' is not accepted from him; for if the transmission is authentic, it is not opposed by analogy." (3)
Study of the Rectification:
In Ibn Atiyyah's statement and Al-Samin's rectification of it are several issues:
The First Issue: Regarding Abu Amr's Reading:
Abu Amr read in the case of two identical letters from two words by assimilating the first into the second of them, whether what was before it was silent or moving. So he would assimilate the Ra into its like, whether what was before it moved or was silent, in all its parsings wherever it occurred (4).

2. An authentic reading. text:
Some of them said: What was narrated from Abu Amr is not true assimilation (Idgham), rather it is hiding (Ikhfa') the first of the two identical letters, a hiding that resembles assimilation. They interpreted what occurred in the expression of the early scholars as 'Idgham' metaphorically; by applying the name of Idgham to Ikhfa', because Ikhfa' is close to it (1).
Imam Ibn Al-Jazari (2) said: "And it differed regarding Abu Amr. The Maghribis (Westerners) entirely narrated Ikhfa' from him—meaning Ikhtilas (stealing/hurrying the vowel)—to flee from combining two silent letters. The Iraqis and Mashriqis (Easterners) entirely narrated Sukoon (Idgham) from him, and they do not mind the combining of two silent letters due to its validity in narration and its occurrence in language... The Kufan grammarians recounted hearing from the Arabs: Shahru Ramadana: assimilated." Then he said: "Both aspects are correct, except that the text from them is for Sukoon (Idgham), and Ikhtilas is not known except from the paths of the Maghribis and those who followed them." (3)
The Second Issue: Regarding the reason for Ibn Atiyyah's criticism of the reading:
Ibn Atiyyah criticized this reading for its contradiction to what was established by the majority of Basrans. Among those who also criticized it was Abu Ja'far Al-Nahhas, where he said: "Abu Amr assimilated the Ra into the Ra, and this is not permissible lest two silent letters meet." (4)

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
The doctrine of the majority of Basrans regarding two identical letters from two words is: The permissibility of assimilation in two identical letters from two words with two conditions: That they are not two Hamzas, and that the letter before them is not a silent letter that is not a letter of softness (Lenis/Vowel), like {Shahr Ramadan}, for this is not permissible to assimilate according to the majority of Basrans. For what is before the Ra here (the Ha) is a sound silent letter, and the assimilated letter is silent; and combining two silent letters in connection (Wasl) where the first is not a vowel letter is not permissible according to them (1).
The Third Issue: Al-Samin Al-Halabi's defense of the Reading:
Al-Samin Al-Halabi defended Abu Amr's reading and replied to Ibn Atiyyah saying: "And his saying 'And that is not necessitated by the principles' is not accepted from him; for if the transmission is authentic, it is not opposed by analogy" (2). Al-Samin Al-Halabi adhered to the traditional (Athari) method in his defense of authentic readings and his response to those who criticized them. So whenever a reading is authentic, no attention is paid to those who criticize it for contradicting their grammatical analogy. What Al-Samin mentioned is a rule in authentic readings; if the reading is established and its transmission is authentic, it must be followed; because it is a followed Sunnah that must be adhered to and resorted to, even if it contradicts linguistic analogies and grammatical rules. Abu Hayyan said in his defense of this reading: "The language of the Arabs is not limited to what the majority of Basrans transmitted, nor to what they chose. Rather, if the transmission is authentic, it is obligatory to resort to it." (3)

3. Tafsir Abi Hayyan (2: 195).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text: Those who narrated assimilation from Abu Amr are trustworthy Imams, and among them are scholars of grammar. So it must be accepted, even if the Basrans other than Abu Amr did not permit it, for Abu Amr is a head among the Basrans (1). Ibn Al-Hajib (2) said after quoting the conflict between the sayings of the Reciters and the Grammarians: "It is more appropriate to refute the Grammarians in forbidding the permissibility, for their saying is not a proof except upon consensus. And among the Reciters is a group of the greatest Grammarians; so the consensus of the Grammarians is not a proof given the Reciters' disagreement with them. Then, even if we assume that the Reciters do not include a Grammarian, they are transmitters of this language, and they share with the Grammarians in transmitting the language, so the consensus of the Grammarians is not a proof without them. If that is established, resorting to the saying of the Reciters is more appropriate; because they are its transmitters from those whose infallibility from error in such matters is established; and because the Reading is established as concurrent (Mutawatir) while what the Grammarians transmitted is singular (Ahad). Then if we concede that it is not concurrent, the Reciters are more just and more numerous, so returning to them is more appropriate." (3)
foot_note:
1. See: Ham' Al-Hawami', by Al-Suyuti (3: 485).
2. Uthman bin Omar bin Abu Bakr Al-Kurdi, Abu Amr, Jamal al-Din, known as Ibn Al-Hajib. The Imam, Scholar, Reciter, Usuli (scholar of principles), Maliki Jurist, and Grammarian. Author of refined classifications. Among his most famous works: (Al-Kafiyah) in Grammar, (Al-Shafiyah) in Morphology, and (Al-Idah Sharh Al-Mufassal). He was a deeply knowledgeable scholar with piety, scrupulousness, and humility. He died in Alexandria in the year 646 AH. text:
Al-Dumyati (1) said: "There is no difference between a silent letter due to a pause (Waqf) and a silent letter for assimilation (Idgham). Their claim regarding the impermissibility of the mentioned assimilation in connection (Wasl) is prohibited, and not finding a thing does not indicate its non-existence in reality. Indeed, the meeting of two silent letters has been heard from the most eloquent of Arabs, nay the most eloquent of creation absolutely, peace be upon him, in what is narrated: (Ni'imma (2) bil-mal al-salih lil-rajul al-salih) (3). This has been concurrently transmitted (Mutawatir) from the Reciters, and it spread and circulated and was not denied, and this is an affirmation beneficial for knowledge. What they mentioned is a negation based on conjecture, so scientific affirmation takes precedence over conjectural negation. Even if we concede that it is not Mutawatir, the least of the matter is that it is established as a dialect by the indication of the transmission of trustworthy narrators for it from those who are more eloquent than those whose speech they used as evidence. Thus, the preponderance remains with affirmation, and it takes precedence over negation." (4)
So the correct view in this issue is: That the Quran is an authority over the language, not that the language is an authority over the Quran. As long as the reading combining two silent letters where the first is not a soft letter (Lin) has been narrated via a path whose authenticity is definitive, then it is what must be resorted to and upon which rules should be based (5). Based on this: Al-Samin's rectification upon Ibn Atiyyah and his defense of Abu Amr's reading is appropriate.

Makki (3) recounted from him

(Li-nahkuma) (1), and I think it is a transcription error (Tashif) (2); because he did not recount from him the passive voice construction as people recounted." (3)

One of them, which is the most apparent, is that it refers back to Allah - the Exalted - due to His preceding mention in His saying: {Then Allah sent}, and because attributing judgment to Him is literal/real. It is not appropriate to consider him in error due to the possibility that there are two readings from him." (4)

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
Analysis and Study of the Rectification:
Two readings were narrated from Al-Jahdari regarding His saying: {Li-yahkuma}:
1 - (Li-yuhkama) in the passive voice, which is the reading people transmitted from him (1).
2 - (Li-nahkuma) with the Nun of greatness, which is the reading Makki bin Abi Talib transmitted from him.
Ibn Atiyyah commented on what Makki transmitted from Al-Jahdari saying: "And I think it is a transcription error; because he did not recount from him the passive voice construction as people recounted."
Al-Samin replied to Ibn Atiyyah saying that it is not appropriate to consider Makki in error; due to the possibility that Al-Jahdari had two readings: in the passive voice, and with the Nun of greatness. It also appears from Abu Hayyan's speech that he did not agree with Ibn Atiyyah in what he went to, as he said in Al-Bahr Al-Muhit: "Ibn Atiyyah thought this reading was a transcription error, saying essentially: because Makki did not recount from Al-Jahdari his reading which people transmitted from him, which is: (Li-yuhkama) based on the passive voice construction, and Makki transmitted (Li-nahkuma) with the Nun." (2)
However, the claim of transcription error is plausible for two reasons:
1 - That Makki did not transmit from Al-Jahdari the reading people transmitted from him in the passive voice. This reason was mentioned by Ibn Atiyyah.
2 - That Makki was alone in transmitting this reading from Al-Jahdari, and I did not find it with others, and he mentioned it in (Al-Hidayah) (3) and did not mention it in his other books.
Except that it is not possible to be certain about the occurrence of transcription error; because Makki bin Abi Talib is among the trustworthy and reliable Imams, so it is possible, as Al-Samin said: that Al-Jahdari has two readings: in the passive voice, and with the Nun of greatness.

Say, "It is harm, so keep away from wives during menstruation. And do not approach them until they are pure. And when they have purified themselves, then come to them from where Allah has ordained for you. Indeed, Allah loves those who are constantly repentant and loves those who purify themselves."} [Al-Baqarah: 222]: "Each of the two readings bears the possibility that what is meant by it is washing with water (Ghusl), and that what is meant by it is the cessation of blood and the removal of its harm. What Al-Tabari went to, that the reading with the doubling of the Ta implies washing, and the reading with lightening implies the cessation of blood: is a non-binding matter, and likewise his claim of consensus." (2)

text:
Al-Samin said, rectifying Ibn Atiyyah in his response to Al-Tabari: "And in Ibn Atiyyah's rejection of him there is a point of view (questionable aspect); for if we carried both readings to a single meaning, repetition would be necessary." (1)
Analysis of the Rectification:
Al-Samin rectified Ibn Atiyyah's opinion which he mentioned in the course of his response to Al-Tabari. Al-Tabari held that the reading with lightening means: cessation of blood, and the reading with doubling means: washing with water. Ibn Atiyyah responded to him that this differentiation is not necessary, and that each of the two readings bears the possibility of meaning washing with water or the cessation of blood. Al-Samin rectified this statement of Ibn Atiyyah; since carrying both readings on a single meaning would necessitate repetition.

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
Study of the Rectification:
This rectification revolves around the issue: Are the two readings with doubling and lightening in His saying: {Yathurna}... of one meaning or does each reading have a meaning?
A large number of exegetes and some linguists went to the view that the reading with lightening means: cessation of blood, and the reading with doubling means: washing with water. Among those who said this: Al-Farra (1), Ibn Qutaybah (2) (3), Makki bin Abi Talib (4), Al-Zamakhshari (5), and Ibn Al-Arabi (6) (7).
Some scholars from among exegetes, jurists, and linguists went to the view that both readings have one meaning, among them: Al-Mubarrad (8) in what was transmitted from him (9), and Abu Ja'far Al-Nahhas (10).

The view that there is a difference between the two readings is the preponderant one for several reasons, including:
1 - That most scholars hold this view, and those who said there is no difference aimed to secure their position in this issue (1) from a jurisprudential perspective (2).
2 - That it is not said: (Ittaharat Al-Mar'ah) meaning her blood stopped, just as it is not said (Qatta'a) doubled meaning (Qata'a) lightened; rather, doubling implies intensification of the lightened form (3).
3 - That (Al-Tatahhur) is not used except for what a human acquires/undertakes and performs with effort, which is washing with water. As for the cessation of blood, it is not acquired/voluntary (4).
4 - That the difference of the two meanings, if no contradiction arises from it, is more appropriate; so that the second word provides something new (5).

Ibn Khalawayh (1) said: "The argument for those who doubled (used Shadda) is that he matched the two expressions due to His saying: {And when they have purified themselves (Tatahharna)}, and the argument for those who lightened is that He meant until the blood ceases; because that is not of their doing, then He said: {And when they have purified themselves} meaning with water." (2)
So the sum of the two readings dictates two matters:
First: That a menstruating woman is not approached by her husband until the origin of purity occurs, which is by the cessation of menstruation, based on the reading of lightening.
Second: That she is not approached by her husband until the blood ceases, and she adds to it purification by washing the area or Wudu or Ghusl, based on the reading of doubling.
So these two readings combined two rulings, and both are necessary for the permissibility of approaching the menstruating woman (3).
Based on what was mentioned, Al-Samin's rectification upon Ibn Atiyyah is appropriate; since making the two readings in {Tatahharna} - with doubling and lightening - have one meaning is questionable.

Indeed, it has appeared - praise be to Allah - the correctness of Al-Tabari's speech via the speech of Abu Al-Qasim Al-Zamakhshari, and it appeared that Ibn Atiyyah's rejection of him is rejected." (1)
Study of the Rectification:
First: The Exegetes and Grammarians differed in directing the reading with Nasb of the Ra in {Wa-la Ya'murakum} into three opinions:
1 - That (An) is estimated before the verb {Ya'murakum} so it is in Nasb due to it, and the meaning is: Nor is it for him to order you. (La) would be emphasizing the previous meaning of negation, like a speaker saying: 'There was no coming from Zaid nor standing' while intending the negation of each of them from Zaid (2). Abu Ali Al-Farisi pointed to this opinion (3).

The Second: That you make (La) not extra. When they said to him: Shall we take you as a lord? It was said to them: It was not for a human that Allah chooses him as a prophet, then he orders people to worship him, and forbids you from worshipping angels and prophets." (1)
Second: Reason for Ibn Atiyyah's faulting of Al-Tabari's direction:
Abu Hayyan said: "The aspect of error is that if it is conjoined to {Yaqula}, (La) would be for establishing negation. It is only possible to estimate the operator before (La), which is (An); so a negated verbal noun (Masdar) is molded from (An) and the negated verb. The meaning becomes: It was not for a human described by what he was described with that his ordering to take angels and prophets as lords be negated. And if negation is not for him, then affirmation is for him, so he becomes ordering to take them as lords, and this is an error. If you make (La) for emphasizing the previous negation, the negation applies to both estimated verbal nouns (Masdars) whose affirmation is estimated, so His saying: Be servants to me, and his ordering to take angels and prophets as lords, are negated. This meaning is clarified by placing (Ghayr) in place of (La). If you said: Zaid has no Fiqh nor (La) Grammar; (La) would be for emphasizing negation and both descriptions are negated from him. If you made (La) for establishing negation it would be in the meaning of Ghayr (other than), so the meaning becomes the negation of Fiqh from him and the affirmation of Grammar for him. For if you said: Zaid has no Fiqh and other than (Ghayr) Grammar; that would entail affirming Grammar for him, as if you said: He has nothing other than Grammar. Do you not see that if you said: I came with no (bi-la) provision; the meaning is: I came without (bi-ghayr) provision. And if you said: I did not come without (bi-ghayr) provision, its meaning is: that you came with provision; because (La) here is for establishing negation. So Ibn Atiyyah's absolute declaration of error and lack of coherence of meaning is only on one of the two estimations: that (La) be

Ibn Atiyyah estimated its response from the genus of what preceded it; he said: "Meaning: When you were in this state, leaders of people and their best, the covenant was taken from you, for from leaders it is taken." (2)
2 - That (Lamma) is a particle of existence for existence (Hinu Wujud li-Wujud), which is the doctrine of Sibawayh and the majority of Grammarians (3), and Abu Hayyan (4) and Al-Samin Al-Halabi (5) preferred it. Its response is as preceded from the estimations of Ibn Atiyyah and Al-Zamakhshari.
3 - That its origin is (Lamin Ma), and (Min) was added in the affirmative according to Al-Akhfash's doctrine (6), then it was assimilated, as is obligatory in such a case, so it became (Lamimma), and the meeting of three Mims became heavy, so they deleted one of them. This is Ibn Jinni's opinion (7). Abu Hayyan said: "This direction in the reading of doubling is extremely far-fetched, and Arab speech is above having the likes of it occur in it, so how about the speech of Allah - the Exalted?" (8)

text:
4 - That the origin is also: Lamin Ma, and what preceded of flipping, assimilation, then deletion was done to it, except that (Min) is not extra but rather causative. Al-Zamakhshari said: "Its meaning is: For the sake of what I gave you, you must believe in him. This is similar to Hamza's reading in meaning." (1) Al-Samin said: "This aspect is more plausible than what preceded it due to its safety from claiming the addition of (Min), and for the clarity of its meaning." (2)
The preponderant view - and Allah knows best - is the saying of Sibawayh and the Majority, which is what Al-Samin Al-Halabi preferred; for reasons including:
1 - That (Lamma) has none of the signs of nouns (3).
2 - That if it were an adverb, its response would govern it, and that would necessitate the response occurring within it, because the operator in the adverb must occur within it, as in His saying: {And those cities - We destroyed them when (Lamma) they wronged} [Al-Kahf: 59]. The intent: They were destroyed because of their wronging, not that they were destroyed at the time of their wronging, because their wronging preceded their warning, and their warning preceded their destruction (4).
3 - That it implies causation, as in the mentioned verse, and adverbs do not imply causation (5).

Second: On the view that (Lamma) originates from (Lamin Ma) and underwent flipping, assimilation, and deletion; which of the Mims was deleted? Ibn Atiyyah said: "The first Mim was deleted." (1)
Al-Samin said rectifying him: "In this is a point of view, because the heaviness only occurred by what follows the first, therefore the correct view in its parallels is the deletion of the seconds, like: (Tanazzalu)." (2)
Abu Al-Baqa said: "Deleting the second due to its weakness by being a substitute, and the occurrence of repetition by it." (3)
The Preponderant View: That the second Mim is the one deleted; due to what Abu Al-Baqa and Al-Samin mentioned.
