text: [8]: Ibn Atiyyah said in his talk about the readings appearing in {La Yadurrukum} (1) from His saying - the Exalted -: {If good touches you, it distresses them; but if harm strikes you, they rejoice at it. And if you are patient and fear Allah, their plot will not harm you at all} [Al Imran: 120]: "It is permissible to open the Ra (Fatha) and break it (Kasra) with the intention of Jazam (jussive mood). As for the Kasra, I do not know it as a reading, and Al-Zajjaj's (2) expression in this is loose (Mutajawwaz fiha), as it appears from the context (Darj) (3) of his speech that it is a reading." (4)
foot_note:
1. Ibn Kathir, Nafi', Abu Amr, Hamza, Yaqub, Ibn Muhaysin, and Al-Yazidi read (La Yadir-kum) from Dara Yadiru. Ibn Amir, Asim, Hamza, Al-Kisa'i, Abu Ja'far, and Khalaf read (La Yadurru-kum) with Damma on the Dad and a doubled Ra, from Darra Yadurru. Asim read, in what Abu Zaid narrated from Al-Mufaddal, (Yadurra-kum) with Damma on the Dad and Fatha on the doubled Ra. Al-Dahhak read (La Yadurri-kum) with Damma on the Dad and Kasra on the doubled Ra; based on the principle of meeting of two silent letters. Ubayy bin Ka'b read (La Yad-rur-kum) by undoing the assimilation, which is the dialect of the people of Hejaz. See: Tafsir Al-Tabari (7: 157), Al-Sab'ah, by Ibn Mujahid (p. 215), Al-Hidayah ila Bulugh Al-Nihayah, by Makki bin Abi Talib (2: 1108), Tafsir Abi Hayyan (3: 323), Al-Nashr, by Ibn Al-Jazari (2: 242), Fath Al-Qadir, by Al-Shawkani (1: 431).
2. See: Ma'ani Al-Quran wa I'rabuhu, by Al-Zajjaj (1: 465).
3. Its folds and layers. See: Asas Al-Balaghah, by Al-Zamakhshari, root: Daraja (1: 282), Lisan Al-Arab, by Ibn Manzur, root: Daraja (2: 269).
4. Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (1: 499).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "Al-Dahhak bin Muzahim (1) read: (La Yadurri-kum) with Damma on the Dad and doubling on the broken Ra; based on what I mentioned to you of the meeting of two silent letters. It seems Ibn Atiyyah did not memorize it as a reading for he said: 'As for the Kasra, I do not know it as a reading, and Al-Zajjaj's expression in that is loose as it appears from the context of his speech that it is a reading'. I say: I have clarified that it is a reading as Al-Zajjaj said, and praise be to Allah." (2)
Study of the Rectification:
The rectification revolves around the issue: Did a reading with Kasra on the Ra in (La Yadurri-kum) appear?
1 - Most scholars affirmed the permissibility of breaking the Ra from a linguistic perspective, except that they did not affirm it as a reading, let alone attribute it to Al-Dahhak or anyone else (3).
2 - Abu Ja'far Al-Nahhas mentioned the reading with Kasra on the Ra without attribution (4), and it is understood from Al-Zajjaj's speech that it is a reading (5). Abu Hayyan (6) and Al-Samin Al-Halabi mentioned it attributed to Al-Dahhak.
foot_note:
1. Al-Dahhak bin Muzahim Al-Hilali Al-Khurasani, Abu Muhammad, and it was said: Abu Al-Qasim. One of the vessels of knowledge, and he has a book in Tafsir. He died in the year 105 AH. See: Siyar A'lam Al-Nubala, by Al-Dhahabi (4: 598), Ghayat Al-Nihayah fi Tabaqat Al-Qurra, by Ibn Al-Jazari (1: 338), Tabaqat Al-Mufassirin, by Al-Dawudi (1: 222).
2. Al-Durr Al-Masun (3: 377).
3. See: Tafsir Al-Tabari (7: 158), Tafsir Al-Raghib Al-Isfahani (2: 831), Tafsir Ibn Atiyyah (1: 499), Ibraz Al-Ma'ani min Hirz Al-Amani, by Abu Shama (p. 397), Al-Tahrir wa Al-Tanwir, by Ibn Ashour (4: 69).
4. See: I'rab Al-Quran, by Al-Nahhas (1: 178).
5. See: Ma'ani Al-Quran wa I'rabuhu, by Al-Zajjaj (1: 465) and his phrase is: "Whoever opened the Ra, the opening is light and used in the meeting of two silent letters in doubling, and whoever broke it, it is on the principle of the meeting of two silent letters."
6. See: Tafsir Abi Hayyan (3: 323)

text: [9]: Ibn Atiyyah said in his talk about the readings appearing in His saying - the Exalted -: {When you climbed [the mountain] and did not turn toward anyone while the Messenger was calling you from behind you} [Al Imran: 153]: "Some Reciters (1) read (Wa-la Tal'una) with Hamza on the Damma'd Waw. This is a dialect. And some of them read (Wa-la Taluna) with Damma on the Lam and a single Waw. It is a reading compounded upon the dialect of Hamza on the Damma'd Waw, then the vowel of the Hamza was transferred to the Lam, and one of the two silent Waws was deleted." (2)
foot_note:
1. The majority read: (Talwuna) with two Waws. It was read anomalously by substituting the first with a Hamza due to dislike of combining two Waws, which is not by analogy because the Damma is incidental. Al-Hasan read: (Taluna) with a single Waw. Al-A'mash and Abu Bakr in a narration from Asim read: (Wa-la Tulwuna) with Damma on the Ta, which is an anomalous dialect. See: I'rab Al-Quran, by Al-Nahhas (1: 184), Tafsir Al-Zamakhshari (1: 427), Tafsir Ibn Atiyyah (1: 526), Tafsir Al-Qurtubi (4: 239), Tafsir Abi Hayyan (3: 385), Ithaf Fudala' Al-Bashar fi Al-Qira'at Al-Arba'a Ashar, by Al-Dumyati (p. 230), Fath Al-Qadir, by Al-Shawkani (1: 447).
2. Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (1: 526).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "Al-Hasan read: (Taluna) with a single Waw. They extracted (explained) it on the basis that he substituted the Waw with a Hamza, then transferred the vowel of the Hamza to the Lam, and then deleted the Hamza according to the rule, so nothing remained of the word except the Fa (first radical), which is the Lam. Ibn Atiyyah said: 'And one of the two Waws was deleted due to the two silent letters.' Yet, he had previously stated that this reading is compounded upon the dialect of those who use Hamza on the Waw and transfer the vowel. This is strange; after making it from the category of transferring the Hamza's vowel, how does he return to say: one of the two Waws was deleted? It is possible to extract Al-Hasan's reading on two other aspects. First: That the Damma (vowel 'u') was deemed heavy on the Waw because it is its sister, so it was as if three Waws gathered. Thus, the Damma was transferred to the Lam, so two silent letters met: the Waw which is the 'Ayn (middle radical) of the word, and the Waw which is the pronoun. So the first was deleted due to the meeting of two silent letters. Had Ibn Atiyyah said this, it would have been more appropriate. Second: That (Taluna) is the present tense of 'Waliya Kadha' (he was near/followed such), from Al-Wilayah (nearness/succession), and it was made transitive with (Ala) because it implies the meaning of inclination (Atf)." (1)
Study of the Rectification:
First: Scholars' opinions on directing Al-Hasan's reading:
1 - That it is a reading compounded upon the dialect of those who use Hamza on the Damma'd Waw (Tal'una), then the vowel of the Hamza was transferred to the Lam and one of the two silent Waws was deleted. This is Ibn Atiyyah's opinion (2).
foot_note:
1. Al-Durr Al-Masun (3: 440).
2. See: Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (1: 526).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
2 - That the Damma was deemed heavy on the Waw in (Talwuna) because the Damma is like a Waw, so it was as if three Waws gathered. Thus, the Damma was transferred to the Lam, so two silent letters met: the Waw which is the 'Ayn of the word and the Waw which is the pronoun. So the first was deleted due to the meeting of two silent letters, resulting in (Taluna). This is the opinion of Abu Hayyan (1) and Al-Samin Al-Halabi (2).
3 - That the Damma'd Waw was flipped into a Hamza (Tal'una), then it was deleted, and its vowel - the Damma - was cast onto what was before it - the Lam - resulting in (Taluna). This is the opinion of the majority in directing the reading (3).
4 - That (Taluna) is the present tense of 'Waliya Kadha' from Al-Wilayah, and it was made transitive with (Ala) because it implies the meaning of inclination. Al-Raghib Al-Isfahani mentioned this opinion (4), and Abu Hayyan (5) and Al-Samin (6) considered it a plausible aspect.
Second: Critique of the opinions:
The first opinion - Ibn Atiyyah's opinion - was criticized because if the reading is compounded upon the dialect of those who use Hamza on the Waw and then transfer its movement to the Lam, then the Hamza is deleted in that case, and two silent Waws would not meet (7).

4. See: Tafsir Al-Raghib Al-Isfahani (3: 922).
5. See: Tafsir Abi Hayyan (3: 386).
6. See: Al-Durr Al-Masun (3: 441).
7. See: Tafsir Abi Hayyan (3: 386), Al-Durr Al-Masun (3: 441).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
As for the second opinion - the opinion of Abu Hayyan and Al-Samin - it is a correct direction and closer to the reading of the majority.
As for the third opinion - the opinion of the majority - it is close to correctness, except that it contradicts analogy; because the Damma on the Waw of (Talwuna) is incidental (1).
As for the fourth opinion, some considered it weak, but Al-Raghib directed it saying that the verse contains a rebuke to those addressed, and that they did not follow/be near (Lam Yalu) what they were entrusted with (Wullu), but rather fell short (2).
The closest opinion to correctness is the second opinion - which is Al-Samin's opinion - due to its agreement with analogy, its freedom from opposition, and its proximity to the concurrent (Mutawatir) reading of the majority (3).

text: [10]: Ibn Atiyyah said upon his talk about the readings appearing in His saying - the Exalted -: {And fear Allah, through Whom you ask one another, and the wombs} [An-Nisa: 1]: "And Abdullah bin Yazid (1) read (Wal-Arhamu) (2) with Raf' (nominative), and that is as an inceptive (Mubtada) and the predicate (Khabar) is estimated. Its estimation is: And the wombs are worthy of being joined." (3)
foot_note:
1. Abdullah bin Yazid Al-Ahwazi originally, Al-Basri then Al-Makki, Abu Abdul Rahman. The Imam, Hafiz, Reciter, Authority. One of the Imams of Hadith and Readings. He narrated the letters (readings) from Nafi' and from the Basrans, and he has a choice (Ikhtiyar) in reading. He died in the year 213 AH. See: Siyar A'lam Al-Nubala, by Al-Dhahabi (10: 166), Ghayat Al-Nihayah fi Tabaqat Al-Qurra, by Ibn Al-Jazari (1: 463).
2. Hamza - from the Ten - and Al-Hasan, Qatadah, and Al-A'mash read with Genitive (Jar) on the Mim (Wal-Arhami). The rest of the Ten read with Accusative (Nasb) (Wal-Arhama). Abdullah bin Yazid read with Nominative (Raf') (Wal-Arhamu). See: Al-Sab'ah, by Ibn Mujahid (p. 226), Al-Taysir fi Al-Qira'at Al-Sab', by Al-Dani (p. 93), Tafsir Ibn Atiyyah (2: 4), Tafsir Al-Qurtubi (5: 2), Tafsir Abi Hayyan (3: 497), Al-Nashr fi Al-Qira'at Al-Ashr, by Ibn Al-Jazari (2: 247), Fath Al-Qadir, by Al-Shawkani (1: 479).
3. Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (2: 4).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "And Abdullah also read: (Wal-Arhamu) with Raf' (nominative), which is based on inception (Mubtada), and the predicate is deleted. Ibn Atiyyah estimated it as: 'Worthy of being joined'. Al-Zamakhshari estimated it as: 'And the wombs are among that which should be feared', or 'And the wombs are among that which are asked by'. This is better for the verbal and semantic indication, unlike the first, for it is for the semantic indication only." (1)
Study of the Rectification:
Scholars have two opinions in directing the reading with Raf' (Wal-Arhamu):
First: That the Raf' is for incitement (Ighra'); because some Arabs put the object of incitement in the nominative case. Some scholars mentioned this as a plausible aspect (2).
Second: That the Raf' is for inception (Mubtada), which is the opinion of the majority. They differed in estimating the predicate:
Ibn Jinni estimated it: "And the wombs are among that which you must fear, and regarding which you must take precaution for yourselves." (3)
Al-Zamakhshari estimated it: "And the wombs are among that which is feared, or And the wombs are among that which is asked by." (4)
Ibn Atiyyah estimated it: "And the wombs are worthy of being joined." (5)
foot_note:
1. Al-Durr Al-Masun (3: 555).
2. See: Tafsir Al-Tha'labi (3: 242), Tafsir Al-Qurtubi (5: 2), Fath Al-Qadir, by Al-Shawkani (1: 481).
3. Al-Muhtasib fi Tabyin Wujuh Shawadh Al-Qira'at wa Al-Idah Anha (1: 179).
4. Tafsir Al-Zamakhshari (1: 462).
5. Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (2: 4).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
Al-Samin Al-Halabi preferred Al-Zamakhshari's estimation; he said: "This is better for the verbal and semantic indication," unlike Ibn Atiyyah's estimation; he said: "for it is for the semantic indication only." (1)
Abu Al-Baqa estimated it: "And the wombs are obligatory to be joined." (2)
There is no contradiction between these estimations, and each of them has what supports it from the concurrent readings and the interpretation of the Companions and Followers. Al-Zamakhshari's estimation is supported by the reading with Genitive (Wal-Arhami), and the interpretation appearing in the verse that its meaning is their saying (3): I ask you by Allah and by the womb (4). The estimation of Ibn Jinni, Ibn Atiyyah, and Abu Al-Baqa is supported by the reading with Accusative (Wal-Arhama), and the interpretation appearing in the verse that its meaning is: Fear Allah and join the wombs, or Fear the wombs lest you sever them (5).
* * *
foot_note:
1. Al-Durr Al-Masun (3: 554).
2. I'rab Al-Qira'at Al-Shawadh (1: 364)
3. Some scholars went to the view that their saying: "I ask you by Allah and by the womb" does not fall under swearing by other than Allah, but rather it is an appeal to another by the right of the womb, so there is no prohibition in it. Others went to the view that this is a recount of what they were upon in the Days of Ignorance (Jahiliyyah), so He urged them to join the womb and forbade them from severing it, and alerted them that it reached such sanctity with them that they would ask by it, then the Law did not affirm that asking for them but forbade them from it, while its sanctity remains and joining it is required and severing it is forbidden. Thus, the occurrence of this action from them in the past does not contradict the arrival of prohibition regarding it in the future. See: Tafsir Al-Qurtubi (5: 4), Ibraz Al-Ma'ani min Hirz Al-Amani, by Abu Shama Al-Dimashqi (1: 410), Al-Lubab fi Ulum Al-Kitab, by Ibn Adil Al-Hanbali (6: 146).
4. This is the interpretation of Mujahid, Al-Hasan, and Ibrahim Al-Nakha'i. See: Tafsir Sufyan Al-Thawri (p. 85), Tafsir Al-Tabari (7: 519), Tafsir Al-Mawardi (1: 447), Tafsir Al-Sam'ani (1: 394), Al-Durr Al-Manthur, by Al-Suyuti (2: 424).
5. This is the interpretation of Ibn Abbas, Ikrimah, Qatadah, and Al-Suddi. See: Tafsir Sufyan Al-Thawri (p. 85), Tafsir Al-Tabari (7: 521), Tafsir Al-Mawardi (1: 447), Al-Durr Al-Manthur, by Al-Suyuti (2: 424).

text: [11]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his talk about the readings appearing in {Was'alu} (And ask) from His saying - the Exalted -: {And do not wish for that by which Allah has made some of you exceed others. For men is a share of what they have earned, and for women is a share of what they have earned. And ask Allah of his bounty. Indeed Allah is ever, of all things, Knowing} [An-Nisa: 32]: "The majority of the Seven read: {Was'alu} with Hamz and a silent Sin. Al-Kisa'i (1) and Ibn Kathir (2)
foot_note:
1. Ali bin Hamza bin Abdullah Al-Kufi, Al-Asadi their client, Abu Al-Hasan, nicknamed Al-Kisa'i; because of a cloak (Kisa) he wore while in Ihram. The Imam, Sheikh of Reading and Arabic. One of the Seven Readers, and one of the major Imams of language and grammar. He has several works including: (Ma'ani Al-Quran) and (Al-Masadir). He died in the year 189 AH. See: Tarikh Al-Ulama' Al-Nahwiyyin, by Al-Tanukhi (p. 190), Nuzhat Al-Alba', by Al-Anbari (p. 58), Ghayat Al-Nihayah, by Ibn Al-Jazari (1: 535).

See: Wafiyat Al-A'yan, by Ibn Khallikan (3: 41), Ma'rifat Al-Qurra Al-Kibar, by Al-Dhahabi (p. 49), Ghayat Al-Nihayah fi Tabaqat Al-Qurra, by Ibn Al-Jazari (1: 443).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
read (Wasalu) casting the vowel of the Hamza onto the Sin. This applies wherever the word appears except in His saying: {And ask [Was'alu] what you have spent} [Al-Mumtahanah: 10], for they agreed on using Hamz in it." (1)
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "His saying: {Was'alu}: The majority are for affirming the Hamza in the imperative of asking directed towards the addressee if preceded by a Waw or Fa, like: {So ask [Fas'al] those} [Yunus: 94] and {And ask [Was'alu] Allah of His bounty} [An-Nisa: 32]. Ibn Kathir and Al-Kisa'i transfer the vowel of the Hamza to the Sin for lightening due to frequent usage. If it is not preceded by a Waw or Fa, everyone is for transfer, like: {Ask [Sal] the Children of Israel} [Al-Baqarah: 211]. And if it is for an absent person, everyone is for Hamz, like: {And let them ask [Walyas'alu] what they have spent} [Al-Mumtahanah: 10]. Ibn Atiyyah erred, for he reported the consensus of the readers on Hamz in the likes of: {And ask [Was'alu] what you have spent} [Al-Mumtahanah: 10], but their agreement is not in this, but rather in {And let them ask [Walyas'alu] what they have spent} as preceded." (2)

Study of the Rectification:
First: Ibn Kathir, Al-Kisa'i, and Khalaf (1) read by transferring the vowel of the Hamza to the silent Sin and deleting the Hamza: (Salu) in His saying: (Wa Salu Allah min Fadlihi) [An-Nisa: 32] and His saying: (Wa Salu ma anfaqtum) [Al-Mumtahanah: 10], and in the entire Quran (2). Hamza agreed with them in pause (Waqf) (3). The rest read with Hamz (4): {Was'alu Allah min Fadlihi}, {Was'alu ma anfaqtum}. All readers agreed on Hamz in {Walyas'alu ma anfaqu} [Al-Mumtahanah: 10] (5).
Second: Conditions for leaving the Hamz in the reading of Ibn Kathir, Al-Kisa'i, and Khalaf: That the Sin be preceded by a Waw or Fa, like: (Wa Salu Allah) [An-Nisa: 32], (Fa Sal al-ladhina) [Yunus: 94], (Wa Sal man arsalna min qablika) [Az-Zukhruf: 45], and that it be an imperative of asking directed towards the addressee

[12]: Ibn Atiyyah said in his direction of the reading appearing in {Yura'un} (1) from His saying - the Exalted -: {Indeed, the hypocrites [think to] deceive Allah, but He is deceiving them. And when they stand for prayer, they stand lazily, showing [themselves to] the people and not remembering Allah except a little} [An-Nisa: 142]: "And the majority of people read (2) (Yura'un) with a doubled Damma'd Hamza between the Ra and the Waw without an Alif. It is making (Ra'a) transitive by doubling (Tad'if), and it is stronger in meaning than {Yura'un}; because its meaning is that they compel people to see them, and they pretend to them with prayer while they conceal hypocrisy." (3)
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said rectifying him: "And this from him is not good; because 'Mufa'ala' (reciprocity/interaction form), if it serves its primary function, is more eloquent as known more than once. And if it is in the meaning of 'Taf'il' (activation/causative form), then it fulfills the meaning he intended. It is as if he did not know that 'Mufa'ala' may come in the meaning of 'Taf'il'." (4)
foot_note:
1. The majority read: (Yura'un) with an Alif followed by a Hamza then the Waw of plurality. Hamza has facilitation (Tashil) of the Hamza with lengthening and shortening in pause. Abdullah bin Abi Ishaq, Al-Ashhab Al-Uqayli, and Al-A'raj read (Yura'un) with a doubled Damma'd Hamza between the Ra and the Waw. It is narrated from Ibn Abbas that he read (Yurawun) with two Waws without a Hamza. See: Al-Muhtasib fi Tabyin Wujuh Shawadh Al-Qira'at, by Ibn Jinni (1: 202), I'rab Al-Quran, by Al-Nahhas (1: 245), Mukhtasar Shawadh Al-Quran, by Ibn Khalawayh (p. 181), Tafsir Al-Zamakhshari (1: 580), Tafsir Ibn Atiyyah (5: 527), Tafsir Abi Hayyan (4: 109), Lisan Al-Arab, by Ibn Manzur (14: 295), Al-Budur Al-Zahirah fi Al-Qira'at Al-Ashr Al-Mutawatirah, by Abdul Fattah Al-Qadi (p. 86).
2. Ibn Atiyyah erred where he attributed it to the majority, while it is an anomalous reading, and the majority read: (Yura'un) as clarified in the extraction of the reading.
3. Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (2: 127).
4. Al-Durr Al-Masun (4: 126).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
Study of the Rectification:
Scholars differed in directing (Yura'un - with doubling) and comparing it to the concurrent reading {Yura'un - with elongation}. They have two main opinions in this:
The First Opinion: That it is making (Ra'a) transitive by doubling, and it is stronger in meaning than the concurrent reading {Yura'un}; because its meaning is: they compel (people) to hypocrisy/showing off (1), or they compel people to see them, and they pretend to them with prayer while concealing hypocrisy. This is the opinion of Ibn Jinni (2) and Ibn Atiyyah (3). Ibn Jinni said: "Its meaning is: they make people see, and compel them to see them doing what they undertake. It is stronger in meaning than {Yura'un} with lengthening on (Yufa'ilun); because the meaning of 'Yura'unahum' is they expose themselves so they see them, while 'Yura'unahum' (with doubling) is they compel them to see them." (4)
The Second Opinion: That (Yura'un - with doubling) is close to the meaning of the concurrent reading {Yura'un} and is not stronger than it, and that {Yura'un} is a 'Mufa'ala' form with the meaning of 'Taf'il', just as it is said: Ra'a (with elongation); meaning: Ra'a (with doubling), and Na'amahu and Na'amahu. And that the concurrent reading {Yura'un} is stronger and more appropriate. This was said by: Al-Nahhas (5), Al-Zamakhshari (6), and Al-Samin Al-Halabi (7). Al-Farra held that (Fa'ala) and (Fa'ala) - as in Ra'a and Ra'a - are close in meaning (8).

text:
The second opinion is the preponderant one for reasons including:
1 - Because {Yura'un} (with elongation) is the concurrent (Mutawatir) reading upon which the Ten Readers agreed (1).
2 - Because the unity of meaning of the two readings is more appropriate than their difference (2).
3 - Because the 'Mufa'ala' form - Fa'ala: Ra'a - comes for meanings including: 'Taf'il' - Fa'ala: Ra'a (3).
Based on this: Al-Samin Al-Halabi's rectification upon Ibn Atiyyah is valid.

[13]: Ibn Atiyyah said in his direction of the reading with Raf' (nominative) for {Wa Rusulan} (4) from His saying - the Exalted -: {And [We sent] messengers about whom We have related [their stories] to you before and messengers about whom We have not related to you. And Allah spoke to Moses with [direct] speech} [An-Nisa: 164]: "And in the letter (reading) of Ubayy bin Ka'b: (Wa Rusulun) in both places with Raf', on the estimation: They are messengers." (1)
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "And Ubayy read: (Wa Rusulun) with Raf' in both places, and there are two extractions (explanations) for it. The more apparent of them: That it is an inceptive (Mubtada) and what follows it is its predicate." Then he said: "The second: - and Ibn Atiyyah went to it - is that it was raised as the predicate of a hidden inceptive, i.e.: And they are messengers. This is unclear, and the sentence after (Rusul) based on this aspect would be in the place of Raf' (nominative) as it occurs as a description (Sifah) for the indefinite noun before it." (2)
Study of the Rectification:
The subject of this rectification is the direction of Ubayy bin Ka'b's reading with Raf': (Wa Rusulun qad qasasnahum 'alayka). Some scholars transmitted this reading without direction, and some directed it grammatically. They have four opinions in directing it:
1 - That his saying: (Rusulun) is an inceptive (Mubtada) raised by the return of the mention, and what is after it is its predicate. The return of the mention is his saying: (Qad qasasnahum). This was said by: Al-Farra (3), Al-Tabari (4), Abu Hayyan (5), and Al-Samin Al-Halabi (6).

This is, according to them, from the category of raising the 'busy noun' (Al-Ism Al-Mashghul 'anhu). The busy noun allows both Raf' (nominative) and Nasb (accusative), and there are cases where one aspect is preferred over the other. (1) Al-Farra said: "And if it were Raf', it would be correct due to the mention of them that returned, and in Ubayy's reading with Raf': (Wa Rusulun qad qasasnahum 'alayka min qablu wa Rusulun lam naqsushum 'alayka)." (2)
Abu Hayyan said in his direction of the majority's reading: "And the accusative state of {Wa Rusulan} is upon the hiding of a verb, i.e.: We have related [stories of] messengers to you. So it is from the category of 'Ishtighal' (preoccupation), and the sentence from His saying: {Qad qasasnahum} explains that deleted verb. This is indicated by Ubayy's reading: (Wa Rusulun) with Raf' in both places based on inception." (3)
2 - That (Rusulun) is a predicate for a deleted inceptive, and the estimation is: They are messengers (Hum Rusulun), and the sentence: {Qad qasasnahum} is in the place of Raf' as a description (Sifah).
foot_note:
1. Ishtighal (Preoccupation) is when a noun precedes and a governing agent (verb) follows it, preoccupied from acting upon that noun by acting upon its pronoun directly or causally. The principle is that the noun 'preoccupied from' allows two aspects: One is preponderant due to safety from estimation, which is Raf' by inception, so what follows is in the place of Raf' as a predicate, and the sentence structure is nominal. The second is outweighed due to needing estimation, which is Nasb, for it is by a verb matching the mentioned verb, so what follows has no place (grammatically) because it is explanatory, and the sentence structure is verbal. Then, something might occur to this noun necessitating its Nasb, or preferring it, or making Raf' and Nasb equal. See: Awdah Al-Masalik ila Alfiyyat Ibn Malik, by Ibn Hisham (2: 139 - 141)
2. Ma'ani Al-Quran (1: 295).
3. Tafsir Abi Hayyan (4: 138).

This was said by: Ibn Atiyyah (1). Al-Samin commented on it saying: "This is unclear." (2)
3 - That (Rusulun) is an inceptive and its predicate is deleted, i.e.: And there are messengers (Wa Thamma Rusulun), and the sentence: {Qad qasasnahum} is a description for Rusul. This was said by: Abu Al-Baqa (3).
4 - That (Rusulun) is an inceptive for a deleted predicate, and the estimation is: And among them are messengers (Wa minhum Rusulun). This was said by: Al-Qurtubi (4) (5).
All these directions are plausible and consistent with the meaning of the verse, with the exception of Ibn Atiyyah's opinion; for it is far-fetched from the perspective of meaning. The estimation of speech based on Ibn Atiyyah's opinion is: And they are messengers whom We have related to you before, and they are messengers whom We have not related to you. This estimation is not apparent.
The first opinion - which is Al-Samin's choice - is the most preponderant of these directions; because it is closest to the preponderant opinion in directing the concurrent reading {Wa Rusulan}, which is that His saying: {Wa Rusulan} is an object for a

So it is from the category of 'Ishtighal', and the sentence {Qad qasasnahum} is explanatory (1). The 'busy noun' allows Raf' and Nasb, but Nasb is preferred here; because the conjunction was upon a verbal sentence (2): {Wa atayna Dawuda Zabura} [An-Nisa: 163] (3), while Raf' based on inception remains permissible according to the principle.

text: [14]: Ibn Atiyyah said in his talk about the readings appearing (1) in His saying - the Exalted -: {And We ordained for them therein a life for a life, an eye for an eye, a nose for a nose, an ear for an ear, a tooth for a tooth, and for wounds is legal retribution} [Al-Ma'idah: 45]: "Ibn Kathir, Abu Amr, and Ibn Amir (2) read: {Anna Al-Nafsa bi-Al-Nafsi} with Nasb on (Al-Nafsa) as the noun of (Anna), and conjoining what follows that as accusative onto {Al-Nafsa}, and they raise (Wal-Juruhu Qisasun) on the basis that it is a separate sentence.
foot_note:
1. Nafi', Hamza, Asim, Khalaf, Yaqub, and Al-A'mash read with Nasb on the Eye and the conjoined items following it: (Wal-'Ayna bil-'Ayni wal-Anfa bil-Anfi wal-Udhuna bil-Udhuni wal-Sinna bil-Sinni wal-Juruha Qisas). Anas and Al-Kisa'i read with Raf' on the Eye and what follows: (Wal-'Aynu bil-'Ayni wal-Anfu bil-Anfi wal-Udhunu bil-Udhuni wal-Sinnu bil-Sinni wal-Juruhu Qisas). The Waw conjoined nominal sentences to (Anna) and its noun regarding meaning, while the place is raised. Ibn Kathir, Abu Amr, Ibn Amir, Abu Ja'far, and Ibn Muhaysin read with Nasb on the four and Raf' on (Al-Juruhu) separating it from what preceded, so it is an inceptive and its predicate is: Qisas. Ubayy bin Ka'b read: (Wa Anna Al-Juruhu) adding (Anna) to the reading of the group, and raising Al-Juruh. See: Al-Sab'ah fi Al-Qira'at, by Ibn Mujahid (p. 244), I'rab Al-Quran, by Al-Nahhas (1: 269), Al-Hujjah fi Al-Qira'at Al-Sab', by Ibn Khalawayh (p. 130), Ma'ani Al-Qira'at, by Al-Azhari (1: 329), Al-Hujjah lil-Qurra Al-Sab'ah, by Al-Farisi (3: 223 - 226), Al-Tadhkirah fi Al-Qira'at Al-Thaman, by Ibn Ghalbun (p. 245), Hujjat Al-Qira'at, by Ibn Zanjalah (p. 226), Al-Kashf 'an Wujuh Al-Qira'at Al-Sab' wa 'Ilaliha, by Makki bin Abi Talib (1: 409), Al-Taysir fi Al-Qira'at Al-Sab', by Al-Dani (p. 99), Al-Unwan fi Al-Qira'at Al-Sab', by Ibn Khalaf Al-Muqri (p. 87), Tafsir Al-Baghawi (2: 56), Zad Al-Masir fi Ilm Al-Tafsir, by Ibn Al-Jawzi (1: 553), Tafsir Al-Qurtubi (6: 192), Tafsir Abi Hayyan (4: 271), Al-Nashr fi Al-Qira'at Al-Ashr, by Ibn Al-Jazari (2: 254), Al-Ithaf, by Al-Dumyati (p. 253).
2. Abdullah bin Amir bin Yazid Al-Yahsubi Al-Dimashqi, Abu Imran. The Great Imam, one of the Seven Readers, the Reciter of the Levant (Sham), and one of the notables. He read the Quran to Abu Darda and others, and narrated from a number of Companions. He died in the year 118 AH. text:
And Nafi' (1), Hamza, and Asim (2) read with Nasb on all of that, and {Qisasun} is the predicate of (Anna)." (3)
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "As for the reading of Nafi' and those with him, the Nasb is based on the noun of (Anna) verbally, which is {Al-Nafsa}, and the prepositional phrase after it is its predicate. And {Qisasun} is the predicate of (Al-Juruha), i.e.: And the wounds are retribution. This is from sentence coordination; we conjoined the noun to the noun and the predicate to the predicate, like your saying: 'Indeed Zaid is standing and Amr is leaving': You conjoined 'Amr' to 'Zaid' and 'leaving' to 'standing', and the prescription/writing covers all (4). However, in Ibn Atiyyah's speech is what implies that {Qisasun} is a predicate for all the accusatives, for he said: 'And Nafi', Hamza, and Asim read with Nasb on all of that, and {Qisasun} is the predicate of (Anna)' (5). This, although it is true that taking a life for a life and an eye for an eye is retribution (Qisas), yet it became here, by the context of pairing, specific to wounds, and it is a point of view (questionable)." (6)

The leadership of recitation in Kufa ended with him after Abu Abdul Rahman Al-Sulami. He combined eloquence, precision, and Tajweed, and he had one of the best voices in Quran. He died in the year 127 AH. See: Siyar A'lam Al-Nubala, by Al-Dhahabi (5: 256), Ghayat Al-Nihayah, by Ibn Al-Jazari (1: 346).
3. Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (2: 196).
4. Meaning that taking a life for a life, an eye for an eye, a nose for a nose, an ear for an ear, a tooth for a tooth, and that wounds are retribution, all of that is written in the Torah.
5. Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (2: 196).
6. Al-Durr Al-Masun (4: 277).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
Study of the Rectification:
The readers agreed on raising His saying: {Qisasun}, but the direction of this raising differs according to their difference in reading what precedes it. The subject of this rectification is the direction of the reading of Nafi', Hamza, and Asim with Nasb on (Al-Juruha) and the preceding conjoined items, and the parsing of {Qisasun} based on that.
Ibn Atiyyah said that {Qisasun} in this reading is the predicate of (Anna), meaning it is a predicate for all the accusatives before it (1). Among those who also said this: Makki bin Abi Talib in (Al-Kashf) (2), and Al-Fakhr Al-Razi (3). Al-Fakhr Al-Razi said: "Nafi', Asim, and Hamza read all of them with Nasb conjoining some of that to others, and the predicate for all is: Qisas." (4)
Al-Samin commented on this saying with valid speech, saying: "This, although it is true that taking a life for a life and an eye for an eye is retribution (Qisas), yet it became here, by the context of pairing, specific to wounds." (5)
foot_note:
1. See: Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (2: 196).
2. See: Al-Kashf 'an Wujuh Al-Qira'at Al-Sab' wa 'Ilaliha (1: 409).
3. Muhammad bin Omar bin Al-Hussein Al-Razi Al-Qurashi, from the descendants of Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq, Fakhr al-Din, Abu Abdullah. The Great Scholar, Master of Arts, Usuli, Exegete, Shafi'i Jurist. Among his works: The Great Interpretation (Mafatih Al-Ghayb), and (Al-Mahsul) in Usul Al-Fiqh. He died in the year 606 AH. See: Uyun Al-Anba' fi Tabaqat Al-Atibba', by Ibn Abi Usaybi'ah (p. 462), Siyar A'lam Al-Nubala, by Al-Dhahabi (21: 500), Tabaqat Al-Shafi'iyyah Al-Kubra, by Al-Subki (8: 81), Tabaqat Al-Mufassirin, by Al-Suyuti (p. 115).
4. Tafsir Al-Fakhr Al-Razi (12: 368).
5. Al-Durr Al-Masun (4: 278).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
Al-Samin Al-Halabi went to the view that {Qisasun} here is the predicate of (Al-Juruha), meaning: And that wounds are legal retribution. Among those who said this were: Makki bin Abi Talib in (Al-Mushkil) (1), Abu Hayyan (2), and others (3). Makki said: "Whoever put (Al-Juruha) in the accusative (Nasb) conjoined it to {Al-Nafsa}, and {Qisasun} is its predicate." (4)
This direction is the most preponderant, for the saying that {Qisasun} is a predicate for all the accusatives - which is Ibn Atiyyah's saying - implies that taking an eye for an eye and everything mentioned is (Qisas) retribution. While this is indeed named retribution, the retribution here has become specific to wounds by the context of the pairing. Therefore: His saying {Qisasun} is the predicate of (Al-Juruha) (5). This direction is also supported by the reading of Ubayy bin Ka'b: (Wa Anna Al-Juruha Qisasun) (6). It is also supported by the reading of those who raised (Al-Juruhu) as a new sentence (Istin'af) and put what was before it in the accusative; they started a new sentence saying: (Wal-Juruhu Qisasun) because the predicate of wounds did not resemble the news (predicates) of what preceded it, so he resorted to starting a new sentence (7).

3. See: Tafsir Al-Tha'labi (4: 71), Al-Bayan fi I'rab Gharib Al-Quran, by Al-Anbari (1: 250), Al-Tafsir Al-Munir, by Al-Zuhayli (6: 203).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
Ibn Khalawayh said: "And what indicates its separation from the first [part] is that He did not say in it: And the wounds for the wounds are retribution." (1)
Some exegetes and jurists even mentioned a benefit in His saying: {Wal-Juruha Qisas}, which is that it indicates retribution in wounds where retribution is possible and equality is known. As for where retribution is not possible, there is no retribution (Qisas); because it is impossible to stop at its exact limit (2). They also explicitly stated that His saying: {Wal-Juruha Qisas} is an independent sentence containing a generalization after specification (3). Thus, His saying: {Qisasun} is a predicate specific to wounds and not a predicate for all the accusatives before it. Based on this: Al-Samin Al-Halabi's rectification upon Ibn Atiyyah is valid.

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text: [15]: Ibn Atiyyah said upon his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {And We have revealed to you, [O Muhammad], the Book in truth, confirming that which preceded it of the Scripture and as a criterion over it} [Al-Ma'idah: 48]: "Mujahid (1) said: His saying - the Exalted -: {Wa Muhayminan 'alayh} means Muhammad, peace be upon him, is trustworthy over the Quran. Judge Abu Muhammad (Ibn Atiyyah) said: And Al-Tabari, may Allah have mercy on him, erred regarding this expression against Mujahid; for he explained his interpretation based on the reading of the people (2) {Wa Muhayminan} with Kasra on the second Mim, so the interpretation became far-fetched. Mujahid, may Allah have mercy on him, only reads - he and Ibn Muhaysin (3) - (Wa Muhaymanan 'alayh) with Fatha on the second Mim. It is the structure of the passive participle, and it is a circumstantial accusative (Hal) from the Book conjoined to His saying: {Musaddiqan}. On this basis, it is plausible that the one entrusted over it is Muhammad, peace be upon him, and {Alayhi} is in the place of Raf' (nominative) on the estimation that it is a pro-agent (Na'ib Fa'il). This is on Mujahid's reading, and likewise Makki (4) walked [this path], may Allah have mercy on him, and he went deep into Al-Tabari's path in this place." Then Ibn Atiyyah concluded his talk about the verse saying: "And it is possible that {Musaddiqan} and {Wa Muhayminan} are both circumstantial accusatives (Hal) from the Kaf in {Ilayka} (to you), and this is not specific to Mujahid's reading alone as Makki claimed." (5)
foot_note:
1. Mujahid bin Jabr Al-Makki, Abu Al-Hajjaj. The Imam, Sheikh of Reciters and Exegetes. He took the Quran, Tafsir, and Fiqh from Ibn Abbas and other Companions. He died in the year 104 AH. See: Siyar A'lam Al-Nubala, by Al-Dhahabi (4: 449), Ghayat Al-Nihayah fi Tabaqat Al-Qurra, by Ibn Al-Jazari (2: 41), Tabaqat Al-Mufassirin, by Al-Dawudi (2: 305), Tabaqat Al-Mufassirin by Al-Adnawi (p. 11).
2. The reading of the majority is with Kasra on the second Mim (Muhayminan) active participle. Mujahid and Ibn Muhaysin read (Wa Muhaymanan) with Fatha on the second Mim: passive participle. See: Ma'ani Al-Quran, by Al-Nahhas (2: 318), Mukhtasar fi Shawadh Al-Quran, by Ibn Khalawayh (p. 39), Al-Hidayah ila Bulugh Al-Nihayah, by Makki bin Abi Talib (3: 1767), Tafsir Al-Qurtubi (6: 210), Tafsir Abi Hayyan (4: 282), Fath Al-Qadir, by Al-Shawkani (2: 55).
3. Muhammad - and said: Omar - bin Abdul Rahman bin Muhaysin Al-Sahmi their client, Al-Makki, Abu Hafs. The Reciter of the people of Mecca after Ibn Kathir and the most knowledgeable of its reciters in Arabic. He was unique in letters (readings) in which he contravened the Mushaf (codex), so people abandoned his reading and did not attach it to the authentic readings. He died in the year 123 AH. See: Ghayat Al-Nihayah fi Tabaqat Al-Qurra, by Ibn Al-Jazari (2: 167), Tahdhib Al-Tahdhib, by Ibn Hajar (7: 474).
4. See: Al-Hidayah ila Bulugh Al-Nihayah (3: 1767).
5. Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (2: 200).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text: Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "Ibn Muhaysin and Mujahid read: (Wa Muhaymanan) with Fatha on the second Mim on the basis that it is a passive participle, meaning that it was protected from alteration and change. The Actor is Allah - the Exalted -: {Indeed, it is We who sent down the Qur'an and indeed, We will be its guardian} [Al-Hijr: 9], or the preserver of it in every land, such that if a vowel in it is changed, the people notice it and correct its reciter with the truth. The pronoun in {Alayhi} in this reading returns to the first Book, and in the famous reading it returns to the second Book. Ibn Abi Najih (1) narrated from Mujahid his reading with Fatha and said: 'Its meaning: Muhammad is trustworthy over the Quran'. Al-Tabari said: 'Based on this, {Wa Muhayminan} would be a circumstantial accusative (Hal) from the Kaf in {Ilayka}' (2). He (Al-Tabari) challenged this opinion due to the presence of the Waw in {Wa Muhayminan}; because it is a conjunction to {Musaddiqan}, and {Musaddiqan} is a Hal from the Book, not a Hal from the Kaf; for if it were a Hal from it, the construction would be: Lima bayna yadayka (what is before you); with a Kaf." Then Al-Samin said: "Ibn Atiyyah said here after recounting Mujahid's reading and his interpretation that Muhammad, peace be upon him, is a trustee over the Quran: 'Al-Tabari said: And his saying (Muhaymanan) based on this is a Hal from the Kaf in his saying {Ilayka}. He said: And this is an interpretation far from the understood meaning.' He (Ibn Atiyyah) said: 'And Al-Tabari erred in this expression against Mujahid, for he explained his interpretation based on the reading of the people: {Wa Muhayminan} with Kasra on the second Mim, so the interpretation became far-fetched. Mujahid, may Allah have mercy on him, only reads - he and Ibn Muhaysin -: (Wa Muhaymanan) with Fatha on the second Mim. It is the structure of the passive
foot_note:
1. Abdullah bin Abi Najih Yasar Al-Thaqafi Al-Makki, Abu Yasar. The Imam, the Trustworthy, the Exegete. He narrated from a group of the Followers. Al-Dhahabi said of him: "He is among the closest people to Mujahid". He died in the year 131 AH. See: Siyar A'lam Al-Nubala, by Al-Dhahabi (6: 125), Tabaqat Al-Mufassirin, by Al-Dawudi (1: 258).
2. Tafsir Al-Tabari (10: 381).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
participle, and it is a Hal from the Book conjoined to His saying: {Musaddiqan}. On this basis, it is plausible that the one entrusted over it is Muhammad, peace be upon him. He said: And likewise Makki walked [this path], may Allah have mercy on him.' I (Al-Samin) say: What Abu Muhammad said does not contain a refutation of Al-Tabari, for Al-Tabari found the existence of (Muhaymanan) as a Hal from the Kaf to be problematic on Mujahid's reading. Furthermore, Ibn Atiyyah said afterwards: 'And it is possible that {Musaddiqan} and {Wa Muhayminan} are both circumstantial accusatives (Hal) from the Kaf in {Ilayka}, and this is not specific to Mujahid's reading alone as Makki claimed'. So people only found them being Hals from the Kaf of {Ilayka} problematic...; due to the awkwardness of the structure (Qalaq al-Tarkib)." (1)
Study of the Rectification:
First: Mujahid's reading and interpretation:
Mujahid read (Wa Muhaymanan) with Fatha on the second Mim: passive participle. It is an anomalous reading, contrary to what the Ten (Readers) agreed upon (2). It was said regarding the direction of Mujahid's reading that its meaning is: Allah - Glory be to Him - watched over it (Haymana 'alayh) (3).

3. See: Fath Al-Qadir, by Al-Shawkani (2: 55).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
Al-Zamakhshari said in his direction of Mujahid's reading: "And the one whom Allah Almighty or the Preservers in every land watched over, if a letter of it or a vowel or a silence were altered, everyone would notice it." (1)
Mujahid said in his interpretation of His saying: {Wa Muhayminan 'alayh} [Al-Ma'idah: 48]: "Trustworthy over the Books." (2) And in a narration: {Wa Muhayminan 'alayh}: "Muhammad, peace be upon him, is trustworthy over the Quran, and the Muhaymin is the witness over the Books before it." (3) Most exegetes mention this interpretation of Mujahid immediately after his reading, meaning they see that his interpretation is based on his reading, not on the reading of the majority (4).
Second: Al-Tabari's opinion on Mujahid's reading and interpretation:
Al-Tabari said after mentioning Mujahid's interpretation: "So the interpretation of the speech according to what Mujahid interpreted is: And We revealed the Book confirming the Books before it to you, entrusted (Muhaymanan) over it. So His saying: {Musaddiqan} would be a Hal from {Al-Kitaba} and a part of it, and the confirmation (Tasdiq) would be an attribute of the Book. And the Muhaymin would be a Hal from the Kaf which is in {Ilayka},

1. Tafsir Al-Zamakhshari (1: 640).
2. Tafsir Mujahid (p. 310).
3. Tafsir Al-Tabari (10: 381), Tafsir Ibn Abi Hatim (4: 1150), Al-Asma' wa Al-Sifat, by Al-Bayhaqi (1: 168), Al-Durr Al-Manthur fi Al-Tafsir bi Al-Ma'thur, by Al-Suyuti (3: 95).
4. See: Ma'ani Al-Quran, by Al-Nahhas (2: 318), Al-Hidayah ila Bulugh Al-Nihayah, by Makki bin Abi Talib (3: 1767), Tafsir Al-Qurtubi (6: 210).

text:
which is a metonymy for the mention of the name of the Prophet, peace be upon him, and the Ha in His saying: {Alayhi} returns to the Book." (1)
Then he said: "And this interpretation is far from the understood meaning in the speech of the Arabs, rather it is an error. That is because the Muhaymin is conjoined to the Musaddiq, so it can only be from the attribute of what the Musaddiq was an attribute for. If the meaning of the speech were what was narrated from Mujahid, it would have been said: And We revealed to you the Book confirming what is before it of the Scripture, [and you] entrusted (Muhayminan) over it. Because nothing preceded as an attribute of the Kaf in {Ilayka} after it, upon which {Wa Muhayminan 'alayh} could be conjoined. It was only conjoined to Musaddiq, because it is from the attribute of {Al-Kitaba} whose attribute includes Musaddiq. If a thinker thinks that (Al-Musaddiq), according to Mujahid's saying and this interpretation, is from the attribute of the Kaf in {Ilayka}, then His saying: {Lima bayna yadayhi min Al-Kitab} invalidates that interpretation being so, and invalidates (Al-Musaddiq) being from the attribute of the Kaf in {Ilayka}; because the Ha in His saying: {Bayna yadayhi} is a metonymy for the name of a non-addressee, while the Prophet, peace be upon him, is in His saying {Ilayka} (to you). If (Al-Musaddiq) were from the attribute of the Kaf, the speech would be: And We revealed to you the Book confirming what is before you (Bayna yadayka) of the Scripture and entrusted over it. Then the meaning of the speech would be such." (2)
foot_note:
1. Tafsir Al-Tabari (10: 381).
2. Tafsir Al-Tabari (10: 382).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
Third: Ibn Atiyyah's Rectification upon Al-Tabari:
Ibn Atiyyah went to the view that Al-Tabari's objection is not applicable to Mujahid's reading; because what Al-Tabari said applies to the reading of the majority with Kasra on the second Mim in {Wa Muhayminan} when carrying the meaning on Mujahid's interpretation. However, Mujahid reads with Fatha on the second Mim, and if that is so, then what Mujahid said regarding the meaning of (Muhaymanan) is correct and cannot be rejected (1).
Fourth: Al-Samin's agreement with Al-Tabari and his refutation of Ibn Atiyyah:
Al-Samin did not agree with Ibn Atiyyah in his objection to Al-Tabari; he went to support Al-Tabari in his objection to Mujahid where he said: "What Abu Muhammad said does not contain a refutation of Al-Tabari, for Al-Tabari found the existence of (Muhaymanan) as a Hal from the Kaf to be problematic on Mujahid's reading. Furthermore, Ibn Atiyyah said afterwards: 'And it is possible that Musaddiqan and Muhayminan are both circumstantial accusatives (Hal) from the Kaf in {Ilayka}, and this is not specific to Mujahid's reading alone as Makki claimed'. So people only found them being Hals from the Kaf of {Ilayka} problematic due to the awkwardness of the structure." (2)
The closest view to correctness is the invalidity of Ibn Atiyyah's rectification upon Al-Tabari; because Al-Tabari found Mujahid's interpretation problematic, and it is possible that when Mujahid mentioned this meaning, he based it on the concurrent reading, and it is possible he based it on the anomalous reading. The principle is that when an exegete mentions the meanings of the Quran, he mentions them based on the known concurrent reading, not on the anomalous one (3).
foot_note:
1. See: Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (2: 200).
2. Al-Durr Al-Masun (4: 290).
3. See: Istidrakat Ibn Atiyyah 'ala Al-Tabari, by Shaye' Al-Asmari (p. 556).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
Furthermore, this meaning which Mujahid mentioned is problematic even if carried on the anomalous reading. For His saying - the Exalted - {Wa Muhayminan} on this reading would be a Hal from the Kaf in {Ilayka}, and this is not plausible as Al-Tabari (1) and Al-Samin Al-Halabi (2) said; for {Musaddiqan} is a Hal from the Book, not a Hal from the Kaf in {Ilayka}; because if it were a Hal from it, the structure would be: Lima bayna yadayka (what is before you); with the Kaf of address. Interpreting it as a shift (Iltifat) from address to third person is far from the Quranic arrangement (3).
Adding to the weakness of Mujahid's reading and interpretation is what came from Ibn Abbas: "Al-Muhaymin: The Trustee (Al-Amin). The Quran is a trustee over every book before it." (4)

[16]: Ibn Atiyyah said in his talk about the readings appearing in {Wa 'Abada Al-Taghuta} (1) from His saying - the Exalted -: {Say, "Shall I inform you of [what is] worse than that as penalty from Allah? [It is that of] those whom Allah has cursed and with whom He became angry and made of them apes and pigs and slaves of Taghut} [Al-Ma'idah: 60]: "It was narrated from Al-Hasan via other than the path of Abbad (2) that he read with Fatha on the 'Ayn and Dal and Sukoon on the Ba, and Nasb on the Ta of Taghut ({Wa 'Abda Al-Taghuta}). This is directed in two ways. One of them: That he intended ({Wa 'Abdan Al-Taghuta}) so he deleted the Tanwin as deleted in the poet's saying:
............................................ ... Nor remembering (Dhakiri) Allah except a little (3)
The other way is that he intended ('Abada) which is a past tense verb, and he silenced the Ba similar to how the 'Ayn of the verb is silenced in the poet's saying:
And not every cheated one (Maghbun) (4), even if his deal (Safquhu) (6) passed (Salfa) (5) ... ............................................ (7)

with a silent Lam. And like it is Abu Al-Sammal's reading: (Wa Lu'nu bima qalu) with a silent 'Ayn. I (Al-Samin) say: That is not like (Lu'nu) because lightening the Kasra is analogical (standard), unlike the Fatha." (1)
Study of the Rectification:
Al-Samin criticized Ibn Atiyyah for comparing Al-Hasan's reading of silencing the Ba (Wa 'Abda Al-Taghuta) to Abu Al-Sammal's reading of silencing the 'Ayn in his saying: (Wa Lu'nu bima qalu); because lightening the Kasra is analogical, unlike the Fatha. A number of scholars discussed this issue. The Basrans agreed that the vowel Fatha is not lightened (by silencing), and what came of lightening in the Fatha is anomalous and cannot be used for analogy, like his saying:
And not every cheated one even if his deal passed (Salfa) ... By returning what passed him by restoration
He intends: Salafa, so he silenced it out of necessity. The Kufans permitted that, and cited the previous verse as evidence (2).

text:
The grammarians agreed on the permissibility of silencing the Damma and Kasra. As for the Fatha - according to the majority - it is not silenced as the Damma and Kasra are silenced; due to the lightness of the Fatha. He who says in (Kabid): (Kabd), and in ('Adud): ('Add); does not say in (Jamal): (Jaml) (1). Sibawayh said: "As for what has two consecutive Fathas, they do not silence any of it, because the Fatha is lighter to them than the Damma and Kasra." (2) Ibn Qutaybah said: "And if the verb comes on (Fa'ala), they do not lighten it, like (Daraba), (Qatala), and (Akala); because they do not deem the Fatha heavy." (3) Ibn Jinni said: "And nothing of this came in the Fatha due to the lightness of the Fatha." (4) Based on this: Al-Samin's rectification upon Ibn Atiyyah is valid; because the preponderant view in this issue is that lightening the Kasra and Damma is analogical (standard), unlike lightening the Fatha; for it is anomalous. This is the saying of the Basrans and the majority of grammarians. As for what the Kufans cited, it does not indicate analogy/standardization, but rather indicates the anomaly of that and its permissibility in necessity - as the Basrans said.

text: Al-Samin Al-Halabi said speaking about this reading: "As for the second reading (Baynukum), there are three aspects in it. First: That this adverb was expanded, so the verb was assigned to it, thus becoming a noun like other declinable nouns." (1) Al-Samin spoke at length about this aspect, then mentioned the second aspect saying: "Second: That (Bayn) is a noun, not an adverb, and its meaning is 'Connection' (Al-Wasl), i.e., Your connection has been severed. This is attributed to Abu Amr (2), Ibn Jinni (3), Al-Mahdawi (4), and Al-Zahrawi (5). (1) If this is established, the opinion that it is a metaphor is more appropriate than the opinion that it is a homonym, because when homonymy and metaphor conflict, metaphor is better than it according to the majority'. text:
Study of the Rectification:
First: Scholars' opinions in directing the reading with Raf' of the Nun (Baynukum). The scholars have four opinions on this issue:
The First: That 'Al-Bayn' in (Baynukum) is an adverb used as a noun. When it was used as a noun, it was permissible to assign the verb (Taqatta'a) to it. It is not permissible for (Baynukum) to be a verbal noun (Masdar); because the estimation would become: Your separation has been severed, and this is contrary to the intended meaning; because the intent is: Your connection has been severed. It is permissible for 'Al-Bayn' to mean connection although its origin is separation; because when it was used with two joined things in the likes of: Between me and him is a partnership, and between me and him is friendship; it became, due to its usage in these places, in the status of connection (Waslah) contrary to separation; therefore {Laqad Taqatta'a Baynukum} came meaning: Your connection has been severed. Said by: Al-Farisi (1), Makki bin Abi Talib (2), and preferred by: Ibn Atiyyah (3), Al-Fakhr Al-Razi (4), and Al-Samin Al-Halabi (5). Al-Samin said: 'The opinion that it is a metaphor is more appropriate than the opinion that it is a homonym, because when homonymy and metaphor conflict, metaphor is better than it according to the majority.' (6)

The Second: That (Al-Bayn) remains on its origin in separation, from 'Bana Yabinu' if he became distant. And there is in His saying: (Taqatta'a) a metaphor similar to what is said regarding a matter distant in distance: 'The wide roads (Fijaj) between such and such were cut': An expression for the distance of that. The intent would be: The distance between you was cut due to its length, so He expressed that with 'Al-Bayn' which is separation. Ibn Atiyyah mentioned this aspect as a probable face (1).
The Third: That this is speech carried on its meaning; for the meaning is: Your gathering has dispersed and scattered. Al-Samin Al-Halabi mentioned this and commented that it is not suitable to be an explanation of parsing (2).
The Fourth: That 'Al-Bayn' here is: Connection (Al-Wasl), i.e.: Your connection has been severed. For 'Al-Bayn' is an auto-antonym (Addad); used in the language for connection, and for separation.

Some of them said: It is like His saying - the Exalted -: {And the connections/causes (Al-Asbab) will be cut off from them} [Al-Baqarah: 166], meaning: The connections and communication that existed between them in the world (1).
Second: Discussion and Weighting:
As for the first opinion, its purport is the same as the purport of the majority opinion, except that in its detail it claims metaphor, and there is no need to claim that; because (Al-Bayn) was used with the meaning of connection among the Arabs.
As for the second opinion, Ibn Atiyyah mentioned it, and none of the scholars preferred it.
As for the third opinion, it is an interpretation of meaning, not an interpretation of wording and parsing, and combining wording and meaning in interpretation and direction is more appropriate.
As for the fourth opinion, it is the preponderant one; for the following reasons:
1 - That this opinion agrees with the interpretation of the Predecessors (Salaf) from the Companions and Followers; for they interpreted His saying (Baynukum) as: Your connection (2).

2 - That the Arabs have used (Al-Bayn) with the meaning of connection (Al-Wasl). Among the evidences for that is the saying of the poet (1):
By your life, were it not for the Bayn (Connection), love would have been severed ... And were it not for love, no lover (Alif) would have yearned for the Bayn (Connection) (2)
So (Al-Bayn) here is the Connection (3). And one of them combined both meanings saying (4):
We were upon a Bayn (Connection) that united our gathering ... Then it was followed by the Bayn (Separation) that scattered the gathering
Oh wonder! Two opposites and the word is one ... By Allah, what a word, how bitter and how sweet!
The Quran was revealed in the language of the Arabs, and the words in it came according to the Arabs' usage of them.

So leave them and that which they invent} [Al-An'am: 137]: "Ibn Amir read: {Wa kadhalika Zuyyina} with Damma on the Zay, {Qatlu} with Raf', {Awladahum} with Nasb on the Dal, {Shuraka'ihim} with Khafd (genitive) on the partners (Shuraka'). This is a weak reading in the usage of the Arabs, because he added the Killing (Qatl) to the Actor (Fa'il) which is the Partners, then separated between the annexed (Mudaf) and the annexed to (Mudaf Ilayh) with the Object (Maf'ul). The leaders of Arabic do not permit separation with adverbs in the likes of this except in poetry, like his saying (2):

Ibn Amir read: {Zuyyina li-kathirin min al-mushrikina Qatlu Awladahum Shuraka'ihim}; {Zuyyina} Passive voice, {Qatlu} pro-agent (Na'ib Fa'il) and it is annexed (Mudaf), {Awladahum} object of the verbal noun {Qatlu}, and {Shuraka'ihim} annexed to (Mudaf Ilayh). Then Al-Samin mentioned some of what was said in weakening this reading, and quoted Ibn Atiyyah's statement - previously mentioned - textually, then said: "All these sayings I mentioned should not be paid attention to because they are an attack on the Mutawatir, even if they issued from great Imams. Also, those who oppose them have defended it, and cited from the language of the Arabs, its poetry and prose, what testifies to the linguistic correctness of this reading." (1)
Then he quoted some sayings in defense of the Mutawatir readings generally and this reading specifically. He said after that: "It has been heard from one whose Arabic is trusted: 'Tarku yawman nafsika wa hawaha sa'yun fi radaha' i.e.: Leaving your self one day with its desire is a striving in its destruction. As for what appeared in poetry of separating between two annexed nouns with an adverb and preposition and object, it is frequent, and with other than that is rare." (2)
He cited a number of examples from Arab speech in poetry and prose containing separation between the annexed and annexed to with the adverb and object and others; to prove the correctness of Ibn Amir's reading linguistically (3), and he elaborated on that well. Until he said: "And since you have known this, know that Ibn Amir's reading is correct from the perspective of language just as it is correct from the perspective of transmission." (4)

Then he proved the correctness of separation between the annexed and annexed to from a grammatical perspective. He categorized those who addressed Ibn Amir's reading into two groups: Some weakened the reading, and some declared the reciter ignorant, and both are in error; for it is not permissible to deny a reading authentic from an Imam among the Imams of Muslims. Then he refuted Al-Zamakhshari in his weakening of this reading (1).
Study of the Rectification:
First: Ibn Amir's Reading:
Ibn Amir read: {Zuyyina li-kathirin min al-mushrikina Qatlu Awladahum Shuraka'ihim}: With Damma on the Zay and Kasra on the Ya from {Zuyyina}: passive voice. Raf' on the Lam of {Qatlu}: pro-agent and it is annexed. Nasb on the Dal of {Awladahum} and it is the object of the verbal noun {Qatlu}. Khafd (genitive) on the Hamza of {Shuraka'ihim} by annexation of {Qatlu} to it, and it is the agent (actor) in meaning (2).

text:
Thus, Ibn Amir's reading involves separation between the annexed {Qatlu} and the annexed to {Shuraka'ihim} with the object {Awladahum} (1). The Killing was added to the Partners in this reading; because the Partners are the ones who beautified that and called for it. So the verb (verbal noun) is added to its agent as is obligatory in principle, but he separated between the annexed and annexed to, and advanced the object and left it accusative in its state; as it was delayed in meaning, and delayed the annexed to and left it genitive in its state; as it was advanced after the Killing. The estimation is: And likewise the killing by their partners of their children was made pleasing to many of the polytheists (2).
Second: Scholars' Opinions on Ibn Amir's Reading:
The scholars' opinion on Ibn Amir's reading is built upon their opinion on the issue of separation between two annexed nouns with other than an adverb and prepositional phrase. Whoever permitted that did not weaken the reading, and whoever prevented that weakened the reading and rejected it.
From a grammatical perspective, the Kufans permitted separation between the annexed and annexed to with the adverb and prepositional phrase and others in poetry and prose alike. The majority of Basrans prevented separation between two annexed nouns with other than the adverb and prepositional phrase; arguing that the annexed and annexed to are in the status of one thing,

Al-Samin used more than one method in his defense of Ibn Amir's reading:
1. By proving its concurrent transmission and authenticity of transfer, and consequently the impermissibility of rejecting or weakening it.

3. By proving its correctness from a grammatical perspective (1).
Third: The Ruling on this Reading:
The correct view is that Ibn Amir's reading is authentic in transmission and language - as Al-Samin said - and the preponderant view is the permissibility of separation between two annexed nouns with the object; due to its existence in this concurrently transmitted reading attributed to the purely Arab Ibn Amir, who took the Quran from the Companions before solecism (Lahn) appeared in the Arabic tongue (2).
Ibn Amir's reading is supported by another reading; for some of the Predecessors read (3): {Fa la tahsabanna Allaha mukhlifa wa'daha rusulihi} [Ibrahim: 47] with Nasb on (Wa'daha) and Khafd on (Rusulihi). (4)
This has occurred in the speech of Arabs in poetry (5) and prose (6). Among the evidences indicating the correctness of what came in Ibn Amir's reading:

The saying of the Messenger, peace be upon him: (Hal antum tariku li sahibi? / Are you leaving my companion for me?) (1); for his saying: (Tariku) is annexed, and his saying: (Sahibi) is annexed to, and he separated between them with the prepositional phrase which is his saying: (Li) (2). Ibn Al-Jazari said: "He separated with the prepositional phrase (Li) between the active participle (Tariku) and its object (Sahibi), along with what it contains of the intended pronoun. So separating the verbal noun due to its freedom from the pronoun is more worthy of permissibility." (3)
It was heard from some Arabs: "Hadha ghulamu - wallahi - Zaydin" (This is the boy - by Allah - of Zaid); they separated between the annexed and annexed to with the oath (4).
In their saying: "Tarku yawman nafsika wa hawaha sa'yun laha fi radaha", there is separation between the annexed (Tarku) and the annexed to in (Nafsika) with the adverb (Yawman) (5).
They separated between them with a sentence in their saying: "Huwa ghulamu - in sha'a Allahu - akhika" (He is the boy - if Allah wills - of your brother), so separation with a singular word is easier (6).

Separation between the annexed verbal noun and the annexed to with the object is permissible; because it is not in its place, for it is intended to be delayed, while it is not permissible with the agent; because it is in its place (1).
Ibn Malik (2) deemed the separation occurring in Ibn Amir's reading good for several reasons:
First: The separator being extra (Fadlah) so it is suitable for not being counted.
Second: That it is not foreign in meaning; because it relates to the annexed which is the verbal noun.
Third: That the separator is estimated to be delayed; because the annexed to is estimated to be advanced; because it is the agent in meaning. Even if the Arabs did not use such separation, analogy would require its use; because they separated in poetry with the foreign extensively; so separating with a non-foreign element deserved to have merit, so it is judged permissible absolutely (3).
Ibn Hisham - who is a Basran - clarified the issues where separation is permitted in prose, mentioning one of them: That the annexed be a verbal noun and the annexed to be its agent, and the separator be either its object; like Ibn Amir's reading, or its adverb; like the saying of some: "Tarku yawman nafsika wa hawaha".
The second: That the annexed be a description (Wasf), and the annexed to be its first object, and the separator be its second object; like the reading of some: {Fa la tahsabanna Allaha mukhlifa wa'daha rusulihi} [Ibrahim: 47].

The third: That the separator be an oath; like their saying: "Hadha ghulamu - wallahi - Zaydin" (1).
Ibn Al-Jazari said: "The correct view is the permissibility of such separation, which is separation between the verbal noun and its agent annexed to it by the object in eloquent, widespread, well-known usage by choice, and this is not specific to poetic necessity. Sufficient as evidence for that is this authentic famous reading which reached concurrent transmission. How could it be otherwise when its reciter is Ibn Amir, one of the senior Followers who took from the Companions?" (2)
Then he said: "It has not reached us from any of the Predecessors, may Allah be pleased with them, despite the difference of their schools and variance of their dialects and intensity of their piety, that he denied anything of Ibn Amir's reading, or attacked it, or pointed to it with weakness. The people in Damascus and all the lands of Sham up to Al-Jazirah Al-Furatiyyah (3) and its districts used only Ibn Amir's reading, and the matter remained so until around the year 500. The first one we know who denied this reading and other authentic readings and committed this prohibition was Ibn Jarir Al-Tabari after the year 300, and this has been counted among Ibn Jarir's lapses." (4)
Al-Shihab Al-Khafaji (5) said: "And the speech of Allah is more deserving that rules be derived from it and referred back to it, not that it be referred to other than it. It is strange that someone affirms those rules by the narration of a single person from a pre-Islamic Arab, but when it comes to the [Quranic] System, he hesitates in affirming with it." (6)

Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "Al-Hasan, Abu Haywah, and Malik bin Dinar (1) read (Wa min Rubut) with two Dammas, and from Al-Hasan also (Rubt) with Damma and Sukoon. That is like Kitab and Kutub. Rather, Abu Zaid (2) recounted that (Ribatan) means five horses and above, and that its plural is (Rubut). Even if it is conceded that it is a verbal noun, we do not concede that its types did not vary. It has been preceded that (Ribat) can be a plural for the verbal noun Rabt, so what was the answer there is the answer here." (3)
Analysis of the Rectification:
The subject of this rectification is the direction of the reading with Damma on the Ra and Ba (Rubut), and the opinion on it is based on the meaning of (Ribat al-khayl) in the verse. Ibn Atiyyah went to the view that (Rubut) is the plural of Ribat, and criticized it on the grounds that it is a plural for a non-diverse verbal noun (Ribat).

Al-Samin rectified him; he did not concede that (Ribat) is a verbal noun, and quoted Abu Zaid's saying regarding the intended meaning of Ribat, which is the opinion that weakens what Ibn Atiyyah went to - that (Ribat) is a verbal noun. Study of the Rectification:
First: Scholars' opinions on the intended meaning of Ribat in the verse:
1 - That Ribat: Five horses and above. Its singular is: Rabit, like Fisal and Fasil, and its group is: Rubut, which are those that are tied. This is Abu Zaid's opinion, and the majority of exegetes and linguists mentioned it (1).
2 - That it is a noun for horses tied in the cause of Allah. Said by: Al-Zamakhshari (2), Al-Fakhr Al-Razi (3), and others (4), and it is close to the meaning of the first opinion.
3 - That Ribat is the verbal noun (Masdar) of Rabata or Rabata. Said by Ibn Atiyyah (5), and some scholars considered it a probable aspect (6).

He reached the Jahiliyyah and embraced Islam after the Conquest of Mecca, but did not see the Prophet, peace be upon him. He presented the Quran to Ibn Abbas and learned it from Abu Musa. He died in the year 105 AH. See: Usd Al-Ghabah, by Ibn Al-Athir (4: 267), Siyar A'lam Al-Nubala, by Al-Dhahabi (4: 253), Ghayat Al-Nihayah fi Tabaqat Al-Qurra, by Ibn Al-Jazari (1: 604).
3. Lahiq bin Humayd Al-Sadusi Al-Basri, Abu Mijlaz. Trustworthy. He heard from a number of Companions, and narration regarding Quranic letters (readings) was reported from him. He died in the year 110 AH, and other dates were said. See: Al-Tabaqat Al-Kubra, by Ibn Sa'd (7: 216), Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir, by Al-Bukhari (8: 258), Ghayat Al-Nihayah fi Tabaqat Al-Qurra, by Ibn Al-Jazari (2: 363).
4. Aws bin Abdullah Al-Raba'i Al-Basri, Abu Al-Jawza. One of the senior scholars. He narrated from a group of Companions including: Ibn Abbas and Aisha. He died in the year 83 AH. See: Al-Tabaqat Al-Kubra, by Ibn Sa'd (7: 166), Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir, by Al-Bukhari (2: 16), Siyar A'lam Al-Nubala, by Al-Dhahabi (4: 371).
5. The reading of the group is (Maqami) with Fatha on the Mim, which is the place of standing from (Qama). Abu Mijlaz, Abu Raja, and Abu Al-Jawza read (Muqami) with Damma on the Mim, which is the place of residence, or the residence itself. See: Zad Al-Masir fi Ilm Al-Tafsir, by Ibn Al-Jawzi (2: 340), Tafsir Abi Hayyan (6: 87), Al-Durr Al-Masun (6: 239).

text:
Ibn Atiyyah said: 'And it was not read here with Damma on the Mim'. It is as if he did not view the reading of these Fathers." (1)
Study of the Rectification:
Most exegetes and people of readings did not speak about the occurrence of readings in His saying {Maqami} other than the reading of the majority. Some of them denied the occurrence of a reading with Damma on the Mim in this place, such as Ibn Atiyyah (2), and Al-Qurtubi where he said: "And Al-Muqam with Damma: is residence, and it was not read with it as far as I know." (3) Al-Shawkani said: "And the readers agreed on Fatha." (4)
Three scholars affirmed the occurrence of an anomalous reading with Damma on the Mim from Abu Al-Jawza, Abu Raja, and Abu Mijlaz: Ibn Al-Jawzi (5), Abu Hayyan (6), and Al-Samin Al-Halabi (7). I did not find it with others among the people of Tafsir and Readings.

text:
In this rectification, Al-Samin criticized Ibn Atiyyah for his lack of knowledge of the reading with Damma. This is one of the aspects of Al-Samin's rectification upon Ibn Atiyyah in the field of readings, where he criticizes him for his lack of knowledge regarding some readings that were recited (1). Affirming the reading with Damma - especially since it is attributed to great Imams - and benefiting from it in interpretation is more appropriate than negating it. However, Ibn Atiyyah's lack of knowledge of this reading does not diminish his knowledge of readings, especially since anomalous readings vary in their fame.

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
[22]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {And it was said, "O earth, swallow your water, and O sky, withhold [your rain]." And the water subsided, and the matter was accomplished, and the ship came to rest on the Judiyy. And it was said, "Away with the wrongdoing people."} [Hud: 44]: "The majority of people read: {Ala Al-Judiyyi} (1) with Kasra on the Ya and doubling it. Al-A'mash (2) and Ibn Abi Abla (3) read (Ala Al-Judi) with Sukoon on the Ya. They are two dialects." (4)
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "Al-A'mash and Ibn Abi Abla read with lightening of (Al-Judi). Ibn Atiyyah said: 'They are two dialects'. The correct view is to say: The Ya of Nisba (attribution) was lightened, even if that is not permissible in their common speech." (5)
Study of the Rectification:
Most exegetes, when interpreting this verse, mentioned the intended meaning of Al-Judiyy (6) without detailing the pronunciation of the word, and whether (Al-Judiyyi) is originally attributed to Al-Jud and the Ya is the Ya of Nisba or otherwise (7).
foot_note:

2. Sulayman bin Mihran Al-Asadi Al-Kahili their client, Abu Muhammad, known as Al-A'mash. The Follower, Imam, Hafiz, Sheikh of Reciters and Muhaddithin. He was a head in beneficial knowledge and righteous deed, and one of the most knowledgeable people in inheritance laws. He died in the year 148 AH. See: Tarikh Baghdad, by Al-Baghdadi (10: 5), Siyar A'lam Al-Nubala, by Al-Dhahabi (6: 226), Ghayat Al-Nihayah fi Tabaqat Al-Qurra, by Ibn Al-Jazari (1: 315).
3. Ibrahim bin Abi Abla Al-Uqayli Al-Shami Al-Maqdisi, Abu Ishaq. The Follower, Imam, Exemplar. Ibn Al-Jazari said: "He has letters in readings and a choice in which he differed from the general public, regarding the authenticity of its attribution to him there is a view (doubt)." He died in the year 151 AH, and other dates were said. See: Siyar A'lam Al-Nubala, by Al-Dhahabi (6: 323), Ghayat Al-Nihayah fi Tabaqat Al-Qurra, by Ibn Al-Jazari (1: 19).

6. A mountain overlooking Jazirat Ibn Umar on the eastern side of the Tigris in the province of Mosul, upon which Noah's Ark rested - peace be upon him. Yaqut Al-Hamawi said: "Its Ya is doubled." text:
Some of them said that in (Al-Judi) there are two dialects: with doubling the Ya and silencing it, without indicating that the Ya in Al-Judi is the doubled Ya of Nisba or that Al-Judi is originally attributed to Al-Jud. Makki bin Abi Talib (1) and Ibn Atiyyah (2) said this. Makki said: "And in Al-Judi there are two dialects: doubling the Ya, and lightening it." (3)
As for the majority of scholars who discussed this word, they affirmed that Al-Judi is originally attributed to Al-Jud, and the Ya in it is doubled, which is the Ya of Nisba, and lightening it is anomalous. Among those who said this: Al-Akhfash (4), Ibn Jinni (5), Abu Al-Baqa (6), Abu Hayyan (7), Al-Samin (8), and others (9).

text:
Al-Akhfash said: "As for (Al-Judiyyu), it was made heavy because it is the Ya of Nisba, so it is as if it was attributed to Al-Jud." (1) Al-Raghib said: "It is originally attributed to Al-Jud." (2) Abu Al-Baqa said: "His saying - the Exalted -: {Ala Al-Judiyyi}: with doubling of the Ya, and it is the original form." (3)
Doubling the Ya of Nisba is obligatory linguistically by the agreement of linguists, so it is not permissible to lighten it; lest it be confused with the Ya of the first person speaker added to it, and because the relation (Nisba) becomes inherent to the related noun, so this addition - Ya of Nisba - became more emphatic than other additions, so they doubled the Ya of Nisba to indicate this meaning (4). As for lightening the Ya of Nisba in this reading, it is due to deeming the two Yas - the two Yas of Nisba - heavy (5). This lightening - by deleting one of the two Yas of Nisba - is rare and anomalous, and its domain is poetry (6). Al-Farra said about this reading: "It is among what speech became frequent with among its people, so it was lightened." (7)

5. In Nisba there are two Yas: The first of them is silent and assimilated into the other, and what is before it is broken (Kasra). See: Al-Usul fi Al-Nahw, by Ibn Al-Sarraj (3: 63).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
So Al-Samin's rectification upon Ibn Atiyyah is valid; because the silencing of the Ya in this reading is more appropriately said to be: deletion of one of the two Yas of Nisba; due to deeming the two Yas heavy, and that is rare and anomalous. The reading of the majority with doubling may be considered a preponderant factor for the view that the Ya in (Al-Judi) is the Ya of Nisba, and it may be lightened as in the reading of Al-A'mash and Ibn Abi Abla. In summary, the disagreement between the statements of Ibn Atiyyah and Al-Samin does not entail a difference in meaning, for Al-Judi is the same in both directions. The disagreement is only in the pronunciation of the word and its origin, not in its meaning.
* * *

Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "As for affirming the Ya in (Narta'i) with the jussive of (Nal'ab), which is Qunbul's reading (1), some people dared to reject it. Ibn Atiyyah said: 'It is a weak reading not permissible except in poetry'. It was said: It is the dialect of those who make the jussive by estimating the vowel (on the weak letter), and he recited: Alam ya'tika wal-anba'u tanmi ... ........................" (2)
Study of the Rectification:
Several readings appeared in the word (Yarta') from His saying - the Exalted -: {Arsilhu ma'ana ghadan yarta' wa yal'ab}, among them the reading with Nun and affirming the Ya: (Narta'i). Ibn Atiyyah weakened this reading and did not permit it. Al-Samin denounced its rejection by some scholars, including Ibn Atiyyah, and mentioned a justification for it. The discussion of this issue is from two aspects:
foot_note:
1. Muhammad bin Abdul Rahman bin Muhammad Al-Makhzumi their client, Al-Makki, Abu Omar, known as Qunbul. Reciter of the people of Mecca. He took reading by presentation from Al-Qawwas, and narrated reading from Al-Bazzi. A multitude read to him, including Abu Bakr bin Mujahid. He died in the year 291 AH. See: Mu'jam Al-Udaba', by Yaqut Al-Hamawi (5: 2238), Ma'rifat Al-Qurra Al-Kibar, by Al-Dhahabi (p. 133), Ghayat Al-Nihayah fi Tabaqat Al-Qurra, by Ibn Al-Jazari (2: 165).
