book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
First: The meaning of the reading (Narta'i):
The reading affirming the Ya in (Narta'i) is like the other correct reading with Kasra on the 'Ayn: (Narti'); its origin is: Narta'i, but the Ya was deleted for the jussive case (1). (Narta'i) is 'Ifti'al' from grazing (Al-Ra'y), on the measure: Nafta'il, i.e., we graze livestock (2). It was said: The meaning of (Narta'i) is we guard each other and preserve one another, so it is 'Ifti'al' from guardianship (Al-Ri'ayah) meaning: preservation (3). This meaning is supported by what came from Mujahid in interpreting the verse: (Narta'i) i.e., we guard one another (4). Ibn Qutaybah said: "Whoever read: (Narti') with Kasra on the 'Ayn meant: We guard and tend to each other, i.e., preserve. From it is said: Ra'ak Allah (May Allah tend to you); i.e., preserve you." (5) Ibn Khalawayh said: "The argument for whoever broke it (Kasra) is that he took it from Al-Ra'y, and its origin is affirming the Ya in it, so he deleted it to indicate the jussive; because it is the response to the request in their saying: {Arsilhu ma'ana}." (6)

Second: Ruling on the reading affirming the Ya linguistically:
The reading affirming the Ya (Narta'i) came according to the dialect of those who affirm the weak letter in the jussive case and estimate the deletion of the estimated vowel on the weak letter (1). Ibn Atiyyah weakened this reading from this aspect, for that, according to him, is not permissible except in poetry (2). The correct view is that this reading is linguistically correct. Affirming the weak letter at the end of the jussive present tense verb, and making it jussive with an estimated Sukoon on the weak letter before the arrival of the jussive article, is a dialect of some Arabs (3), and it is correct and not a matter of necessity at all (4). Al-Azhari (5) said: "The silent Ya is left as it is in the place of jussive in some dialects." (6) Ibn Khalawayh said: "Some Arabs treat the weak verb like the sound verb, so they say: Lam ya'ti (with Ya) Zaidun." (7)

It was said: The Ya in (Narta'i) is from the Kasra in (Narti'); it was saturated so a Ya resulted from it (1). Similar to it is the reading affirming the Ya in (Yattaqi) (2) from His saying - the Exalted -: {Indeed, he who fears Allah and is patient, then indeed, Allah does not allow to be lost the reward of those who do good} [Yusuf: 90]. Abu Shama said: "Some Arabs treat the weak verb like the sound verb, so they do not delete anything of its letters for the jussive as they do not delete anything in the sound verb, and they suffice with silencing its end. From this is his saying: Alam ya'tika wal-anba'u tanmi ... ........................ Another aspect is that the Kasra was saturated so a Ya was generated from it." (3) Ibn Al-Jazari said speaking about affirming the Ya in (Narta'i) and (Yattaqi): "The justification for affirming the Ya in these two particles (words) despite them being jussive: Treating the weak verb like the sound verb, and that is a dialect of some Arabs." (4) Based on this: Al-Samin's rectification upon Ibn Atiyyah is valid, and Qunbul's reading (Narta'i) is correct linguistically; for affirming the weak letter in the jussive case is a dialect of some Arabs and is permissible, not as Ibn Atiyyah said that it is not permissible except in poetry.

text:
[24]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {So when she heard of their scheming, she sent for them and prepared for them a banquet and gave each one of them a knife and said [to Joseph], "Come out before them." And when they saw him, they greatly admired him and cut their hands and said, "Perfect is Allah! This is not a man (Ma hadha basharan); this is none but a noble angel."} [Yusuf: 31]: "And the Nasb (accusative) of (Al-Bashar) in His saying: {Ma hadha basharan} (1) is according to the dialect of Hijaz, (Ma) was likened to (Laysa). As for Tamim, they raise (use nominative), but it was not read with." (2)
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "Ibn Atiyyah transmitted that no one read except with the dialect of Hijaz. Al-Zamakhshari said: 'And whoever read according to his instinct from Banu Tamim read (Basharun) with Raf', and it is the reading of Ibn Mas'ud'. (3) I say: So Ibn Atiyyah's claim that it was not read with is not conceded." (4)
Study of the Rectification:
In His saying - the Exalted -: {Wa qulna hasha lillahi ma hadha basharan}, (Basharan) is in accusative state as the predicate of (Ma), because (Ma) in the dialect of the people of Hijaz has the meaning of (Laysa) in negation, and the Quran was revealed in the dialect of the people of Hijaz. (5)
foot_note:
1. The group read: {Ma hadha basharan} with Nasb; according to the ancient dialect of the people of Hijaz, they made (Ma) operate like (Laysa) so it raised (Hadha) and put (Basharan) in Nasb. Abdullah bin Mas'ud, Abu Al-Mutawakkil, Abu Nahik, Ikrimah, and Mu'adh Al-Qari' read: (Ma hadha basharun) with Raf', which is the dialect of Tamim. Ubayy bin Ka'b, Al-Hasan, Abu Al-Huwayrith, Abdul Warith from Abu Amr, Abu Al-Jawza, and Abu Al-Sawwar read: (Ma hadha bishira) i.e., not one who is bought. Ibn Mas'ud and Al-Hasan read: (Ma hadha bishira'in) with lengthening and Hamz, genitive with Tanwin. In Hafsa's codex: (Ma hadha bi-basharin) with addition of Ba in the predicate of (Ma), which is most common in the dialect of Hijaz. text:
Al-Tabari said: "As for the Quran, it came with Nasb in all of that; because it was revealed in the dialect of the people of Hijaz." (1)
Making (Ma) operate like (Laysa) is the ancient Hijazi dialect. More common in the Hijazi dialect is putting the predicate in the genitive with Ba, so they say: "Ma Zaidun bi-qa'imin"; and (Qa'imin) here is: genitive in wording, accusative in place (2). Al-Farra said about His saying {Ma hadha basharan}: "Everything in the Quran came with Ba except this, and His saying: {Ma hunna ummahatihim} [Al-Mujadilah: 2]." (3) Among what came in the Quran with Ba is His saying - the Exalted -: {Wa ma hum bi-mu'minin} [Al-Baqarah: 8], and His saying: {Wa ma hum bi-mu'jizin} [Az-Zumar: 51].
As for Banu Tamim, the predicate according to them is raised; for they do not make (Ma) operate like (Laysa) (4). Ibn Atiyyah denied the occurrence of a reading according to the dialect of Tamim - with Raf' of (Bashar) - in this verse (5). Al-Samin criticized him for that (6); as the reading with Raf' appeared attributed to Abdullah bin Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, in Al-Zamakhshari (7).

text:
[25]: Ibn Atiyyah said in his discussion of the readings appearing in His saying - the Exalted -: {Until when the messengers despaired and thought that they had been denied, there came to them Our aid, and whoever We willed was saved (Fanujjiya). And Our punishment is not repelled from the people who are criminals} [Yusuf: 110]: "A group read (Fanunjiya) (1) with two Nuns and Fatha on the Ya. Hubayrah (2) narrated it from Hafs (3) from Asim, and it is a mistake by Hubayrah." (4)
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said rectifying him: "Ibn Atiyyah imagined that it is a present tense verb remaining in its nominative state, so he denied the Fatha of its Lam (last letter), and considered its narrator in error. It is not an error; for if it falls after the condition and consequence (Jaza') together,
foot_note:
1. Ibn Amir, Asim, and Yaqub read: (Fanujjiya) with one Nun, doubled Jim, and open Ya; based on passive voice and (Man) is pro-agent. Mujahid, Al-Hasan, Al-Jahdari, Talha bin Musarrif, and Ibn Hormuz read: (Fanujjiy) with one Nun, doubled Jim, silent Ya, which is past passive voice, and the Ya was silenced according to the dialect of those who deem movement on the Ya heavy absolutely. Ibn Kathir, Nafi', Abu Amr, Hamza, Al-Kisa'i, Khalaf, and Abu Ja'far read: (Fanunji) with two Nuns: first Damma'd, second silent, and silent Ya, which is present tense of (Anja) and (Man) is its object, and the agent is the first person pronoun. Hubayrah narrated from Hafs from Asim: (Fanunjiya) with two Nuns, from (Anja), so it is like the previous reading except that the Ya is open. Al-Hasan and Al-Kisa'i in a narration read: (Fanunajji) with two Nuns: first Damma'd, second open, doubled Jim, silent Ya, which is present tense of (Najja) with doubled 'Ayn. Nasr bin Asim, Al-Hasan, Abu Haywah, and Isa bin Omar read: (Fanaja) making it past tense with lightened Jim, and (Man) is its agent. Al-Dani reported that it was read for Ibn Muhaysin: (Fanajja) like the previous one except with doubled Jim, and the agent is the pronoun of Victory (Nasr), i.e., So the Victory saved, and (Man) is its object. This has preceded at his saying: {To Allah belongs whatever is in the heavens and whatever is in the earth. Whether you show what is within yourselves or conceal it, Allah will bring you to account for it} [Al-Baqarah: 284] up to his saying: (Fayaghfira) read with its Nasb (1), and its direction preceded (2). There is no difference whether the conditional particle is jussive like the verse of Al-Baqarah or non-jussive like this verse." (3)
Study of the Rectification:
Ibn Atiyyah considered the narration of Hubayrah from Hafs from Asim (Fanunjiya) with two Nuns and open Ya as incorrect (Ghalat). Ibn Mujahid preceded him in declaring this narration incorrect where he said: "Hubayrah narrated from Hafs from Asim (Fanunjiya) with two Nuns, Damma'd and light, and this is a mistake." (4) Al-Farisi followed him in this declaration of error, and explained its reason grammatically saying: "Because there is nothing here by which the Ya from his saying (Fanunjiya) would be put in Nasb, and the first Nun is for the present tense, so it is not permissible for it to be in Nasb without a particle of Nasb." text:
Several scholars refuted this declaration of error and validated this narration linguistically, including: Abu Hayyan (1), Al-Samin (2), and Al-Shihab Al-Khafaji (3). Its justification in language: That it is permissible for the condition and consequence to be followed by a present tense verb in accusative (Nasb) by estimating (An) after the Fa, like the reading of whoever read: {And if you disclose what is within yourselves or conceal it, Allah will bring you to account for it. Then He will forgive (Fayaghfira)} [Al-Baqarah: 284] with Nasb of: (Fayaghfira); by estimating (An) after the Fa. There is no difference in that whether the conditional particle is jussive or non-jussive (4).
So Al-Samin Al-Halabi replied to Ibn Atiyyah with this justification, which is correct in Arabic. However, it cannot be asserted that Ibn Atiyyah's declaration of error was from the linguistic aspect; perhaps he intended that it is an error from the aspect of narration (Riwayah), which is more apparent; since he said: "And it is a mistake by Hubayrah" (5), and he did not address the grammar or deny the opening of the Ya linguistically. It was Al-Farisi who declared it incorrect both narrationally and linguistically. As for Ibn Atiyyah's declaration of error, it allows both possibilities. If his declaration of error was from the aspect of narration, this is correct; for it is an anomalous reading and is not authentic from Hafs from Asim. But if the declaration of error was from the linguistic aspect, then Al-Samin's rectification upon him is valid; since this reading has a correct aspect in the language and is not a mistake.

[26]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his discussion of the readings appearing in {Kalla} (1) from His saying - the Exalted -: {And they have taken besides Allah deities that they would be for them [a source of] honor (81). No! (Kalla) They will deny their worship and will be against them opponents (contrary)} [Maryam: 81 - 82]: "Abu Nahik read (Kallan) with Fatha on the Kaf and Tanwin. Abu Al-Fath (2) recounted it from him, and it is a description (Na't) for (Alihatan)." (3)
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said regarding the aspects of Abu Nahik's reading: "Fourth: That it is a description for (Alihatan), said by Ibn Atiyyah. And in this there is a point of view; for the meaning is not according to that. An aspect might appear for it: That he described the deities with (Al-Kall) which is the verbal noun meaning fatigue and incapacity. As if it were said: 'Alihatan Kallayna' (Fatigued deities), i.e., incapable, cut off. And when he described them with the verbal noun, he kept it singular." (4)
Study of the Rectification:
Scholars have four opinions regarding the direction of Abu Nahik's reading with Fatha on the Kaf and Tanwin (Kallan):
1 - That (Kallan) is the verbal noun of (Kalla) (5) and it is an absolute object (Maf'ul Mutlaq) for a deleted verb. The estimation is: Kalla hadha al-ra'yu wal-i'tiqadu kallan (This opinion and belief fatigued a fatigue - became completely tired/wrong).
foot_note:
1. The general reading: (Kalla) with Fatha on the Kaf, without Tanwin, as a particle of deterrence and rebuke for a denied statement. Abu Nahik read: (Kullan) with Damma on the Kaf meaning 'All', so it is a circumstantial accusative (Hal), i.e., They will all deny. Abu Nahik also read: (Kallan) with Fatha on the Kaf and Tanwin. See: Tafsir Al-Tabari (18: 251), Mukhtasar Shawadh Al-Quran, by Ibn Khalawayh (p. 89), Al-Muhtasib, by Ibn Jinni (2: 45), Tafsir Al-Zamakhshari (3: 41), Tafsir Ibn Atiyyah (4: 31), Tafsir Al-Qurtubi (11: 149), Tafsir Abi Hayyan (7: 296), Fath Al-Qadir, by Al-Shawkani (3: 413).

In connection: Khalaf, Ibn Kathir, and Ibn Muhaysin read (Qawariran, Qawarira), the first with Tanwin because it is the head of a verse, and the second without Tanwin because it is not the head of a verse. B. In pause: (Qawarira, Qawarira) with Alif in the first, and without it in the second.

4 - That (Kallan) is a description (Na't) for (Alihatan), which is Ibn Atiyyah's opinion (1). Al-Samin critiqued him then sought a direction for it saying: "In this there is a point of view, for the meaning is not according to that. An aspect might appear for it: That he described the deities with (Al-Kall) which is the verbal noun meaning fatigue and incapacity. As if it were said: 'Alihatan Kallayna', i.e., incapable, cut off. And when he described them with the verbal noun, he kept it singular." (2).
The first opinion is the closest to correctness, and the majority held it. As for Ibn Atiyyah's opinion, it is far-fetched. Al-Samin tried to bring it closer to the first opinion in his direction of it, but this direction does not strengthen it. Al-Samin mentioned that there is a point of view in it; since the meaning is not according to that, and this is correct. So Ibn Atiyyah's opinion remains weak; especially since Ibn Atiyyah was unique in it, and no other scholar said it.

Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "Ibn Kathir and Abu Amr read with Fatha, estimating the Ba (Bi-Anni / That I); because the call (Nida') is connected with it. You say: I called him by such (Nadaytuhu bi-kadha). The poet said - recited by Al-Farisi:
I called by the name of Rabi'ah bin Mukaddam ... Indeed, the one whose name is acclaimed is the one trusted.
Ibn Atiyyah allowed that it be in the meaning of (Li-ajli / Because of), and it is not apparent." (1)
Study of the Rectification:
Scholars have two opinions in directing the reading with Fatha on the Hamza (Anni):
1 - That it is on the estimation of the Ba (Bi-Anni); because the call is connected with it. You say: Nadaytuhu bi-kadha. The estimation is: He was called that (Bi-Anni) I am your Lord. This is the opinion of the majority (2).

Al-Baquli (1) said: "Whoever opened (used Fatha), it is due to the occurrence of the call upon it, on the estimation: He was called, O Moses, that (Bi-Anni) I am your Lord." (2)
2 - That it is on the meaning of (Li-ajli Anni / Because I) am your Lord, so remove your sandals. This is Ibn Atiyyah's opinion (3).
The first opinion is the preponderant one; for the majority, including Imams in Readings and Language, held it. As for what Ibn Atiyyah went to, that it is on the meaning of (Li-ajli Anni), it is far-fetched, and I did not find it with other scholars. Furthermore, what Ibn Atiyyah said afterwards "and Nudiya can be connected with a preposition..." does not align with the meaning he just mentioned, but rather applies to the opinion of the majority.

[28]: Ibn Atiyyah said upon speaking about His saying - the Exalted -: {It has been decreed for every devil that whoever turns to him - then indeed he will misguide him (Annahu man tawallahu fa-annahu yudilluhu) and guide him to the punishment of the Blaze} [Al-Hajj: 4]: "Abu Amr read (Innahu man tawallahu fa-innahu yudilluhu) (4) with Kasra in both." Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "Al-A'mash and Al-Ju'fi (1) narrated from Abu Amr (Innahu) (Fa-innahu) with Kasra on both Hamzas. Ibn Atiyyah said: 'Abu Amr read (Innahu) (Fa-innahu) with Kasra in both'. This implies that it is famous from him, and it is not so." (2)
Study of the Rectification:
The subject of this rectification is Abu Amr's reading in this verse, as Ibn Atiyyah said that Abu Amr read with Kasra on both Hamzas in His saying - the Exalted -: (Innahu man tawallahu fa-innahu yudilluhu). Al-Samin criticized him in this statement; because it creates the impression that this is the famous concurrently transmitted reading from Abu Amr, and the matter is not so. Rather, Abu Amr read in this verse with Fatha on both Hamzas, which is the reading of the majority. As for the reading with Kasra on both Hamzas, it was read by (3):

text: [29]: Ibn Atiyyah said in his talk about the readings appearing in His saying - the Exalted -: {Certainly will the believers have succeeded} [Al-Mu'minun: 1]: "Talha bin Musarrif (1) read (Qad Aflahu Al-Mu'minun) (2) with Damma on the Ha, meaning: They have succeeded (Qad Aflahu). And it is a rejected reading." (3)
foot_note:
1. Talha bin Musarrif bin Amr Al-Yami Al-Hamdani Al-Kufi, Abu Muhammad. The Imam, Hafiz, Reciter. A senior Follower. He has a choice in reading attributed to him. Talha bin Musarrif, Amr bin Ubayd, Asim Al-Jahdari, Ikrimah, and Ubayy bin Ka'b read (Ufliha) with Damma on the Hamza and Kasra on the Lam in the passive voice, meaning: They were entered into success. Talha also read (Aflahu) with Fatha on the Hamza and Lam and Damma on the Ha. It was said: The Damma sufficed for the Waw. It was narrated from Talha that he read: Uflihu, with a Waw and the Hamza at its beginning with Damma on the passive construction. The reading of the majority: Qad Aflaha Al-Mu'minun. text:
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "And Talha also read (Aflahu) with Fatha on the Hamza and Lam and Damma on the Ha. Its extraction is on the basis that the origin is (Aflahu Al-Mu'minun) by attaching the plural marker before the subject (Fa'il), like the dialect of 'Akaluni Al-Baraghith'. So what I presented regarding His saying: {Thumma 'Amu wa Sammu kathirun minhum} (1) [Al-Ma'idah: 71], {Wa asarru al-najwa al-ladhina zalamu} [Al-Anbiya': 3] (2) applies to it." Then he said: "Ibn Atiyyah said: 'And it is a rejected reading'. I say: I do not know how they reject it despite the existence of its like in the Quran by consensus, which are the two aforementioned verses?" (3)
Study of the Rectification:
Ibn Atiyyah rejected Talha bin Musarrif's reading: (Aflahu) with Fatha on the Hamza and Lam and Damma on the Ha, whose origin is: (Aflahu). Al-Samin critiqued him on that, and defended this reading by analogizing it to two concurrently transmitted readings, which are His saying - the Exalted -: {Then many of them became blind and deaf} [Al-Ma'idah: 71] (4), and His saying: {... And those who did wrong concealed their private conversation} [Al-Anbiya': 3].
foot_note:
1. See: Al-Durr Al-Masun (4: 371).
2. See: The previous source (8: 132).
3. The previous source (8: 314).
4. There are three aspects in the parsing of (Kathirun):
1. Raised as a substitute (Badal) for the pronoun - the Waw.
2. Raised as the subject (Fa'il), and the Waw is for plurality not the subject, this is according to the dialect of those who said: Akaluni Al-Baraghith (The fleas ate me).
3. Predicate of a deleted inceptive, i.e.: The blind and deaf are many of them. text: What appeared in the two verses and in Talha's reading is according to the dialect of 'Akaluni Al-Baraghith'; by the coming of a plural or dual marker in the verb before the subject (1). Ibn Malik said: "The Prophet, peace be upon him, spoke in this dialect; for he said: (Yata'aqabuna fikum mala'ikatun bil-layli, wa mala'ikatun bil-nahari - Angels succeed one another among you by night and angels by day) (2)." (3) Ibn Rajab (4) said: "His saying: (Yata'aqabuna fikum mala'ikatun) contains the pluralization of the verb along with attributing it to an explicit noun. It is extracted on the dialect known as the dialect of 'Akaluni Al-Baraghith'. Some late grammarians defined it by this Hadith, saying: It is the dialect of Yata'aqabuna fikum mala'ikatun." (5)

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
Ibn Hajar said: "Some grammarians burdened themselves to return this dialect to the famous dialect, which is not attaching the marker of plural or dual or feminine to the verb if it precedes the nouns. They extracted aspects and estimations for it, most of which are questionable. There is no need for that after its establishment by transmission, and its correctness in usage." (1)
So the preponderant view is that Talha's reading is correct from a linguistic perspective, and Al-Samin's rectification upon Ibn Atiyyah is valid. The occurrence of this dialect in the Quran and Sunnah - which are the most eloquent speech - is evidence of its correctness.
* * *

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
[30]: Ibn Atiyyah said upon speaking about the readings appearing in His saying - the Exalted -: {[And] so they do not prostrate to Allah, who brings forth what is hidden within the heavens and the earth and knows what you conceal and what you declare} [An-Naml: 25]: "The majority of reciters read (Yukhfuna) and (Yu'linuna) with the Ya of the absent (1). Judge Abu Muhammad said: This reading implies that the verse is from the speech of the Hoopoe. Al-Kisa'i and Asim in the narration of Hafs read: {Ma tukhfuna wa ma tu'linuna} with the Ta of address. This reading implies that the verse is from the speech of Allah Almighty to the nation of Muhammad, peace be upon him." (2)
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "His saying: {Ma tukhfuna} Al-Kisa'i and Hafs read with the Ta from above (dots) in both. The rest read with the Ya from below. The address is apparent on Al-Kisa'i's reading; because before it is the command to them to prostrate and addressing them with it. The absence (third person) on the reading of the rest other than Hafs is also apparent; due to the precedence of the absent pronouns in His saying: (Lahum), (A'malahum), (Saddahum), and (Fahum) (3).

As for Hafs's reading, its interpretation is that he shifted to addressing those present after completing the story of the people of Saba'. It is permissible that it be a shift (Iltifat) on the basis that he treated the absent as present and addressed him, shifting to him. Ibn Atiyyah said: 'The reading with the Ya of absence implies that the verse is from the speech of the Hoopoe, and with the Ta of address implies that it is from the speech of Allah to the nation of Muhammad, peace be upon him'. It has been preceded that the apparent view is that it is from the speech of the Hoopoe absolutely." (1)
Study of the Rectification:
First: Direction of the readings of Al-Kisa'i and Hafs and the difference between them:
Al-Kisa'i and Hafs read {Ma tukhfuna wa ma tu'linuna} with Ta in both. Al-Kisa'i read them with address based on his reading in which he commanded them to prostrate and addressed them with it (Ala ya-sjudu): with lightening (Ala) as alert, (Ya) as vocative particle, and (Isjudu) as imperative verb. The meaning: Lo, O these people, prostrate to Allah who knows what you conceal and what you declare (2).
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "The right of the script on this reading would be (Ya isjudu), but the Companions dropped the Alif of (Ya) and the Hamzat al-Wasl of (Isjudu) in script when they dropped in pronunciation, and connected

Second: Scholars' opinions in directing the reading with Ta (Ma tukhfuna wa ma tu'linuna) and the reading with Ya (Ma yukhfuna wa ma yu'linuna):

Ibn Al-Qayyim (1) said: "And in the Hoopoe mentioning this affair of the Lord's actions - the Exalted - specifically, there is an indication of what Allah specialized him with of bringing out water hidden under the earth" (2). It is understood from his saying "in the Hoopoe mentioning this affair of the Lord's actions - the Exalted -" that he sees that what is in the verse is from the speech of the Hoopoe.
The apparent view - and Allah knows best - is that what is in the verse is from the speech of the Hoopoe in both readings; by the indication of the context. For what is before it is from the speech of the Hoopoe: {I have encompassed [in knowledge] that which you have not encompassed, and I have come to you from Sheba with certain news (22) Indeed, I found [there] a woman ruling them, and she has been given of all things, and she has a great throne (23) I found her and her people prostrating to the sun instead of Allah, and Satan has made their deeds pleasing to them and averted them from [His] way, so they are not guided (24)} [An-Naml]. And what is after it is Solomon's response... peace be upon him to the Hoopoe: {He said, "We will see whether you were truthful or were of the liars."} [An-Naml: 27]. The subject of these verses is the dialogue that took place between the Hoopoe and Solomon peace be upon him; so it is more apparent that all the speech in the verse is on the tongue of the Hoopoe.

Hafs's reading is a transition from talking about the absent ones, namely: the woman and her people, and his denunciation of their lack of prostration to Allah, to addressing those present, both believer and disbeliever, that Allah knows their secret and publicity all together. For Allah's knowledge is not limited to those absent ones whom he denounced, but includes them and the addressees. As for Al-Kisa'i's reading, it is a continuation of the address after commanding the addressees to prostrate, and there is no evidence that this is not from the speech of the Hoopoe. Thus: Both readings, with Ya and Ta, imply that it is from the speech of the Hoopoe.

I say: Attributing transcription error to these [Imams] is not praiseworthy, just as Al-Hudhali's arrogance in choosing the anomalous [reading] is not praiseworthy." (1)
Study of the Rectification:
Al-Samin Al-Halabi's methodology in his stance towards anomalous readings appears clearly in this rectification, as he was objective and moderate in that. He neither attributes transcription error to those who read or narrated it, nor does he prefer it over a concurrently transmitted reading. Here he rectifies Ibn Atiyyah's saying that the reading with 'Ayn and Nun (Fasta'anahu) is a transcription error not a reading, and he also rectifies Ibn Jabarah's choice of this anomalous reading and his preference of it over the concurrent one. As for Abu Hayyan, he mentioned Ibn Atiyyah's statement and refuted it, denying that this reading is a transcription error; because Ibn Khalawayh transmitted it from Sibawayh, and because Ibn Jabarah transmitted it from Al-Za'farani and Ibn Miqsam. He quoted Ibn Jabarah's statement in which he chose the anomalous reading without criticism or comment (2).
The correct view is that the reading with 'Ayn and Nun (Fasta'anahu) is indeed an anomalous reading and not a transcription error as Ibn Atiyyah mistakenly thought, for the following reasons:
1 - Its narration from more than one reciter, namely: Al-Hasan Al-Basri, Sibawayh, Al-Za'farani, and Ibn Miqsam (3).

Study of the Rectification:
Ibn Abi Bazzah narrated from Ibn Kathir (Ta'tadunaha) with lightening the Dal. Ibn Atiyyah declared this narration an error (Ghalat), and Al-Samin did not agree with him in that. Among those who defended this narration and refuted Ibn Atiyyah: Abu Hayyan; where he said: "It is not a fancy/error (Wahm), since Ibn Khalawayh and Abu Al-Fadl Al-Razi (1) in the book (Al-Lawamih fi Shawadh Al-Qira'at) (2) transmitted it from Ibn Kathir. The mentioned Al-Razi transmitted it from the people of Mecca and said: 'It is from (Al-I'tidad) without doubt, but they disliked the doubling so they lightened it'." (3)
This narration was not attached by the people of Readings to the concurrent or authentic from Ibn Kathir, and some of them explicitly stated that it is a fancy/error (Wahm) (4). Some of them mentioned that Ibn Abi Bazzah had retracted this reading (5). Ibn Mujahid said: "Qunbul said to me: Ibn Abi Bazzah had fancied/erred in {Ta'taddunaha} so he used to lighten it. So Al-Qawwas (6) said to me: Go to Abu Al-Hasan and say to him 'What is this reading which you read? We do not know it.' So I went to him and he said: I retracted it." (7)

[Al-Munafiqun: 6]: "The majority of people read: {Astaghfarta} with disjunction (Qat') and the interrogative Alif (Hamza). Study of the Rectification:
Two readings were narrated from Abu Ja'far Al-Madani in his saying (Astaghfarta). The first: with an elongation (Maddah) on the Hamza (Astaghfarta), i.e.: with a Hamza then an Alif. This reading was weakened by Ibn Atiyyah, and Al-Samin agreed with him in that. The second: connecting the Alif without Hamza (Hamz) as a declarative statement (Istaghfarta). This was also weakened by Ibn Atiyyah; arguing that deleting the interrogative Hamza is not used except in poetry. Al-Samin opposed him in that; because deleting the interrogative Hamza before (Am) is permissible in prose and poetry.
The subject of this rectification is the ruling on deleting the interrogative Hamza if it occurs before (Am). Scholars have two opinions on this issue:
1 - The impermissibility of deleting the interrogative Hamza, with the presence of (Am) and without its presence, except in poetry; where it is permissible. This is the opinion of Sibawayh (1), Ibn Jinni (2), and Ibn Atiyyah (3). Ibn Jinni said: "As for (Istaghfarta) with connection (Wasl), it is at the other extreme of weakness. That is because he deleted the interrogative Hamza while intending it, and this is something specific to poetic license, not the Quran." (4)
2 - The permissibility of deleting the interrogative Hamza before (Am); due to the indication of (Am) towards it.

Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "His saying: {Min sharri ma khalaqa} relates to (A'udhu). The general public is on adding (Sharri) to (Ma). Amr bin Fa'id (4) read with Tanwin on it. It is a rejected reading based on a false doctrine'. End quote. It is not necessary that (Ma) be negative (Nafiyah), rather it is permissible that it be relative (Mawsulah) as a substitute (Badal) for (Sharr) on the basis of a deleted annexer (Mudaf), i.e.: Min sharrin sharri ma khalaqa (From an evil, the evil of what He created), generalizing first, then specifying second.

text:
Study of the Rectification:
The subject of this rectification is the direction of the reading with Tanwin (Min sharrin ma khalaqa), which is the reading attributed to some Mu'tazilah and others, and the parsing of (Ma) in this reading. Scholars have two main opinions in directing it:
1 - That (Ma) in this reading is negative (Nafiyah), and based on this the reading is rejected; since its meaning is that Allah did not create evil. Said by: Makki bin Abi Talib (1), Ibn Atiyyah (2), and Al-Shawkani (3). Makki said: "The famous Reciters and others from the people of anomaly agreed on adding (Sharr) to (Ma khalaqa), and that indicates His creation of evil. Amr bin Ubayd, the head of the Mu'tazilah, separated from the community of Muslims and read: (Min sharrin ma khalaqa) with Tanwin, to establish that there are creators with Allah creating evil, and this is heresy (Ilhad). The correct view is that Allah - Majestic is His mention - informed us that He created evil and commanded us to seek refuge in Him from it." (4)
2 - That (Ma) in this reading cannot be negative; because what follows negation cannot relate to what precedes it. This is the opinion of the majority (5). Then they differed regarding (Ma); some made it infinitival (Masdariyyah) (6), some made it relative (Mawsulah) (7), and some made it an extra particle (Za'idah) (8).

text:
Preamble on Linguistic Interpretation
First: Concept of Linguistic Interpretation:
The term 'Linguistic Interpretation' is used to mean: Explaining the meanings of the Quran through what appeared in the language of the Arabs (1). This is Linguistic Interpretation in the narrow sense.
It is also used to mean: Interpretation concerned with the Holy Quran in terms of its strange vocabulary and roots, its parsing, and the rhetoric of its style (2). This is Linguistic Interpretation in the broad sense, encompassing three main sections:
Section One: What relates to the singular Quranic word - noun, verb, and particle - (3), and that includes (4): interpretation of vocabulary (philology) (5), and discussion of word derivation and morphology, and the significations of particles of meaning.
foot_note:
1. See: Al-Tafsir Al-Lughawi, by Musa'id Al-Tayyar (p. 38).

text:
Section Two: What relates to extracting the structures of the Quran based on grammatical rules, which is the science of Quranic Parsing (I'rab Al-Quran) (1).
Section Three: What relates to explaining the rhetoric of the Quranic style, including: sciences of Quranic Rhetoric (2).
The intended meaning of Linguistic Interpretation in this research is: Linguistic Interpretation in its broad sense. Quranic parsing falls within the sciences of linguistic interpretation, but I have dedicated a separate section for rectifications in Quranic parsing; due to the abundance of rectifications in Quranic parsing, and because it is considered an independent science (3), having its own dedicated works, and even works specific to its problematic and strange aspects (4).
Second: Importance of Linguistic Interpretation:
Knowledge of the Arabic language is a condition for understanding the Quran; because whoever wants to interpret it while not knowing the language in which the Quran was revealed will fall into error and slippage (5). Al-Raghib Al-Isfahani said: "The first of the Quranic sciences one needs to engage with is: The verbal sciences, and among the verbal sciences: investigation of single words." (6)

Then he said: "And that is not beneficial in the science of the Quran only, but rather it is beneficial in every science of the Sharia. For the words of the Quran are the core and essence of Arab speech, and its center and valuables, and upon them the jurists and wise men rely in their rulings and wisdoms." (1)
Al-Zarkashi said: "And knowledge of this art (2) is necessary for the exegete, otherwise it is not permissible for him to undertake [interpreting] the Book of Allah - the Exalted -." (3)
He also said: "And know that it is not for other than the one knowledgeable in the realities of language and its designations to interpret anything from the speech of Allah. Learning a little of it is not sufficient in his right; for a word might be a homonym and he knows one of the two meanings while the intended is the other meaning." (4)
He said in his discussion on the strange words of the Quran: "And the one uncovering that needs to know the science of language: noun, verb, and particle. As for particles, due to their scarcity, grammarians spoke on their meanings, so that is taken from their books. As for nouns and verbs, that is taken from the books of language." (5)
As for Parsing (I'rab), it is part of the perfection of Arab speech, and parsing the Quran is part of the perfection of the Quran (6). Scholars have emphasized the importance of this science; because parsing clarifies the meaning, distinguishes meanings, so ambiguity clears up, benefits appear, and the address is understood (7).

Ibn Faris said: "Among the majestic sciences with which the Arabs were distinguished: Parsing (I'rab), which is the differentiator between meanings equivalent in wording. By it the predicate, which is the root of speech, is known. Were it not for it, a subject would not be distinguished from an object, nor an annexed from a described, nor an exclamation from an interrogation, nor a source from a verbal noun, nor a description from an emphasis." (1)
Abu Al-Baqa said in his talk about the Quran: "And the most upright path taken in standing upon its meaning, and by which one reaches clarifying its purposes and intent: is knowing its parsing, and deriving its intents from the modes of its address." (2)
Likewise, the science of Morphology (Tasrif) must be known; because difference in forms leads to difference in meanings (3). Ibn Jinni said: "This type of science - I mean Morphology - is needed by all people of Arabic with the utmost need, and their poverty regarding it is most severe; because it is the balance of Arabic. By it, the roots of Arab speech are known from the additions entering upon them, and etymology cannot be reached except by it. A large part of language may be taken by analogy, and that cannot be reached except through the path of Morphology." (4)

As for the science of Rhetoric, its benefit is revealing the eloquence of the Quranic style, and its miraculous arrangement (3). Al-Zamakhshari said: "It is the duty of the interpreter of Allah's dazzling Book and His miraculous speech to ensure in his approaches the preservation of the arrangement in its beauty, and rhetoric in its perfection, and keeping what the challenge occurred with safe from defect." (4)
Al-Zarkashi said: "And this science is the greatest pillar of the exegete; for it is necessary to observe what inimitability requires of literal and metaphorical meaning, and composition of arrangement, and to harmonize between the resources, and rely on what the speech was driven for so it does not conflict, and other than that." (5)

Section One
His Rectifications in Linguistic Interpretation
First: In Language:
[1]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {Indeed, those who disbelieve - it is all the same for them (sawa'un 'alayhim) whether you warn them or do not warn them - they will not believe} [Al-Baqarah: 6]: "Abu Ali (1) said: In the word there are four dialects: (Siwa) with Kasra on Sin, and (Sawa') with Fatha on it and Madd (lengthening). These are two known dialects. Some Arabs use Kasra on Sin and Madd, and some use Damma on its beginning and Qasr (shortening). These two dialects are less [common] than those." (2)
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said rectifying him: "Ibn Atiyyah transmitted from Al-Farisi regarding it the four famous dialects in (Sawa') the exceptive particle. This is strange, for these dialects are in the adverb, not in (Sawa') which means equality." (3)

text:
Study of the Rectification:
Al-Samin Al-Halabi saw that Ibn Atiyyah erred in his transmission of the dialects appearing in (Siwa) while discussing (Sawa') which means equality (1). The correct view is that Al-Farisi transmitted these dialects from Al-Akhfash (2); he transmitted from him that in (Siwa) and (Sawa') there are four dialects (3):
1 - With Fatha on its beginning and lengthening (Sawa').
2 - With Kasra on its beginning and shortening (Siwa).
3 - With Kasra on its beginning and lengthening (Siwa').
4 - With Damma on its beginning and shortening (Suwa).
Al-Farisi also transmitted from Al-Akhfash that (Sawa') is used as an adverb as in their saying: Inna siwa'ka Zaidan (Indeed, in your place is Zaid), and this is like their saying: Inna 'indaka Zaidan (Indeed, with you is Zaid) (4). Likewise in the likes of their saying: Atani al-qawmu sawa'aka (The people came to me in your place), as if they said: Atani al-qawmu makanaka (5).
It appears from the context of the examples transmitted by Al-Farisi that the dialects cover (Siwa) (6) and (Sawa') (7) the adverb, not (Sawa') which means equality.

Some linguists transmitted from Al-Akhfash (3) that (Siwa) if it is in the meaning of (Ghayr) or meaning the middle has three dialects: If you add Damma or Kasra to the Sin, you shorten in both, and if you open (Fatha), you lengthen; you say: Makanun Siwan, and Suwan, and Sawa'un, i.e.: A middle [place] between the two parties (4).

text:
Al-Samin Al-Halabi quoted Ibn Atiyyah's previous statement textually, then said: "This which he said is close to the interpretation of Al-Ghufran (Forgiveness), because Al-Ghafr is covering and veiling, and from it comes: Al-Mighfar (1). However, a distinction has been made between them that Al-'Afw may be after punishment so it combines with it, while Al-Ghufran is not with punishment." (2)
Study of the Rectification:
Scholars went to the view that Al-'Afw in the language is applied to erasure (Mahw) (3), leaving (Tark) (4), and facilitation (Tashil) (5). None of the scholars said that Al-'Afw applies to covering and veiling; rather they mention veiling in the meaning of Al-Ghufran. Ibn Atiyyah opposed them in that, as he mentioned covering in the meaning of Al-'Afw (6). More than one scholar distinguished between Al-'Afw and Al-Ghufran (7), among them: Abu Hilal Al-Askari (8) (9), and Al-Qurtubi (10).

text:
Abu Hilal Al-Askari said: "Al-Ghufran necessitates dropping the punishment, and dropping the punishment is necessitating the reward. So no one deserves Al-Ghufran except the believer deserving of reward. Therefore, it is not used except for Allah; so it is said: Ghafara Allahu laka (Allah forgave you), and it is not said: Ghafara Zaidun laka (Zaid forgave you), except rarely and anomalously." Then he said: "And Al-'Afw necessitates dropping blame and condemnation, and does not necessitate necessitating reward. Therefore, it is used for the servant, so it is said: 'Afa Zaidun 'an Amr (Zaid pardoned Amr), and if he pardons him, rewarding him is not incumbent upon him." (1)
Al-Qurtubi said: "Al-'Afw: Allah Almighty's pardon of His creation. It may be after punishment and before it, unlike Al-Ghufran; for there is no punishment with it at all." (2)
However, Ibn Atiyyah's statement has an aspect from the perspective of Shar'i terminology; because Al-'Afw and Al-Ghufran, when their meanings became close, overlapped and were used in the attributes of Allah - Glory be to Him and Exalted - in one sense. So it is said: 'Afa Allahu 'anhu, and Ghafara lahu; meaning one thing (3). As for the linguistic perspective: Covering is not among the meanings of Al-'Afw, rather it is among the meanings of Al-Ghufran (4).

Al-Samin Al-Halabi said after mentioning Al-Hudhali's verse: "Ibn Atiyyah declared him in error, and claimed consensus that Al-Salwa is a bird. Study of the Rectification:
First: Scholars' opinions on the intended meaning of Al-Salwa:
The exegetes of the Salaf from the Companions and Followers (4) agreed that Al-Salwa is a bird, and the majority of exegetes said likewise (5).

Second: Ibn Atiyyah's statement and Al-Samin's rectification upon him:
Ibn Atiyyah reported the consensus of exegetes that Al-Salwa is a bird. Al-Samin criticized him for that - and Al-Qurtubi before him (1) -; because linguists mentioned that Al-Salwa is honey. As for what Ibn Atiyyah said regarding the consensus of exegetes that Al-Salwa is a bird, it has justification from two aspects:
First: The realization of the consensus of the Salaf and early exegetes that Al-Salwa is a bird (2).
Second: That those who transmitted from the linguists the other opinion regarding the meaning of Al-Salwa - Honey -, mentioned it but did not prefer it (3).
As for language, there is no consensus; rather, linguists stated both meanings - Bird and Honey - (4). Some of them preferred that Al-Salwa in the verse is a bird, such that some said: Al-Salwa in the Quran is a bird, and outside the Quran is honey (5).

Study of the Rectification:
The subject of this rectification is the word (Qiss) and (Qissis): Is it Arabic or foreign and Arabized? Scholars have three opinions on this issue:
1 - That it is a foreign word; in the language of the Romans, meaning: The Scholar, then it was Arabized. This was said by: Qutrub (2), Ibn Atiyyah (3), and Al-Suyuti (4). Al-Hakim Al-Tirmidhi (5) said: "Al-Qissis is the one who follows the trace of the Messenger, and confirms him in what he brought. This is in the language of the Children of Israel, and in the language of the Arabs: The Truthful (Al-Siddiq)." (6)

Al-Qurtubi said: "The word Al-Qissis is either Arabic, or it is in the language of the Romans but the Arabs mixed it with their speech so it became from their language; since there is nothing in the Book that is not from the language of the Arabs." The preponderant view is that it exists in both languages, spoken by Arabs and Romans; and there is nothing in the Quran that is not from the language of the Arabs according to the preponderant view. What appeared in the Quran is sufficient evidence for that; for it has come in many places in the Quran affirming its Arabic nature, including His saying - the Exalted -: {... an Arabic Qur'an, without any deviance} [Az-Zumar: 28], and His saying: {In a clear Arabic language} [Ash-Shu'ara: 195].

text:
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "Al-Harur: The intense heat of the sun. Al-Zamakhshari said: 'Al-Harur: Al-Samum, except that Al-Samum is during the day, and Al-Harur is during it and during the night' (1). I say: This is the doctrine of Al-Farra and others. It was said: Al-Samum is during the day, and Al-Harur is during the night specifically. Ibn Atiyyah transmitted this from Ru'bah and said: 'It is not correct, rather the correct view is what Al-Farra said'. This is strange from him, how does he refute the people of the tongue (native speakers) with the saying of those who take from them?" (2)
Study of the Rectification:
Al-Samin Al-Halabi criticized Ibn Atiyyah for rejecting Ru'bah's saying regarding Al-Harur and Al-Samum, arguing that Ru'bah is one of the people of the tongue and Sheikhs of Arabic from whom language is taken; so how can he refute him with the saying of one who takes from them? This rectification is not in place; for Ibn Atiyyah has the right to prefer the opinion he sees as correct, especially since this issue is not agreed upon among linguists, early or late. Indeed, the majority hold the contrary of what Ru'bah said. The majority also distinguished between Al-Harur and Al-Samum from a temporal perspective, and some distinguished between them from the perspective of intensity; holding that Al-Harur is more intense than Al-Samum (3).

Scholars have three main opinions on this issue:
1 - That Al-Harur is at night, and Al-Samum during the day. Said by: Ibn Abbas (1) may Allah be pleased with him, Ru'bah (2), Ibn Qutaybah (3), and others (4).
2 - That Al-Harur in this place is what occurs during the day with the sun. Said by: Abu Ubaidah (5) Ma'mar bin Al-Muthanna (6), and preferred by: Al-Tabari (7). Al-Tabari said: "And the saying in that according to me is: That Al-Harur occurs by night and day, except that in this place it is more likely to be with the sun as Abu Ubaidah said; because the shade only exists in a day of sun, so that indicates that the intended meaning of Al-Harur is: that which is found in the state of the existence of shade." (8)

Study of the Rectification:
The subject of this rectification is the verb {Tawallaw}, is it present tense or past tense?
Scholars have two opinions on this issue:
The First: Which is the opinion of the majority: That {Tawallaw} is a present tense verb, and its origin is: Tatawallaw; the first Ta is the Ta of address, and the second is the Ta of the present tense, so one of the two Tas was deleted for lightening (2). And {Tawallaw} is the verb of the condition, jussive by deletion of the Nun, and the Waw of plurality is the subject (Fa'il) (3).

Ibn Hisham explained that this verb is among those that are confusing after the jussive and accusative particles; is it present or past? That is known through context clues. For example, what came in His saying: {But if they turn away (Tawallaw), then say, "Sufficient for me is Allah"} [At-Tawbah: 129] is past tense, and what came in His saying: {And if you turn away (Tawallaw), then indeed, I fear for you} [Hud: 3] is present tense (1).
Ibn Ashour said: "The origin of {Tawallaw} is: Tatawallaw; one of the two Tas was deleted for brevity. It is present tense, and it is the address of Hud - peace be upon him - to his people, which is apparent in running the pronouns on one pattern." (2)
So the apparent view is that {Tawallaw} is present tense, and the pronoun in it is for the people of Hud and the address is with them, and it is from the completion of the sentences said before that (3).

And (Al-A'jamun) is the plural of A'jam, which is that which does not speak eloquently even if of Arab lineage; he is called: A'jam. Likewise it is said for animals and inanimate objects." (1)
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "Al-A'jamin is the plural of A'jamiyy with lightening (Takhfif). Were it not for this estimation, it would not be permissible to pluralize it as a sound plural. The reason for preventing its pluralization (as A'jam): It is from the category of Af'al Fa'la' like Ahmar Hamra', and the Basrans do not permit its pluralization as a sound plural except in necessity." Then Al-Samin mentioned Ibn Atiyyah's statement - previously mentioned - and followed it with Al-Zamakhshari's statement, where he said: "And Al-Zamakhshari said: 'Al-A'jam: The one who does not speak eloquently, and in his tongue is foreignness (Ujmah) or impediments to speech (Isti'jam). And Al-A'jamiyy is like it, except that it has the addition of Nisba (attribution) for emphasis'." (2)
Then Al-Samin said: "Abu Al-Baqa explicitly stated the prevention of (Al-A'jamin) being the plural of A'jam, but rather it is the plural of A'jamiyy lightened from A'jamiyy like Al-Ash'arun; in Al-Ash'ari. He said: '(Al-A'jamin) i.e.: Al-A'jamiyyin; the Ya of Nisba was deleted, just as they said: Al-Ash'arun i.e.: Al-Ash'ariyyun. Its singular is: A'jamiyy. It is not permissible for it to be the plural of A'jam; because its feminine is 'Ajma', and the likes of this is not pluralized as a sound plural'. (3) I say: This has preceded. So in what Ibn Atiyyah said there is a point of view. As for Al-Zamakhshari, there is nothing in his speech indicating it is the plural of A'jam lightened or unlightened, although its apparent meaning is that it is the plural of A'jam without lightening.

However, in what Ibn Atiyyah said, he followed Al-Farra (1), for he said: (Al-A'jamin) is plural of A'jam or A'jamiyy (2); based on deleting the Ya of Nisba as they said: Al-Ash'arin, and their singular is: Ash'ari." (3)
Study of the Rectification:
Scholars discussed the word (Al-A'jamin) appearing in the verse from a linguistic and morphological perspective. This rectification revolves around the morphology of this word. Ibn Atiyyah went to the view that (Al-A'jamin) is the plural of A'jam. Al-Samin did not agree with him in that; he preferred that it is the plural of A'jamiyy. Scholars have three main opinions on this issue:
1 - That the word (Al-A'jamin) can be the plural of A'jam, and can be the plural of A'jamiyy. This is the opinion of Al-Farra - as attributed to him - (4). Ibn Ashour justified this by saying that (A'jam) here is a synonym of (A'jamiyy) with the Ya of Nisba; so it is valid in its plural form (A'jamin) to consider that there is no deletion in it considering it the plural of (A'jam), and it is valid to consider the deletion of the Ya of Nisba for lightening, and its origin is: Al-A'jamiyyin (5).
2 - That it is the plural of (A'jam), which is the one who does not speak eloquently.

Al-Anbari said: "Al-A'jamin: Plural of A'jamiyy, its origin: A'jamiyyin. They found the gathering of similar letters heavy, so they deleted the second Ya of the two Yas of Nisba, so the first Ya remained silent, and the plural letter (Ya of masculine plural) was silent, so two silent letters met, and two silent letters do not meet, so they deleted the first Ya; due to the meeting of two silent letters." (1)
The third opinion is the preponderant one; because (A'jam) is not pluralized with Waw and Nun, but rather pluralized on (Ujm) (2). Al-Muntajib said: "(Al-A'jamin) is the plural of A'jamiyy, attributed to the 'Ajam (non-Arabs/Persians). The origin is: Al-A'jamiyyin, then the Ya of Nisba was deleted from it as was done with Al-Ash'arin. Pluralizing it with Waw and Nun was made an indication of it (the Nisba) and a sign of intending it, not the plural of A'jam as Abu Ishaq and those who agreed with him claimed. Because A'jam is like Ahmar, and what is of the adjectives on the measure of (Af'al) and its feminine is (Fa'la') is not pluralized with Waw and Nun, nor its feminine with Alif and Ta. So no one said regarding Ahmar: Ahmarun, nor regarding Hamra': Hamrawat. Since no one said this, and they said: Al-A'jamun while its feminine is 'Ajma', it indicated that the intended is what I mentioned, and that the origin is: Al-A'jamiyyin,

But if they give up willingly to you anything of it, then take it in satisfaction and ease} [An-Nisa: 4]: "And (Min) implies genus here, and therefore it is permissible for her to gift the entire mahr (dowry). text:
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "And (Min) has two aspects. One of them: That it is for partition, and therefore it is not permissible for her to gift him all of the dowry, and Al-Layth (1) went to this. The second: That it is for explanation (Bayan), and therefore it is permissible for her to gift him all of the dowry. Ibn Atiyyah said: 'And (Min) is for explaining the genus here, and therefore it is permissible for her to gift the entire mahr. If it stood for partition, that would not be permissible' End quote. It has preceded that Al-Layth forbids that, so its being for partition is not problematic." (2)
Study of the Rectification:
The subject of the rectification is the meaning of (Min) in His saying - the Exalted -: {Fa in tibna lakum 'an shay'in minhu nafsan fakuluhu hani'an mari'an}. The opinion on (Min) is linked to a jurisprudential issue, which is: Is it permissible for a woman to gift the entire dowry to her husband? Scholars have two opinions on the ruling of that and on the meaning of (Min) here:
1 - That (Min) is for explaining the genus, i.e.: If they willingly give up a thing of this genus which is mahr or sadaq. So it is permissible for the woman to gift the entire dowry to the husband.
foot_note:
1. Al-Layth bin Sa'd bin Abdul Rahman Al-Fahmi, Abu Al-Harith. The Imam, Hafiz, Scholar of the Egyptian lands. One of the senior jurists. He was known for his piety, generosity, and magnanimity. Al-Shafi'i said: "Al-Layth is more knowledgeable in jurisprudence than Malik, except that his companions did not undertake his work (spread his school)." He died in the year 175 AH. Al-Zajjaj said: "If a questioner asks: It was only said: {But if they give up willingly to you anything of it (Minhu) nufsan}, so how is it permissible for the man to accept the entire mahr, while it was said to him {Minhu} (of it/from it)? The answer to that: That {Minhu} here is for genus, as He said - Majestic and Exalted -: {So avoid the uncleanliness of (Min) idols} [Al-Hajj: 30]; we were not commanded to avoid some idols, but the meaning is avoid the uncleanliness which is idols (idol-ness), i.e., so eat the thing which is a mahr." (8) Al-Sam'ani said: "And (Min) is for choice here, not for partition; so that it is permissible for the woman to gift all the dowry." (9)

2 - That (Min) is partitive (Tab'idiyyah), i.e.: from some of the dowry, because it is not permissible for her to gift the husband except a little of the dowry. This is the opinion of Al-Layth bin Sa'd in this issue. Said by: Abu Hayyan (1), and Al-Samin Al-Halabi (2). Abu Hayyan said: "And the apparent meaning of (Min) is partition, and in it is an indication that what she gifts is part of the dowry, and for that reason Al-Layth bin Sa'd held that it is not permissible for her to donate to him except a little." (3)
The preponderant view: That (Min) is for explaining the genus and not for partition. What Al-Layth bin Sa'd held, that she is not permitted to donate except a little, has no evidence. Rather, the apparent view is the permissibility of her donating the entire dowry, or most of it, or a little of it. All of that is permissible provided she gifts it willingly. If she gifts the husband the entire dowry willingly, it is permissible for him to take it. This is the opinion of the majority of jurists (4).

Each has his evidence. As for the permissibility of gifting the entire dowry, it is indicated by what Ibn Abbas narrated that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was asked about this verse and said: (If the woman gives generously to her husband with the gift without being coerced, no authority judges against him regarding it, and Allah will not hold him accountable for it in the Hereafter) (1). He said: (with the gift) and did not specify that to a little of it.
As for the permissibility of gifting part of the dowry, it is attested to by what Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "If one of you complains of something, let him ask his wife for three Dirhams or thereabouts, and let him buy honey with it, and let him take from rain water, so it combines [being] satisfying, easy to digest, and a blessed cure." (2) Meaning that Allah - Glory be to Him and Exalted - named what the woman gifts to her husband satisfying (Hani'an) and easy to digest (Mari'an), and named honey a cure (3), and named rain water blessed (4).
Therefore: Ibn Atiyyah's statement that (Min) implies the genus is the preponderant view, and Al-Samin's rectification upon him and his argumentation with Al-Layth bin Sa'd's opinion is not in place.

[2]: Ibn Atiyyah said upon his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {They said, "O Hud, you have not brought us clear evidence, and we are not ones to leave our gods on your say-so ('an qawlika), nor are we believers in you."} [Hud: 53]: "And His saying: {'An qawlika} meaning: Your saying will not be the cause of our leaving, since it is devoid of a sign." (1)
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "His saying: {'An qawlika} is a circumstantial accusative (Hal) from the pronoun in (Tariki), i.e.: And we do not leave our gods proceeding from (Sadireen 'an) your saying. It is permissible that ('An) be for causation (Ta'lil), like His saying - the Exalted -: {Except for a promise he had made to him} [At-Tawbah: 114], i.e.: Except because of a promise. The meaning here is: leaving our gods because of your saying, so it relates to (Tariki). Ibn Atiyyah pointed to causation, but the chosen view is the first, and Al-Zamakhshari did not mention other than it." (2)
Study of the Rectification:
Ibn Atiyyah held that the meaning of His saying: (... Wa ma nahnu bi-tariki alihatina 'an qawlika) is: Your saying will not be the cause of our leaving our gods (3). A large number of exegetes and parsers agreed with him in this meaning - causality - (4), among them: Al-Tabari (5), Makki bin Abi Talib (6), and Al-Sam'ani (7).

[3]: Ibn Atiyyah said in his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {And there is no city but that We will destroy it before the Day of Resurrection or punish it with a severe punishment. That has ever been in the Register inscribed} [Al-Isra: 58]: "Allah - the Exalted - informed in this verse that there is no city among the cities but that it is perishing before the Day of Resurrection by death and annihilation, this along with safety and taking it part by part, or it is punished and taken all at once. This is a generalization for every city. And (Min) is for explaining the genus. It was said: The intended is specification: And there is no unjust city." (1)
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "His saying - the Exalted -: {Wa in min qaryatin}: (In) is negative, and (Min) is extra in the inceptive (Mubtada) for encompassing the genus. Ibn Atiyyah said: 'It is for explaining the genus'. There is a point of view (criticism) in this from two aspects. First: The Sheikh said: 'Because that which is for explanation must be preceded by something ambiguous which it explains, like His saying: {Whatever Allah grants to people of mercy} [Fatir: 2], and here nothing ambiguous preceded'. Then he said: 'Perhaps his saying: "for explaining the genus" is from the copyist, and he might have said: for encompassing the genus (Istighraq al-Jins), do you not see that he said after that: "And it was said: The intended is specification".' (2) The predicate of the inceptive is the confined sentence from His saying: {Illa nahnu muhlikuha}.

Second: That the condition for that is that it be preceded by [a noun] adorned with the Generic Al (Alif Lam), and that it (Min) takes the place of (Alladhi) like His saying: {So avoid the uncleanliness of (Min) idols} [Al-Hajj: 30]." (1)
Study of the Rectification:
The exegetes went to the view that the meaning of His saying: {Wa in min qaryatin} is: And there is no city - any city or an unjust city - but that it will perish by punishment or death (2). So (Min) here came in negation. Some of them spoke about (Min) specifically; explicitly stating that it is extra for encompassing (Istighraq) (3). Abu Hayyan said: "(In) is negative, and (Min) is extra in the inceptive indicating the encompassing of the genus." (4) Al-Shawkani said: "(In) is negative, and (Min) is for encompassing, i.e.: There is no city." (5)

While Ibn Atiyyah went to the view that it is for explaining the genus, even though the context of his speech implies that it is for encompassing and generalization, as he said: "There is no city among the cities but that it is perishing." (1) Abu Hayyan said: "Perhaps his saying: 'for explaining the genus' is from the copyist, and he might have said: for encompassing the genus, do you not see that he said after that: 'And it was said: The intended is specification'." (2)
The correct view is that (Min) here is the emphatic one (3), which grammarians call: (Extra/Za'idah) (4). It often comes in negation; purifying it for the genus, emphasizing the meaning of generalization in it, i.e.: for encompassing (5). It is not correct for it to be for explaining the genus, for the following reasons:
1 - That the one for explanation must be preceded by something ambiguous which it explains, and here nothing ambiguous preceded (6).
2 - That the condition for the explanatory (Min) is that it be preceded by [a noun] adorned with the Generic Al, and that it takes the place of (Alladhi) like His saying: {So avoid the uncleanliness of (Min) idols} [Al-Hajj: 30] (7); because the meaning is: So avoid the uncleanliness which is an idol (8).

[4]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {And similarly We awakened them that they might question one another. A speaker from among them said, "How long have you remained?" They said, "We have remained a day or part of a day." They said, "Your Lord is most knowing of how long you remained."} [Al-Kahf: 19]: "And the Lam in His saying: {Li-yatas'alu} is the Lam of becoming (Sayrurah); because their awakening was not for the sake of their questioning." (1)
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said regarding this Lam: "It was said: It is for becoming (Sayrurah), because the awakening was not for the questioning, said by Ibn Atiyyah. The correct view is that it is on its standard usage of causation (Sababiyyah)." (2)
Study of the Rectification:
Scholars discussed the Lam in His saying: {Li-yatas'alu} and differed on its type into two opinions:
First: That it is the Lam of becoming (Sayrurah) and consequence ('Aqibah). Said by: Al-Baghawi (3), Ibn Atiyyah (4), Al-Qurtubi (5), and others (6).

Al-Baghawi said: "The Lam in it is the Lam of consequence; because they were not awakened to question." (1)
Second: That it is the Lam of causation (Ta'lil/Sababiyyah). Said by: Al-Fakhr Al-Razi (2), Al-Samin Al-Halabi (3), and others (4). Al-Fakhr Al-Razi said: "If it is said: Is it permissible that the purpose of their awakening be that they question one another and dispute? We say: That is not far-fetched; because if they question one another, amazing matters and strange conditions of Allah's power - Exalted be He - are revealed to them, and that revelation is a matter sought for itself." (5)
It is understood from the words of Makki bin Abi Talib (6), and also Al-Muntajib Al-Hamadhani (7), that it is for causation. Makki said: "So that some of them ask others, and We make known to them the greatness of Our power; so they increase in insight into their affair, and in their faith; since they remained a great period of time, while they did not change in their appearance, nor did their clothes change." (8)

The Lam of becoming, consequence, and outcome resembles the Lam of causation (1). Therefore, according to most Basrans, it is a category of the Lam of causation or Lam of 'Kay' (2), while the Kufans made it a category independent of the Lam of causation (3). Even Al-Zamakhshari - who is Basran - made the Lam in His saying - the Exalted -: {And the family of Pharaoh picked him up [out of the river] so that he would become to them an enemy and a [cause of] grief} [Al-Qasas: 8] for causation, and made this causation by way of metaphor not literal reality. He said: "The Lam in {Li-yakuna} is the Lam of 'Kay' whose meaning is causation, like your saying: 'I came to you to honor me' (Li-tukrimani) exactly. But the meaning of causation in it appears by way of metaphor not literal reality; because their motive for picking him up was not that he be an enemy and a grief for them, but rather: love and adoption. However, since that was the result of their picking him up and its fruit, it was likened to the motive for which the doer does the action." (4)
Linguists distinguished between the Lam of causation and the Lam of consequence saying that in the Lam of causation, the action following it is intended by the doer of the action preceding it, as in His saying - the Exalted -: {And We made you peoples and tribes that you may know one another} [Al-Hujurat: 13] (5).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
As for the Lam of consequence, the action following it is not intended by the doer of the action preceding it (1), as in His saying: {And the family of Pharaoh picked him up so that he would become to them an enemy and a [cause of] grief} [Al-Qasas: 8]; they did not pick him up for that, but rather they picked him up to be a joy and delight for them, but he became an enemy and a grief for them (2).
The preponderant view - and Allah knows best - is that the Lam in His saying {Li-yatas'alu} is the Lam of causation (Sababiyyah); for the context of the verses is in clarifying the power of Allah - Glory be to Him and Exalted. Awakening them was necessary for Allah's power to become manifest to them. This questioning is what reveals Allah's power to them, and questioning cannot happen during their sleep, so they were awakened so that this questioning would occur between them, resulting in their knowledge of what happened to them, their certainty of the greatness of Allah's power, and the increase of their faith. This came according to the will of Allah - the Exalted - for He willed the occurrence of questioning between them just as He willed their awakening. Therefore: Al-Samin Al-Halabi's rectification upon Ibn Atiyyah is valid.
* * *
[5]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {Rather, it will come to them unexpectedly and bewilder them, and they will not be able to repel it, nor will they be reprieved} [Al-Anbiya': 40]: "His saying: {Bal ta'tihim} is an estimated rectification (Istidrak) preceded by a negation. Its estimation is: The signs do not come according to their suggestion but rather they come to them unexpectedly." (1)

Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "His saying: {Bal ta'tihim} is a transitional strike (Idrab Intiqal). Ibn Atiyyah said: '(Bal) is an estimated rectification preceded by a negation, its estimation is: The signs do not come according to their suggestion'. In this there is a point of view (criticism); because the estimation becomes: The signs do not come to them according to their suggestion, but rather they come to them unexpectedly. So the apparent meaning would be that the signs come unexpectedly, and that is definitely not intended." (2)

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text: Ibn Atiyyah held that His saying: {Bal ta'tihim} is an estimated rectification preceded by a negation, and the estimation is: The signs (1) do not come according to their suggestion but rather they come to them unexpectedly. Al-Samin did not agree with him in what he went to; because based on his saying, the estimation becomes: The signs do not come to them according to their suggestion, but rather they come to them unexpectedly, so the meaning would be: that the signs come to them unexpectedly, and this is definitely not the intended meaning, nor does it agree with what the exegetes stated regarding the meaning of the verse. What Ibn Atiyyah said contradicts the opinion of the majority; who held that (Bal) in the verse is a transitional strike (2), not an estimated rectification preceded by negation. So (Bal) in the verse is for emphatic transitional strike, and its benefit is: Transitioning from one sentence to another sentence more important than the first (3). What follows (Bal) here explains the previous verse: {If those who disbelieved but knew the time when they will not avert the Fire from their faces or from their backs and they will not be aided} [Al-Anbiya': 39] and adds to it. Al-Fayruzabadi said: "Based on this, His saying: {If those who disbelieved but knew the time when they will not avert the Fire from their faces} up to His saying: {Bal ta'tihim baghtatan} means: If they knew what they know, which is in addition to the first, and greater than it, which is that it comes to them unexpectedly." (4)

Ibn Ashour said: "And (Bal) is for transitional strike from maximizing the horror prepared for them to threatening that it will descend upon them unexpectedly and suddenly, which is more severe on the souls; due to lack of preparation for it." (1)
Al-Samin was correct in his rectification upon Ibn Atiyyah; since the estimation mentioned by Ibn Atiyyah leads to an incorrect meaning; for it is not the signs that come unexpectedly. Although the words of the exegetes differed in interpreting the pronoun {Ta'tihim}, that is a difference of variety, and all they said leads to one meaning, and it is not among their opinions that the signs are what comes unexpectedly. Some said: The Hour is what comes to them unexpectedly (2), which is evidenced by their question: {And they say, "When is this promise, if you should be truthful?"} [Al-Anbiya': 38]. Some interpreted it as the punishment (3). Others said: It is the Fire (4). And it was said: It is the promise or the time or the threat (5).

Al-Muntajib Al-Hamadhani said: "The intended refers to (Al-Nar / The Fire), or to the Promise; because it is in the meaning of the Fire, which they were promised, or on the interpretation of the threat and appointed time, or to the time; because it is in the meaning of the Hour, or to the Hour even if it was not mentioned; due to it being known." (1)
All those meanings they mentioned do not agree with Ibn Atiyyah's estimation. Indeed, this estimation contradicts what Ibn Atiyyah himself said afterwards; where he said: "And the pronoun is for the Hour which brings them to the punishment, and it is possible that it is for the Fire" (2). Where is this from the estimation: Indeed the signs do not come according to their suggestion, but rather they come to them unexpectedly?

Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "His saying: {Min asawira min dhahab} in the first (Min) there are three aspects. One of them: That it is extra, as preceded in its establishment from Al-Razi (2) and Abu Al-Baqa (3), even if it is not from the principles of the Basrans. The second: That it is for partition, i.e.: some bracelets. The third: That it is for explaining the genus, said by Ibn Atiyyah, and he started with it. In it there is a point of view; since nothing ambiguous preceded." (1)
Study of the Rectification:
Disagreement among scholars abounds regarding particles of meaning, and possibilities multiply in their meanings, especially in such a place as His saying - the Exalted -: {Yuhallawna fiha min asawira min dhahab}. Scholars' opinions multiplied regarding the first (Min), such that most of them mentioned more than one opinion regarding it without preferring one over another (2). Ibn Atiyyah mentioned that it is for explaining the genus - which is the opinion he started with -, then said: "And it is possible that it is for partition." (3) While Al-Samin ruled out that it is for explaining the genus; because nothing ambiguous preceded it (4).
Scholars have four opinions regarding the first (Min):
The First: That it is for emphasis (extra) (5), and the meaning: They are adorned with bracelets.

Said by: Abu Al-Baqa (1), Al-Qurtubi (2), and others (3). Ibn Ashour said: "And (Min) in His saying: {Min Asawira} is extra for emphasis. Its justification is that since adorning men with bracelets was not customary, the news about them being adorned with bracelets was exposed to hesitation regarding intending the literal meaning; so the emphasizer was brought; to convey the literal meaning." (4)
The permissibility of the extra (Min) absolutely is the doctrine of Abu Al-Hasan Al-Akhfash, and those who agreed with him from the Kufans and Basrans. They held the permissibility of its addition in negation and affirmation; due to the establishment of hearing (Sama') of that (5). They directed His saying upon it: {And there has already come to you from (Min) the news of the messengers} [Al-An'am: 34]. Among their evidences also: His saying - the Exalted -: {He will forgive you your sins} [Al-Saff: 12], and in another place He said: {He will forgive you of (Min) your sins} [Al-Ahqaf: 31], and among them His saying: {And He will remove from you your misdeeds} [Al-Anfal: 29], and He said in another place: {And He will remove from you of (Min) your misdeeds} [Al-Baqarah: 271].

Discussion of Opinions:
As for the opinion that it is emphatic (extra), it is strengthened by His saying - the Exalted -: {Wa hullu asawira} [Al-Insan: 21] (3). As for the opinion that it is for explaining the genus, it is a plausible opinion, and the ambiguous antecedent is jewelry (Al-Huli) (4), so this (Min) would be for explaining the genus of jewelry. As for the opinion that it is partitive, it is also a plausible opinion, except that His saying in another place: {Wa hullu asawira} [Al-Insan: 21] does not strengthen that its meaning here is: from some bracelets.

(1)
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "His saying: {Min khashyati rabbihim} has two aspects. One of them: That it is for explaining the genus. Ibn Atiyyah said: 'It is for explaining the genus of apprehension' End quote. I say: And it is an awkward expression. The second: That it relates to {Mushfiqun}, said by (2) Al-Hawfi (3), and it is clear." (4)
Study of the Rectification:
In (Min) of His saying: {Min khashyati rabbihim} there are two aspects:
The First: That it is causative (Ta'liliyyah) related to the predicate: {Mushfiqun}. This is the opinion of the majority (5).

The correct view is that it is causative related to the predicate: {Mushfiqun}. This aspect is more fitting to the meaning of the verse, because its meaning is: That they, because of their being characterized by fear of Allah, are apprehensive of His punishment (2).

And (Man) can be conditional, which is the apparent view, and the Fa in {Fa-ula'ika} is the answer to the condition. It can also be relative (Mawsulah), and the Fa entered due to what you know of the resemblance of the relative pronoun to the condition." (1)
Study of the Rectification:
Scholars have two main opinions regarding the Lam of {Wa-lamani intasara} ...:
The First: That it is the Lam with which the oath is received, and based on this, there is a deleted oath in the verse. Said by: Ibn Atiyyah (2), Abu Zaid (3) Al-Tha'alibi (4), and others (5). Al-Samin weakened it because he preferred that (Man) be conditional, so the antecedent ... - the oath - should have been answered, but here only the condition {Fa-ula'ika ma 'alayhim min sabil}: the answer to the condition, was answered (6).
The Second: That it is the Lam of initiation (Ibtida'), and its benefit is emphasizing the content of the sentence. Said by: Abu Hayyan (7), Al-Samin (8), and others (9), and preferred by Al-Shawkani (10).

Abu Hayyan said: "And the Lam in {Wa-lamani intasara} ... is Lam of emphasis." (1)
Both opinions share two aspects:
1 - Emphasis; for the meaning of Lam of initiation is emphasizing speech, and likewise the Lam of oath (2). Al-Zajjaji (3) clarified that the wording is the same in both but the intent is inferred by meaning. He said: "If the future tense occurs after it accompanied by the heavy or light Nun, it is the Lam of oath, whether the oath was mentioned before it or not." Then he said: "Likewise, everything of this type that has an indication is carried on the oath. Whatever has no indication in it, the Lam in it is the Lam of initiation. The meaning between them is close; due to their meeting in emphasis and verification." (4)
2 - That the Lam of initiation is among the non-governing particles of meaning, and likewise the Lam of oath is non-governing (5).
The preponderant view - and Allah knows best - is that it is the Lam of initiation for emphasis; because the apparent structure of the verse does not indicate an oath, and the exegetes did not indicate that there is an estimated oath in the verse. Therefore: Al-Samin Al-Halabi's rectification upon Ibn Atiyyah is valid.
