Fourth: In General Linguistic Issues:
[1]: Ibn Atiyyah said upon speaking about His saying - the Exalted -: {And of the people are some who say, "We believe in Allah and the Last Day," but they are not believers} [Al-Baqarah: 8]: "And His saying - the Exalted -: {Man yaqulu amanna billahi} returned from the singular wording to the plural wording according to the wording of (Man) and its meaning. This is good; because the singular is before the plural in rank. It is not permissible for a speaker to return from a plural wording to a singular. If you said: 'Wa min al-nasi man yaquluna wa yatakallamu', it would not be permissible." (1)
Al-Samin said speaking about this issue and rectifying Ibn Atiyyah: "Know that (Man) and its sisters have a wording and a meaning. Its wording is singular masculine. If other than that is intended by it, you may observe its wording once, and its meaning another time. So you say: 'Ja'a man qama wa qa'adu' (Came he who stood and they sat). The noble verse is likewise; the wording was observed first so it was said: {Man yaqulu}, and the meaning second in {Amanna}. Ibn Atiyyah said: 'That is good because the singular is before the plural in rank. It is not permissible for a speaker to return from a plural wording to a singular. If you said: "Wa min al-nasi man yaqumuna wa yatakallamu" it would not be permissible'. End quote. There is a point of view (criticism) in Judge Ibn Atiyyah's statement, because he prevented observing the wording after observing the meaning, and that is permissible, except that observing the wording first is more appropriate. Among what refutes him is the poet's saying:
I am not of those who shy away (yaku'u) (2) or submit (yastakinuna) (3) ... If the horses of the enemies confront him (kafahathu) (4) (5)
And He said - the Exalted -: {And whoever believes in Allah and does righteousness} [Al-Talaq: 11] until He said: {Khalidina} (abiding eternally) so He observed the meaning, then He said: {Qad ahsana Allahu lahu rizqan} (Allah has made good provision for him) [Al-Talaq: 11] so He observed the wording after observing the meaning. Likewise, he observed the meaning in his saying: (Aw yastakinuna) then observed the wording in (Idha kafahathu).

text:
This carrying applies to it in all its states, I mean being relative, conditional, and interrogative." (1)
Analysis and Study of the Rectification:
(Man) in His saying: {Wa min al-nasi man yaqulu amanna} its wording is singular masculine, and the intended meaning in the verse is plural. So the wording was observed first {Yaqulu}: in singular, then the meaning was observed {Amanna}: in plural. Ibn Atiyyah stated the occurrence of this in the verse, but he did not permit returning from the plural wording to singular, meaning he prevented observing the wording after observing the meaning. Al-Samin rectified him; stating the permissibility of observing the wording after observing the meaning, even if observing the wording first is more appropriate. He cited its occurrence in His saying: ... {And whoever believes in Allah and does righteousness} [Al-Talaq: 11] until He said: ... {Khalidina} so He observed the meaning, then He said: {Qad ahsana Allahu lahu rizqan} [Al-Talaq: 11] so He observed the wording after observing the meaning. He also cited the poet's saying:
I am not of those who shy away (yaku'u) or submit (yastakinuna) ... If the horses of the enemies confront him (kafahathu)
He observed the meaning in his saying: (Aw yastakinuna) then observed the wording in (Idha kafahathu). Among those who agreed with him in stating permissibility: Al-Baquli (2), Abdul Rahman Al-Anbari (3), Abu Hayyan (4), and Al-Suyuti (5).

Among those who disagreed with him: Al-Muntajib Al-Hamadhani (1), and Ibn Ajiba (2). Ibn Ajiba said: "But if he observes the meaning first, he does not return to observing the wording; because observing the meaning is stronger." (3)
There is detail in this issue: If observing the wording and meaning combine in pronouns, one starts with the wording then the meaning. This is predominant in the Quran and Arab speech. He said - the Exalted -: {Wa min al-nasi man yaqulu} then He said: {Wa ma hum bi-mu'minin}. He singularized first considering the wording, then pluralized considering the meaning. Likewise in His saying: {And among them are those who listen to you... and We have placed over their hearts coverings} [Al-An'am: 25], and His saying: {And among them is he who says, "Permit me [to remain at home] and do not put me to trial." Unquestionably, into trial they have fallen} [At-Tawbah: 49] (4).

Ibn Jinni said: "Know that when the Arabs carry on the meaning, they hardly ever revert to the wording, like your saying: Shakartu man ahsanu ilayya 'ala fi'lihi (I thanked those who did good to me for his deed)." (1)
It is permissible to start with the meaning, like the speaker saying: Man qamat wa qa'ada (Who stood [fem.] and sat [masc.]), but that is rare. It was said to be forbidden. Some stipulated for its permissibility the occurrence of a separation between the two sentences, like: Man yaqumuna fi ghayri shay'in wa yanzuru fi amrina qawmuka (Who stand [pl.] for no reason and your people looks [sing.] into our matter) (2). Those who said it is forbidden justified it by saying it creates confusion after clarification, unlike considering the wording then the meaning for it acts as an explanation (3). Al-Radi (4) said: "As for prioritizing the observance of meaning over the observance of wording from the beginning of the matter, Abu Sa'id (5) transmitted from some Kufans its prohibition. The more appropriate view: Permissibility with weakness." (6)

So give him tidings of a painful punishment (7)} [Luqman] (4); the wording of (Man) was observed first in three pronouns in: {Yashtari}, {Li-yudilla}, and {Wa yattakhidhaha},

1. See: Al-Itqan fi Ulum Al-Quran, by Al-Suyuti (2: 342).
2. It was said: The intended by what is in the bellies of cattle: their milk, and it was said: their fetuses. Linguists differed on the reason for making (Khalisatun) feminine; some said: It was feminized for hyperbole like saying: (Nassabah / Genealogist) and (Allamah / Very learned). Others said: It was feminized for the femininity of the cattle, because what is in their bellies is like them, so it was feminized for their femininity. It was said: Khalisatun was feminized carrying on the meaning of Ma; because the intended meaning of what is in the bellies of these cattle is: fetuses. See: Ma'ani Al-Quran, by Al-Farra (1: 358), Tafsir Abd Al-Razzaq (2: 67), Tafsir Al-Tabari (12: 148), Al-Bayan fi I'rab Gharib Al-Quran, by Al-Anbari (1: 290), Tafsir Ibn Kathir (3: 346).
3. Makki bin Abi Talib said in Al-Hidayah ila Bulugh Al-Nihayah (3: 2204): "In this verse carrying on the meaning was prioritized so He said: (Khalisatun), then He carried after that on the wording so He said: (Wa Muharramun)." He compared it to His saying - the Exalted -: {All that - its evil (Sayyi'uhu) was ever, to your Lord, detested} [Al-Isra: 38] on the reading of Ibn Kathir, Nafi', Abu Amr, and Yaqub: (Sayyi'atan) feminine with Tanwin; he said: "He said first (Sayyi'atan) so He feminized and carried on the meaning of (Kull), because it is a noun for all that preceded of forbidden sins, then He said after that (Makruhan), so He masculinized on the wording of (Kull)." He also compared it to His saying: {And [He] has created for you of ships and animals those which you ride (Ma tarkabun) * That you may settle yourselves upon their backs (Zuhurihi)} [Az-Zukhruf: 12, 13]; he said: "So He pluralized the backs carrying on the meaning of (Ma), and singularized the Ha carrying on the wording of (Ma)." Ibn Ashour considered this style a type of artful variation (Tafannun), see: Al-Tahrir wa Al-Tanwir (1: 117).
4. See: Hashiyat Al-Sabban 'ala Sharh Al-Ashmuni li Alfiyyat Ibn Malik (1: 221).

text:
and its meaning was observed in two places, namely: {Ula'ika} and {Lahum}, then it returned to the wording in the pronouns of the following verse, first of them: {Tutla 'alayhi} and last of them {Fa bashshirhu} (1).
Ibn Khalawayh said: "There is nothing in the speech of Arabs nor in anything of Arabic where reference returns from its meaning to its wording except in one letter (word) which Ibn Mujahid extracted from the Quran, which is His saying - the Exalted -: {Wa man yu'min billahi} so He singularized 'yu'min' and made it masculine according to the wording of (Man), likewise {yudkhilhu jannatin}, then He said: {khalidina fiha abadan} so He pluralized 'khalidina' according to the meaning of (Man) then He said: {Qad ahsana Allahu lahu rizqan} [Al-Talaq: 11] so He returned after the plural to singular." (2)
The preponderant view: The permissibility of observing the wording at times, and observing the meaning at other times absolutely, contrary to those who held that observing the wording after observing the meaning is invalid. In the verse of Surah Al-Talaq is a refutation of those who held that observing the meaning cannot be followed by observing the wording (3); for in that verse He observed the wording of (Man) first; so He singularized the pronoun in His saying: {Yu'min}, and His saying: {Wa ya'mal}, and His saying: {Yudkhilhu}, and observed the meaning in His saying: {Khalidina}... so He used the plural form in it, then He observed the wording after that in His saying: {Qad ahsana Allahu lahu rizqan} [Al-Talaq: 11] so He singularized (4).
foot_note:
1. See: I'rab Al-Quran Al-Karim wa Bayanuhu, by Muhyi al-Din Darwish (6: 77).
2. Laysa fi Kalam Al-Arab (p. 219).
3. See: Al-Bayan fi I'rab Gharib Al-Quran, by Al-Anbari (1: 290).
4. See: Adwa' Al-Bayan, by Muhammad Al-Amin Al-Shanqiti (3: 313), Daf' Iham Al-Idtirab 'an Ayat Al-Kitab, by Al-Shanqiti also (p. 240).

text:
Also in His saying: {And they said, "What is in the bellies of these cattle is exclusively for our males (Khalisatun) and forbidden to our wives (Muharramun)."} [Al-An'am: 139] is a refutation of those who prevented that; because He feminized saying: {Khalisatun} carrying it on the meaning of femininity (of Ma), then He returned to the wording saying: {Wa Muharramun} (1).
They are also refuted by what appeared in Surah Az-Zukhruf: {And whoever is blinded from remembrance of the Most Merciful - We appoint for him a devil, and he is to him a companion (36). And indeed, they avert them from the way [of Guidance] while they think that they are [rightly] guided (37). Until, when he comes to Us (Ja'ana), he says, "Oh, I wish there was between me and you the distance between the East and West - how wretched a companion." (38)} in the reading of whoever singularized the pronoun in {Ja'ana} (2): He singularized in {Ya'shu}, {Nuqayyid lahu}, and {Fa huwa lahu}, then pluralized in {La-yasuddunahum}, and {Wa yahsabuna annahum muhtadun}, then singularized in {Ja'ana} (3). Abu Hayyan said: "He returned first to the wording, then pluralized on the meaning, then singularized on the wording." (4)

2. Ibn Kathir, Nafi', Ibn Amir, and Asim in the narration of Abu Bakr read: {Ja'ana} in the dual form, i.e.: Whoever is blinded from remembrance of the Most Merciful, and the Devil accompanying him. Abu Amr, Hamza, Al-Kisa'i, and Hafs from Asim read: {Ja'ana} in the singular form, i.e.: Whoever is blinded from remembrance of the Most Merciful. See: Al-Sab'ah fi Al-Qira'at, by Ibn Mujahid (p. 586), Tafsir Al-Tabari (21: 605), Al-Taysir fi Al-Qira'at Al-Sab', by Al-Dani (p. 196), Tafsir Abi Hayyan (9: 374), Al-Nashr fi Al-Qira'at Al-Ashr, by Ibn Al-Jazari (2: 369), Fath Al-Qadir, by Al-Shawkani (4: 637).
3. See: Al-Tadhyil wa Al-Takmil fi Sharh Al-Tashil, by Abu Hayyan (3: 116), and (Man) in the verse is conditional and its ruling is the ruling of the relative pronoun.
4. Tafsir Abi Hayyan (9: 374).

text:
They are also refuted by what appeared in the two verses from Surah Luqman previously mentioned, and by the poetic verse Abu Hayyan mentioned, and Al-Samin quoted from him. It appeared in anomalous readings what indicates the permissibility of starting with observing the meaning then the wording. In His saying: {And whoever of you devoutly obeys Allah and His Messenger and does righteousness} [Al-Ahzab: 31], some read: (Taqnut) with Ta (feminine); observing the meaning, and (Ya'mal) with Ya (masculine); observing the wording (1).
Therefore: Al-Samin's rectification upon Ibn Atiyyah is valid; since observing the wording after observing the meaning is permissible, and has what attests to it as has been clarified.

[2]: Ibn Atiyyah said in his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {The lightning almost snatches away their sight. Every time it lights [the way] for them, they walk therein; but when it becomes dark over them, they stand [still]. And if Allah had willed, He could have taken away their hearing and their sight. Indeed, Allah is over all things competent} [Al-Baqarah: 20]: "(Yakadu) is a verb that negates the meaning with its affirmation, and affirms it with negation. So here the lightning did not snatch the sight." (1)

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text: Al-Samin Al-Halabi said in his discussion on (Kada): "Know that its predicate, if it is affirmed, is negated in meaning because it is for approximation. So if you said: 'Kada Zaidun yaf'alu' (Zaid almost did), its meaning is he approached the action, but he did not do it. If it is negated, its predicate is negated by greater reason (a fortiori); because if the approximation of the action is negated, the action itself is negated by greater reason. For this reason, His saying - the Exalted -: {Lam yakad yaraha / He almost could not see it} [Al-Nur: 40] was more eloquent than if it were said: Lam yaraha (He did not see it), because he did not approach the vision, so how could he have it? A group including Ibn Jinni (2), Abu Al-Baqa (3), and Ibn Atiyyah claimed that its negation is affirmation and its affirmation is negation.
foot_note:
2. Abu Hayyan and Al-Samin attributed it to Ibn Jinni, but I did not find it in his printed books. Another opinion was attributed to him, which is that its negation is negation, except that it may be used to indicate the occurrence of the action after delay. See: Tafsir Abi Hayyan (1: 144), Ham' Al-Hawami' fi Sharh Jam' Al-Jawami', by Al-Suyuti (1: 483), Al-Tahrir wa Al-Tanwir, by Ibn Ashour (1: 558).
3. See: Al-Tibyan fi I'rab Al-Quran (1: 36).

And they recounted regarding Dhu Al-Rummah (1) that when he recited his verse (2):
If distance (Al-Na'y) (3) changes lovers, the remnant (Rasis) (4) of passion from the love of Mayya (5) almost does not (Lam yakad) leave
He was criticized; because he said: 'Lam yakad yabrah' (It almost did not leave) so it would mean it left. So he changed it to his saying: 'Lam yazal' (Did not cease) or what is in its meaning (6). What misled these people is His saying - the Exalted -: {Fa dhabahuha wa ma kadu yaf'alun} [Al-Baqarah: 71]. They said: So it is negated here and its predicate is affirmed in meaning, because the slaughter occurred; due to His saying: {Fa dhabahuha}. The answer to this verse is from two aspects. One of them: That it is carried on the difference of two times, i.e.: They slaughtered it at a time, and they almost did not do so at another time. The second: That He expressed by negating the approximation of the action the intensity of their obstinacy and their difficulty in the action. As for what they recounted about Dhu Al-Rummah, the majority declared Dhu Al-Rummah in error in his retraction from his saying, and said: It is more eloquent (7) and better than what he changed it to." (8)

Study of the Rectification:
First: Scholars' opinions on the meaning of (Kada) in Negation and Affirmation:
1 - That its affirmation is affirmation of approximation without the action, and its negation is negation of approximation which entails negation of the action. Said by: Al-Samin Al-Halabi (1), Ibn Hisham (2), Al-Suyuti (3), and others (4). Ibn Hisham said: "The correct view is that its ruling is the ruling of other verbs in that its negation is negation and its affirmation is affirmation. Its explanation is that its meaning is approximation. There is no doubt that the meaning of Kada yaf'al: He approached the action, and that the meaning of Ma kada yaf'al: He did not approach the action. So its predicate is always negated. As for if it is negated (Ma kada), it is clear; because if the approximation of the action is negated, the occurrence of that action is negated rationally. Its evidence is: {Idha akhraja yadahu lam yakad yaraha} [Al-Nur: 40], and for this reason it was more eloquent than saying: Lam yaraha (He did not see it); because he who did not see might approach seeing. As for if the approximation is affirmed (Kada); it is because reporting the proximity of a thing implies customarily its non-occurrence, otherwise the report then would be of its occurrence not the approximation of its occurrence." (5)
2 - That its affirmation is negation, and its negation is affirmation.

2. See: Mughni Al-Labib 'an Kutub Al-A'arib (1: 869).

4. See: Taj Al-Arus, by Al-Zubaidi, root: Kawada (9: 118), Al-Mu'jam Al-Wasit, root: Kada (2: 804).

Said by: Ibn Faris (1), Ibn Atiyyah (2), Abu Al-Baqa (3), and others (4). Ibn Faris said: "If (Kada) occurs stripped (positive), then that thing did not happen; you say: Kada yaf'al; so this did not do. And if it is conjoined with denial (negation), then it happened. If you say: Ma kada yaf'aluhu; then he did it. Allah - Glory be to Him - said: {Fa dhabahuha wa ma kadu yaf'alun} [Al-Baqarah: 71]." (5)
3 - That negation of the past tense is affirmation; evidenced by: ... {Fa dhabahuha wa ma kadu yaf'alun} [Al-Baqarah: 71], and negation of the present tense is negation evidenced by {Lam yakad yaraha} [Al-Nur: 40] while he did not see anything. Some scholars mentioned this and weakened it (6).
4 - That its affirmation is affirmation of approximation without the action, and its negation is negation, but negation might be used to indicate the occurrence of the action with difficulty or after delay and the like. Said by: Al-Farra (7), Al-Akhfash (8), Al-Tabari (9), Abdul Qahir (10) Al-Jurjani (11), Ibn Malik (12), and others (13).

text: Ibn Malik said: "And its negation might be notification of the slowness of occurrence, while the affirmation (of the event) is achieved, like His saying - the Exalted -: {So what is [the matter] with those people that they can hardly (La yakaduna) understand any statement?} [An-Nisa: 78] i.e.: They understand with slowness and difficulty." (1)

text:
5 - That its affirmation is affirmation of approximation and negation of the action, and its negation is affirmation of the occurrence of the action after delay. Said by: Makki bin Abi Talib (1), Al-Wahidi (2), Al-Muntajib Al-Hamadhani (3), and others (4). Al-Muntajib said: "If a negative particle does not accompany it, it approached occurrence but did not occur. If a negative particle accompanies it, it occurs inevitably, but after delay." (5)
6 - That its affirmation is affirmation of approximation without the action. Its negation, if it is in one sentence, is for negating approximation. If it is in two sentences, it implies the occurrence of the action after it was not approximate. Said by: Ibn Al-Qayyim (6).
Second: Critique of the Opinions:
There are aspects of agreement and difference between these opinions. The last three opinions are close, and they are closer to correctness.

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
As for the first opinion - which is Al-Samin's opinion - it is objected to by the fact that negating (Kada) does not necessitate negating the action always. Rather, the action might occur as in His saying: {He sips it and can hardly swallow it (Wa la yakadu yusighuhu)} [Ibrahim: 17] while he swallows it (1) against his will after delay (2).
As for the second opinion - which is Ibn Atiyyah's opinion - it is objected to by the fact that its negation might be negation not affirmation, as in His saying: {Darknesses, some of them upon others. When one puts out his hand, he can hardly see it (Lam yakad yaraha)} [Al-Nur: 40]. The majority of exegetes hold that he did not see it nor did he approach [seeing it], and some went to the view that this is more eloquent than negating the vision itself (3).
Al-Tabari has good words on this issue; he clarified what is more apparent from the linguistic perspective, and what is more apparent from the interpretive perspective. He said: "He might have seen it after slowness and effort, as one says to another: I hardly saw you due to the darkness, while he has seen him, but after despair and hardship. This opinion is the more apparent of the meanings of the word in terms of how Arabs use (Kada) in their speech. The other opinion which we said tends towards meaning he did not see it, is a clearer opinion in terms of interpretation, while it is the more hidden of its meanings. This was only good in this place, I mean saying: 'He can hardly see it' with the intensity of darkness he mentioned; because that is a parable not a report about an event that happened." (4)
As for the third opinion, none of the scholars preferred it, and most of them turned away from mentioning it.

3. See: Tafsir Muqatil bin Sulayman (3: 202), Ma'ani Al-Quran, by Al-Farra (2: 72), Tafsir Al-Tabari (16: 549), Tafsir Ibn Abi Hatim (8: 2615), Al-Tafsir Al-Wasit, by Al-Wahidi (3: 323), Tafsir Al-Sam'ani (3: 537), Tafsir Al-Zamakhshari (3: 244).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
Perhaps the sixth opinion is the most preponderant of the last three opinions. The detail mentioned by Ibn Al-Qayyim agrees with the meanings in which (Kada) was used in the Quran and the language of the Arabs. Ibn Al-Qayyim said: "The correct view is that it is a verb implying approximation and has the ruling of other verbs. Negation of the predicate is not derived from its wording and establishment; for it was not established to negate it. Rather, it is derived from the implications of its meaning. For if it implies approximation of the action, it did not happen; so it is negated by necessity. As for if it is used negated, if it is in one sentence it is for negating approximation, as if you say: La yakadu al-battalu yuflihu (The idler hardly succeeds), and La yakadu al-bakhilu yasudu (The miser hardly prevails), and La yakadu al-jabanu yafrahu (The coward hardly rejoices) and the like. If it is in two sentences, it implies the occurrence of the action after it was not approximate as Ibn Malik said. This is the verification of its matter. The intent is that His saying - the Exalted -: {Lam yakad yaraha} [Al-Nur: 40] either indicates that he does not approach seeing it due to the intensity of darkness, which is the more apparent, so if he does not approach seeing it how does he see it? Dhu Al-Rummah said:
Idha ghayyara al-na'i al-muhibbina lam yakad ... Rasisu al-hawa min hubbi Mayyata yabrahu
i.e.: It did not approach leaving (Al-Barah) - which is cessation - so how can it cease?" (1)
* * *
[3]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {O you who have believed, do not invalidate your charities with reminders or injury as does one who spends his wealth [only] to be seen by the people and does not believe in Allah and the Last Day. His example is like that of a [large] smooth stone upon which is dust and is hit by a downpour that leaves it bare (Saldan). They are unable [to do] anything (La yaqdiruna 'ala shay'in) with what they have earned. And Allah does not guide the disbelieving people}
foot_note: 1. Ijtima' Al-Juyush Al-Islamiyyah (2: 61 - 62).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
[Al-Baqarah: 264]: "His saying - the Exalted -: {La yaqdiruna} refers to those who spend to be seen. i.e.: They are unable to benefit from the reward of anything of that spending of theirs, which is their earning. The expression {Yaqdiruna} came according to the meaning of (Alladhi), and the speech before it was carried on the wording of (Alladhi). This is the clear way (Mahya') (1) of Arab speech. Had it been carried first on the meaning, it would be ugly afterwards to be carried on the wording." (2)
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said in his discussion of His saying: {La yaqdiruna}: "The pronoun was pluralized carrying on the meaning, because the intended by (Alladhi) is the genus. Therefore, it was permissible to carry on its wording once in His saying: {Malahu}, {Wa la yu'minu}, {Fa mathaluhu}, and on its meaning another time. This became analogous to His saying: {Ka-mathali alladhi istawqada naran} [Al-Baqarah: 17] then He said: {Dhahaba Allahu bi-nurihim wa tarakahum fi zulumatin la yubsirun} [Al-Baqarah: 17]. The verification of the statement on that has preceded. Ibn Atiyyah claimed that the clear way of Arab speech is carrying on the wording first then the meaning second, and that the reverse is ugly. The discussion with him on that has preceded." (3)
Study of the Rectification:
The subject of this rectification is the ruling of observing the wording after observing the meaning. Ibn Atiyyah held that this is ugly, while Al-Samin Al-Halabi permitted it and did not weaken it, and he has his evidences. This issue has been previously studied (4).

[4]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {And whoever obeys Allah and His Messenger - He will admit him to gardens beneath which rivers flow, wherein they abide eternally (Khalidina)} [An-Nisa: 13]: "And He pluralized {Khalidina} according to the meaning of {Man} after singularity preceded observing the wording of {Man}. The reverse of this is not permissible." (1)
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "His saying - the Exalted -: {Yudkhilhu}: He carried on the wording of {Man}; so He singularized the pronoun in His saying: {Yuti'} and {Yudkhilh}, and on its meaning; so He pluralized in His saying: {Khalidina}. This is the better of the two carryings, I mean carrying on the wording then the meaning. The reverse is permissible, even though Ibn Atiyyah prevented it. It is nothing (baseless); due to its establishment from the Arabs. This has preceded more than once, and there is detail in it." (2)
Study of the Rectification:
Ibn Atiyyah prevented observing the wording after observing the meaning, while Al-Samin permitted that, and he has his evidences. This issue has been previously studied (3).

text: [5]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {But when they saw a transaction or a diversion, they rushed to it (Ilayha) and left you standing. Say, "What is with Allah is better than diversion and than a transaction, and Allah is the best of providers."} [Al-Jumu'ah: 11]: "He - the Exalted - said: {Ilayha} and did not say: Ilayhima (to them both); concerning with the more important; since it (trade) was the cause of diversion and diversion was not its cause. And reflect that Trade was advanced with 'seeing' (Ra'aw) because it is more important, and delayed with 'preference' (Khayrun min); so that the soul falls first on the more evident." (1)

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "He returned the pronoun to Trade without Diversion; because it is the more important in the cause. Ibn Atiyyah said: 'And He said: {Ilayha} and did not say: Ilayhima; concerning with the more important, since it was the cause of diversion and diversion was not its cause. And reflect that Trade was advanced over Diversion in 'seeing'; because it is more important, and delayed with 'preference'; so that the soul falls first on the more evident' End quote. In his saying: 'He did not say Ilayhima' then answering with what he mentioned, there is a point of view that is not hidden; because conjunction with (Aw / Or) does not have the pronoun dualized with it, nor the predicate, nor the Hal, nor the description; because it is for one of the two things. For that reason, people interpreted {If he be rich or poor, Allah is more worthy of them both (Bihima)} [An-Nisa: 135]. The answer regarding it is only: That He singularized the pronoun because the conjunction is with (Aw). The pronoun of Trade came without the pronoun of Diversion, although permissible; for what Ibn Atiyyah mentioned of the answer, which is importance, as more than one said." (1)
Study of the Rectification:
First: Reference of the pronoun in {Ilayha}:
The majority (2) including Ibn Atiyyah and Al-Samin Al-Halabi went to the view that the pronoun (Ha) returns to Trade, which is the first of the conjoined items - Trade and Diversion.

It was said: The pronoun returns to the totality of what they saw of Diversion and Trade. Al-Samarqandi (1) mentioned this as a probable opinion (2).
It was said: The pronoun is for the 'seeing' (Ru'yah), indicated by His saying: {Ra'aw}. Al-Alusi (3) mentioned it and did not prefer it (4).
It was said: The pronoun returns to Diversion, considering the meaning. The secret in it is: That Trade if it distracts the accountable person from Remembrance is considered diversion, and is considered bounty if it does not distract him. Some scholars (5) transmitted it from Al-Tibi (6).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
The preponderant view: That the pronoun returns to Trade, and the news is about Trade and Diversion together. It is the habit of Arabs to inform about one of the two things while it applies to both (1). Their rushing was for the sake of Trade primarily, and Diversion was only due to its arrival. He - the Exalted - said after that: {And Allah is the best of providers}, this implies that Trade is the origin, and provision is the fruit of trade, so this was a Quranic clarification for the return of the pronoun to Trade without Diversion (2).
Second: The reason for specifying Trade by returning the pronoun to it:
The pronoun was returned to Trade because their inclination was towards Trade, and most of their rushing was for it not Diversion; so it was the more important to them. It is the cause of Diversion and Diversion was not its cause. Trade is a stronger cause for rushing away from the Prophet, peace be upon him (3).

text:
Al-Baydawi said: "Singularizing Trade is by returning the pronoun; because it is the intended one, for what is meant by Diversion is the drum which they used to welcome the caravan with." (1)
Abu Al-Saud said: "And specifying Trade with returning the pronoun is because it is the intended one, or because rushing to Trade despite the need for it and benefiting from it, if it is blameworthy, then what do you think of rushing to Diversion which is blameworthy in itself." (2)
Third: Issue: Returning the pronoun after items conjoined by (Aw / Or):
This issue is the main subject of the rectification. Al-Samin Al-Halabi sees that conjunction with (Aw) does not have the pronoun dualized with it, but rather it is for one of the two things; contrary to Ibn Atiyyah whose apparent speech indicates the permissibility of returning the pronoun to both things. There are two main opinions on this issue:
The First: That when conjoining with (Aw), it is permissible to return the pronoun to one of the conjoined items, and to both of them. Said by: Al-Farra (3), Ibn Qutaybah (4), Al-Zamakhshari (5), Ibn Atiyyah (6), and Al-Qurtubi (7).

6. See: Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (5: 310).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
However, it is better to return the pronoun to one of them without the other (1), and the best of all is: returning the pronoun to the last of the conjoined items (2). Al-Farra said: "And if it were said: Infaddu ilayhima (they rushed to both), as He said: {If he be rich or poor, Allah is more worthy of them both (Bihima)} [An-Nisa: 135], it would be correct. But better than that in Arabic is that you make the returning mention refer to the last of the two nouns, and what is after that is permissible." (3)
The Second: That conjunction with (Aw) does not have the pronoun dualized with it, but rather it is for one of the two things. Said by: Al-Akhfash (4), Abu Hayyan (5), Al-Samin Al-Halabi (6), and others (7). Al-Akhfash said: "(Aw) only informs about one of the two things, and you have a choice in (Aw); if you wish you make the speech about the first, and if you wish about the other. Carrying it on the other is more analogical; because if you make the predicate about the noun that follows it - the predicate -, it is more exemplary than surpassing it to a noun far from it." (8)

text:
Abu Hayyan said: "The principle in conjoining with Waw is the agreement of the pronoun with what preceded it in dual and plural, but conjoining with (Aw), the pronoun in it does not return except to one of what preceded." (1)
The proponents of this opinion burdened themselves in interpreting what appeared in His saying - the Exalted -: {If he be rich or poor, Allah is more worthy of them both (Bihima)} [An-Nisa: 135]; to align with their doctrine. They mentioned several directions for that, including: That (Aw) here is in the meaning of (Waw / And). Others said: The pronoun returns to richness and poverty indicated by the words rich and poor, and the estimation is: Allah is more worthy of the richness of the rich and the poverty of the poor. It was said: The pronoun returns to the two adversaries, the estimation is: If the two adversaries be rich or poor, Allah is more worthy of these two adversaries (2). All of this is affectation that is not needed, and the principle is: Relying on the apparent meaning of the verse without resorting to estimations.
The preponderant view: That conjunction with (Aw) allows dualizing the pronoun and singularizing it. The stronger of the two aspects is: Returning the pronoun to one of the conjoined items, and choosing one over the other is based on benefit and importance. The permissibility of dualizing the pronoun is indicated by what came in His saying: {If he be rich or poor, Allah is more worthy of them both} [An-Nisa: 135]; and it is also indicated by the anomalous reading in the verse: (Infaddu ilayhima) (3). Those who interpreted what came in the Quran to agree with their linguistic and grammatical doctrine erred; for rules are taken from the Quran, and what came in the Quran is not interpreted to agree with the analogies of linguists.

2. See: Al-Durr Al-Masun (4: 116), Tafsir Al-Alusi (14: 300).
3. It is the reading of Abdullah bin Mas'ud and Ibn Abi Abla. See: Tafsir Al-Zamakhshari (4: 537), Zad Al-Masir, by Ibn Al-Jawzi (4: 285), Tafsir Abi Hayyan (10: 176), Al-Durr Al-Masun (10: 333).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
Therefore: Al-Samin's rectification upon Ibn Atiyyah is not in place; for dualizing the pronoun when conjoining with (Aw) is permissible, the utmost is that it is contrary to the best, strongest, and most predominant usage in the Quran. For dualizing the pronoun in concurrent (Mutawatir) reading did not appear except in one place (1) which is His saying: {If he be rich or poor, Allah is more worthy of them both}, while in other places of conjunction with (Aw), the return of the pronoun was to one of the conjoined items, the first or the last. Among the return to the first without the last: {But when they saw a transaction or a diversion, they rushed to it (Ilayha)} [Al-Jumu'ah: 11]; where He returned to the first of the conjoined: Trade. And among the return to the last: {And whoever earns a fault or a sin then throws it (Bihi) upon an innocent person has taken upon himself a slander and a manifest sin} [An-Nisa: 112] so He said: {Bihi} meaning the sin; so He returned to the last of the conjoined items.

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
Section Two
His Rectifications in Quranic Parsing
[1]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {And [mention, O Muhammad], when your Lord said to the angels, "Indeed, I will make upon the earth a successive authority." They said, "Will You place upon it one who causes corruption therein and sheds blood, while we declare Your praise and sanctify You?" He said, "Indeed, I know that which you do not know."} [Al-Baqarah: 30]: "And their saying: {Wa nahnu nusabbihu bi-hamdika} some interpreters said: It is by way of interrogation, as if they intended: Do we declare Your praise or do we change from this state? Judge Abu Muhammad said: And this is good with the view of pure interrogation in their saying: (A-taj'alu)." (1)
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "He went far who claimed that the sentence of their saying: {Wa nahnu nusabbihu bi-hamdika} falls within the scope of an estimated interrogation, its estimation being: A-nahnu nusabbihu am nataghayyar (Do we declare praise or do we change?), and Ibn Atiyyah deemed it good with the view of pure interrogation in their saying: (A-taj'alu). The majority refuse this, I mean deleting the interrogative Hamza without mentioning the equivalent (Am), which is Al-Akhfash's opinion (2). He made of that His saying - the Exalted -: {And is [that] a favor of which you remind me} [Ash-Shu'ara: 22] i.e.: A-wa tilka ni'matun (Is that a favor?)." Then Al-Samin said: "As for with (Am), it is permissible; due to its indication of it, like his saying:
By Allah, I do not know, even if I was knowing ... With seven they threw the pebbles or with eight (3)
i.e.: A-bi-sab'in (With seven?)." (4)

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
Study of the Rectification:
Ibn Atiyyah deemed good the opinion that there is an estimated interrogation in His saying: {Wa nahnu nusabbihu bi-hamdika}, and the estimation is: Do we declare Your praise or do we change from this state. Among those who went to the view that there is an estimated interrogation in it: Al-Sam'ani (1), and Al-Kirmani (2). Al-Samin considered that far-fetched; because it contradicts what the majority of grammarians hold; as they established that it is not permissible to delete the interrogative Hamza without mentioning (Am) after it. Al-Samin Al-Halabi contented himself with weakening this opinion from a grammatical perspective. The summary of the grammarians' opinions on this issue is as follows:
1 - The majority went to the permissibility of deleting the interrogative Hamza if evidence indicates it, which is: mentioning (Am) after it, so it is inferred by it that there is an estimated interrogation before it (3).
foot_note:
1. See: Tafsir Al-Sam'ani (1: 65).
2. See: Ghara'ib Al-Tafsir wa 'Aja'ib Al-Ta'wil (1: 132).
3. See: Ma'ani Al-Quran wa I'rabuhu, by Al-Zajjaj (1: 81), Al-Muqtadab, by Al-Mubarrad (3: 294), Al-Mufassal fi San'at Al-I'rab, by Al-Zamakhshari (p. 438), Sharh Al-Kafiyah Al-Shafiyah, by Ibn Malik (3: 1215), Sharh Ibn Aqil 'ala Alfiyyat Ibn Malik (3: 230).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
2 - Some grammarians expanded this, allowing the deletion of interrogation from speech; relying on a verbal clue which is (Am), or a semantic one relying on the listener's acumen (1).
3 - Al-Akhfash permitted deleting the interrogative Hamza by choice even if the equivalent (Am) is not mentioned after it, provided ambiguity is safe. If deletion leads to ambiguity, it is not permissible (2).
The correct view is that deleting interrogation from speech, even if permissible despite its rarity and with conditions, the claim of the existence of an estimated interrogation - which is Ibn Atiyyah's opinion - in His saying: {Wa nahnu nusabbihu bi-hamdika} is very far-fetched and weak from several aspects:
1 - The apparent meaning of the verse does not indicate that this phrase falls within the scope of an estimated interrogation, but rather it is a circumstantial sentence (Jumlat Hal), confirming the previous wonder and objection, and emphasizing it (3). Ibn Ashour said: "So it is a Hal confirming the meaning of the sentence: {A-taj'alu fiha man yufsidu} completing the surprise." (4)

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
Some exegetes said: This is in the manner of one who strives in the service of his master while he orders another to do it: Do you use the disobedient while I strive in it? (1) As if it were said: Do You appoint as successor one whose offspring's nature is corruption while there exists one whose nature is not that at all? (2) The meaning: Inform us, O our Lord, are You making in the earth one whose description is this, while we declare Your praise and sanctify You (3). Their question: {A-taj'alu fiha man yufsidu}... is a question of inquiry and seeking uncovering of the wisdom in that (4). They say: O our Lord, what is the wisdom in creating these while among them are those who cause corruption in the earth and shed blood, if the intent is Your worship, then we declare Your praise and sanctify You, and nothing of that corruption issues from us, so why was it not restricted to us? So Allah said answering this question: {Indeed, I know that which you do not know}. (5)
2 - Allah Almighty informed them that He will place a successor on earth, so what is the relevance of the question: Do we declare praise or do we change? to that news. Rather, the question in such a case is about the wisdom of that given their description of declaring praise and sanctity, i.e.: How do You make a successor who causes corruption and is not like our state in declaring praise and sanctity.

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
The question in such a subject is not about whether they change or not, and whether placing a successor on earth necessitates their changing from the state they are in? Rather, this is among their constant attributes that do not change (1). It has been established by evidences that they are described by complete obedience to Allah - the Exalted -, declaring His praise, prostrating to Him, and other acts of worship. Among the evidences for that: His saying - the Exalted -: {They do not disobey Allah in what He commands them but do what they are commanded} [Al-Tahrim: 6], and His saying: {They exalt [Him] night and day [and] do not slacken} [Al-Anbiya': 20], and His saying: {And the angels exalt [Him] with praise of their Lord} [Ash-Shura: 5]. Furthermore, their saying: {Wa nahnu nusabbihu bi-hamdika} is a nominal sentence, indicating permanence, i.e.: their description inherent to their nature (2), i.e.: We are the ones constant in declaring praise and sanctity.
3 - The context does not indicate that, and context is relied upon in weighting between possibilities (3). The context here does not indicate that its meaning is: And do we declare praise or do we change, since He said after that: {Indeed, I know that which you do not know}. This indicates that their question was about the wisdom they were ignorant of only, and it is unlikely to be an answer to a question estimated as: Do we declare praise or do we change? The context of the verses in this subject contains affirmation of Allah's knowledge - Glory be to Him - (4), and showing their ignorance (5): {They said, "Exalted are You; we have no knowledge except what You have taught us. Indeed, it is You who is the Knowing, the Wise."} [Al-Baqarah: 32]. So the verses established their ignorance when they were ignorant of the names, while there is nothing in them indicating their change.

5 - Parsing free of estimation and deletion is more appropriate than parsing in which that is claimed, because deletion is contrary to the principle (2). So there is no need to say that there is a deleted interrogation estimated as: And do we declare praise or do we change?
Therefore: Al-Samin's rectification upon Ibn Atiyyah is valid.

[2]: Ibn Atiyyah said upon his parsing of His saying - the Exalted -: {They said, "Exalted are You; we have no knowledge except what You have taught us. Indeed, it is You who is the Knowing, the Wise."} [Al-Baqarah: 32]: "Al-Zahrawi said: The position of {Ma} from their saying: {Ma 'allamtana} is accusative (Nasb)... by {'Allamtana}, and the predicate of exoneration (Tabri'ah - La Nafi li-jins) is in {Lana}. It is possible that the position of (Ma) is nominative (Raf') as a substitute (Badal) from the predicate of exoneration, as you say: La ilaha illa Allah (There is no god but Allah), i.e.: No god exists but Allah." (1)

text:
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "{Ma} is relative (Mawsulah), and {'Allamtana} is its relative clause (Silah), and its return pronoun ('A'id) is deleted, on the basis that ('Ilm) means Ma'lum (Known). It is permissible that it be infinitival (Masdariyyah) and it is in the place of accusative (Nasb) for exception. It is not permissible for it to be accusative by the Knowledge which is the noun of (La) because if it operated it would be declinable (Mu'rab). It was said: In the place of nominative (Raf') as a substitute (Badal) from the noun of (La) based on the position. Ibn Atiyyah said: 'It is a substitute from the predicate of exoneration like their saying: La ilaha illa Allah'. In this there is a point of view (criticism); because the exception is only from the subject ruled upon with the constraint of the ruling, not from the predicate (Mahkum bihi)." (1)
Study of the Rectification:
The subject of this rectification is {Ma} and its grammatical position in His saying: {La 'ilma lana illa ma 'allamtana}. The parsers of the Quran have several opinions on this:
foot_note: 1. Al-Durr Al-Masun (1: 266).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study

1 - That {Ma} is relative, and {'Allamtana} is its clause, and its return pronoun is deleted, i.e.: 'Allamtanahu, and {'Ilm} would mean: Ma'lum (Known). It, with its clause, is in the place of Raf' as a substitute from the position of {La 'ilm}, i.e.: There is no known for us except what You taught us. Said by: Abu Al-Baqa (1), Al-Muntajib Al-Hamadhani (2), Abu Hayyan (3), Al-Samin (4), and others (5). This is the clearest and most apparent of aspects, and it is consistent with the apparent meaning of the verse.
2 - That {Ma} is infinitival (Masdariyyah), i.e.: [No] knowledge except the one You taught us ('Ilman 'allamtana), and it is in the place of Raf' as a substitute from the position of ... (La 'ilm) like "La ilaha illa Allah". Said by: Abu Al-Baqa - as a probable aspect - (6), Ismail (7) Haqqi (8), and others (9). It is a probable opinion, and its meaning is close to the meaning of the first opinion.

Therefore: Al-Samin's rectification upon Ibn Atiyyah is valid; because both opinions Ibn Atiyyah mentioned have weakness in them, and he did not mention others.

[3]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {And [mention] when We said to the angels, "Prostrate to Adam," and they prostrated, except for Iblees. He refused and was arrogant and became of the disbelievers} [Al-Baqarah: 34]: "{Idh} from His saying: {Wa idh qulna} is conjoined to the preceding {Idh}." (1)

It was said: The operator is (Udhkur) estimated. It was said: {Idh} is extra. The weakness of these two opinions has preceded. Ibn Atiyyah said: '{Wa idh qulna} is conjoined to the preceding {Idh}' End quote. And this is not correct; due to the difference of the two times." (2)

In His saying - the Exalted -: {And when We said to the angels, "Prostrate to Adam," and they prostrated}, the parsers of the Quran discussed {Idh} and its operator, and its grammatical position. The discussion on that divides into two parts:
First: Their opinion on (Idh) and its operator:
1 - That (Idh) is extra, and the meaning: And We said to the angels. Said by: Abu Ubaidah (1), and Al-Harith (2) Al-Muhasibi (3). The majority weakened it (4); because addition is only in particles, while nouns are not added (5).
2 - That it is not extra, and the operator in it is deleted, and the estimation is: And mention when We said. Said by: Al-Baquli (6), Al-Qurtubi (7), Ibn Hisham (8), Al-Shawkani (9), and others (10).

text:
In the Quran, (Idh) is frequently mentioned coupled with the conjoining Waw without mentioning the operator in it if the speech is in the context of enumerating blessings and repeating stories, so the conjoining Waw points to it, as if it is mentioned in the wording; due to the addressee's knowledge of the intended (1). The preponderant view: That the conjunction here is conjoining a story to a story, not conjoining an adverb to an adverb - as Ibn Atiyyah said -, nor is it conjoining a sentence to a sentence. The context indicates conjoining a story to a story, and it is another great blessing He counted for His servants (2), worthy of mention and reminding on its own (3), and the context of the verses consists of sequential stories. Ibn Ashour said regarding conjoining a story to a story here: "It is supported by the fact that marvelous stories indicating the power of Allah - the Exalted - are started with it. Do you not see that it was mentioned in His saying - the Exalted -: {Wa idh qulna lil-mala'ikah isjudu li-Adam} and was not mentioned between them. And (Idh) would be a noun of time as an object with the estimation: Mention (Udhkur). Its parallel is frequent in the Quran. The intended by hanging the mention and the story to the time is only what happened in that time of conditions." (4)

[4]: Ibn Atiyyah said upon his parsing of His saying - the Exalted -: {And do not mix the truth with falsehood or conceal the truth while you know [it]} [Al-Baqarah: 42]: "{Wa antum ta'lamun} is a sentence in the position of Hal (circumstantial accusative). He - Exalted - did not testify for them to knowledge, but rather He forbade them from concealing what they knew. It is possible that it is a testimony against them of specific true knowledge regarding the matter of Muhammad peace be upon him, and He did not testify for them to knowledge absolutely. On this basis, the sentence would not be in the position of Hal." (1)
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "His saying: {Wa antum ta'lamun} is a sentence of inceptive and predicate in the place of Nasb as Hal." Al-Samin spoke in detail about its operator, then said: "Ibn Atiyyah allowed that this sentence not be a Hal, for he said: 'It is possible that it is a testimony against them of specific true knowledge regarding the matter of Muhammad peace be upon him, and He did not testify for them to knowledge absolutely. On this basis, the sentence would not be in the position of Hal' End quote. In what he said there is a point of view." (2)
Study of the Rectification:
The parsers of the Quran agreed that His saying: {Wa antum ta'lamun} is a sentence in the position of Nasb as Hal (3).

text:
Abu Ja'far Al-Nahhas said: "{Wa antum}: inceptive, {Ta'lamun}: future verb in the position of the predicate, and the sentence is in the position of Hal." (1)
Abdul Rahman Al-Anbari said: "{Wa antum ta'lamun} is a nominal sentence in the position of Nasb as Hal from the hidden pronoun in (Taktumu)." (2)
Ibn Atiyyah allowed another aspect where he said: "It is possible that it is a testimony against them of specific true knowledge regarding the matter of Muhammad peace be upon him, and He did not testify for them to knowledge absolutely. On this basis, the sentence would not be in the position of Hal" (3), meaning that the sentence is conjoined, not circumstantial (4). This aspect which Ibn Atiyyah allowed is not needed. Conjoining the affirmative declarative sentence {Wa antum ta'lamun} to what precedes it of the prohibition sentence {Wa la talbisu al-haqqa bil-batili wa taktumu al-haqqa}, even if permissible from a grammatical perspective, the meaning of the verse and its interpretation do not indicate that. Not everything permissible in grammar is permissible in parsing the Quran; rather, one must choose the parsing aspect consistent with the interpretation of the verse.

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
Ibn Al-Qayyim said: "It is not permissible to carry the speech of Allah Almighty and interpret it merely by the grammatical parsing possibility that the sentence structure allows while the speech has some meaning with it, for this is a station where most parsers of the Quran erred." (1)
The apparent speech of the exegetes indicates that His saying: {Wa antum ta'lamun} is a circumstantial sentence linked to what precedes it in meaning, i.e.: Do not conceal the truth, meaning the matter of Muhammad peace be upon him, while you know that he is the truth and a sent Prophet in the books in your hands (2).
Ibn Abbas may Allah be pleased with him said in his interpretation of this verse: "Do not conceal what you have of knowledge regarding My Messenger and what he brought, while you find it with you in what you know of the books in your hands." (3)
Mujahid said: "The People of the Book conceal Muhammad peace be upon him, while they find him written with them in the Torah and the Gospel." (4)
Al-Zajjaj said: "{Wa antum ta'lamun} i.e.: You commit your mixing of truth and its concealment based on knowledge from you and insight." (5)
The parallel of this verse is His saying - the Exalted -: {Those to whom We have given the Scripture know him as they know their own sons. And indeed, a party of them conceal the truth while they know [it]} [Al-Baqarah: 146]

text:
[5]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {And [recall] when We saved you from the people of Pharaoh, who afflicted you with the worst torment (yasumunakum su'a al-'adhab), slaughtering your sons and keeping your women alive} [Al-Baqarah: 49]: "{Yasumunakum}: its parsing is Raf' (nominative) for resumption (Isti'naf), and the sentence is in the position of Nasb (accusative) as Hal (circumstantial accusative), i.e., afflicting you with the worst torment. It is permissible not to estimate Hal in it, and for it to be a description of a past state." (1)
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "His saying: {Yasumunakum su'a al-'adhab} this sentence is in the place of Nasb as Hal from {Al} (Family/People), in the state of them being afflicters. It is permissible for it to be resumed merely for informing about that, and to be a narration of a past state. Ibn Atiyyah said its meaning, and it is not apparent." (2)
Study of the Rectification:
The majority of the parsers of the Quran went to the view that His saying: {Yasumunakum} is in the place of Nasb as Hal from {Ali Fir'awn} (3), or from the pronoun in {Najjaynakum} (4), or from both of them; because it contains a pronoun for each of them (5).

The meaning: And when We saved you from the people of Pharaoh [while they were] afflicting you with the worst torment. Abdul Rahman Al-Anbari said: "{Yasumunakum} is a verbal sentence in the position of Nasb as Hal from the family of Pharaoh." (1)
Al-Akhfash (2), Al-Tabari (3), Ibn Atiyyah (4), and others (5) permitted that His saying: {Yasumunakum} be a resumed sentence in the position of Raf' (nominative), narrating a past state.

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
Al-Akhfash said: "{Yasumunakum} is in the position of Raf', and if you wish you can make it in the position of Nasb as Hal, as if he says: And when We saved you from the family of Pharaoh [while they were] afflicting you. And the Raf' is on inception." (1)
Al-Tabari said: "And in His saying: {Yasumunakum} there are two aspects of interpretation. One of them: That it is a resumed report about Pharaoh's action with the Children of Israel, so its meaning then would be: And remember My favor upon you when I saved you from the family of Pharaoh, and they were before that afflicting you with the worst torment. If that is its interpretation, the position of {Yasumunakum} is Raf'. The second aspect: That {Yasumunakum} is Hal, so its interpretation then would be: And when We saved you from the family of Pharaoh [while they were] afflicting you with the worst torment, so it is Hal from the family of Pharaoh." (2)
Both aspects are permissible, except that making the sentence in the position of Nasb as Hal is closer in terms of meaning and interpretation. This verse and what follows it are in explaining Allah's favor and grace upon the Children of Israel. Among His favors upon them: That He saved them from the family of Pharaoh. The verses detail Allah's favors upon them. So it is more appropriate that His saying: {Yasumunakum} be a Hal from the family of Pharaoh by which clarification of what the saving was from occurs, which is the severe torment that befell the Children of Israel from the family of Pharaoh (3). Therefore: Al-Samin's rectification upon Ibn Atiyyah is valid; because making it an explanatory Hal connected to what precedes it is more appropriate than making it a resumed sentence.

[6]: Ibn Atiyyah said in his parsing of His saying - the Exalted -: {And [recall] when We made an appointment with Moses for forty nights. Then you took [for worship] the calf after him, while you were wrongdoers} [Al-Baqarah: 51]: "And the pronoun in {Min ba'dihi} returns to Moses, and it was said: to his departure for the speech; since the appointment implies it. And it was said: to the appointment." (1)
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "The pronoun returns to Moses, and an annexed noun must be deleted, i.e.: After his departure or passing. Ibn Atiyyah said: 'It returns to Moses, and it was said: to his departure for the speech, and it was said: to the appointment' End quote. In his speech there is some discussion, for his saying: 'And it was said it returns to his departure' implies its return to Moses without estimating an annexed noun, and that is inconceivable." (2)

text:
Study of the Rectification:
The exegetes and parsers discussed His saying: {Min ba'dihi}. Some of them said (1): The Ha returns to Moses peace be upon him, and they did not mention that there is a deleted annexed noun known from the context.
Al-Tabari said: "And the Ha in His saying: {Min ba'dihi} refers back to the mention of Moses." (2)
Al-Qurtubi said: "{Thumma ittakhadhtum al-'ijla min ba'dihi} i.e.: You took it as a god after Moses." (3)
The majority went to the view that there is a deleted annexed noun, and the estimation is: After the departure of Moses or his passing (4).
Al-Wahidi said: "{Min ba'dihi}: After his leaving you for the appointed time." (5)
Abdul Rahman Al-Anbari said: "The Ha returns to Moses, and the estimation in it is: After his leaving, so the annexed noun was deleted, and the annexed to was put in its place." (6)

text:
Abu Al-Baqa said: "{Min ba'dihi}: i.e., after his departure, so the annexed noun was deleted." (1)
As for Al-Samin's rectification upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding returning the pronoun to Moses without estimating an annexed noun, stating that it is inconceivable: He means that transitivity in essence is inconceivable, so there must be a deletion, thus a verbal noun is estimated (2) from the context, and it is the deleted annexed noun. So Al-Samin's rectification upon Ibn Atiyyah is valid, because deleting the annexed noun understood from the context is common in Arab speech (3), but in parsing and interpretation this annexed noun should be clarified. An example of deleting the annexed noun in the Quran is what came in His saying - the Exalted -: {Have you not considered the assembly of the Children of Israel after Moses} [Al-Baqarah: 246] i.e.: after the death of Moses peace be upon him (4).
* * *
[7]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {He said, "He says, 'It is a cow neither trained to plow the earth nor to irrigate the field, one free from fault with no spot upon her.'"} [Al-Baqarah: 71]: "And {Tuthiru al-arda} means by plowing. According to a group, it is a sentence in the position of Raf' (nominative) as an attribute for the cow, i.e.: not trained, stirring. A group said: {Tuthiru} is a resumed verb, and the meaning is affirming plowing and that it used to plow but not irrigate. It is not permissible for this sentence to be in the position of Hal (circumstantial accusative); because it is from an indefinite noun." (1)

text: Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "His saying: {Tuthiru al-arda}, there are many opinions regarding this sentence. The most apparent of them is that it is in the place of Nasb (accusative) as Hal from the pronoun hidden in {Dhalul}, its estimation: It is not tamed in the state of its plowing the earth.

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
Ibn Atiyyah said: 'According to a group, it is a sentence in the position of attribute for the cow, i.e.: not trained, stirring', and he also said: 'And it is not permissible for this sentence to be in the position of Hal because it is from an indefinite noun' End quote. As for his saying: 'in the position of attribute', it entails that the cow was stirring the earth, and the majority did not say this, rather some of them said it. As for his saying: 'It is not permissible to be Hal - meaning from {Baqarah} - because it is indefinite', the answer is: We do not concede that it is Hal from {Baqarah}, rather from the pronoun in {Dhalul} as explained previously. Or we say: Rather it is Hal from the indefinite noun which has been described and specified by his saying: {La Dhalul}, and if the indefinite noun is described, bringing the Hal from it is permissible by agreement. It was said: It is resumed (Musta'nafah), and its resumption is on two aspects. One of them: That it is a predicate for a deleted inceptive, i.e.: It stirs. The second: That it is resumed by itself without estimating an inceptive, rather it is a verbal sentence initiated merely to inform about that." (1)
Study of the Rectification:
First: Scholars' opinions on parsing the sentence: {Tuthiru al-arda} from His saying - the Exalted -: {Qala innahu yaqulu innaha baqaratun la dhalulun tuthiru al-arda wa la tasqi al-hartha}:

Perhaps this opinion was taken from the reading of Abu Hatim Al-Sijistani; as he used to pause at (La Dhalul) then begin {Tuthiru al-arda}, contrary to the majority (1), so the sentence on his reading is affirmative, i.e.: It stirs the earth.
Second: Discussion of Opinions:
The opinion that the sentence {Tuthiru al-arda} is in the place of Nasb as Hal from the pronoun hidden in {Dhalul}, and the opinion that it is in the place of Raf' as an attribute for {Dhalul}, are both correct from a semantic perspective and from a technical grammatical perspective. However, the second opinion is clearer and closer to the apparent meaning of the verse.
As for the opinion that it is in the place of Raf' as an attribute for {Baqarah}, and likewise the opinion that it is a resumed sentence, both entail that the cow is stirring, while the majority of exegetes from the Salaf and Khalaf hold that the cow was not stirring (2), and that the sentence enters into the negation.

text: Abu Al-Aliyah said: "{Tuthiru al-arda} means: It is not trained so it stirs the earth." (1) Al-Zajjaj said: "Its meaning is not trained nor stirring." (2) Al-Mawardi (3) said: "It was said: {Tuthiru} is a resumed verb, and the meaning is affirming plowing for it, and that it used to plow but not irrigate. This aspect is nothing; rather all of that is negated from it." (4) Abu Hayyan said weakening the opinion that it is affirmative: "This opinion was rejected from the perspective of meaning, because what plows does not negate being trained." (5) Some scholars said in weakening Abu Hatim Al-Sijistani's reading: That which stirs the earth is not devoid of irrigating the field, and whenever it stirred the earth it was trained (6).

text:
If it were stirring the earth, the stirring would have tamed it, and Allah - the Exalted - negated tameness from it by His saying: {La Dhalul} (1). It was said that that cow was wild (2), therefore Allah described it as neither stirring the earth nor irrigating the field.
Also, the opinion that it is resumed and affirmative is weak from a grammatical perspective. It is not permissible for {Tuthiru} to be resumed; because after it is {Wa la tasqi al-hartha}. If it were resumed, He would not have combined the Waw and (La) (3). Abu Al-Baqa said: "Because He conjoined to it: {Wa la tasqi al-hartha}: so He negated the conjoined; so the conjoined to must be likewise; because it is one in meaning. Do you not see that you do not say: I passed by a man standing nor sitting (Qa'im wa la qa'id), but you say: La qa'id (not sitting); without Waw. Likewise it must be here." (4)
Meaning that if it were resumed affirmative, the phrase would be: Tuthiru al-arda la tasqi al-hartha (Stirring the earth, not irrigating the field), because it is not said: Yaqumu Zaid wa la yaq'udu (Zaid stands nor sits), but it is said: Yaqumu Zaid la yaq'udu (Zaid stands, not sits). The Waw only comes after negation like: La

[8]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {They ask you about the sacred month - about fighting therein. Say, "Fighting therein is great: but averting from the way of Allah and disbelief in Him and [preventing access to] al-Masjid al-Haram and the expulsion of its people therefrom are greater [evil] in the sight of Allah." } [Al-Baqarah: 217]: "And {Al-Masjidi} is conjoined to {Sabil Allah}, and this is the correct view." Al-Samin Al-Halabi said rectifying Ibn Atiyyah: "This is rejected because it leads to separating between parts of the relative clause with a foreign element. Its explanation is that (Saddan) is a verbal noun estimated by (An) and the verb, and (An) is a relative particle. You have made {Wal-Masjidi} a conjunction to {Sabil} so it is part of completing its clause, and a foreign element separated them which is {Wa kufrun bihi}. The meaning of it being foreign is that it has no relation to the clause. If it is said: There is expansion in the adverb and preposition that is not expanded in other things, it is said: This was only said regarding advancing (Taqdim), not regarding separation (Fasl)." Study of the Rectification:
Scholars differed in parsing His saying: {Wal-Masjidi Al-Harami}, and they have five opinions on that:
1 - That His saying: {Wal-Masjidi Al-Harami} is conjoined to {Sabil Allah}, i.e.: Averting from the way of Allah and the Sacred Mosque. Said by: Ibn Qutaybah (1), Abu Ja'far Al-Nahhas (2), Makki bin Abi Talib (3), Al-Wahidi (4), Al-Zamakhshari (5), Ibn Atiyyah (6), and others (7). Ibn Qutaybah said: "And He put {Wal-Masjidi Al-Harami} in the genitive (Khafd) following the pattern of {Sabil Allah}, as if He said: And averting from the way of Allah and from the Sacred Mosque." (8) A number of parsers (9) weakened this opinion arguing that it leads to separating between the clause and the relative pronoun with a foreign element which is His saying: {Wa kufrun bihi}.

Al-Samin said in his weakening of this opinion - which is Ibn Atiyyah's opinion -: "This is rejected because it leads to separating between parts of the relative clause with a foreign element. Its explanation is that (Saddan) is a verbal noun estimated by (An) and the verb, and (An) is a relative particle. You have made {Wal-Masjidi} a conjunction to {Sabil} so it is part of completing its clause, and a foreign element separated them which is {Wa kufrun bihi}. The meaning of it being foreign is that it has no relation to the clause." (1)
Those who weakened it were answered with two aspects:
One: That averting from the way of Allah and disbelief in Him are like one thing in meaning; so it is as if there is no separation by a foreign element between {Sabil Allah} and what was conjoined to it.
Two: That the position of His saying: {Wa kufrun bihi} is after His saying: {Wal-Masjidi Al-Harami}, but it was advanced over it due to extreme care, like His saying - the Exalted -: {Wa lam yakun lahu kufuwan ahad} [Al-Ikhlas: 4]. The right of speech was to say: Wa lam yakun ahadun kufuwan lahu, but extreme care necessitated its advancement, so likewise here (2).
Ibn Ashour said: "The motive for this arrangement is that the composition of speech be in a style more precise than the apparent requirement, which is the concern with presenting what is more atrocious of their crimes. For disbelief in Allah is more atrocious than preventing access to the Sacred Mosque. So the arrangement of the composition was based on presenting the more important then the next more important. For preventing from the way of Islam gathers many injustices; because it is an aggression against people in what they choose for themselves, and a denial of the message of the Messenger of Allah.

And from Arab speech: "Marartu bika wa Zaidin" (I passed by you and Zaid) conjoining without repeating the preposition, and the estimation is: I passed by you and by Zaid.
It was answered that even if this is grammatically correct, it is far-fetched from the perspective of meaning (2), and the speech of Allah is not carried on mere grammatical possibility (3). For the meaning of this opinion is that fighting in the sacred month is disbelief in Allah and disbelief in the Sacred Mosque, and disbelief in the Sacred Mosque is a far-fetched phrase in terms of meaning. It was not heard that they used to say: So-and-so disbelieved in the Sacred Mosque. This is in addition to the fact that the polytheists used to venerate the Sacred Mosque despite their disbelief and misguidance (4). Abdul Rahman Al-Anbari said: "{Wal-Masjidi Al-Harami} is genitive by conjunction to {Sabil Allah}, not by conjunction to {Bihi}. The estimation in it is: And averting from the way of Allah and from the Sacred Mosque; because adding 'averting' to it is more common in usage than adding 'disbelief' in it. Do you not see that they say: I averted him from the Mosque, and they hardly ever say: I disbelieved in the Mosque?" (5)

Said by: Al-Farra (1), Al-Raghib Al-Isfahani (2), and Al-Kirmani (3). It was weakened because the people did not ask about the Sacred Mosque; as they did not doubt its sanctity. They only asked about fighting in the sacred month because it occurred from them, and they did not realize its entry, so they feared sin, and the polytheists reproached them for that (4). Al-Tabari said weakening this opinion: "This opinion, with its departure from the opinions of the people of knowledge, is an opinion that has no validity; because the people were not in doubt about the enormity of what the polytheists did to the Muslims in expelling them from their homes in Mecca, such that they needed to ask the Messenger of Allah peace be upon him about the polytheists expelling them from their homes, and was that [right] for them? Rather, none of the Muslims claimed that against them, nor that they asked the Messenger of Allah peace be upon him about that. Since that is so, the people did not ask the Messenger of Allah peace be upon him except about what they doubted its ruling (5)." (6)

Also, this opinion was weakened because it necessitates deleting the preposition while retaining its operation, and that is not permissible except in forms of which this is not one, and grammarians stated that it is necessity (1).
5 - That the genitive of {Wal-Masjidi Al-Harami} is by deleting the annexed noun, i.e.: And averting [from] the Sacred Mosque. Said by: Al-Baydawi (2), and the majority turned away from mentioning it. It is a far-fetched opinion, and there is no need to estimate a deleted annexed noun in this place.
The preponderant view is that His saying: {Wal-Masjidi Al-Harami} is conjoined to {Sabil Allah}, and the meaning is: Averting from the way of Allah and the Sacred Mosque. There are several factors supporting this opinion: Including what was mentioned that the separation was not by a foreign element; because averting from the way of Allah and disbelief in Him are like one thing in meaning, and that the separator {Wa kufrun bihi} was advanced for a benefit. And because averting from the Sacred Mosque came in more than one place in the Quran, unlike disbelief in the Sacred Mosque which did not appear. He - the Exalted - said: {And let not the hatred of a people for having obstructed you from al-Masjid al-Haram lead you to transgress} [Al-Ma'idah: 2], and He - the Exalted - said: {But what is [the matter] with them that Allah should not punish them while they obstruct [people] from al-Masjid al-Haram} [Al-Anfal: 34], and He said: {They are the ones who disbelieved and obstructed you from al-Masjid al-Haram} [Al-Fath: 25].

Also because this direction aligns with the interpretation of the Salaf (Predecessors) for the verse, for they said: {Wal-Masjidi Al-Harami} means: And averting from the Sacred Mosque (1). Therefore: Ibn Atiyyah's opinion is the preponderant one and Al-Samin's rectification upon him is not in place. As for what Al-Samin preferred, that {Wal-Masjidi Al-Harami} is conjoined to the Ha in {Bihi} meaning: And disbelief in Him and in the Sacred Mosque, it is correct from a grammatical perspective, but not every aspect valid in grammar is permissible in parsing the Quran; rather one must choose the parsing aspect appropriate to the meaning of the verse and its interpretation.

text:
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "His saying: {Qala Awa lam tu'min}: There are two aspects regarding this Waw. The more apparent of them: That it is for conjunction, preceded by the interrogative Hamza because it has priority in speech - as has been edited more than once -, and the Hamza here is for confirmation (Taqrir). The second: That it is the Waw of Hal, entered upon by the Alif of confirmation, said by Ibn Atiyyah. In this there is a point of view (criticism), from the perspective that if it were for Hal, the sentence after it would be in the place of Nasb (accusative), and if it were so, it would require an operator (Nasib), and there is no operator in the wording. So it must be estimated: The estimation is 'Did you ask while you have not believed?', so the Hamza in reality entered upon the operator in the Hal. This is not apparent; rather, the first is apparent. Therefore, it was answered with {Bala} (Yes), and according to what Ibn Atiyyah said, this meaning becomes difficult." (1)
Study of the Rectification:
The parsers discussed the Waw in His saying: {Awa lam tu'min} and they have two main opinions:
1 - That it is the Waw of Hal, entered upon by the Alif of confirmation. Said by: Ibn Atiyyah (2), and agreed upon by: Al-Qurtubi (3). Ibn Ashour clarified it saying: "The Waw in it is the Waw of Hal, and the Hamza is confirmation interrogation upon this state, and the operator of the Hal is an estimated verb indicated by his saying: {Arini}, and the estimation is: Do I show you in the state that you have not believed?" (4)

text: This opinion was weakened by a number of scholars, among them: Abu Hayyan (1), Al-Samin Al-Halabi (2), and Al-Tha'alibi (3). The weakness lies in that if the Waw is for Hal, it is not fitting for the operator in the Hal to be answered with His saying: {Bala} (Yes) (4). Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "In this there is a point of view (criticism), from the perspective that if it were for Hal, the sentence after it would be in the place of Nasb (accusative), and if it were so, it would require an operator (Nasib), and there is no operator in the wording. So it must be estimated: The estimation is 'Did you ask while you have not believed?', so the Hamza in reality entered upon the operator in the Hal. This is not apparent; rather, the first is apparent. Therefore, it was answered with {Bala} (Yes), and according to what Ibn Atiyyah said, this meaning becomes difficult." (5) What Al-Samin said is valid speech, but it does not necessitate that the estimation be: Did you ask while you have not believed? Rather, the estimation could be as Ibn Ashour said: Do I show you in the state that you have not believed?
