text:
Al-Shawkani said: "His saying: {Awa lam tu'min} is conjoined to an estimated element, i.e.: Did you not know, and did you not believe that I am capable of giving life so that you ask Me to show it? He said: Yes, I knew and believed that You are capable of that, but I asked so that my heart may be satisfied." (1)
Some of them said that the conjunction is on what preceded, and the Hamza is for interrogation and its original place is after the Waw, i.e.: Wa alam tu'min? (2)
The preponderant of these opinions: That the Waw is conjunctive, and conjoining to what preceded is better than conjoining to an estimated element, for one might estimate a verb that is not the intended one (3). Moreover, scholars differ in estimating that verb; since it is not textually stated, but rather depends on their understanding of the verse and its context. Therefore: Estimating the deleted sentence is not consistent (4). So it is more appropriate that the conjunction be on what preceded not on an estimated sentence, i.e.: Wa alam tu'min? This is the doctrine of the majority of grammarians regarding (Awa lama) and the like: That the Waw in it is a conjunction particle, and the sentence after the conjunction is conjoined to what is before it, and there is no deleted sentence between the Hamza and the conjunction (5). The Hamza is originally after the conjunction, but it was advanced to alert to its priority in starting speech (6). Therefore: Al-Samin's rectification upon Ibn Atiyyah is valid; since making the Waw for Hal is a far-fetched opinion as has been clarified.
* * *
[10]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {And it is not [possible] for one to die except by permission of Allah at a decree determined (kitaban mu'ajjalan). And whoever desires the reward of this world - We will give him thereof; and whoever desires the reward of the Hereafter - We will give him thereof. And we will reward the grateful} [Al Imran: 145]: "And His saying: {Kitaban} is Nasb (accusative) for specification (Tamyiz)." (1)
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "His saying: {Kitaban mu'ajjalan} in its Nasb there are three aspects. The most apparent of them: That it is a verbal noun (Masdar) confirming the content of the sentence before it. So its operator is hidden, estimated as: Kataba Allahu dhalika kitaban, like: {Sun'a Allah} [An-Naml: 88], {Wa'da Allah} [An-Nisa: 122], and {Kitaba Allah 'alaykum} [An-Nisa: 24]. The second: That it is accusative for specification (Tamyiz), mentioned by Ibn Atiyyah. This is not straight; because Tamyiz is transferred and non-transferred, and its types are limited and this is not one of them. Also, where is the ambiguous entity that needs explanation?" (2)
Study of the Rectification:
Scholars have three opinions regarding the Nasb of His saying: {Kitaban}:
First: That it is a verbal noun (Masdar) in accusative as an absolute object (Maf'ul Mutlaq), to confirm the content of what precedes it; meaning: Kataba al-mawta kitaban mu'ajjalan (He decreed death as a determined decree).

The preponderant view: That {Kitaban} is a verbal noun (Masdar) in accusative as an absolute object, to confirm the content of what precedes it. It is the most apparent parsing aspect, and consistent with the meaning of the verse. It is a confirmation that death is only by Allah's hand, and no one will die except by Allah's decree, and until he completes the term Allah has decreed for him. This verse contains encouragement for the cowardly and incitement for them to fight, for advancing and retreating does not decrease the lifespan nor increase it (1).
As for Ibn Atiyyah's opinion, it is weak from a grammatical perspective. As for the third opinion, it is far-fetched from a semantic perspective.

[11]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {And never think of those who have been killed in the cause of Allah as dead. Rather, they are alive with their Lord (Inda Rabbihim), receiving provision} [Al Imran: 169]: "And His saying: {Inda Rabbihim} contains a deleted annexed noun (Mudaf), its estimation is: At the honor of their Lord, because {Inda} implies utmost proximity." (1)
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "His saying: {Inda Rabbihim} has five aspects. One of them: That it is a second predicate for {Ahya'} according to the majority reading. Al-Samin mentioned the rest of the five aspects, until he said: 'Ibn Atiyyah said: "It is on the basis of a deleted annexed noun, i.e.: At the honor of their Lord" End quote. There is no need for it; because the first is more fitting'." (2)
Study of the Rectification:
The opinions of parsers multiplied regarding the parsing of His saying: {Inda Rabbihim}, such that the majority mentioned several aspects in its parsing without preference. The total opinions on that are six, as follows:

Deletion is contrary to the principle (1); so there is no need to say there is a deleted annexed noun as long as the phrase is correct without estimating an annexed noun. The 'With-ness' (Indiyyah) as in His saying: (Inda Rabbihim) intends Nearness (Al-Qurb) (2), so it includes the meaning of honor without the need to estimate an annexed noun. 'Indiyyah' has appeared frequently in the Quran in various subjects, as in His saying about the angels: {Indeed, those who are near your Lord (Inda Rabbika) are not prevented by arrogance from His worship} [Al-A'raf: 206], and His saying: {And those near Him (Wa man 'indahu) are not prevented by arrogance from His worship} [Al-Anbiya': 19], and His saying: {Then those who are near your Lord (Inda Rabbika) exalt Him by night and day} [Fussilat: 38]. All this is regarding the nearness of the angels to Allah Almighty. Al-Fakhr Al-Razi mentioned a benefit regarding the 'with-ness' of martyrs and 'with-ness' of angels, saying: "('Inda) just as it is mentioned here, so too in the description of angels it is mentioned, which is His saying: {And those near Him are not prevented by arrogance from His worship} [Al-Anbiya': 19]. So if you understand the happiness obtained for the angels by being with Allah, you understand the happiness obtained for the martyrs by being with Allah. These are words that open for the intellect the doors of knowledge of the Hereafter." (3)

[12]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {So for their breaking of the covenant We cursed them and made their hearts hard. They distort words from their [proper] usages and have forgotten a portion of that of which they were reminded. And you will still observe deceit among them, except a few of them} [Al-Ma'idah: 13]: "He - Blessed and Exalted - excepted from them the few, so it is possible that the exception is in persons, and it is possible that it is in actions." Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "His saying: {Illa qalilan} is accusative for exception. Regarding the excepted from (Mustathna minhu), there are four opinions. The most apparent of them: That it is the word {Kha'inatin} (deceit/treachery), and they are the persons mentioned in the sentence before it, i.e.: You will still observe those who betray among them except the few, for they do not betray so you do not observe them. The second: Ibn Atiyyah mentioned that it is the Action, i.e.: You will still observe the act of treachery except a few acts. This is clear if Treachery is intended as an attribute of the estimated singular act as preceded, but what Ibn Atiyyah said is made unlikely by His saying after it {Minhum}. The third: That it is {Qulubahum} in His saying: {Wa ja'alna qulubahum qasiyatan}. The author of this opinion said: The intended by them are the believers, because hardness was removed from their hearts. This has great distance, due to His saying: {La'annahum}. The fourth: That it is the pronoun in {Minhum} from His saying - the Exalted -: {Ala kha'inatin minhum}, said by Makki (1)." (2)
Study of the Rectification:
The exegetes and parsers discussed the exception in His saying: {Wa la tazalu tattali'u 'ala kha'inatin minhum illa qalilan minhum}. In this issue there are five opinions:
1 - That the exception is in persons. The meaning: Except a few of them did not betray and did not break the covenant, and they are those who embraced Islam among them. It is possible that this few are from those who remained on their disbelief but did not betray.

This is the opinion of the majority of exegetes (1). They did not explicitly state whether the excepted from is the word {Kha'inatin} or the pronoun in Minhum. They mentioned the two probable opinions in {Kha'inatin}: That it is a verbal noun meaning treachery, or the intended is a treacherous group. It was narrated from Mujahid that the intended by His saying {Kha'inatin}: A treacherous group; because the verse is about the Jews (2). Al-Raghib Al-Isfahani said: "His saying: {Wa la tazalu tattali'u 'ala kha'inatin minhum illa qalilan minhum} i.e.: A small group." (3) Al-Baghawi said: "{Illa qalilan minhum} did not betray and did not break the covenant, and they are those who embraced Islam from the People of the Scripture." (4)
2 - That the exception is from the Ha and Mim in {Kha'inatin minhum}.

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
Al-Samin said: "Regarding the excepted from, there are four opinions. The most apparent of them: That it is the word {Kha'inatin}, and they are the persons mentioned in the sentence before it, i.e.: You will still observe whoever betrays among them except the few, for they do not betray so you do not observe them." (1)
4 - That the exception is in actions, i.e.: You will still observe the act of treachery except a few acts. Ibn Atiyyah mentioned this as a probable aspect (2), and Al-Samin Al-Halabi weakened it. Al-Samin said: "What Ibn Atiyyah said is made unlikely by His saying after it {Minhum}." (3) Meaning that His saying: {Minhum} (of them) implies that the exception is in persons not actions. This opinion is also weakened by the fact that the preponderant view regarding the meaning of His saying: {Kha'inatin}: A treacherous group. Al-Tabari said: "That is because the report began about their group, so it was said: {O you who have believed, remember the favor of Allah upon you when a people determined to extend their hands against you} [Al-Ma'idah: 11], then it was said: {Wa la tazalu tattali'u 'ala kha'inatin minhum}. Since the beginning was about the group, concluding with the group is more appropriate." (4)
5 - That the exception is from {Qulubahum} in His saying: {Wa ja'alna qulubahum qasiyatan}. Some scholars mentioned it and weakened it (5).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah regarding Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Parsing: Collection and Study
text:
Abu Hayyan said: "It was said: The exception is from His saying: {Wa ja'alna qulubahum qasiyatan}, and the intended by it is the believers, for hardness was removed from their hearts. This is far-fetched." (1) It is very weak and not apparent, especially with the long separation between the excepted and the excepted from, and because making their hearts hard is a branch of {Naqdihim mithaqahum} (their breaking of their covenant), and breaking the covenant necessitates hardness definitely (2).
The first three opinions are the strongest and most apparent, and all of them lead to one meaning which is that the exception is in persons not actions. As for the fourth opinion which Ibn Atiyyah considered probable and Al-Samin weakened, it has weakness for the reasons explained. As for the fifth opinion, it is the weakest of opinions and has no aspect strengthening it, and no scholar preferred it, and those who pointed to it weakened it. Therefore: Al-Samin's exclusion of the opinion mentioned by Ibn Atiyyah is in place, except that Ibn Atiyyah did not err by mentioning this opinion - that the exception is in actions -; for he mentioned it as a probability and did not start with it nor prefer it.
* * *
[13]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {He said, "Is it other than Allah I should desire for you as a god while He has preferred you over the worlds?"} [Al-A'raf: 140]: "{Abghikum} means: I seek for you, from 'Baghaytu al-shay'a' if I sought it. And {Ghayra} is accusative (Nasb) by a hidden verb, this is the apparent view. It is possible that it is accusative as a Hal, as if the estimation of speech is: He said I desire for you a god other than Allah, so it is in the place of the attribute, so when it was advanced it was put in accusative as a Hal." (1)
Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "In the Nasb of {Ghayra} there are two aspects. One of them: That it is an object (Maf'ul bihi) ... for {Abghikum} on the deletion of the Lam, estimation: Abghi lakum ghayra Allah (I seek for you other than Allah), i.e.: I seek for you. When the particle was deleted, the verb connected directly, which is not by analogy. The second of the two aspects of {Ghayra}: That it is accusative as Hal from {Ilahan}, and {Ilahan} is the object of {Abghikum} as established. The origin: I seek for you a god other than Allah. So {Ghayra Allah} is an attribute for (Ilah), so when the attribute of the indefinite noun was advanced over it, it was put in accusative as a Hal. Ibn Atiyyah said: 'And {Ghayra} is accusative by a hidden verb, this is the apparent view, and it is permissible to be a Hal' End quote. This which he mentioned of hiding the verb, there is no need for it. If he meant that it is on Ishtighal (Preoccupation), it is not correct; because its condition is that the explanatory [verb] operates in the pronoun of the first or its connection." (2)

text: And Al-Samin said: "Regarding the 'exempted-from' (Al-Mustathna minhu), there are four opinions. The most apparent of them: It is the word {a treacherous one} (khā'inatin), referring to the persons mentioned in the sentence before it. Meaning: You will not cease to discover those who betray among them, except a few, for they do not betray, so you will not discover it about them." End quote (1). 4 - That the exception is in the actions. Meaning: You will not cease to discover the act of treachery, except a few acts. Ibn Atiyyah mentioned this as a probable aspect (2), and Al-Samin Al-Halabi weakened it. Al-Samin said: "What makes what Ibn Atiyyah said unlikely is his saying after it {from them} (minhum)." End quote (3). Meaning that his saying: {from them} indicates that the exception is regarding the persons, not the actions. This opinion is also weakened by the fact that the preferred meaning of his saying: {khā'inatin} is: a treacherous group. Al-Tabari said: "That is because the news began regarding their group/community, for it was said: {O you who have believed, remember the favor of Allah upon you when a people determined to extend their hands against you} [Al-Ma'idah: 11], then it was said: {And you will still observe deceit among them}, so since the beginning was about the group, concluding with the group is more appropriate." End quote (4). 5 - That the exception is from {their hearts} in his saying: {And We made their hearts hard}. This was mentioned by some scholars and they weakened it (5).

text: Abu Hayyan said: "It was said: The exception is from his saying: {And We made their hearts hard}, and the intended meaning is the believers, for the hardness was removed from their hearts, but this is far-fetched." End quote (1). Thus, it is very weak and not apparent, especially given the long separation between the exempted and the exempted-from, and because making their hearts hard is a branch of {their breaking of their covenant}, and breaking the covenant necessitates hardness absolutely (2). The first three opinions are the strongest and most apparent, and all of them lead to one meaning, which is that the exception is regarding persons, not actions. As for the fourth opinion, which Ibn Atiyyah made a probable opinion and Al-Samin weakened, it contains weakness for the reasons that have been explained. As for the fifth opinion, it is the weakest of the opinions and has no aspect to strengthen it, and no scholar has preferred it; those who pointed to it weakened it. Therefore: Al-Samin's dismissal of the opinion mentioned by Ibn Atiyyah is in its place, except that Ibn Atiyyah did not err by mentioning this opinion—that the exception is in the actions—; for he mentioned it as a probability and did not begin with it nor did he prefer it. * * *

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: [13]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {He said, "Is it other than Allah I should seek for you as a deity while He has preferred you over the worlds?"} [Al-A'raf: 140]: "{I seek for you} (Abghikum) means: I seek for you, from 'I sought the thing' (baghaytu) when I requested it. And {other} (ghayra) is in the accusative case (mansub) due to a hidden verb; this is what is apparent. It is also possible that it is in the accusative as a circumstantial state (Hal), as if the estimation of the speech is: 'He said, do I seek for you a deity other than Allah?', so it was in the place of an adjective, but when it was advanced, it was put in the accusative as a circumstantial state." End quote (1). And Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "In the accusative case of {other} (ghayra) there are two aspects. One of them: That it is a direct object... for {I seek for you} (Abghikum) upon the deletion of the 'Lam' (preposition 'for'), the estimation is: 'I seek for you other than Allah' (Abghi lakum ghayra Allahi), meaning: I request for you. So when the preposition was deleted, the verb connected directly, which is not analogously standard. The second of the two aspects for {other} (ghayra): That it is accusative as a circumstantial state (Hal) from {a deity} (ilahan), and {a deity} is the direct object of {I seek for you} according to what has been established. The original structure is: 'I seek for you a deity other than Allah', so {other than Allah} is an adjective for (deity), but when the adjective of the indefinite noun was advanced upon it, it was put in the accusative as a circumstantial state. Ibn Atiyyah said: 'And {other} is accusative due to a hidden verb; this is what is apparent, and it is permissible for it to be a circumstantial state.' End quote. And this which he mentioned regarding the hiding of the verb, there is no need for it. If he intended that it is based on 'Occupancy' (Ishtighal), then it is not valid; because its condition is that the explanatory verb governs the pronoun of the first noun or something connected to it." End quote (2).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Study of the Rectification: First: The sayings of the scholars regarding the syntax (I'rab) of (other) {ghayra} from His saying - the Exalted -: {He said, "Is it other than Allah I should seek for you as a deity"}: They have four opinions on this: 1 - That His saying: {ghayra} is accusative as a circumstantial state (Hal); because if an adjective advances upon the qualified noun, it becomes accusative as a circumstantial state. So his saying: {ghayra} is an adjective that advanced upon the qualified noun {a deity} (ilahan), so it became accusative as a Hal. This was said by: Abdul Rahman Al-Anbari (1), and a number of scholars mentioned it as a probable aspect, among them: Ibn Atiyyah (2), Al-Baquli (3), Al-Fakhr Al-Razi (4), Al-Muntajib Al-Hamadhani (5), and others (6). Abdul Rahman Al-Anbari said: "{Other than Allah} (ghayra Allahi) is accusative as a Hal; because if the adjective of an indefinite noun advances upon it, it becomes accusative as a Hal." End quote (7). And Al-Baquli said: "And it is not permissible for {ghayra} to be an adjective for {a deity}; because the adjective does not precede the qualified noun." End quote (8).

text: ...the explaining sentence has no link in it, neither a pronoun nor a connected element that links it to {ghayra}. If the structure was: 'Is it other than Allah that I seek [it] for you' (A ghayra Allahi abghikumuh), it would be valid." End quote (1). And Al-Samin said, commenting on Ibn Atiyyah's statement: "And this which he mentioned regarding the hiding of the verb, there is no need for it. If he intended that it is based on 'Occupancy' (Ishtighal), then it is not valid; because its condition is that the explanatory verb governs the pronoun of the first noun or something connected to it." End quote (2). And what Al-Samin said has been stated by the grammarians in their discussion on Ishtighal (3). He means by that that the pronoun in {I seek for you} (abghikum) is not the first one that Ibn Atiyyah estimated as accusative by a verb explained by what follows it. If the explainer was: 'I seek [it] for you' (abghikumuh), that would be valid; because it would contain the link that binds it to {ghayra}. 4 - That His saying: {ghayra} is a direct object advanced for the verb (I seek) [abghi], meaning: Do I seek for you other than Allah? This was said by: Abu Al-Baqaa (4), Al-Samin Al-Halabi (5), Abu Al-Saud (6), Al-Shawkani (7), and others (8).

text: Abu Al-Saud said: "And the accusative status of {ghayra} is on the basis that it is the direct object of (I seek) [abghi], with the deletion of the 'Lam', meaning: 'I seek for you', i.e., 'I request for you other than Allah - the Exalted -'." End quote (1). Second: Weighting (Tarjih): The fourth opinion, which is that his saying {ghayra} is a direct object for the verb mentioned after it {I seek for you}, is the clearest of the opinions and closest to the apparent meaning of the verse, and there is no hidden estimation in it. As for making {ghayra} a circumstantial state (Hal), it is not impossible, except that the advancement of the adjective over the qualified noun and its becoming accusative as a Hal is contrary to the original rule and is rare (2). As for the accusative status of {ghayra} as an exception, it has nothing to strengthen it, and for that reason, the majority of syntacticians turned away from mentioning it. As for the accusative status of {ghayra} as a direct object for a hidden verb—which is the opinion Ibn Atiyyah began with—it is the weakest of the opinions; since hiding and estimation are contrary to the original rule and there is no need for it here. Furthermore...

Therefore: Al-Samin's rectification of Ibn Atiyyah is in its place, especially since he [Ibn Atiyyah] started with the weakest of the opinions, to the extent that the majority of syntacticians who mentioned more than one aspect in the syntax of {ghayra} did not point to this opinion. * * *

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: [14]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {And We made an appointment with Moses for thirty nights and perfected them by ten; so the term of his Lord was completed as forty nights} [Al-A'raf: 142]: "And {forty} (arba'in) in this verse is in the position of a circumstantial state (Hal), and it is valid for {forty} to be an adverb (Zarf) from the perspective that it is a number of times." End quote (1). And Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "In the accusative status of {forty}, there are aspects. One of them: That it is a Hal. Al-Zamakhshari said: '{Forty} is accusative as a Hal, meaning: completed reaching this number.' End quote (2). The Sheikh [Abu Hayyan] said: 'So based on this, the Hal is not {forty}, rather the Hal is this deleted element, so it contradicts his statement.' End quote (3). I say: There is no contradiction in it; because the grammarians have never ceased attributing the ruling to the remaining agent after the deletion of its factor which it substitutes. There are evidences for this, among them: 'Zaid fi al-dar' (Zaid is in the house) or 'indaka' (with you), so they say: The preposition/phrase and the adverb are the predicate (Khabar), while the predicate in reality is the estimated event which governs them. Likewise, they say: 'Ja'a Zaid bi-thiyabihi' (Zaid came with his clothes), 'with his clothes' is a Hal, while the Hal is actually the factor governing it, and so on. Al-Farisi estimated it as (numbered) [ma'dudan], saying: 'Like your saying: The people completed twenty men, meaning: numbered this number' End quote (4), and it is a good estimation. The second: That {forty} is accusative as a direct object. Abu Al-Baqaa said: 'Because its meaning is: reached (balagha), so it is like their saying: Your land reached two Jaribs (5)' End quote (6), meaning implying (completed) [tamma] with the meaning of (reached).
foot_note:
1. Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (2: 449).
2. Tafsir Al-Zamakhshari (2: 151).
3. Tafsir Abi Hayyan (5: 161).
4. I did not find this saying in the printed books of Al-Farisi.
5. Al-Jarib of land is a known measure of area and size, and it is ten Qafiz. See: Tahdhib Al-Lughah, by Al-Azhari, entry: Jarab (11: 37), Taj Al-Arus, by Al-Zubaidi, entry: Jarab (2: 147).
6. Al-Tibyan fi I'rab Al-Qur'an (1: 593).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: The third: That it is accusative as an adverb (Zarf). Ibn Atiyyah said: "And it is valid for {forty} to be an adverb from the perspective that it is a number of times" End quote. There is a point of view regarding this; how can it be an adverb for the completion (Tamam), when the completion is only by the last part of those times? Unless by a far-fetched metaphor: which is that every part of the parts of the time, whether it is the first or the last, if it is missing, the completion is gone. The fourth: That it is accusative as a specification (Tamyez). The Sheikh [Abu Hayyan] said: "The original is: 'So forty completed the term of his Lord' (fa tamma arba'una miqata rabbihi), then the completion was attributed to the term, and (forty) became accusative as a Tamyez" End quote (1). So it is transferred from being the subject (Fa'il), meaning it would be like His saying: {And the head flared with hoariness} [Maryam: 4]. And this which he said and made apparent is problematic due to what he himself mentioned in refuting Al-Hawfi, where he said there: That the thirty were not deficient so as to be completed (2). Likewise, it should be said here that the forty were not deficient so as to be completed, so how can he estimate: 'So forty completed the term of his Lord'? If he answers here with an answer, it is an answer there to whoever objected to him." End quote (3). Study of the Rectification: First: The sayings of the scholars regarding the syntax of {forty} from His saying: {so the term of his Lord was completed as forty nights}: 1 - That {forty} is accusative as a circumstantial state (Hal) from the term (Miqat), meaning: So the term of his Lord was completed reaching this number, or: So the term of his Lord was completed numbered forty nights.

text: Makki said: "The forty was put in the accusative on the basis that it is in the position of a Hal, as if he said: So the term of his Lord was completed numbered forty nights, or estimated at this amount." End quote (1). Al-Anbari said: "{Forty nights} is accusative as a Hal, as if he said: So the term of his Lord was completed numbered forty nights." End quote (2). Abu Hayyan weakened this aspect, saying: "So based on this, the Hal is not {forty}, rather the Hal is this deleted element, so it contradicts his statement." End quote (3). Al-Samin replied to Abu Hayyan that there is no contradiction in Al-Zamakhshari's statement; because the grammarians attribute the ruling to the remaining agent after the deletion of its factor which it substitutes (4). 2 - That {forty} is a direct object for the verb (completed) [tamma] which is intransitive; because it implies the meaning of the verb (reached) [balagha] which is transitive. This was said by: Abu Al-Baqaa (5), Al-Muntajib Al-Hamadhani (6), and others (7) as a probable aspect. Al-Muntajib said regarding the aspects of the accusative status of {forty}: "On the basis that it is a direct object for his saying: (so it was completed) based on implying (completed) the meaning of: reached.

text: If you say: What led you to this implication, and why didn't you leave it as it is and put the forty in the accusative as some claimed? I say: What led me to that is its lack of transitivity; because (completed) [tamma] is an intransitive verb, and (reached) [balagha] is in its meaning, and it is transitive." End quote (1). 3 - That {forty} is an adverb (Zarf) from the perspective that it is a number of times. This was allowed by: Al-Kirmani (2), and Ibn Atiyyah (3). It was weakened by Al-Samin Al-Halabi and others (4). Al-Samin said: "There is a point of view regarding this; how can it be an adverb for the completion, when the completion is only by the last part of those times? Unless by a far-fetched metaphor: which is that every part of the parts of the time, whether it is the first or the last, if it is missing, the completion is gone." End quote (5). 4 - That {forty} is a specification (Tamyez) transformed from the subject (Fa'il), and its original is: 'So forty completed the term of his Lord', meaning perfected, then the completion was attributed to the term, and (forty) became accusative as a Tamyez. This was said by: Abu Hayyan (6).

text: And Al-Samin commented on it saying: "And this which he said and made apparent is problematic due to what he himself mentioned in refuting Al-Hawfi, where he said there: That the thirty were not deficient so as to be completed, likewise it should be said here: That the forty were not deficient so as to be completed, so how can he estimate: 'So forty completed the term of his Lord'? If he answers here with an answer, it is an answer there to whoever objected to him." End quote (1). Second: Weighting (Tarjih): It is correct for his saying: {forty} to be a circumstantial state (Hal), meaning: So the term of his Lord was completed numbered forty nights, and it has been established in the science of syntax that the Hal can be indicative of a number, and {forty} here is a Hal indicative of a number (2). And (forty) here is a Hal; because it indicates the condition/form in which that completion occurred. It is also valid for {forty} to be a direct object based on implying (completed) the meaning of: reached. text: [15]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {Allah has already given you victory in many places, and [on] the day of Hunayn, when your great number pleased you, but it did not avail you at all} [At-Tawbah: 25]: "{And the day of} (wa yawma) is conjoined to the position of His saying: {in places} (fi mawatin), or to the word itself with the estimation: 'and in the day of', so the preposition was deleted." End quote (1). And Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "{And the day of Hunayn}: In it are aspects. One of them: That it is conjoined to the locus of His saying: {in places}, conjoining the adverb of time without the mediation of (fi/in) to the adverb of place governed by it. And there is no wonder in coordinating an adverb of time to a place or the opposite. You say: 'I walked in front of you on Friday', except that it is better for the conjunction to be left like it [matching]. The second: Ibn Atiyyah claimed that it is permissible to be conjoined to the wording of {places} with the estimation: 'and in', so he deleted the preposition, and there is no need for this." End quote (2).

text: Study of the Rectification: The subject of this rectification is the syntax of His saying: {And the day of Hunayn} (wa yawma Hunayn), and the scholars have four opinions on this issue: 1 - That {the day} (yawma) is conjoined to the locus of {in places} (fi mawatin), and the meaning is: And He gave you victory on the day of Hunayn. This was said by: Makki bin Abi Talib (1), Al-Kirmani (2), Abdul Rahman Al-Anbari (3), Abu Al-Baqaa (4), Al-Samin (5), and others (6). Makki said: "{The day} was put in the accusative based on conjunction to the position of {in many places} (7), its estimation is: And He gave you victory on the day of Hunayn." End quote (8). And this is the most apparent of the aspects, and I did not find anyone among the scholars who weakened it. 2 - That {the day} is accusative by a hidden verb, and the estimation is: And [He gave you victory] the day of Hunayn.

text: This was said by: Al-Zamakhshari (1), Ibn Juzayy (2), and others (3). Al-Zamakhshari said in his argument for this aspect: "It is obligatory that {and the day of Hunayn} be accusative by a hidden verb, not by this apparent one, and the reason for that is that His saying: {when your great number pleased you} is a substitute (Badal) for {and the day of Hunayn}, so if you made its governor this apparent one, it would not be valid, because their number did not please them in all those places, and they were not many in all of them, so it remains that its governor is a verb specific to it." End quote (4). Ibn Juzayy said: "And this is better for two reasons: One of them: That His saying: {when your great number pleased you} is specific to Hunayn, and is not valid in other places; so conjoining {the day of Hunayn} to the places is weakened; due to the difference between them in that regard. The other: That places is an adverb of place, and {the day of Hunayn} is an adverb of time, so conjoining one of them to the other is weakened, unless he intended by the places the times." End quote (5). And this was refuted by stating that substituting His saying: {when your great number pleased you} from it does not prevent it from being conjoined to the position of {in places}, for it does not necessitate their sharing in what the conjoined noun was added to...

text: necessitates their number and their being pleased with it in all places; for coordination does not require the sharing of the coordinated terms in everything established for the antecedent (1). As for the coordination of time to place and vice versa, it is permissible according to the preferred opinion and there is no impediment to it as long as ambiguity is avoided, like: 'I met you in front of your house *this* [place] and *on* Thursday' [time] (2). Al-Samin considered Al-Zamakhshari's opinion good and explained it, then he rectified it saying: 'And its estimation is that the verb is restricted by the adverb of place, so if we make {when} (idh) a substitute (Badal) for {the day} (yawma), it becomes governed by it; because the substitute takes the place of the substituted-from. This necessitates that He gave them victory *when* their great number pleased them in many places, while the premise is that in some of these places they were not in this state [of great number/pride], unless it could be argued that He - the Exalted - did not say: 'in *all* places', so that what he [Al-Zamakhshari] said would be necessary.' End quote (3). 3 - That {the day} is conjoined to the word {places} (mawatin), with the estimation: 'and in the day of', so the preposition was deleted. Ibn Atiyyah mentioned this (4), and Al-Samin Al-Halabi considered it unlikely and said: 'And there is no need for this.' End quote (5). The aspect of its weakness is that {places} is genitive due to {in} (fi), and {the day} is accusative as an adverb, so if it were conjoined to it, it would have been genitive (6).

text: 4 - That {the day} (yawma) is a direct object for a deleted verb estimated as: Remember (udhkur), meaning: And remember the day of Hunayn. This was said by: Al-Baquli (1), Al-Fakhr Al-Razi (2), and others (3). Al-Fakhr Al-Razi said: "Meaning: And remember the day of Hunayn from among those places, at the time when your great number pleased you." End quote (4). The Preferred View: That {the day} is conjoined to the position/locus of {in places} (fi mawatin), and the estimation is: And He gave you victory on the day of Hunayn; for this is the most correct of the aspects due to its soundness regarding both meaning and grammatical structure. It is also valid for {the day} to be accusative by a hidden verb estimated as: 'And He gave you victory', even if there is some debate in the words of those who chose this aspect, yet its meaning ultimately returns to the same meaning as the preferred opinion: 'And He gave you victory on the day of Hunayn'. As for the opinion that {the day} is an object for an estimated verb: 'Remember', it is a probable opinion, but there is no necessity here requiring the hiding of a verb estimated as: 'Remember'. As for coordination to the word {places}—which is the aspect Ibn Atiyyah mentioned—it is the weakest of the opinions; because the word {places} is genitive, and {the day} is accusative, so if it were conjoined to it, it would have come as genitive. Therefore: Al-Samin's rectification of Ibn Atiyyah is in its place, for the coordination here is not to the genitive word {places}, but to the accusative locus of {in places} as an adverb. * * *

text: [16]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {The example of the two parties is like the blind and the deaf, and the seeing and the hearing. Are they equal in example? Then will you not remember?} [Hud: 24]: "{In example} (mathalan) is accusative as specification (Tamyez), and it is permissible for it to be a circumstantial state (Hal)." End quote (1). And Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "His saying: {mathalan} is Tamyez, and it is transferred from the subject (Fa'il), and the original is: 'Does their example (mathaluhuma) equal?', like His saying - the Exalted -: {And the head flared with hoariness} [Maryam: 4]. And Ibn Atiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, allowed it to be a Hal, but this contains far-fetchedness in structure and meaning; because it is based on the meaning of 'from' (min), not on the meaning of 'in' (fi)." End quote (2). Study of the Rectification: The subject of this rectification is the syntax of {mathalan}, where both Ibn Atiyyah and Al-Samin held that it is Tamyez, except that Ibn Atiyyah allowed another aspect, which is that it is a Hal, and Al-Samin considered that unlikely. There are two aspects in the syntax of {mathalan}: First: That it is Tamyez transferred from the subject, and the meaning is: Does the example of the two equal? This was said by the majority, among them: Ibn Atiyyah (3), Abu Al-Baqaa (4), Al-Muntajib Al-Hamadhani (5), Al-Qurtubi (6), Al-Samin (7), Al-Shawkani (8), and others (9).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: The second: That it is a circumstantial state (Hal). This was said by Makki bin Abi Talib (1), and allowed by Ibn Atiyyah (2). Abu Hayyan considered it unlikely but did not explain the reason for its unlikelihood (3). Al-Samin Al-Halabi explained that by saying it contains far-fetchedness in structure and meaning; because here it is based on the meaning of 'from' (min), not on the meaning of 'in' (fi) (4). Meaning that Tamyez is based on the meaning of 'min', and Hal is based on the meaning of 'fi', and the meaning here is: Are the two equal *regarding* (min) example? So it is Tamyez, not Hal. And what Al-Samin said contains some room for debate; because it is not impossible for the meaning here to be: Are the two equal *in* the example? Some exegetes have stated this meaning, such as Al-Wahidi (5), Ibn Al-Jawzi (6), and others (7).

text: However, its being Tamyez remains the more apparent and stronger aspect. What strengthens it being Tamyez and not Hal is: its being indefinite and non-derivative (jameed), while the Hal usually comes as a derivative indicating conditions/forms as established in the science of syntax (1). Also, {... mathalan} here is accusative as Tamyez from the subject of {Are they equal} (yastawiyan) (2), and the subject is an entity, not a condition. Noting that the aspect which Ibn Atiyyah allowed here, he did not allow in other similar places, as in His saying - the Exalted -: {Allah presents an example: a man owned by quarreling partners and another belonging exclusively to one man - are they equal in example?} [Az-Zumar: 29], where he mentioned one aspect for the syntax of (mathalan), which is accusative as Tamyez (3). * * * [17]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {Indeed in that is a sign for those who fear the punishment of the Hereafter. That is a Day for which the people will be collected, and that is a Day witnessed} [Hud: 103]: "The meaning: Indeed, in these villages and what befell them is a lesson and a sign of guidance for whoever fears the matter of the Hereafter, and expects that its punishment will reach him, so he looks and contemplates, for his looking leads him to faith in Allah - the Exalted -. Then Allah magnified the matter of the Day of Resurrection by describing it with what is attached to something foreign...

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: ...to it, due to the connection between them, and the pronoun refers back to it. And {the people} (An-Nas) - based on this - is an object whose agent is not named (passive subject). It is also valid for {the people} to be nominative by inchoation (Mubtada) and {collected} (majmu'un) to be a fronted predicate." End quote (1). And Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "{That} is a reference to the Day of Resurrection, indicated by the context from His saying: {punishment of the Hereafter}. And {collected} is an adjective/attribute for {a Day}, which applies to other than what it belongs to [grammatically], so for that reason it raised the apparent noun which is {the people}. This syntax is like: 'I passed by a man whose slave was beaten'. Ibn Atiyyah analyzed {the people} as a delayed subject and {collected} as its fronted predicate, and in this there is weakness; for if it were so, it would have been said: 'majmu'un' (plural), just as one says: 'The people are standing (qa'imun) and beaten (madrubun)', and one does not say: 'standing (singular) and beaten (singular)' except with weakness. And based on his syntax, it requires the deletion of a returning pronoun, since the sentence is an attribute for the Day, which is the Ha in 'lahu' (for it), meaning: The people are collected for it. And {witnessed} (mashhud) is determined to be an attribute; so likewise is what precedes it." End quote (2). Study of the Rectification: First: The sayings of the syntacticians regarding the syntax of His saying - the Exalted -: {That is a Day for which the people will be collected}: 1 - That {That} is a subject, and {a Day} is its predicate, and {collected} is an attribute for {a Day}, and {for it} (lahu) is connected to the passive participle {collected}, and {the people} is the deputy agent (Na'ib Fa'il) for the passive participle. This is the opinion of the majority (3).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Al-Nahhas said: "{That is a Day} is a subject and predicate, {collected} is one of its attributes, {the people} is the name of what has not been named its agent (passive subject), and for this reason He did not say: 'majmu'un' (plural)." End quote (1). And Al-Muntajib Al-Hamadhani said: "{collected} is an attribute for the Day, and {the people} is raised by the passive participle which is {collected} in the manner of the passive verb (what has not been named its agent), just as it is raised by its verb if you said: The people are collected for it (yujma'u lahu al-nas), and {for it} (lahu) is part of the connection of {collected}." End quote (2). 2 - That his saying: {the people} is a delayed subject, and {collected} is a fronted predicate. Allowed by: Ibn Atiyyah (3), and weakened by more than one of the syntacticians (4), among them: Al-Samin Al-Halabi, where he said: "And in it there is weakness; for if it were so, it would have been said: 'majmu'un' (plural), just as one says: 'The people are standing and beaten', and one does not say: 'standing (singular) and beaten (singular)' except with weakness.

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: And based on his syntax, it requires the deletion of a returning pronoun, since the sentence is an attribute for the Day, which is the Ha in {for it} (lahu), meaning: The people are collected for it. And {witnessed} (mashhud) is determined to be an attribute for the Day, so likewise is what precedes it {collected}." End quote (1). Second: The Preferred Opinion: What the majority said is the apparent and preferred view, so {collected} is an attribute for the Day, and {the people} is a deputy agent. As for Ibn Atiyyah's statement that {the people} is a delayed subject and {collected} is a fronted predicate, it contains far-fetchedness; because if it were so, it would have been said: 'majmu'un' (plural) (2), just as it is said: The people are gathered (majmu'un); this is the standard analogy based on Ibn Atiyyah's syntax. Al-Farra said: "If you want the plural of a dispersed thing, you say: 'Jama'tu al-qawm' (I gathered the people), so they are 'majmu'un' (gathered)." End quote (3). So if the sentence consisted of a subject and predicate as Ibn Atiyyah said, it would have been said: 'majmu'un', just as it is said about the people: they are 'majmu'un', not they are 'majmu'' (singular). The other reason mentioned by Al-Samin in his weakening of Ibn Atiyyah's opinion—that based on his syntax it requires deleting a returning pronoun because the sentence is an attribute for the Day, and the returner is the Ha in {lahu}, meaning: The people are collected for it, and {witnessed} is determined to be an attribute for the Day so likewise what is before it {collected}—is a valid reason. Therefore: Al-Samin's rectification of Ibn Atiyyah is in its place, and the opinion of the majority is the correct one. * * *

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: [18]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {Kill Joseph or cast him out to [another] land; the countenance of your father will [then] be only yours, and you will be after that a righteous people} [Yusuf: 9]: "And {a land} (ardan) is a second object by dropping the preposition, because (taraha) [cast] does not transit to two objects except in this way. And a group said: It is accusative as an adverb (Zarf), and that is a mistake; because the adverb should be ambiguous (mubham), and this one here is not so, rather it is a land restricted by being far or distant and the like, so its ambiguity was removed by that. And it is known that Joseph was not devoid of being in a land, so it became clear that it is a far land other than the one he is in close to his father." End quote (1). And Al-Samin Al-Halabi said regarding the aspects of the accusative status of {ardan}: "The second: Accusative as an adverb of place. Al-Zamakhshari said: '{ardan}: An indefinite, unknown land, far from civilization; this is the meaning of its being indefinite and devoid of people. And due to its ambiguity from this perspective, it was put in the accusative as ambiguous adverbs are.' End quote (2). Ibn Atiyyah rejected this aspect and said: 'And that is a mistake; because the adverb should be ambiguous, and this is not so, rather it is a land restricted by being far or distant or the like, so its ambiguity was removed by that. And it is known that Joseph was not devoid of being in a land, so it became clear that they intended a far land other than the one he is in close to his father.' End quote (3).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: The Sheikh [Abu Hayyan] approved this rejection and said: 'And this rejection is correct if you said: I sat [in] a far house (jalastu daran ba'idatan) or a far place, it would not be valid except with the medium of (fi), nor is its deletion permissible except in poetic necessity, or with (dakhaltu) [I entered] regarding the disagreement about (dakhaltu), is it intransitive or transitive?' End quote (1). I say: And in both statements there is a point of view; for the ambiguous adverb (Zarf Mubham) is an expression for what has no boundaries confining it nor diameters containing it, and {ardan} in the noble verse is of this type." End quote (2). Study of the Rectification: The subject of this rectification is the syntax of His saying: {ardan}, and on this issue, the syntacticians have three opinions. Ibn Atiyyah mentioned two of them and weakened one, and Al-Samin mentioned the three opinions and refuted Ibn Atiyyah's weakening of one of the opinions as will follow. First: The opinions on the syntax of {ardan}: 1 - That {ardan} is accusative due to the removal of the genitive particle (fi), meaning: in a land. This was said by: Al-Akhfash (3), Al-Nahhas (4), Al-Khatib (5) Al-Tabrizi (6), and others (7).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Al-Zamakhshari said: "{ardan} is indefinite, unknown, far from civilization; this is the meaning of its being indefinite and devoid of description. And due to its ambiguity from this perspective, it was put in the accusative as ambiguous adverbs are." End quote (1). And Al-Anbari said: "{ardan} is accusative on the basis that it is an adverb of place, and {cast him} transited to it while being intransitive [regarding place], because it is an ambiguous adverb of place, and it has no boundaries confining it, nor an end encompassing it." End quote (2). A number of syntacticians weakened this aspect, among them: Al-Akhfash (3), Al-Nahhas (4), Makki bin Abi Talib (5), Ibn Atiyyah (6), and Abu Hayyan (7). The reason for their weakening of this aspect: That the adverb should be ambiguous, and this is not so, rather it is a land restricted by being far or distant. Makki said: "It is not an adverb; because it is not ambiguous." End quote (8).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: And Ibn Atiyyah said: "That is a mistake because the adverb should be ambiguous, and this one here is not so, rather it is a land restricted by being far or distant and the like, so its ambiguity was removed by that." End quote (1). And Al-Samin Al-Halabi defended this aspect saying: "The ambiguous adverb (Zarf Mubham) is an expression for what has no boundaries confining it nor diameters containing it, and {ardan} in the noble verse is of this type." End quote (2). 3 - That {ardan} is a second direct object, based on implying (Tadmeen) in {cast him} (itrahuhu) - the intransitive [concerning place] - the meaning of: bring him down (anziluhu) - the transitive. This was said by: Abu Al-Baqaa (3), Abu Hayyan (4), Al-Samin (5), and others (6) as a probable aspect. Abu Hayyan said: "A second object based on implying in {cast him} the meaning of: bring him down, just as you say: I brought Zaid down to the house (anzaltu Zaidan al-dara)." End quote (7). Al-Muntajib Al-Hamadhani weakened this aspect saying: "And it is nothing; because (taraha) is a verb that transits to one object." End quote (8).

text: Second: Weighting: The closest opinion to correctness is that {ardan} is accusative due to the removal of the genitive particle, meaning: in a land. It is also permissible for {ardan} to be accusative as an adverb, and the saying that it is a far land does not contradict its adverbial nature, for here it is an ambiguous, unknown land indicating an undetermined and unconfined place (1). Furthermore, it is not necessary that the land be far, rather they intended that there be destruction/perishing in it (2) for Joseph... peace be upon him. This perishing might be by the land's distance from civilization and its emptiness of life's means, or by the presence of predators in it and the like. This was stated by some exegetes (3). So the intention was casting him in *any* land where there is perishing and indirect killing of Joseph peace be upon him, evidenced by the saying of one of Joseph's brothers immediately after that: {Do not kill Joseph; but throw him into the bottom of the well; some travelers will pick him up - if you would do [something]} [Yusuf: 10]. And that land is not confined but is ambiguous, and its ambiguity increased by the indefiniteness, so it was treated like the names of directions (4). Therefore: Al-Samin's rectification of Ibn Atiyyah in his rejection of the opinion of its adverbial nature, and what Al-Samin said regarding the permissibility of that, is speech in its place. * * *

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: [19]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {And she certainly determined [to seduce] him, and he would have determined [to yield] to her had he not seen the proof of his Lord. And thus [it was] that We might avert from him evil and immorality. Indeed, he was of Our chosen servants} [Yusuf: 24]: "And the Kaf in His saying: {Thus} (kadhalika) is connected to a hidden element whose estimation is: 'Our actions and decrees proceeded *thus* to avert', and it is valid for the Kaf to be in the position of nominative with the estimation: 'Our protection of him was *thus* to avert'." End quote (1). And Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "His saying: {Thus that We might avert} regarding this Kaf there are aspects. One of them: That it is in the place of accusative. Al-Zamakhshari estimated it: 'Like that stabilization We stabilized him' End quote (2). And Ibn Atiyyah estimated it: 'Our actions and decrees proceeded *thus* to avert' End quote (3). The second: That the Kaf is in the place of nominative. Al-Zamakhshari (4) and Abu Al-Baqaa (5) estimated it: 'The matter is like that'. And Ibn Atiyyah estimated it: 'His protection was like that' End quote (6). The third: That there is advancement and delay in the speech, its estimation is: She determined upon him and he determined upon her *like that*, then He said: 'had he not seen the proof of his Lord to avert from him what he determined upon her'. This is the text of Ibn Atiyyah, and it is nothing; because even accepting the permissibility of advancement and delay, there is no meaning to what he mentioned." End quote (7).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Study of the Rectification: Ibn Atiyyah discussed the Kaf from His saying: {Thus that We might avert} and mentioned two aspects in it: One of them: That this Kaf is connected to a hidden element, estimated as: 'Our actions and decrees proceeded thus to avert', and the Second: That the Kaf is in the position of nominative, with the estimation: 'Our protection of him was thus to avert' (1). And Abu Hayyan attributed to Ibn Atiyyah a third opinion which I did not find in Ibn Atiyyah, which is that there is advancement and delay in the speech, estimated as: She determined upon him and he determined upon her *like that*, then He said: 'had he not seen the proof of his Lord to avert from him what he determined upon her' (2). And this opinion which Abu Hayyan attributed to Ibn Atiyyah was copied by Al-Samin from his Sheikh, then he said: "This is the text of Ibn Atiyyah, and it is nothing; because even accepting the permissibility of advancement and delay, there is no meaning to what he mentioned." End quote (3). Upon reviewing the interpretation of Ibn Atiyyah, I did not find him pointing to this meaning, let alone it being a text [from him]; he sufficed with mentioning the first two aspects, then discussed the readings in the verse, then moved to the verse following it (4). Therefore: Al-Samin's rectification of Ibn Atiyyah is void/fallen, due to the incorrectness of attributing the saying to Ibn Atiyyah. * * *

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: [20]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {And when they entered from where their father had ordered them, it did not avail them against Allah at all except [it was] a need within the soul of Jacob, which he satisfied} [Yusuf: 68]: "And His saying: {it did not avail them against Allah at all except a need within the soul of Jacob, which he satisfied} is like their saying: 'There was not in that the repelling of Allah's decree, rather it was a wish of Jacob which he satisfied'... So the answer to {when} (lamma) is in the meaning of His saying: {it did not avail them against Allah at all}." Then he said: "And it is possible that the answer to {lamma} in this verse is deleted and estimated, then He informs about their entering that it {did not avail}." End quote (1). And Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "His saying - the Exalted -: {And when they entered from where their father had ordered them}: regarding the answer to this {when} (lamma) there are three aspects. One of them: And it is the apparent one, that it is the negative sentence from His saying: {it did not avail} (ma kana yughni), and in it is a proof for those who claim that (lamma) is a particle not an adverb; because if it were an adverb, its answer would govern it, since nothing is fit to govern it except its answer, but what is after the negative (ma) does not govern what is before it. It is not permissible to say: 'When your brother stood up, your father did not stand up' (using 'ma'), while it is permissible: 'When (lamma) your brother stood up, your father did not stand up'. The second: That its answer is deleted. Abu Al-Baqaa estimated it: 'They complied and satisfied their father's need' (2), and Ibn Atiyyah also leaned towards this, and it is arbitrary; because in the speech there is what constitutes an explicit answer as I have presented. The third: That the answer is His saying: {he sheltered} (awa) (3). Abu Al-Baqaa said: 'And it is the answer to the first and second {lamma}, as you say: 'When you came to me, and when I spoke to you, you answered me', and what makes this good is that their entering upon...

text: ...Joseph, peace be upon him, follows their entering through the gates' End quote (1), meaning that {he sheltered} is the answer to the first and the second, and it is clear." End quote (2). Study of the Rectification: First: The sayings of the syntacticians regarding the answer to (lamma) from His saying: {And when they entered from where their father had ordered them}: They mentioned four aspects in that: 1 - That the answer to {lamma} is deleted, indicated by the meaning of {it did not avail}, meaning: what befell them befell them (3). This was said by: Ibn Atiyyah (4), and allowed by: Abu Al-Baqaa (5), and Al-Muntajib Al-Hamadhani (6). Abu Al-Baqaa said: "And it is permissible for the answer to be the meaning of {it did not avail them}." End quote (7).

7. Al-Tibyan fi I'rab Al-Qur'an (2: 738).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: And Al-Alusi discussed this aspect in some detail where he said: "And the opinion that the purpose did not result from the plan was objected to on the basis that the purpose was nothing but averting the evil eye from them, and that was realized by their entering separately. It was answered that the intended meaning of averting the evil eye is that no harm touches them, and the striking of the evil eye was specified due to its distinctness. It was said: That they were struck by the evil eye also, so the purpose did not result from the plan, rather what he, peace be upon him, wanted failed his plan. This was criticized as being forced. It was made apparent that the intended meaning is that he, peace be upon him, feared the evil of the eye for them, but another evil befell them which did not cross his mind, so averting what he feared was of no benefit. In that case, it is claimed that their entering from where their father ordered them was beneficial for them in that it averted the eye from them, except that *when* what befell them befell them—regarding the attribution of theft to them and their disgrace by that along with their brother due to finding the drinking cup in his saddlebag and the doubling of the calamity upon their father—that was not considered a benefit, so it was as if their entering did not benefit them at all." End quote (1). 2 - That the answer to {lamma} is His saying: {he sheltered} (awa), and it is the answer to the first {lamma}: ...{And when they entered from where their father had ordered them}, and the answer to the second {lamma}: {And when they entered upon Joseph}. This was said by: Abu Al-Baqaa (2), and Al-Muntajib Al-Hamadhani (3).
foot_note:
1. Tafsir Al-Alusi (7: 20).
2. See: Al-Tibyan fi I'rab Al-Qur'an (2: 738).
3. See: Al-Farid fi I'rab Al-Qur'an Al-Majid (3: 610).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Abu Al-Baqaa said: "{He sheltered} (awa) is the answer to the first and the second {when} (lamma); like your saying: 'When I came to you and when I spoke to you, you answered me.' What makes this appropriate is that their entering upon Joseph followed their entering through the gates." End quote (1). 3 - That the answer to {lamma} is deleted, estimated as: 'They complied' or 'They satisfied their father's need'. This was mentioned by: Ibn Atiyyah (2), Abu Al-Baqaa (3), and Al-Muntajib Al-Hamadhani (4) as a probable aspect. Ibn Atiyyah said: "And it is possible that the answer to 'lamma' in this verse is deleted and estimated, then He informs about their entering that it {did not avail}." End quote (5). Abu Al-Baqaa said: "Deleted, estimated as: They complied, or satisfied their father's need, and the like." End quote (6). Al-Samin weakened this aspect, saying: "And it is arbitrary; because in the speech there is what constitutes an explicit answer." End quote (7). 4 - That the answer to {lamma} is His saying: {it did not avail them against Allah at all}, and it is the answer to a non-jussive condition. This was said by: Abu Hayyan (8), Al-Samin (9), Ibn Ajiba (10), Al-Shawkani (11), and others (12).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Abu Hayyan said: "The answer to {lamma} is His saying: {it did not avail them against Allah at all}." End quote (1). And Al-Shawkani said: "And the answer to {lamma} is: {it did not avail them} - meaning that entering - {against Allah} - meaning from His direction - {at all} - meaning any of the things which Allah decreed upon them; because caution does not repel the decree." End quote (2). Some exegetes mentioned a benefit in this aspect, which is that the verse combines the past tense form {they entered} (dakhalu) and the future tense form {avail} (yughni); this is to achieve the necessary comparison between the answer of {lamma} and its condition, for the lack of availing in reality is realized at the descent of the feared event, not at the time of entry. What is realized then is what the mentioned combination indicates: that the mentioned entry would not be availing in what was to come (3). Second: Weighting (Tarjih):
foot_note:
1. Tafsir Abi Hayyan (6: 298).
2. Fath Al-Qadir (3: 49).
3. See: Tafsir Abi Al-Saud (4: 293), Tafsir Al-Alusi (7: 20).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: The preferred view is that His saying: {it did not avail them} is the answer to the condition, and there is no need to say that the answer is deleted as long as there is something in the apparent text of the verse suitable to be an answer. For syntax free of estimations is better than syntax involving deletion and estimation. Therefore: Al-Samin's rectification of Ibn Atiyyah is valid. Furthermore, the opinion that the answer is deleted and estimated as: 'they complied' and the like, there is no necessity calling for it, for this meaning is understood and derived from His saying: {And when they entered from where their father had ordered them}... for this sentence indicated that they traveled and entered from where their father ordered them, complied with his command, and fulfilled the purpose that was in his soul (1). * * * [21]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {And He cast into the earth firm mountains lest it shift with you, and rivers and roads, that you might be guided} [An-Nahl: 15]: "His saying: {and rivers} (wa anharan) is accusative due to a hidden verb, estimated as: 'and He made' or 'and He created' rivers. Judge Abu Muhammad [Ibn Atiyyah] said: And their consensus on hiding this verb is proof of a specificity for {cast} (alqa), and if {alqa} meant 'created', it would not require this hiding." End quote (2).
foot_note:
1. Ibn Ashur said in Al-Tahrir wa Al-Tanwir (13: 24): "And the sentence (And when they entered from where their father had ordered them) sufficed for many sentences, which are: that they traveled, and entered from where their father ordered them, and when they entered from where their father ordered them, they were safe from what he feared for them." End quote.
2. Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (3: 384).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: And Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "His saying: {and rivers} is conjoined to {firm mountains} (rawasiya) because 'casting' (al-ilqa') has the meaning of 'creation'. And Ibn Atiyyah's claim that it is accusative due to a hidden verb, meaning: 'and He made rivers in it', is not as he mentioned. Abu Al-Baqaa estimated it as: 'and He cut/dug rivers in it' (1), which is appropriate." End quote (2). Study of the Rectification: First: The sayings of the scholars regarding the syntax of {rivers} (anharan) from His saying: {And He cast into the earth firm mountains lest it shift with you, and rivers}: There are three opinions on the syntax of {rivers}: 1 - That His saying: {rivers} is conjoined to {firm mountains}, because 'casting' has the meaning of 'making' (ja'l); since casting is a specific type of making. This was said by: Al-Tabari (3), Makki bin Abi Talib (4), Al-Fakhr Al-Razi (5), Al-Samin (6), and others (7).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Al-Tabari said: "He conjoined rivers to the firm mountains, and applied to it what He applied to the firm mountains (syntactically), since the meaning of the speech and the intent were understood." End quote (1). Al-Fakhr Al-Razi said: "{and rivers} is conjoined to His saying: {And He cast into the earth firm mountains}, and the estimation is: 'And He cast firm mountains and rivers'. And the creation of rivers is not far from being called 'casting', so it is said: 'Allah cast rivers into the earth' just as He said: {And We cast into it firm mountains} [Qaf: 7]. And 'casting' means 'making'; do you not see that He - the Exalted - said in another verse: {And He placed therein firm mountains from above it, and He blessed it} [Fussilat: 10]." End quote (2). 2 - That {rivers} is accusative due to a hidden verb, meaning: 'and He made' or 'and He created' rivers. This was said by: Ibn Atiyyah (3), and weakened by: Al-Samin Al-Halabi (4). Ibn Atiyyah said: "And his saying: {rivers} is accusative due to a hidden verb, estimated as: 'and He made' or 'and He created' rivers." Then he said: "And their consensus on hiding this verb is proof of a specificity for {cast} (alqa), and if {alqa} meant 'created', it would not require this hiding." End quote (5).
foot_note:
1. Tafsir Al-Tabari (17: 184).
2. Tafsir Al-Fakhr Al-Razi (20: 191).
3. See: Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (3: 384).
4. See: Al-Durr Al-Masun (7: 202).
5. Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (3: 384).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: So his saying: {rivers}, according to Ibn Atiyyah, is not conjoined to {firm mountains}, but rather it is a conjunction of a sentence to a sentence, and the estimation is: 'And He cast into the earth firm mountains lest it shift with you, [and He made] rivers.' 3 - That {rivers} is a direct object for a deleted verb, and the estimation is: 'and He cut/dug rivers'. This was said by: Abu Al-Baqaa (1), and approved by Al-Samin Al-Halabi (2). Abu Al-Baqaa said: "Meaning: and He cut/dug rivers." End quote (3). Al-Samin said, commenting on this estimation: "And it is appropriate." End quote (4). So in this opinion, there is hiding of a verb like the opinion of Ibn Atiyyah, with a difference in the estimated verb. Second: Weighting (Tarjih): The preferred view is that His saying: {rivers} is conjoined to {firm mountains} in the accusative case; this is the strongest of the opinions because there is no hiding/estimation in it.
foot_note:
1. See: Al-Tibyan fi I'rab Al-Qur'an (2: 792).
2. See: Al-Durr Al-Masun (7: 202).
3. Al-Tibyan fi I'rab Al-Qur'an (2: 792).
4. Al-Durr Al-Masun (7: 202).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: And the governor (operator) in {rivers} is the verb {cast} (alqa), considering the meaning. Makki bin Abi Talib said: "And it is not proper to carry it upon {cast} [literally] because it is not said: 'Allah cast the rivers and the roads', rather it is carried upon the meaning; because the meaning of {And He cast into the earth firm mountains} is: He made/placed firm mountains in it, so he conjoined {and rivers and roads} based on this meaning." End quote (1). As for Ibn Atiyyah's statement that rivers is a direct object for an estimated verb, estimated as: 'and He made rivers', it is not weak as Al-Samin said; rather it is permissible, and it is better than the other estimation he approved: 'He cut/dug rivers', because (made) has what testifies for it unlike (cut); He - the Exalted - said: {And He placed therein firm mountains and rivers} [Ar-Ra'd: 3], and He said: {And He made rivers within it} [An-Naml: 61]. However, the mistake lies only in what Ibn Atiyyah said after that, where he claimed consensus on hiding a verb, and said that this consensus is proof that {cast} is not in the meaning of (made) or (created) (2). And Al-Samin did not clarify this in his rectification of Ibn Atiyyah, but Abu Hayyan explicitly stated it, saying: "And what consensus is in this, when it has been narrated from the interpreters that {cast} is in the meaning of: created and made." End quote (3).
foot_note:
1. Al-Hidayah ila Bulugh Al-Nihayah (6: 3965).
2. See: Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (3: 384).
3. Tafsir Abi Hayyan (6: 514).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: So this consensus which Ibn Atiyyah claimed is not correct, and the majority (1) have stated that {cast} in the verse is in the meaning of (made) and (created). Al-Zajjaj said: "The meaning: And He made firm mountains and rivers and roads in it, because the meaning of 'cast firm mountains into the earth' is: made firm mountains in it. The evidence for that is His saying: {And the mountains as pegs} [An-Naba: 7]." End quote (2). And Al-Zamakhshari said: "{and rivers}: And He made rivers in it, because 'cast' contains the meaning of: made. Do you not see His saying: {Have We not made the earth a resting place? (6) And the mountains as pegs? (7)} [An-Naba: 6, 7]." End quote (3). And what the scholars mentioned, that {cast} is in the meaning of (made), is correct—contrary to Ibn Atiyyah—evidenced by the verse of An-Naba - previously mentioned -, and His saying - the Exalted -: {And He placed therein firm mountains and rivers} [Ar-Ra'd: 3], and His saying: {And We placed in the earth firm mountains lest it shift with them} [Al-Anbiya: 31], and His saying: {And made for it firm mountains} [An-Naml: 61], and His saying: {And He placed therein firm mountains from above it} [Fussilat: 10], and His saying: {And We placed therein lofty firm mountains} [Al-Mursalat: 27]. * * *

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: [22]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {And when We said to the angels, "Prostrate to Adam," and they prostrated, except Iblees. He said, "Should I prostrate to one You created from clay?"} [Al-Isra: 61]: "His saying: {clay} (teenan) is valid to be a specification (Tamyiz), and it is valid to be a circumstantial state (Hal)." End quote (1). And Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "His saying - the Exalted -: {teenan} contains aspects. One of them: That it is a Hal from {one} (man) [the relative pronoun], so the governor in it is {Should I prostrate}, or from the returning pronoun of this relative pronoun, meaning: You created him as clay (khalaqtahu teenan), so the governor in it is {You created}. And the occurrence of (clay) as a Hal is permissible, even if it is a rigid noun (jamid); due to its indication of origin, as if he said: originating from clay. The second: That it is accusative due to the dropping of the preposition/genitive particle, meaning: from clay (min teen), as explicitly stated in another verse: {and You created him from clay} [Sad: 76]. The third: That it is accusative as a Tamyiz. Al-Zajjaj said this, and Ibn Atiyyah followed him, but this is not apparent since no ambiguity of entity or relation preceded it." End quote (2).
foot_note:
1. Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (3: 469).
2. Al-Durr Al-Masun (7: 378).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Study of the Rectification: First: The sayings of the scholars regarding the syntax of his saying: {clay} (teenan): regarding that, there are three opinions: 1 - That his saying: {teenan} is accusative due to the removal of the preposition/genitive particle, and the estimation is: from clay (min teen); so when the preposition was deleted, the verb connected to it and put it in the accusative. This was said by: Al-Tabari (1), Al-Baquli (2), Abdul Rahman Al-Anbari (3), Al-Baydawi (4), and others (5).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Al-Tabari said: "{Should I prostrate to one You created from clay?} He says: To one You created from clay; so when (from/min) was deleted, his saying {You created} connected to it and put it in the accusative." End quote (1). 2 - That {teenan} is accusative as a Tamyiz (specification), and its governor is the verb {You created}. This was said by: Al-Zajjaj (2), Al-Khatib Al-Tabrizi (3), Ibn Atiyyah (4), and others (5). Al-Zajjaj said: "And {teenan} is accusative on two aspects: One of them: Tamyiz, and the meaning is: to one You created from clay." End quote (6). A number of syntacticians weakened this aspect, among them Al-Samin Al-Halabi; because no ambiguity of entity or relation preceded it. (7) 3 - That {teenan} is a Hal (circumstantial state) from the relative pronoun {one} (man), or from the deleted returning pronoun - the Ha -, meaning: You created him.

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: And it is permissible for {teenan} to be a Hal despite its rigidity; because it indicates origin, as if he said: originating from clay. This was said by: Makki bin Abi Talib (1), Al-Sam'ani (2), Al-Zamakhshari (3), Abu Al-Baqaa (4), Al-Samin Al-Halabi (5), and others (6). Al-Zamakhshari said: "{teenan} is a Hal either from the relative pronoun, and the governor in it is 'prostrate', meaning: Should I prostrate to him while he is clay, i.e., his origin is clay, or from the pronoun returning to it from the relative clause, meaning: Should I prostrate to one who was clay at the time of his creation." End quote (7).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Second: Weighting: The preferred view is that His saying: {teenan} is accusative due to the deletion of the preposition (from/min); evidenced by the explicit mention of this preposition in other verses, like His saying: {He said, "What prevented you from prostrating when I commanded you?" He said, "I am better than him. You created me from fire and created him from clay."} [Al-A'raf: 12], and His saying: {He said, "I am better than him. You created me from fire and created him from clay."} [Sad: 76]. And the majority of exegetes stated that the meaning of His saying: {to one You created from clay} [Al-Isra: 61] is: to one You created from clay (1). It is also permissible for His saying: {teenan} to be a Hal indicating origin (2), meaning: originating from clay, and this is correct from the perspective of grammatical structure, as well as from the perspective of meaning, for the meaning of being originating from clay is: his origin and the beginning of his creation is from clay, and He - the Exalted - has said: {And He began the creation of man from clay} [As-Sajdah: 7]. As for the opinion that {teenan} is accusative as a Tamyiz - which is Ibn Atiyyah's opinion - it is the weakest of the opinions (3); because no ambiguity of entity or relation preceded it - as Al-Samin said -, so this aspect is weak from...
