text: ...the structural perspective. As for the perspective of meaning, it comes close to the import of the preferred opinion, for the Tamyiz as established in the science of syntax implies the meaning of (from/min) (1), i.e., from clay, so from this aspect it is close to the preferred opinion. However, Al-Samin's rectification of Ibn Atiyyah remains in place, for Ibn Atiyyah began with the weakest of the opinions, and did not point out that the meaning is: from clay, neither from the perspective of syntax nor from the perspective of interpretation. * * *

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: [23]: Ibn Atiyyah said in his syntax of His saying - the Exalted -: {Indeed, those who have disbelieved and avert [people] from the way of Allah and [from] the al-Masjid al-Haram, which We made for the people - equal are the resident therein and the one from outside; and [also] whoever intends therein [a deed] of deviation [in religion] or wrongdoing - We will make him taste of a painful punishment.} [Al-Hajj: 25]: "His saying: {and avert} (wa yasudduna) its estimation is: 'and they avert' (wa hum yasudduna), and by this, the conjunction of the future tense to the past tense becomes good. And a group said: The 'Waw' (And) is extra (zaidah), and {avert} (yasudduna) is the predicate of {Indeed} (Inna). And this corrupts the intended meaning, rather the predicate is deleted and estimated at His saying: {and the one from outside}, its estimation is: 'they have lost' or 'they have perished'." End quote (1). And Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "His saying: {and avert}: in it are three aspects." And he mentioned these three aspects in detail, and regarding the third aspect he said: "That the Waw in {and avert} is extra in the predicate of {Indeed} (Inna), its estimation is: 'Indeed those who have disbelieved avert'. And the addition of the Waw is a Kufan doctrine whose invalidity has been presented. Ibn Atiyyah said: 'And this corrupts the intended meaning'. End quote. I say: And I do not know the corruption of meaning from which direction? Do you not see that if we explicitly said: 'Indeed those who have disbelieved avert', there would be no corruption of meaning. So the preventer is only a structural matter according to the people of Basra, not semantic, unless he intends a specific meaning that becomes corrupt by this estimation, which would need explanation." End quote (2).
foot_note:
1. Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (4: 115).
2. Al-Durr Al-Masun (8: 255).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Study of the Rectification: The scholars differed regarding the syntax of His saying: {and avert} (wa yasudduna), and their estimations and interpretations varied. They have three main opinions on this: 1 - That the Waw is a conjunction, so his saying: {and avert} is conjoined to what is before it. This was said by: Al-Tabari (1), Al-Zajjaj (2), Al-Nahhas (3), Makki bin Abi Talib (4), Ibn Atiyyah (5), and others (6). And regarding the conjunction of the future tense {and avert} to the past tense {have disbelieved} (kafaru), there are four interpretations:

2. See: Ma'ani Al-Qur'an wa I'rabuhu (3: 420).
3. See: I'rab Al-Qur'an (3: 65).
4. See: Mushkil I'rab Al-Qur'an (2: 489).
5. See: Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (4: 115).
6. book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: One of them: That the present/future tense {and avert} is not intended to mean the present or future, but rather it is intended to mean the continuous occurrence of the action from them, which is hindering, just like His saying - the Exalted -: {Those who have believed and whose hearts are assured by the remembrance of Allah} [Ar-Ra'd: 28]. (1) Al-Tabari said: "He conjoined with {and avert}, which is future, to {disbelieved}, which is past; because the hindering is in the sense of a description of them and permanence. And if that is the meaning of the speech, it can only be with the wording of the noun or the future, and cannot be with the wording of the past. And if that is the case, the meaning of the speech is: Indeed those who disbelieved, among their descriptions is hindering from the way of Allah. And that is similar to the saying of Allah: {Those who have believed and whose hearts are assured by the remembrance of Allah} [Ar-Ra'd: 28]." End quote (2). The second: That {and avert} is a present tense verb intended as the past (3), meaning: what passed of hindering, and the estimation is: Indeed those who disbelieved and hindered. Al-Baghawi said: He conjoined the future to the past; because the intended meaning of the future wording is the past, as He - the Exalted - said in another place: {Those who disbelieved and hindered from the way of Allah} [Muhammad: 1]." End quote (4).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: The third: That the past {disbelieved} is intended as future, and the estimation is: they disbelieve and avert (1). Al-Samin Al-Halabi said discussing this interpretation: "That {and avert} is on its default state, and the past before it is interpreted as future." End quote (2). The fourth: That the intended meaning is: Indeed those who disbelieved in the past, and they are hindering from the way of Allah in the present, and the estimation is: Indeed those who disbelieved *while* they are hindering, and upon this the conjoined sentence is nominal not verbal. (3) Al-Sam'ani said: "Some of them said: Its meaning is: Indeed those who disbelieved in the past." End quote (4). And Al-Fakhr Al-Razi said: "The estimation is: Indeed those who disbelieved in the past while they are now hindering." End quote (5). And Ibn Atiyyah said: "Its estimation is: 'and they avert', and by this, the conjunction of the future tense to the past tense becomes good." ... End quote (6).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Those who agreed that the Waw is a conjunction differed regarding the predicate (khabar) of {Indeed} (Inna). The majority (1) went to the view that it is deleted, indicated by the end of the verse, and the estimation is: Indeed those who disbelieved and avert from the way of Allah have perished or lost, or: are punished. Ibn Atiyyah said: "The predicate is deleted and estimated at His saying {and the one from outside}, its estimation is: they lost or perished." ... End quote (2). And Abdul Rahman Al-Anbari said: "The predicate of {Inna} is estimated, and its estimation is: Indeed those who disbelieved and avert from the way of Allah are punished." End quote (3). Al-Zajjaj went to the view that the predicate is His saying: {We will make him taste of a painful punishment} (4). A number of scholars weakened this view of Al-Zajjaj, among them: Al-Nahhas (5), and Makki bin Abi Talib (6). Al-Nahhas said: "This is a mistake, and I do not know what aspect supports it; because he brought the predicate of {Inna} in the jussive (jazm), and also because it is the answer to the condition, so if it were a predicate, the condition would remain without an answer, especially since the verb for the condition is future so it must have an answer." End quote (7).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Makki said: "Abu Ishaq said: 'The predicate is: {We will make him taste of a painful punishment}' End quote, and this is a mistake; because it is the answer to the condition." End quote (1). 2 - That the Waw in {and avert} is the Waw of Hal (circumstantial), and the sentence {avert} is in the position of accusative as a Hal from the Waw of the group in {disbelieved}. And the predicate of {Inna} is deleted - as in the previous opinion -, indicated by the end of the verse, its estimation is: are punished. This was said by: Abu Al-Baqaa (2), and allowed by: Al-Baquli (3), Abdul Rahman Al-Anbari (4), Al-Baydawi (5), and others (6). Al-Samin Al-Halabi weakened the sentence being a Hal saying: "And it is corrupt ostensibly; because it is a positive present tense verb, and what is like that, the Waw does not enter upon it. And what has been reported of it, which is rare, is interpreted, so the Qur'an should not be carried upon it." End quote (7).

text: 3 - That the Waw is extra (zaidah), and the sentence {avert} is in the position of nominative as the predicate of {Inna}, and the estimation is: Indeed those who disbelieved avert. This was said by: Al-Khalil bin Ahmad (1). Some scholars mentioned it as a probable aspect, among them: Makki bin Abi Talib (2), Al-Kirmani (3), Abu Al-Baqaa (4), and Al-Shawkani (5). Al-Khalil bin Ahmad said: "{Indeed, those who have disbelieved and avert from the way of Allah} its meaning is: they avert, and the Waw in it is a Waw of insertion (insertion for emphasis)." End quote (6). A number of scholars weakened this opinion (7), among them Ibn Atiyyah who considered it impossible from the perspective of meaning, where he said: "And a group said: The Waw is extra and {avert} is the predicate of {Inna}, and this corrupts the intended meaning." End quote (8). Al-Samin rectified him as he held that the meaning is not corrupt, and the weakness is only from the structural perspective not semantic, where he said: "And I do not know the corruption of meaning from which direction? Do you not see that if we explicitly said: 'Indeed those who have disbelieved avert'; there would be no corruption of meaning. So the preventer is only a structural matter according to...

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: ...the people of Basra, not semantic, unless he intends a specific meaning that becomes corrupt by this estimation, which would need explanation." ... End quote (1). The Kufans held that the conjunctive Waw is permitted to be extra, and argued with a number of evidences. As for the Basrans, they held that it is not permitted for the conjunctive Waw to be extra. Abdul Rahman Al-Anbari discussed this issue in (Al-Insaf), and refuted the evidences of the Kufans, concluding that the Waw in what they cited as evidence is actually conjunctive not extra (2). So Al-Samin Al-Halabi weakened this opinion from the structural perspective, and did not agree with Ibn Atiyyah regarding its corruption from the semantic perspective. The correct view is to say: Even accepting that the meaning based on that is not corrupt, this opinion remains weak; because it has nothing to strengthen it or testify for it, and the Waw is originally a particle established for a meaning; so it is not permissible to judge it as extra as long as it is possible to carry it upon its original function, and it is possible here (3). And He - the Exalted - said in other places: {It is they who have disbelieved and averted you from al-Masjid al-Haram} [Al-Fath: 25], and He said: {Indeed, those who disbelieved and averted from the way of Allah have caused their deeds to be lost} [Muhammad: 1], and He said: {Indeed, those who disbelieved and averted from the way of Allah and opposed the Messenger} [Muhammad: 32]. So the Waw is established in all these places which are similar to what came in the verse of rectification, which weakens the opinion of its addition.

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: As for the preferred view among these three opinions, it is the first opinion, which is that the Waw is a conjunction. As for the predicate of {Inna}, the preferred view is that it is deleted, estimated as: 'are punished'. This estimation is the closest to the apparent wording at the end of the verse: {We will make him taste of a painful punishment}, unlike the other estimation: 'they perish' or 'they lose'; for that agrees with the meaning of the end of the verse but not its wording. This opinion is correct from both structural and semantic perspectives, and there is nothing to weaken it, and a large number of scholars have preferred it (1). * * * [24]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {Indeed, those who came with the falsehood are a group among you. Do not think it bad for you; rather it is good for you.} [An-Nur: 11]: "His saying: {a group} (usbatun) is nominative as a substitute (badal) for the pronoun in {came}, and the predicate of {Indeed} (Inna) is in His saying: {Do not think it}, and the estimation is: 'Indeed the action of those...'. And this is more consistent in meaning and more beneficial than {a group} being the predicate of {Inna}." End quote (2). And Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "His saying: {Indeed, those who came with the falsehood}: regarding the predicate of {Inna} there are two aspects. One of them: That it is {a group} and {among you} is its attribute. Abu Al-Baqaa said: 'And with it the predicate provided meaning.' End quote (3). The second: That the predicate is the sentence from His saying: {Do not think it}, and {a group} would be a substitute for the subject of {came}.

3. Al-Tibyan fi I'rab Al-Qur'an (2: 966).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Ibn Atiyyah said: 'The estimation is: Indeed the action of those..., and this is more consistent in meaning and more beneficial than {a group} being the predicate of {Indeed} (Inna)' End quote. This is how the Sheikh [Abu Hayyan] cited him without objecting to him (1). But the objection to him is clear from the perspective that he made the predicate of {Inna} a demand sentence (request/prohibition), and it has been presented that this is not permissible." End quote (2). Study of the Rectification: First: The sayings of the scholars regarding the predicate of {Inna} in the verse: Scholars have two opinions on this: 1 - That His saying: {a group} (usbatun) is the predicate of {Inna} in the nominative case, and {among you} is an attribute for {a group}, and the sentence {Do not think it} is inception (new sentence). This is the opinion of the majority of syntacticians (3).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Abu Ja'far Al-Nahhas said: "{... those who came with the falsehood} is the noun of {Inna}, and {a group} is its predicate." End quote (1). Abu Al-Baqaa said: "{a group}: is the predicate of {Inna}, and {among you} is an attribute for it, and by it the predicate provided meaning. And His saying - the Exalted -: {Do not think it}: is inceptive." End quote (2). 2 - That His saying: {Do not think it} is the predicate of {Inna}, while {a group} is nominative as a substitute (badal) for the pronoun in {came}. This was said by Ibn Atiyyah (3), and allowed by Al-Shawkani (4), and Ibn Ashur began with it (5). Ibn Atiyyah said: "The predicate of {Inna} is in His saying: {Do not think it}, and the estimation is: 'Indeed the action of those...', and this is more consistent in meaning and more beneficial than {a group} being the predicate of {Inna}." End quote (6). Al-Shawkani said commenting on Ibn Atiyyah's statement: "The sentence: {Do not think it}, even if it is a demand sentence (imperative/prohibitive), making it a predicate is valid with estimation." End quote (7).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Some scholars weakened this aspect, among them: Ibn Juzayy (1), Al-Samin Al-Halabi (2), and Al-Alusi (3). Al-Samin said: "And the objection to him is clear from the perspective that he made the predicate of {Indeed} (Inna) a demand sentence (request/prohibition), and it has been presented that this is not permissible." End quote (4). And Al-Alusi said: "And it is not hidden that this is forced (takalluf)." End quote (5). Second: The ruling on the predicate of (Inna) being a demand sentence: The majority of grammarians held that it is not permissible for the predicate of (Inna) to be a demand sentence, and if any instance of that appears, it is interpreted (6); so they interpreted the saying of the poet (7): 'Indeed those whom you killed their leader yesterday... do not think their night was sleeping unlike your night' as being based on the hiding of a saying (qawl) that serves as the predicate for (Inna), and this demand sentence falls as the object of that [hidden saying]. Thus, the speech belongs to the category of deleting the governor (amil) and retaining the governed (ma'mul), and the estimation is: 'Indeed those whom you killed their leader yesterday, [it is said] regarding their affair: do not think...' (8). Some of them rejected these interpretations and said they are forced and an adherence to what is not necessary (9).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: And some of them held the permissibility of the predicate occurring as a prohibition sentence specifically, to the exclusion of other demand sentences (1). The apparent view is that the predicate of (Inna) is permitted to be a demand sentence absolutely, except that this did not occur frequently in the speech of the Arabs. It has been established in the Qur'an coupled with the 'Fa', He - the Exalted - said: {Indeed, those who disbelieve in the verses of Allah and kill the prophets without right and kill those who order justice from among the people - give them tidings of a painful punishment.} [Ali 'Imran: 21]. So the predicate of {Indeed} (Inna) is His saying: {give them tidings} (fa-bashshirhum) (2), which is a demand sentence. It is noted that the syntacticians of this verse focused on explaining the occurrence of the 'Fa' in the predicate of {Inna}, but they did not discuss the predicate occurring here as a demand sentence. Al-Zamakhshari said: "If you say: Why did the 'Fa' enter the predicate of {Inna}? I say: Because its noun implies the meaning of a condition/recompense (Jaza'), as if it was said: 'Those who disbelieve, so give them tidings', with the meaning: 'Whoever disbelieves, then give them tidings'. And (Inna) does not change the meaning of the inchoation (Ibtida'), so it is as if its entry is like non-entry." End quote (3). Abu Al-Baqaa said: "And the 'Fa' entered it since the relative clause of (alladhi) was a verb, and that indicates the deserving of the tidings of punishment as a recompense for disbelief. And (Inna) does not prevent the entry of the 'Fa' into the predicate; because it did not change the meaning of the inchoation, but rather emphasized it." End quote (4).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: So what appears is that the occurrence of the predicate of (Inna) as a demand sentence is permissible despite its rarity. Third: Weighting (Tarjih): The preferred view is that His saying: {those who came with the falsehood} is the noun of {Inna}, and its predicate is {a group} (usbatun), and this is the apparent meaning. As for Ibn Atiyyah's opinion that {Do not think it} is the predicate of {Inna}, it is a far-fetched opinion, for the following reasons: 1 - It requires estimation for the speech structure to be valid (1), unlike the opinion of the majority which is consistent with the apparent text of the verse and contains no estimation. The estimation of the speech according to Ibn Atiyyah is: 'Indeed the action of those who came with the falsehood [who are] a group among you, do not think it bad for you' (2), and this estimation contains artificiality and there is no need for it. 2 - That His saying: {those who came with the falsehood} is the noun of {Inna}, so it is preferable that the predicate be about 'those who came with the falsehood' and not about 'the falsehood' itself. Therefore, the predicate is: {a group among you}. If the reader pauses here, the sentence is grammatically correct, containing the noun of {Inna} and its predicate, and has provided a complete meaning. The benefit of informing about them that they are a 'group' is: Consolation that those who brought that falsehood are a co-operating faction, and that is one of the signs of it being a falsehood with no basis. And it was said: It is more appropriate that the consolation is that this is something not agreed upon by all, but rather brought by a small band among you (3). * * *

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: [25]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {And if not that a disaster should strike them for what their hands put forth [of sins] and they would say, "Our Lord, why did You not send to us a messenger so we could have followed Your verses and been among the believers?"...} [Al-Qasas: 47]: "The answer to {if not} (lawla) is deleted as implied by the speech, its estimation is: 'We would have hastened for them what they deserve'." End quote (1). And Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "His saying: {And if not that [a disaster] should strike them}: It is the 'lawla' of prevention (Imtina'iyyah), and {that} (an) and what is in its scope are in the position of nominative by inchoation (Mubtada), meaning: 'And were it not for their being struck by the disaster'. Its answer is deleted. Al-Zajjaj estimated it: 'We would not have sent messengers to them' (2), meaning: The motive for sending the messengers is removing their excuses via this saying. So it is...

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: ...like His saying: {lest mankind should have an argument against Allah after the messengers} [An-Nisa: 165]. And Ibn Atiyyah estimated it: 'We would have hastened for them' End quote (1), and there is no meaning to this." End quote (2). Study of the Rectification: The syntacticians agreed that the answer to {lawla} in His saying: {And if not that a disaster should strike them for what their hands put forth} is deleted, but they differed in its estimation on two opinions: The first: That the answer is deleted due to the context indicating it, and its estimation is: 'We would not have sent messengers to them', or 'We would not have needed to send messengers'. This was said by: Al-Zajjaj (3), Al-Nahhas (4), Al-Zamakhshari (5), Al-Muntajib Al-Hamadhani (6), Al-Baydawi (7), and others (8).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: The meaning is: Were it not for their saying, when a punishment strikes them because of their disbelief and sins: "Our Lord, why did You not send to us a messenger so he could convey to us Your verses and we would follow them and be among the believers?"; We would not have sent you to them as a messenger, and We would have punished them for their disbelief without a prior warning before the punishment. However, We sent you to them decisively to cut off their excuses, and to establish the proof against them, similar to His saying - the Exalted -: {[We sent] messengers as bringers of good tidings and warners so that mankind will have no argument against Allah after the messengers} [An-Nisa: 165]. (1) Al-Zajjaj said: "Meaning: Were it not for that, there would be no need for sending messengers, and the succession of argumentation." End quote (2). And since the punishment was the cause for the saying, the punishment was treated as if it were the cause for sending [the messenger], so the preventative {lawla} entered upon it. Thus the meaning reverts to: Were it not for this saying of theirs, when a disaster strikes them, We would not have sent you. Al-Zamakhshari said: "If you say: How is this meaning sound when the punishment/disaster was made the cause for the sending, not the saying, due to the entry of the particle of prevention upon it [the disaster] instead of it [the saying]? I say: The 'saying' is what is intended to be the cause for sending the messengers, but since the punishment is the cause for the saying and its existence depends on its existence, the punishment was made as if it were the cause of sending via the medium of the saying. So {lawla} was introduced upon it [the punishment], and the 'saying' was brought conjoined to it with the 'Fa' which gives the meaning of causality. Its meaning interprets to your saying: 'Were it not for this saying of theirs when a disaster strikes them, We would not have sent [messengers]'. However, this method was chosen for a subtle point: which is that if they were not punished, for example, for their disbelief while they witnessed what would compel them to certain knowledge, they would not say: 'Why did You not send to us a messenger', rather...

2. Ma'ani Al-Qur'an wa I'rabuhu (4: 147).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: ...the reason for this saying of theirs is the punishment and nothing else, not regret over what they missed of believing in their Creator." End quote (1). And Ibn Ashur said: "And the structure of the speech was woven on this pattern and He did not say: 'And were it not that they say: Our Lord... when a disaster strikes them'; for the point of emphasizing the warning against the striking of the disaster. So it was placed in the position of the subject (Mubtada) instead of the position of the adverb (Zarf), so that it equals the intended subject of the condition sentence of {lawla}, so it and its adverb become the two pillars in the speech. So the estimation here is: 'Were it not for their being struck by a disaster followed by their saying: Our Lord, why did You not send... etc, We would not have cared to send you to them; because they are people of stubbornness and determination on disbelief'." End quote (2). The second: That the answer to {lawla} is deleted, and its estimation is: 'We would have hastened the punishment for them'. This was said by: Al-Thalabi (3), Makki bin Abi Talib (4), Al-Wahidi (5), Ibn Atiyyah (6), and others (7).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Makki said: "The answer to 'lawla' is deleted, and the estimation is: Were it not that these whom We sent you to, O Muhammad, would say—if the punishment for their disbelief descended upon them before sending you to them—: 'Why did You not send to us a messenger before Your wrath descended upon us {so we could have followed Your verses and been among the believers}'; the punishment would have been hastened for them." End quote (1). Ibn Atiyyah said: "The answer to {lawla} is deleted as implied by the speech, its estimation is: We would have hastened for them what they deserve." End quote (2). And Ibn Al-Jawzi said: "The answer to {lawla} is deleted, its estimation is: Were it not that they would argue by the lack of sending [messengers] to them, We would have hastened the punishment for them." End quote (3). Al-Samin Al-Halabi objected to this estimation saying: "And there is no meaning to this." End quote (4). The Preferred View: That the answer to the condition is deleted, estimated as: 'We would not have sent messengers'. It is far-fetched for the meaning to be: 'Were it not for their saying and arguing, We would have hastened the punishment for them', so the second estimation mentioned by Ibn Atiyyah and others has nothing to strengthen it. This is unlike the first estimation, for verses have appeared in other places of the Qur'an whose meaning strengthens the first estimation, containing confirmation that sending messengers came decisively to cut off the excuses of the people and to bind the proof against them, so they would not say: 'No messenger came to us'. And were it not for this saying of theirs, Allah would not have sent messengers to them one after another. He - the Exalted - said: {[We sent] messengers as bringers of good tidings and warners so that mankind will have no argument against Allah after the messengers}

text: [An-Nisa: 165], and He - the Exalted - said: {O People of the Scripture, there has come to you Our Messenger to make clear to you [the religion] after a period [of suspension] of messengers, lest you say, "There came not to us any bringer of good tidings or a warner." But there has come to you a bringer of good tidings and a warner} [Al-Ma'idah: 19]. It is permissible in estimating the deleted answer of the condition to combine both meanings: Hastening the punishment and omitting the sending of messengers, meaning: We would have hastened the punishment for them and would not have sent a messenger to them (1). As for limiting it to hastening the punishment, it is not apparent. Therefore: Al-Samin's rectification of Ibn Atiyyah is in its place. * * *

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: [26]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {There was for [the tribe of] Saba' in their dwelling place a sign: two gardens on the right and on the left} [Saba: 15]: "{Two gardens} (jannatani) is a subject (Mubtada), and its predicate is in His saying: {on the right and on the left}, or the predicate of a subject [whose estimation is]: 'they are two gardens' (hiya jannatani), which is a sentence meaning 'this is their state'. And the substitution (Badal) from {a sign} (ayatun) is weak, though Makki (1) and others said it." End quote (2). And Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "His saying: {jannatani}: In it are three aspects: Nominative as a substitute (Badal) for {a sign} (ayatun), and he substituted a dual from a singular; because this singular applies to this dual. The second: That it is the predicate of a hidden subject. Ibn Atiyyah weakened the first aspect but did not explain it [the weakness], and its weakness does not appear, rather its strength does. It is as if he imagined that they differ in singularity and duality; so for that reason, the substitution was weak in his view - and Allah knows best -. The third: - and Ibn Atiyyah leaned towards it - that {jannatani} is a subject, and its predicate is {on the right and on the left}. The Sheikh [Abu Hayyan] rejected it: because it is starting with an indefinite noun without a justifier (3). And he apologized for it: that the deletion of an adjective might be believed; meaning: 'two gardens *for them*', or 'two *great* gardens', if what he went to is valid." End quote (4).

This was said by: Al-Farra (1), Al-Zajjaj (2), Al-Nahhas (3), Makki bin Abi Talib (4), Al-Baquli (5), and others (6).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: And he substituted the dual {jannatani} from the singular {ayatun}; because this singular applies to this dual, for the combination of the two gardens is tantamount to one sign (1). Ibn Atiyyah weakened this aspect but did not explain the direction of its weakness (2). Al-Samin said: "Ibn Atiyyah weakened the first aspect but did not explain it, and its weakness does not appear, rather its strength does. It is as if he imagined that they differ in singularity and duality; so for that reason, the substitution was weak in his view." End quote (3). 2 - That His saying: {jannatani} is nominative on the basis that it is a predicate for a deleted subject, and the estimation is: 'they are two gardens' (hiya jannatani), or: 'The sign is two gardens'. Allowed by: Al-Nahhas (4), Al-Zamakhshari (5), Abdul Rahman Al-Anbari (6), Abu Al-Baqaa (7), and others (8).

text: Al-Anbari said allowing this aspect: "That it be nominative; because it is the predicate of a deleted subject, and its estimation is: 'they are two gardens'." End quote (1). 3 - That His saying: {jannatani} is a subject (Mubtada), and its predicate is in His saying: {on the right and on the left}. This was said by Ibn Atiyyah (2). It was weakened because {jannatani} is an indefinite noun with no justifier for starting a sentence with it, and even if it is said that there is a deleted adjective in the speech, estimated as: 'two gardens *for them*', or 'two *great* gardens'; that would involve separating the speech from what precedes it (3). Second: Discussion and Weighting: The preferred view is that His saying: {jannatani} is a substitute (Badal) for {a sign} (ayatun); and that is because it is a completion of what precedes it (4), for His saying: {jannatani} is an expression of explanation and clarification for the sign, to the extent that some grammarians call the Badal 'Explication' (Tafsir), as in this verse (5), for they justified the nominative case of {jannatani} by it being an explanation for the sign. And this opinion is not weak as Ibn Atiyyah imagined; rather it is the strongest of the opinions, and conformity in singularity and otherwise is not a condition in Badal (6).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: As for the second opinion, which is that {jannatani} is a predicate for a deleted subject, it is permissible, but the first is stronger; because it is free of estimations. As for Ibn Atiyyah's statement that {jannatani} is a subject, and its predicate is: {on the right and on the left}, it is weak; because {jannatani} is an indefinite noun with no justifier to begin with (1), and even if it were said that starting with it here has a justifier, making the speech connected to what precedes it and explanatory of it is better than making His saying: {two gardens on the right and on the left} a new sentence of subject and predicate. (2) Therefore: Al-Samin Al-Halabi's defense of the substitution opinion and his refutation of Ibn Atiyyah is in its place, for the opinion that {jannatani} is a substitute for {a sign} is the strongest of opinions and is not weak as Ibn Atiyyah imagined. * * *
foot_note:
1. See: Tafsir Abi Hayyan (8: 534), Fath Al-Qadir by Al-Shawkani (4: 367).
2. See: Tafsir Abi Hayyan (8: 534), Tafsir Al-Alusi (11: 300).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: [27]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {And if We will, We drown them; then no screamer [to help] is there for them, nor will they be saved} [Ya-Sin: 43]: "And the speech is complete at His saying: {We will, We drown them}. {Then no screamer is there for them} (fa-la sarikha lahum) is a new sentence (Istinaf) giving information about travelers in the sea whether they are saved or drowned, for they are in this state having no salvation for them except by the mercy of Allah. And His saying: {Then no screamer is there for them} is not linked to the drowned ones. It might be valid to link it to them, but the first is better; so contemplate it." End quote (1). And Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "And the 'Fa' in His saying: {fa-la sarikha} links this sentence to what is before it, so the pronoun in {for them} refers back to the drowned ones. Ibn Atiyyah allowed this and another aspect, and made it better than this one: which is that it is a new sentence giving information about travelers in the sea whether they are saved or drowned, that they are in this state having no salvation for them except by the mercy of Allah, and His saying: {fa-la sarikha lahum} is not linked to the drowned ones. And his making this the better view is not good; lest the 'Fa' depart from its function and the speech from its coherence." End quote (2). Study of the Rectification: The subject of this rectification is the 'Fa' in His saying: {And if We will, We drown them; then no screamer is there for them}, where Ibn Atiyyah preferred it to be for inception (Istinaf), while Al-Samin went to the view that it links the sentence to what is before it, and did not agree with Ibn Atiyyah in what he held. So regarding this 'Fa', there are two opinions for the scholars:
foot_note:
1. Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (4: 455).
2. Al-Durr Al-Masun (9: 273).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: 1 - That it is a particle of inception (Istinaf), and the sentence {then no screamer is there for them} is inceptive, not linked to the drowned ones mentioned in the previous sentence, but rather it is information about travelers in the sea whether they are saved or drowned, for they are in this state having no salvation for them except by the mercy of Allah. This is the opinion of Ibn Atiyyah (1), and Al-Samin Al-Halabi weakened it (2) as did other scholars (3); because making it inceptive involves cutting the speech, while the 'Fa' connects what follows it to what precedes it with a clear connection. 2 - That it is a conjunction, linking the sentence to what precedes it, so the sentence {then no screamer} is conjoined to the sentence {We drown them}. This is the opinion of the majority (4), and it is the preferred view; for the 'Fa' in His saying: {then no screamer} connects the sentence to what precedes it with an apparent connection. Deliverance from punishment is either by repelling it from its origin, so it was negated by His saying: {then no screamer is there for them}, or by lifting it after its occurrence, so it was negated by His saying: {nor will they be saved} (5).
foot_note:
1. See: Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (4: 455).
2. See: Al-Durr Al-Masun (9: 273).
3. See: Tafsir Abi Hayyan (9: 71), Tafsir Al-Alusi (12: 28), I'rab Al-Qur'an wa Bayanuhu by Muhyi al-Din Darwish (8: 205).
4. See: Al-Farid fi I'rab Al-Qur'an Al-Majid by Al-Muntajib Al-Hamadhani (5: 353), Tafsir Abi Hayyan (9: 71), Al-Durr Al-Masun (9: 273), Al-Siraj Al-Munir by Al-Khatib Al-Shirbini (3: 353), Tafsir Al-Mazhari (8: 87), Fath Al-Qadir by Al-Shawkani (4: 427), Tafsir Al-Alusi (12: 28), Al-Jadwal fi I'rab Al-Qur'an by Mahmoud Safi (23: 15), I'rab Al-Qur'an wa Bayanuhu by Muhyi al-Din Darwish (8: 205), Al-Mujtaba by Ahmed Al-Kharrat (3: 1019), Ma'rid Al-Ibriz by Abdul Karim Al-As'ad (4: 724), I'rab Al-Qur'an by Muhammad Al-Tayyib (p. 443).
5. See: Tafsir Abi Hayyan (9: 71).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: And this 'Fa' is the 'Eloquent Fa' (Al-Fasiha) (1) which articulates a deleted element, and indicates what resulted from it. This 'Fa' is brought to articulate an estimated speech derived from the speech preceding it (2). An example of it is what came in His saying - the Exalted -: {So whoever among you is ill or on a journey - then an equal number of other days} [Al-Baqarah: 184]. The 'Fa' in His saying: {then an equal number} (fa-'iddatun) articulated a deleted condition, so it is like a link to the answer of the deleted condition, and the estimation is: 'so he broke his fast, then an equal number of other days' (3). Such an estimation is necessary; because the 'equal number' applies only to the one who breaks the fast. Likewise in His saying: {then no screamer is there for them}, the estimated element here is the occurrence of drowning. Therefore: Al-Samin Al-Halabi's rectification of Ibn Atiyyah is in its place; because making the 'Fa' inceptive involves cutting the speech, while the 'Fa' is apparent in connecting what follows it to what precedes it. * * *
foot_note:
1. See: Mu'jam Huruf Al-Ma'ani by Muhammad Al-Sharif (p. 732).
2. See: Al-Kulliyat by Al-Kafawi (p. 676), Dustur Al-Ulama by Al-Qadi Al-Nakari (3: 11), Mu'jam Huruf Al-Ma'ani by Muhammad Al-Sharif (p. 682).
3. See: Tafsir Al-Tabari (3: 457), Al-Tafsir Al-Wasit by Al-Wahidi (1: 273), Tafsir Al-Sam'ani (1: 179), Tafsir Al-Baghawi (1: 215).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: [28]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {And warn them of the Approaching Day, when hearts are at the throats, suppressing [their distress]. For the wrongdoers there will be no devoted friend and no intercessor [who is] obeyed} [Ghafir: 18]: "And His saying: {suppressing} (kathimeen) is a circumstantial state (Hal) from what His saying {when hearts are at the throats} (idh al-qulub) was substituted for, or from what the hearts are added to (possessors), because the intended meaning is 'when the hearts of the people are at their throats'. And this is like His saying - the Exalted -: {[a Day] therein the eyes will stare} [Ibrahim: 42], He intended: 'therein their eyes will stare'." End quote (1). And Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "His saying: {kathimeen} is accusative as a Hal, and they differed regarding its owner (Sahib al-Hal) and the governor in it. Al-Hawfi said: '{The hearts} (al-qulub) is a subject, and {at the throats} is its predicate, and {suppressing} (kathimeen) is a Hal from the pronoun hidden in it' End quote (2). I say: There must be an answer regarding the pluralization of the hearts as a plural of rational beings: which is that when what is attributed to rational beings was attributed to them [the hearts], they were pluralized like them, as in His saying: {I saw them prostrating to me} [Yusuf: 4], {so their necks remained to it humbled} [Ash-Shu'ara: 4]. The second: That it is a Hal from {the hearts}, and in it are the question and answer mentioned previously. The third: That it is a Hal from the owners of the hearts. Al-Zamakhshari said: 'It is a Hal from the owners of the hearts based on the meaning; since the meaning is: when *their* hearts are at the throats, suppressing them' End quote (3). I say: It is as if it has the force of making (Al-) a substitute for the pronoun in 'their throats'.
foot_note:
1. Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (4: 552).
2. Abu Hayyan and Al-Samin Al-Halabi attributed it to Al-Hawfi, and perhaps it is in his book (I'rab Al-Qur'an) or in (Al-Burhan fi Tafsir Al-Qur'an), both of which have not been printed yet. See: Tafsir Abi Hayyan (9: 246), Al-Durr Al-Masun (9: 467).
3. Tafsir Al-Zamakhshari (4: 157).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: The fourth: That it be a Hal from (them) in {warn them} (andhirhum), and it would be an estimated Hal; because at the time of the warning they are not suppressing. And Ibn Atiyyah said: '{kathimeen} is a Hal from what {when hearts} (idh al-qulub) was substituted for, or from what the hearts are added to; since the intended meaning is: when the hearts of the people are at their throats, and this is like His saying: {therein the eyes will stare} [Ibrahim: 42], He intended: therein their eyes will stare'. End quote (1). I say: The apparent meaning of his statement is that it is a Hal from what was substituted for, and his saying: 'when hearts' is problematic; because it was substituted from His saying: {the Approaching Day} (yawm al-azifah), and this is absolutely invalid. Rather he intends by that the second aspect: which is that it be a substitute (Badal) for (them) in {warn them} as a substitution of inclusion (Badal Ishtimal), and in that case it is valid." End quote (2). Study of the Rectification: The scholars agreed that His saying: {kathimeen} is a Hal, but they differed regarding its owner, and they have five opinions on that: 1 - That His saying: {kathimeen} is a Hal from the owners of the hearts based on the meaning; since the original is: when *their* hearts are at their throats, meaning: when their hearts are at their throats while they are suppressing. This was said by: Al-Farra (3), Al-Zajjaj (4), Al-Zamakhshari (5), and others (6).
foot_note:
1. Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (4: 552).
2. Al-Durr Al-Masun (9: 467).
3. See: Ma'ani Al-Qur'an (3: 6).
4. See: Ma'ani Al-Qur'an wa I'rabuhu (4: 369).
5. See: Tafsir Al-Zamakhshari (4: 157).
6. See: Zad Al-Masir by Ibn Al-Jawzi (4: 33), Tafsir Al-Fakhr Al-Razi (27: 503), Tafsir Al-Baydawi (5: 54), Tafsir Abi Al-Saud (7: 272), Ruh Al-Bayan by Ismail Haqqi (8: 170), Tafsir Al-Alusi (12: 312), Adwa' Al-Bayan by Al-Shanqiti (6: 382).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Al-Farra said: "And His saying: {kathimeen} is accusative due to separation (qat') from the meaning which refers back from their mention in the hearts and throats, and the meaning is: when their hearts are at their throats suppressing." End quote (1). And Al-Zamakhshari said: "It is a Hal from the owners of the hearts based on the meaning, because the meaning is: when their hearts are at their throats suppressing them." End quote (2). 2 - That His saying: {kathimeen} is a Hal from what His saying: {when hearts are at the throats} was substituted for. This was said by Ibn Atiyyah, and he began with it (3). Al-Samin Al-Halabi considered it problematic (4); because his saying: {when hearts} was substituted for His saying: {the Approaching Day} (yawm al-azifah), so how can His saying: {kathimeen} be a Hal from {the Approaching Day}?! 3 - That His saying: {kathimeen} is a Hal from the pronoun in {at} (lada). This was said by: Al-Baquli (5), Abdul Rahman Al-Anbari (6), Al-Muntajib Al-Hamadhani (7), and others (8).
foot_note:

2. Tafsir Al-Zamakhshari (4: 157).

5. See: Kashf Al-Mushkilat fi I'rab Al-Qur'an wa 'Ilal Al-Qira'at (p. 727).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Abdul Rahman Al-Anbari said: "{kathimeen} is accusative as a Hal from the pronoun hidden in {lada}." ... End quote (1). 4 - That His saying: {kathimeen} is a Hal from {the hearts}; because the intended meaning is their owners, meaning: when the hearts are at the throats in this state. This was said by: Al-Akhfash (2), Abu Al-Baqaa (3), and others (4). More than one scholar weakened this aspect, among them: Al-Muntajib Al-Hamadhani (5), and Al-Shihab Al-Khafaji (6); because the occurrence of the Hal from the subject (Mubtada) is very weak according to the majority of grammarians, and the subject here is {the hearts}. 5 - That His saying: {kathimeen} is a Hal from the pronoun in {warn them} (andhirhum), and it is an estimated Hal; because at the time of warning they are not suppressing.

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Allowed by: Al-Farra (1), Al-Zamakhshari (2), Abu Al-Baqaa (3), Al-Muntajib Al-Hamadhani (4), and others (5). Al-Zamakhshari said: "And it is permissible for it to be a Hal from his saying: 'and warn them', meaning: and warn them [as being] destined to suppress or on the verge of suppressing." End quote (6). The Preferred View: That His saying: {kathimeen} is a Hal from the owners of the hearts based on the meaning. It is also permissible for it to be a Hal from {the hearts}, where they were described with 'suppression' which is an attribute of their owners (7), and that is according to the opinion of those who allow the Hal to come from the subject. It is also permissible for it to be a Hal from the pronoun in {warn them}. These three opinions do not conflict from the perspective of meaning, and they are the closest to correctness.

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: As for Ibn Atiyyah's statement that {kathimeen} is a Hal from what {when hearts} (idh al-qulub) was substituted for, it leads to an incorrect meaning; for his saying: {when hearts} was substituted for His saying: {the Approaching Day} (yawm al-azifah). Consequently: His saying: {kathimeen} would be a Hal from {the Approaching Day}, and that is not valid. Rather, what he said becomes directed if it is a Hal from the pronoun of {warn them} in {And warn them of the Approaching Day}. Therefore: Al-Samin's rectification of Ibn Atiyyah is in its place; for the apparent wording of Ibn Atiyyah is problematic and its meaning is impossible. * * * [29]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {Then why did those they took besides Allah as offerings and deities not aid them? But they strayed from them. And that was their falsehood and what they were inventing} [Al-Ahqaf: 28]: "And {offerings} (qurbanan) is either the second object of {took} (ittakhadhu), and {deities} (alihatan) is a substitute (Badal) for it; or it is a Hal, and {deities} is the second object. And the first object is the pronoun returning to: {those} (alladhina); the estimation is: 'they took them'." End quote (1).
foot_note: 1. Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (5: 103).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: And Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "His saying: {qurbanan alihatan} contains four aspects. The most prominent of them: That the first object of {took} is deleted, which is the returner of the relative pronoun, and {offerings} (qurbanan) is accusative as a Hal, and {deities} (alihatan) is the second object of taking. The estimation is: 'Then why did those they took [them] seeking nearness by them as deities not aid them'. The second: That the first object is deleted, as previously established, and {offerings} is a second object, and {deities} is a substitute (Badal) for it. Ibn Atiyyah and Abu Al-Baqaa leaned towards this (1), except that Al-Zamakhshari prevented this aspect saying: 'Due to corruption of the meaning' End quote (2), but he did not explain the direction of the corruption. The Sheikh [Abu Hayyan] said: 'And it appears that the meaning is correct upon that syntax' End quote (3). I say: The direction of corruption - and Allah knows best - is that 'Qurban' is a noun for what is used to draw near to the deity, so if we made it a second object, and {deities} a substitute for it, it would necessitate that the thing used to draw near be 'deities', while the premise is that it is other than the deities, rather it is something used to draw near *to* them, so it is other than them. So how can the deities be a substitute for it? This is what is not permissible." End quote (4). Then Al-Samin mentioned the remaining aspects.
foot_note:
1. See: Al-Tibyan fi I'rab Al-Qur'an (2: 1158).
2. Tafsir Al-Zamakhshari (4: 310).
3. Tafsir Abi Hayyan (9: 448).
4. Al-Durr Al-Masun (9: 677).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Study of the Rectification: The syntacticians differed regarding the syntax of His saying: {qurbanan alihatan}, and they have several opinions on that, the most famous of which are four: The first: That {qurbanan} is an object of purpose/reason (Maf'ul li-ajlih) for the verb {took}, meaning: for the sake of drawing near with them, and {alihatan} is a second object for the verb {took}, and the first object is deleted which is the returner of the relative pronoun, i.e., those they took. This was said by: Al-Nahhas (1), Makki bin Abi Talib (2), Al-Muntajib Al-Hamadhani (3), and others (4). Ibn Hisham weakened this aspect; as he considered it unlikely for {qurbanan} to be an object of purpose; because the object of purpose can only be a verbal noun (Masdar) or a noun of action. He said: "And Al-Qurban is a noun for what one draws near with (5), and not a noun for the event/action." End quote (6).
foot_note:
1. See: I'rab Al-Qur'an (4: 114).
2. See: Mushkil I'rab Al-Qur'an (2: 669).
3. See: Al-Farid fi I'rab Al-Qur'an Al-Majid (5: 613).
4. See: Al-Bayan fi I'rab Gharib Al-Qur'an by Al-Anbari (2: 310), Al-Tahrir wa Al-Tanwir by Ibn Ashur (26: 56).
5. Al-Qurban in the language: What you draw near to Allah with, seeking closeness and means. See: Al-Ain by Al-Khalil bin Ahmad, entry: Qarb (5: 153), Tahdhib Al-Lughah by Al-Azhari, entry: Qarb (9: 110).
6. As'ilah wa Ajwibah fi I'rab Al-Qur'an (p. 13).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: The second: That {offerings} (qurbanan) is a second object, and {deities} (alihatan) is a first object, and the estimation is: those who took besides Allah deities as offerings. This was said by: Al-Baquli (1). It was weakened because it leads to the speech being devoid of a returner (pronoun) to {those} (alladhina) (2). The third: That {offerings} is the second object of {took}, and {deities} is a substitute (Badal) for {offerings}, and the first of the two objects of {took} - which refers back to {those} - is deleted, i.e., they took them. This was said by: Ibn Atiyyah (3), Abu Al-Baqaa (4), Al-Baydawi (5), and others (6). Al-Zamakhshari considered it corrupt in meaning (7), and Abu Hayyan refuted him stating that the meaning is correct according to this syntax (8).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: A number of scholars explained the reason for the corruption of meaning based on this syntax, among them: Al-Samin Al-Halabi (1), Ibn Hisham (2), Abu Al-Saud (3), and Ibn Ajiba (4). Al-Samin said: "And the direction of corruption - and Allah knows best - is that 'Qurban' is a noun for what is used to draw near to the deity, so if we made it a second object, and {deities} a substitute for it, it would necessitate that the thing used to draw near be 'deities', while the premise is that it is other than the deities, rather it is something used to draw near *to* them, so it is other than them. So how can the deities be a substitute for it? This is what is not permissible." End quote (5). And Ibn Hisham said: "And its direction is that if they were blamed for taking an offering besides Allah, its implication would require encouraging them to take Allah - Glory be to Him - as an offering, just as if you said: 'Do you take so-and-so as a teacher besides me', you would be ordering him to take you as his teacher besides him. And Allah - the Exalted - is One to whom closeness is sought *by means of* others, not One by whom closeness is sought to others." End quote (6). And Abu Al-Saud said: "And there is no leeway for making {offerings} a second object and {deities} a substitute for it due to the corruption of the meaning; for the substitute, even if it is the intended element, must have a sound meaning without it (except in the substitute of error). And there is no doubt that in our saying: 'they took them besides Allah as offerings', meaning: something to draw near with, is absolutely invalid; because He - the Exalted - is One to whom closeness is sought, not One by whom closeness is sought. So it is not valid that they took them as offerings, bypassing Allah in that." End quote (7).

4. See: Al-Bahr Al-Madid fi Tafsir Al-Qur'an Al-Majid (5: 343).
5. Al-Durr Al-Masun (9: 677).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: And Ibn Ajiba said: "And the direction of its corruption: Is that their taking them as deities contradicts their taking them as offerings; because the offering is intended for the sake of another, while deities are intended for themselves, so contemplate it." End quote (1). The fourth: That {offerings} (qurbanan) is a Hal (circumstantial state), and {deities} (alihatan) is the second object of taking, and the first object is deleted which is the returner of the relative pronoun, i.e., those they took. This was said by: Al-Zamakhshari (2), Al-Qurtubi (3), Al-Samin Al-Halabi (4), Abu Al-Saud (5), and others (6). Al-Samin said: "And the estimation is: Then why did those they took [them] seeking nearness by them as deities not aid them." End quote (7). And Abu Al-Saud said: "And the estimation is: Then why did those whom they took as deities while being [used as] means of drawing near to Allah - the Exalted - not aid them and save them from the punishment, as they used to say: {We only worship them that they may bring us nearer to Allah in position} [Az-Zumar: 3]." End quote (8).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: And the fourth aspect is the preferred one; due to its correctness in meaning and syntax, and I did not find anyone among the scholars who weakened it. And what Al-Samin mentioned in explaining the corruption of meaning based on Ibn Atiyyah's syntax is a valid point. Making {offerings} the second object of {took} and {deities} a substitute for it leads to an incorrect meaning as clarified by a number of scholars. This rectification shows Al-Samin's attention to meaning in syntax; for the meaning must be correct based on the syntax for the syntactic aspect to be accepted. Being grammatically correct does not make it a correct syntax if it leads to a corrupt meaning. However, Ibn Atiyyah is praised for mentioning a second possibility in the syntax of {offerings deities}, which is that {offerings} is a Hal, and {deities} is the second object of taking (1), and this second possibility is the preferred opinion. * * *
foot_note: 1. See: Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (5: 103).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: [30]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {Then indeed you, O those astray [who are] deniers, (51) Will be eating from trees of zaqqum (52) And filling with it your bellies (53) And drinking on top of it from scalding water (54)} [Al-Waqi'ah: 51 - 54]: "The pronoun in (on top of it) [alaihi] refers back to the eaten thing (ma'kul) or to the eating (akl)." End quote (1). And Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "And the pronoun in {with it} (minha) refers back to the trees, and in {on top of it} (alaihi) to the trees as well. It has been presented previously that the generic noun can be masculine or feminine, and they are two dialects. And it was said: in {alaihi} it refers back to the zaqqum. And Abu Al-Baqaa said: 'to the eaten thing' End quote (2). And Ibn Atiyyah said: 'to the eaten thing or the eating' End quote, and in his saying: 'the eating' there is far-fetchedness." End quote (3).
foot_note:
1. Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (5: 247).
2. Al-Tibyan fi I'rab Al-Qur'an (2: 1205).
3. Al-Durr Al-Masun (10: 210).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Study of the Rectification: Ibn Atiyyah held the permissibility of the pronoun in {on top of it} referring to the eaten thing and to the eating, while Al-Samin considered its reference to the eating unlikely. Regarding the referent of the pronoun here, there are two main opinions: First: That the pronoun in {on top of it} refers to the eating or to the filling. The eating is derived from His saying: {Will be eating from trees of zaqqum}, and the filling is taken from His saying: {And filling with it your bellies}. This opinion was mentioned by a number of scholars as a probable aspect and allowed by them, among them: Al-Farra (1), Ibn Atiyyah (2), Al-Biqa'i (3), and Al-Shawkani (4). Al-Farra said: "If you wish, it refers to the trees, and if you wish, to the eating." End quote (5). And Al-Biqa'i said: "{And drinking on top of it} meaning on top of this filling or eating." End quote (6). Al-Samin Al-Halabi considered its reference to the eating unlikely, but did not explain the reason for its unlikelihood (7).

4. See: Fath Al-Qadir (5: 185).
5. Ma'ani Al-Qur'an (3: 127).
6. Nazm Al-Durar fi Tanasub Al-Ayat wa Al-Suwar (19: 217).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Several interpretations have been given for this opinion; some said: It is 'al-ukul' (with Damma on Hamza and Kaf) - meaning the eaten thing -, not 'al-akl' (the source/action). (1) This interpretation, although plausible, is precluded by allowing two aspects: the eating (action) and the eaten thing, for that necessarily means that 'the eating' is the source (Masdar) and not 'al-ukul', otherwise it would be one opinion; for 'al-ukul' is the eaten thing. Ibn Ashur explicitly stated that the pronoun refers to the eating by interpreting the source as a passive participle, meaning: the eating is in the sense of the eaten thing (2). Second: That the pronoun in {on top of it} refers to the eaten thing, which is the trees of zaqqum. This was said by: Al-Akhfash (3), Al-Tabari (4), Al-Nahhas (5), Makki bin Abi Talib (6), Al-Zamakhshari (7), Al-Fakhr Al-Razi (8), Al-Samin (9), and others (10).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: As for the feminine pronoun in His saying: {And filling with it (minha) your bellies} then the masculine in His saying: {And drinking on top of it (alaihi) from scalding water}... that is because it refers to the trees (shajar), which is a generic noun; it can be treated as masculine or feminine. It was said: The feminine first is considering the meaning (trees as plural/collection), and the masculine second is considering the wording (shajar) (1). Al-Tabari said: "And the correct statement regarding that in our view is the second saying, which is that His saying: {filling with it} refers to the trees; feminized for the meaning, and He said: {drinking on top of it} in the masculine; for the wording of the trees." End quote (2). And Al-Zamakhshari said: "He feminized the pronoun of the trees based on the meaning, and masculinized it based on the wording in His saying: {with it} and {on top of it}. And He masculinized the second only based on the interpretation of zaqqum, because it explains it and is in its meaning." End quote (3). The Preferred View: The reference of the pronoun to the trees of zaqqum; because that is taken from the apparent wording as it is: {from trees of zaqqum}, unlike its reference to the eating; for that is derived from His saying: {Will be eating}. And because drinking is on top of the eaten thing, not on top of the consuming of it (4), and making the drinking on top of the eating - the source - is a type of metaphor (5). And what weakens its reference to the eating: is the explicit statement of some that this is based on interpreting the source as a passive participle, so it thereby enters into the preferred opinion which is its reference to the trees of zaqqum - the eaten thing.

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: And the reference of the pronoun to the filling is stronger than its reference to the eating; because the filling is closer in mention than the eating. In summary, the reference of the pronoun to the eating is not impossible or far-fetched, but the other option is stronger than it. So Ibn Atiyyah did not err by mentioning this opinion, especially since he mentioned it second and did not begin with it nor prefer it. * * * [31]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {So I swear by the positions of the stars (75) And indeed, it is a great oath, if you knew (76) Indeed, it is a noble Qur'an (77)} [Al-Waqi'ah: 75 - 77]: "And His saying - the Exalted -: {And indeed, it is an oath} is an emphasis of the matter and an alert about the object of the oath, and this is not a parenthetical clause (i'tirad) between the speech, rather this is a meaning intended to be cared for. The parenthetical clause is only His saying: {if you knew}. And a group said: That His saying: {And indeed, it is an oath} is a parenthetical clause, and that {if you knew} is a parenthetical clause within a parenthetical clause, but the correct view is what we mentioned." End quote (1). And Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "In the speech there are two parenthetical clauses. One of them: The parenthesis with His saying: {And indeed, it is an oath} between the oath and the complement of the oath (muqsam 'alayh). The second: The parenthesis with His saying: {if you knew} between the adjective and the noun described.
foot_note: 1. Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (5: 251).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: And Ibn Atiyyah refused to make His saying: {And indeed, it is an oath} a parenthetical clause, saying: '{And indeed, it is an oath} is an emphasis of the matter and an alert about the object of the oath, and this is not a parenthetical clause between the speech, rather this is a meaning intended to be cared for. The parenthetical clause is only His saying: {if you knew}.' End quote. I say: Its being an emphasis and an alert to the greatness of the object of the oath does not contradict the parenthesis; rather this is the meaning of the parenthesis and its benefit." End quote (1). Study of the Rectification: The majority went to the view that the sentence: {And indeed, it is an oath} is parenthetical; to emphasize the oath, and that His saying: {if you knew} is a parenthesis within a parenthesis (2). Ibn Jinni said: "Allah Glorified and Exalted said: {So I swear by the positions of the stars (75) And indeed, it is a great oath - if you knew - (76) Indeed, it is a noble Qur'an (77)} [Al-Waqi'ah]: This contains two parenthetical clauses: One of them His saying:
foot_note:
1. Al-Durr Al-Masun (10: 223).
2. book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: {And indeed, it is a great oath, if you knew}; because He interposed it between the oath which is His saying: {So I swear by the positions of the stars} and its answer which is His saying: {Indeed, it is a noble Qur'an}. And within this very parenthesis is another parenthesis between the described noun which is (oath) and its adjective which is {great}, and that is His saying: {if you knew}. So those are two parenthetical clauses as you see. If the speech had come without parenthesis, it would have been: 'So I swear by the positions of the stars, indeed it is a noble Qur'an, and indeed it is a great oath if you knew'." End quote (1). And Al-Zarkashi said, discussing the purposes of parenthesis: "Among them: The intent of emphasis, like His saying: {So I swear by the positions of the stars (75) And indeed, it is a great oath, if you knew (76)} [Al-Waqi'ah]. It contains two parentheses, for He interposed His saying: {And indeed, it is an oath} between the oath and its answer, and interposed His saying: {if you knew} between the adjective and the described noun. The intent is magnifying the status of what He swore by from the positions of the stars, and emphasizing its reverence in the souls, especially with His saying: {if you knew}." End quote (2). As for Ibn Atiyyah, he did not agree with the majority that the sentence {And indeed, it is an oath} is parenthetical, as he said: ... "{And indeed, it is an oath} is an emphasis of the matter and an alert about the object of the oath, and this is not a parenthetical clause between the speech, rather this is a meaning intended to be cared for." End quote (3). Al-Samin rectified him saying: "And its being an emphasis and an alert to the greatness of the object of the oath does not contradict the parenthesis, rather this is the meaning of the parenthesis and its benefit." End quote (4).
foot_note:
1. Al-Khasa'is (1: 336).
2. Al-Burhan fi 'Ulum Al-Qur'an (3: 58).
3. Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (5: 251).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: And what Al-Samin said agrees with what is established in the language; for the parenthetical sentence has purposes, and among its most prominent benefits: Emphasis and alerting to the greatness of a certain meaning in a sentence (1). So His saying: {And indeed, it is an oath} is a parenthesis intended to verify and emphasize the content of the oath sentence (2). Ibn Hisham said: "As for Ibn Atiyyah's statement: 'It contains only one parenthesis which is {if you knew}, because {And indeed, it is a great oath, if you knew} is emphasis not parenthesis', it is rejected; because emphasis and parenthesis are not mutually exclusive." End quote (3). Therefore: Al-Samin's rectification of Ibn Atiyyah is in its place, except that the disagreement between Ibn Atiyyah's opinion and the majority's opinion is a verbal disagreement and there is no disagreement between them in substance; for according to both opinions the sentence: {And indeed, it is a great oath, if you knew} was intended for emphasis and magnification. * * * [32]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {Indeed, it is a noble Qur'an (77) In a Register well-protected (78) None touch it except the purified (79) [It is] a revelation from the Lord of the worlds (80)} [Al-Waqi'ah]: "The opinion that {None touch it} (la yamassuhu) is a prohibition is an opinion containing weakness; that is because if it is a predicate (information), it is in the position of an adjective, and His saying after that: {a revelation} is an adjective as well. So if we made it a prohibition, a foreign meaning would come interposed between the adjectives, and that is not good in the arrangement of speech; so contemplate it.
foot_note:
1. See: Al-Khasa'is by Ibn Jinni (1: 336), Al-Tatbiq Al-Nahwi by Abduh Al-Rajhi (p. 350).

3. Mughni Al-Labib 'an Kutub Al-A'arib (1: 511).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: And in the reading of Ibn Mas'ud: (ma yamassuhu) [using 'ma' for negation] (1), and this strengthens what I preferred of it being a predicate whose meaning is: its right and due is that none touch it except a pure one." End quote (2). And Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "His saying: {la yamassuhu}: regarding this {la} there are two aspects. One of them: That it is negative, so the Damma in {la yamassuhu} is a Damma of declension (I'rab). Based on this opinion, there are two aspects for the sentence. One of them: That its locus is genitive as an adjective for {Register} (Kitab), and the meaning of {Register}: is either the Preserved Tablet, and {the purified} then are the angels, or the meaning is the Mushafs, and the meaning of {the purified} is all accountable beings (Mukallafun). The second: That its locus is nominative as an adjective for {Qur'an}, and the meaning of {the purified} is the angels only, i.e., none see it or none touch its tablet. One of these two metaphors must be adopted; because attributing touch to meanings literally is impossible. And what supports this being a negation is the reading of Abdullah [Ibn Mas'ud]: (ma yamassuhu) with the negative (ma). The second of the first two aspects: That it is prohibitive, and the verb after it is jussive (majzum); because if it were separated from assimilation (Idgham), that would appear in it as His saying: {evil did not touch them} (lam yamsashum) [Ali 'Imran: 174], but it was assimilated. And when it was assimilated, its end was moved with Damma due to the Ha of the masculine singular pronoun." Then Al-Samin said: "And with this that I mentioned, the corruption of the rejection of the one who rejected appears: that if this were a prohibition, it would have been said: (la yamassahu) with Fatha; because the permissibility of putting Damma on what is before the Ha in such a case was hidden from him, especially according to Sibawayh's view as he does not allow other than it (3).
foot_note:
1. The reading of the majority: (la yamassuhu), and Ibn Mas'ud read: (ma yamassuhu). See: Tafsir Al-Tabari (23: 152), Al-Hidayah ila Bulugh Al-Nihayah by Makki bin Abi Talib (11: 7292), Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (5: 252), Tafsir Abi Hayyan (10: 93), Al-Durr Al-Manthur by Al-Suyuti (8: 26).
2. Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (5: 252).
3. See: Al-Kitab by Sibawayh (2: 265).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: And Ibn Atiyyah weakened it being a prohibition: because if it is a predicate (information), it is in the position of an adjective, and His saying after that: {a revelation} is an adjective, so if we made it a prohibition, it would be a foreign element interposed between the adjectives, and that is not good in the arrangement of speech; so contemplate it, and in the reading of Ibn Mas'ud: (ma yamassuhu)' End quote. And there is nothing in what he mentioned that weakens this opinion; because we do not concede that {a revelation} is an adjective, rather it is a predicate of a deleted subject, meaning: it is a revelation; so the objection he mentioned does not apply. And even if we concede that it is an adjective... then {None touch it} is an adjective as well, so it is objected against us: that it is a demand/request, so it is answered: that it is based on the hiding of a saying (qawl), i.e., it is said regarding it: do not touch it." End quote (1). Study of the Rectification: Ibn Atiyyah considered it unlikely that His saying: {None touch it} is a prohibition, while Al-Samin did not agree with him in weakening this opinion, and defended it and directed it. This issue contains detail, and it consists of overlapping issues connected to each other. The first opinion in this issue, which is the opinion of the majority: That {None touch it} is a negation, and the pronoun refers to the Book which is in the heaven, and the purified ones are the angels (2).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: This opinion is consistent with what came from the Salaf in the interpretation of the verse (1). From Abdullah bin Abbas - may Allah be pleased with them both: The Book which is in the heaven, none touch it except the angels. (2) And in another narration from him, he said: When Allah wants to send down a Book, the Scribes copy it, so none touch it except the purified, meaning the angels. (3) And Imam Malik said: "The best I have heard regarding this verse: {None touch it except the purified} [Al-Waqi'ah: 79] is that it is of the status of this verse in {He frowned and turned away} [Abasa: 1], the saying of Allah Blessed and Exalted: ... {No! Indeed, it is a reminder (11) So whoever wills may remember it (12) In records honored (13) Exalted, purified (14) By the hands of scribes (15) Noble and dutiful (16)} [Abasa]." End quote (4). This saying of Malik indicates that it is a negation and the sentence is informative (predicate) (5). This negation opinion is supported by the reading of Abdullah bin Mas'ud: (ma yamassuhu); 'ma' being negative. Al-Wahidi said: "Most exegetes are on the view that the pronoun in His saying: {None touch it} refers to the protected Book, and {the purified} are the angels." End quote (6).
foot_note:

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Abdul Rahman Al-Anbari said: "{la} is negative not prohibitive, and for this reason {yamassuhu} was nominative, and the intended meaning of {the purified} is the angels." End quote (1). And the sentence: {None touch it except the purified} is an adjective for {Register} (Kitab), and the pronoun in {None touch it} refers to the protected Book; because it is the closest mentioned. (2) Some added and said: It is a negation with the meaning of prohibition (3); like His saying: {Divorced women remain in waiting for three periods} [Al-Baqarah: 228]; for the sentence is informative, but its meaning is: imperative, and like the saying of the Prophet, peace be upon him: ... (The Muslim is the brother of the Muslim, he does not wrong him nor surrender him) (4), and the meaning is: he should not wrong him. What supports that its meaning is prohibition is what came in the letter of 'Amr bin Hazm (5): (That none touch the Qur'an except a pure one) (6).

5. 'Amr bin Hazm bin Zaid Al-Khazraji Al-Ansari, Abu Al-Dahhak, a noble companion, witnessed the Trench and what followed, and the Messenger of Allah appointed him over Najran. He narrated from him a letter he wrote for him regarding obligations, Zakat, blood money, and other things. He died in 53 AH. The Hadith has several chains, most of which are Mursal, and what came connected has slight weakness in its chain, but its paths strengthen each other, so a number of scholars authenticated it and used it as evidence.
