book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Therefore, the majority of jurists held that it is not permissible for the person in a state of Janabah (sexual impurity), menstruation, or ritual impurity to touch the Mushaf (1), and this prohibition derived from the negation applies to the accountable human being, not the angels. The second opinion in this issue is that {None touch it} (la yamassuhu) is a prohibition, and the pronoun refers to the Mushaf in our hands, and the verb {yamassuhu} is jussive (majzum), and the Damma is a Damma of construction (Bina'), and it was moved with Damma only because of the masculine singular pronoun, and the purified are those purified from impurities. And the sentence {None touch it except the purified} is an adjective for the Qur'an. Makki bin Abi Talib mentioned this opinion as a probable aspect (2), Al-Qurtubi preferred it (3), and Al-Samin Al-Halabi allowed it (4). Makki said: "It was said: {la} is for prohibition, and the Damma in {yamassuhu} is construction, and the verb is jussive." End quote (5).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Ibn Atiyyah weakened that His saying: {None touch it except the purified} is a prohibition; because if it is a predicate (information), it is in the position of an adjective, and His saying after that: {a revelation} is an adjective as well. So if we made it a prohibition, a foreign meaning would come interposed between the adjectives (1). Al-Samin refuted him saying: "And there is nothing in what he mentioned that weakens this opinion; because we do not concede that {a revelation} is an adjective, rather it is a predicate of a deleted subject, meaning: it is a revelation; so the objection he mentioned does not apply. And even if we concede that it is an adjective, then {None touch it} is an adjective as well, so it is objected against us: that it is a demand/request, so it is answered: that it is based on the hiding of a saying (qawl), i.e., it is said regarding it: do not touch it." End quote (2). What Al-Samin mentioned in his defense of this opinion that {a revelation} is a predicate for a deleted subject is permissible. As for his saying that the sentence: {None touch it} involves the hiding of a saying, this is a remote possibility and there is no need to claim hiding. The reason Ibn Atiyyah mentioned for weakening this opinion is not a strong reason, for this aspect is weak for reasons more apparent and stronger than that, which will be mentioned in the weighting section. The third opinion in this issue: Detail; if His saying: {None touch it except the purified} is an adjective for the Book in the heaven, then it is a negation, and the purified are the angels. And if it is...

text: ...an adjective for the Mushaf in our hands, then it is a prohibition or a negation with the meaning of prohibition, and the purified are those purified from impurities or purified from polytheism and the like among humans. This was said by: Ibn Al-Jawzi (1), Al-Muntajib Al-Hamadhani (2), Abu Hayyan (3), and others (4). Weighting: The preferred view is that His saying - the Exalted -: {None touch it except the purified} is a negation, and the pronoun refers to the Book in the heaven, and the purified are the angels, and the sentence is an adjective for the Book. There are several factors supporting this opinion, including: 1 - The reference of the pronoun to the Book in the heaven is preferred over the Qur'an in our hands; because the Book is closer and the pronoun refers to the closest antecedent. (5) 2 - If {la} were prohibitive, the gemination would be undone and the vowel would appear: (yamsashu) (6) as in His saying: {evil did not touch them} (lam yamsashum) [Ali 'Imran: 174], or the gemination would remain and the Sin would come with Fatha; to prevent the meeting of...

text: ...two unvocalized letters (yamassahu). As for the permissibility of Damma, it is the opinion of Sibawayh and the majority did not hold it, and making it a Damma of construction causes confusion (1). 3 - Describing the Book as 'Maknun', meaning concealed from eyes, indicates that it is the Book in the heaven, not the one in our hands. Describing it as 'Maknun' is like describing it as 'Mahfuz' (Preserved); for His saying: {Indeed, it is a noble Qur'an (77) In a Register well-protected (78)} [Al-Waqi'ah] is like His saying: {But this is an honored Qur'an (21) [Inscribed] in a Preserved Tablet (22)} [Al-Buruj]. (2) 4 - Because He said: {None touch it except the purified (al-mutahharun)}, so they are the angels. If He intended the believers performing ablution, He would have said: 'None touch it except the self-purifying (al-mutatahhirun)', as He - the Exalted - said: {Indeed, Allah loves those who are constantly repentant and loves those who purify themselves (al-mutatahhirin)} [Al-Baqarah: 222]. So the angels are 'purified' (mutahharun), and the believers performing ablution are 'self-purifying' (mutatahhirun) (3). 5 - Because the verses are a refutation of those who said: The devils brought this Qur'an. So He - Glorified and Exalted - informed that it is in a protected Book which the devils cannot attain, and they have no access to it, as He - the Exalted - said in Surah Ash-Shu'ara: ... {And the devils have not brought it down (210) It is not allowable for them, nor would they be able (211) Indeed they are, from hearing it, removed (212)}. Rather, only the purified spirits attain it, and they are the angels (4).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: 6 - Because the verse is Meccan, in a Meccan Surah, containing the establishment of monotheism and refutation of the disbelievers. This meaning - that {la} is negative, the Book is the one in the heaven, and the purified are the angels - is more suitable to the intent than a practical subsidiary ruling, which is the ruling of touching the Mushaf by a person in a state of ritual impurity (1). 7 - Because if the Book in the hands of people were intended, there would not be much benefit in swearing by this great oath upon that. It is known that every speech is capable of being in a book, whether true or false. This is unlike if the oath is sworn that it is in a protected Book concealed from eyes with Allah, which no devil reaches, nor attains, and none touch it except the purified spirits; this meaning is more appropriate and majestic for the verse (2). 8 - Because the apparent meaning is that the sentence {None touch it except the purified} is an adjective, and the default in it is to be informative (predicate) (3). 9 - What supports it being negative is the reading of Abdullah bin Mas'ud: (ma yamassuhu); 'ma' being negative (4). 10 - Because the opinion that it is negative, the Book is the one in the heaven, and the purified are the angels is the opinion consistent with the interpretation of the Companions and Tabi'un for this verse. 11 - That this is more eloquent in refuting the deniers and more eloquent in magnifying the Qur'an than the fact that the Mushaf is not touched by a ritually impure person (5).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Therefore: Al-Samin's rectification of Ibn Atiyyah and his allowing {la} to be prohibitive and the verb after it jussive is not in its place. And what came in the verse, even if it is a negation and the purified are the angels, yet the prohibition regarding accountable humans is derived from it. Ibn Al-Qayyim said: "I heard Sheikh al-Islam establishing the deduction from the verse that the Mushaf should not be touched by a ritually impure person in another way. He said: This is by way of alert and indication: If the Scrolls in the heaven are not touched except by the purified, then likewise the Scrolls in our hands from the Qur'an should not be touched except by a pure one." ... End quote (1). The verse indicated the magnification of the Qur'an's status, and touching without purity violates its magnification, so the verse refuses it (2). Ibn Ashur said: "And since this noble rank has been established for the Qur'an, it became worthy that its recitation and writing be magnified. Therefore, it became among the commanded matters: that none touch the written Qur'an except the purified one, in imitation of the state of the angels in handling the Qur'an." End quote (3).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: He also said: "So this verse is not an evidence for the ruling of touching the Qur'an by human hands, but Allah's mention of it is not devoid of the intent that people be measured against the angels in that they do not touch the Qur'an unless they are pure like the angels, meaning to the extent possible of human purity. Thus it is established by this that the command for purification for one who holds a written text of the Qur'an was settled among the Muslims from the early period of Islam in Makkah." End quote (1). * * * [33]: Ibn Atiyyah said in the course of his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {And what Allah restored to His Messenger from the people of the towns - it is for Allah and for the Messenger and for [his] near relatives and orphans and the needy and the traveler - so that it will not be a perpetual distribution among the rich from among you. And whatever the Messenger has given you - take it; and what he has forbidden you - refrain from. And fear Allah; indeed, Allah is severe in penalty. (7) For the poor emigrants who were expelled from their homes and their properties, seeking bounty from Allah and [His] approval and supporting Allah and His Messenger. Those are the truthful. (8)} [Al-Hashr: 7 - 8]: "His saying - the Exalted -: {For the poor emigrants} (li-l-fuqara' al-muhajirin) is an explanation (Bayan)...

text: ...for His saying: {and the needy and the traveler}. He repeated the 'Lam' of genitive (Li-) since the first one was genitive with 'Lam'; to clarify that the substitution is only from them." End quote (1). And Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "His saying: {For the poor}: in it are three aspects. One of them: That it is a substitute (Badal) from {for [his] near relatives} (li-dhi al-qurba). This was said by Abu Al-Baqaa and Al-Zamakhshari. Abu Al-Baqaa said: 'It was said it is a substitute from {and for [his] near relatives} and what is after it' End quote (2). And Al-Zamakhshari said: 'A substitute from His saying: {and for [his] near relatives} and what was conjoined to it. And what prevented substitution from {it is for Allah and for the Messenger} and what was conjoined to them - even if the meaning is for the Messenger of Allah - is: that Allah Almighty and Majestic excluded His Messenger from the poor in His saying: {and supporting Allah and His Messenger}, and that He - the Exalted - elevates His Messenger above being named as poor, and that substitution based on the apparent wording is contrary to the obligation in magnifying Allah Almighty and Majestic.' End quote (3). He means that if it were said: that it is a substitute from {for Allah} and what is after it, what was mentioned would follow: that the substitution based on the apparent wording would be from the Majesty (Allah), so it would be said: {For the poor} is a substitute from {for Allah} and from {for the Messenger}, which is ugly in wording, even if the meaning is contrary to this apparent sense, as he said: Its meaning is for the Messenger of Allah, and Allah Almighty and Majestic was mentioned only for magnification, otherwise Allah - the Exalted - is free of need from the Fay' (spoils) and other things. He made it a substitute from {for [his] near relatives} only because he is Hanafi, and the Hanafis stipulate poverty in giving the near relatives from the Fay'. The second: That it is an explanation for His saying: {and the needy and the traveler}, and the 'Lam' of genitive was repeated since the first one was genitive with 'Lam'; to clarify that the substitution is only from them. This was said by Ibn Atiyyah, and it is a very awkward phrasing.

text: The third: That {For the poor} is a predicate for a deleted subject, i.e., 'But the Fay' is for the poor'. It was said: Its estimation is: 'But it is for the poor'. And it was said: Its estimation is: 'Wonder at the poor'." End quote (1). Study of the Rectification: First: The sayings of the scholars regarding the syntax of His saying: {For the poor} (li-l-fuqara'): They have four main opinions on this: 1 - That His saying: {For the poor} is a substitute from {near relatives} and what was conjoined to it, and it is not valid for it to be a substitute from the Messenger; lest it necessitate describing the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, with poverty. This was said by: Al-Nahhas (2), Al-Zamakhshari (3), Al-Fakhr Al-Razi (4), Abu Al-Baqaa (5), Al-Baydawi (6), and others (7).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Al-Fakhr Al-Razi said: "This is a substitute from His saying: {and for [his] near relatives and orphans and the needy and the traveler}, as if He said: I mean by those four these poor emigrants whose description is such and such." End quote (1). And Al-Baydawi said: "{For the poor emigrants} is a substitute from {for [his] near relatives} and what was conjoined to it; for the Messenger is not called poor." End quote (2). The implication of substitution is the condition of poverty for the near relatives (3) and the mentioned categories, meaning that poverty is a condition in all four categories (4). 2 - That His saying: {For the poor} is an explanation (Bayan) for His saying: {and the needy and the traveler}. This was said by Ibn Atiyyah (5), and Al-Tha'alibi agreed with him (6). Ibn Atiyyah said: "{For the poor emigrants} is an explanation for His saying: {and the needy and the traveler}. He repeated the 'Lam' of genitive since the first one was genitive with 'Lam'; to clarify that the substitution is only from them." End quote (7). Al-Samin weakened what Ibn Atiyyah said, saying: "And it is a very awkward phrasing." End quote (8).

text: 3 - That His saying: {For the poor} is connected to a deleted element indicated by His saying: {so that it will not be a perpetual distribution among the rich from among you}, and the estimation is: 'But it is for the poor', and what is between them is a parenthesis. And it was said: It is connected to a deleted verb estimated as: 'Wonder at the poor'. This was mentioned by some scholars as a probable aspect, among them: Al-Muntajib Al-Hamadhani (1), Al-Qurtubi (2), Al-Samin (3), and Al-Shawkani (4). Al-Qurtubi said: "It was said: {so that it will not be a perpetual distribution among the rich} but it is for the poor." End quote (5). And Al-Shawkani said: "It was said: The estimation is: {so that it will not be a perpetual distribution} but it is for the poor. And it was said: The estimation is: Wonder at the poor." End quote (6). The implication of this direction is the lack of stipulating poverty for the near relatives, and the meaning is: Wonder at these poor emigrants who left their homes and properties (7). 4 - That His saying: {For the poor} is a conjunction to what has passed, without bringing the conjunction particle 'Waw', like the saying of a speaker: The money is for Zaid, for 'Amr, for Bakr.

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Al-Qurtubi (1) and Al-Shawkani (2) mentioned it as a probable aspect. Al-Qurtubi said: "It was said: It is a conjunction to what has passed, and he did not bring the conjunction 'Waw', like your saying: This money is for Zaid, for Bakr, for so-and-so, for so-and-so." End quote (3). Second: Weighting: The preferred view is that His saying: {For the poor emigrants} is a substitute (Badal) from whatever is suitable to be substituted from among the names of the preceding categories (4): {and for [his] near relatives and orphans and the needy and the traveler}. What prevented substitution from (for Allah and for the Messenger) is that it is obligatory to magnify them (5). The 'Lam' was repeated with the substitute to link it to the substituted-from due to the separation between them by the length of speech involving justification and warning, and to provide emphasis (6). This is the opinion of most syntacticians (7).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: It is also valid that His saying: {For the poor emigrants} is a conjunction to what has passed from the preceding categories: {and for [his] near relatives and orphans and the needy and the traveler} with the deletion of the conjunction particle, so {For the poor emigrants}: these are another category of those entitled to the wealth of Fay' (1). This is a strong opinion despite the scarcity of those who held it among syntacticians. As for Ibn Atiyyah's statement: that His saying {For the poor} is an explanation for His saying: {and the needy and the traveler}: this is a specification with no basis. As for those who said: The estimation is: 'But it is for the poor', or: 'Wonder at the poor': their statement, although permissible from the perspective of meaning, is far-fetched from the perspective of syntax; there is no need to claim deletion and estimation. Therefore: Al-Samin's rectification of Ibn Atiyyah is valid; for Ibn Atiyyah's opinion contains weakness, such that the majority of scholars did not mention it among the probable syntactical analyses; which indicates its remoteness. * * *

And the validity of the indefinite noun occurring as a subject is because the context is one of detailing, not that {radiant} is an attribute... for {faces} and the predicate is {Looking} as it was said; because of what is famous that the right of the attribute is that its attribution to the described noun be known to the listener, and since the establishment of radiance for the faces is not so, its right is to be predicated." text: Allowed by Abu Al-Baqaa (1), and Al-Samin Al-Halabi considered it far-fetched, saying: "It is far-fetched due to the lack of need for it, and I do not know what led them to this despite the clarity of the first aspect and its freedom from these arbitrary interpretations? And {at} (ila) being a preposition, and {their Lord} being genitive by it is what comes to mind immediately." End quote (2). 5 - That {faces} is a subject, and {Looking} is an attribute for {radiant} or an attribute for the faces, and {radiant} is the predicate of {faces}. Allowed by: Al-Nahhas (3), and Makki bin Abi Talib (4). And it is not apparent. Second: Weighting: The first opinion is the preferred one, which is that His saying: {faces} is a subject, and {radiant} is an attribute, and {Looking} is the predicate of the subject; this is the clearest and most correct of the aspects from the perspective of meaning and syntax. The meaning of this opinion is: That the beautiful faces on the Day of Resurrection are looking at their Lord. This meaning is correct and apparent, and consistent with what came from the Salaf in the interpretation of the verse, where more than one of the Salaf interpreted it as: beautiful faces looking at their Lord (5).

text: And it is permissible that His saying: {faces} is a subject, and {radiant} is its predicate, and {Looking} is an attribute for the faces, or a second predicate. As for Al-Samin's rectification of Ibn Atiyyah, it is valid; because Ibn Atiyyah's statement that {radiant} is the predicate of {faces} and {Looking at their Lord} is a sentence in the position of a second predicate is an opinion containing far-fetchedness; because speech is not tied together from them, and the apparent meaning is the connection of {at their Lord} to {Looking}, and the majority of syntacticians have stated that (1). * * *

book_title: Al-Samin al-Halabi's Supplementary Notes on Al-Durr al-Masun on Ibn Atiyah in Quranic Readings, Tafsir, and Grammar: Collection and Study
text: Chapter Three: Al-Samin's Supplementary Notes on Ibn Atiyah in Tafsir by Opinion. [1]: Ibn Atiyah said in his Tafsir regarding the verse - Exalted is He -: {Indeed, in the creation of the heavens and the earth, the alternation of night and day, the ships that sail through the sea for the benefit of mankind, what Allah sends down from the sky of water, reviving the earth after its death and spreading in it all kinds of creatures, and the management of the winds and the clouds subservient between the sky and the earth, are signs for a people who reason} [Al-Baqarah: 164]: 'And al-riyah (winds) is the plural of rih (wind). It appears in the Qur’an combined with mercy, and in singular form with punishment, except in Yunus in His saying - Exalted is He -: {And We drove them with a good wind} [Yunus: 22]. This is the most common usage in speech. In the Hadith: the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, when the wind blew, would say: "O Allah, make it a beneficial wind and not a harmful one." (1) Qadi Abu Muhammad said: This is because the wind of punishment is strong and cohesive, as if it were a single body, whereas the wind of mercy is gentle and scattered; hence it is pluralized, and it was singular with ships because the wind that propels ships is continuous. When it is described as good, the similarity with the wind of punishment is removed.' End quote. (2) Al-Samin al-Halabi, supplementing Ibn Atiyah, said: 'What he said is countered by the variation of the reciters in eleven places, details of which will follow. What can be said is that the plural does not occur with punishment at all; the singular appears in both cases. That is why it was specified in the supplication in plural form.' End quote. (3)
foot_note:
1. The Hadith is weak and has no basis; Abu Ja'far al-Tahawi said in Sharh Mushkil al-Athar (2:379): 'It has no basis.' Al-Albani judged its chain as weak. See: Silsilat al-Ahadith al-Da'ifah by Al-Albani (9:228).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Syntax: Collection and Study
text: Study of the Rectification: Some scholars of interpretation and Quranic sciences mentioned a rule regarding the occurrence of the two words (the wind - *al-rih*) and (the winds - *al-riyah*) in the Quran. They stated that this word appears in the singular form with punishment, and in the plural form with mercy, and that this is a predominant rule (1). Among those who stated this was Ibn Atiyyah, as he said: '(The winds) is the plural of wind, and it came in the Quran in the plural form with mercy, and singular with punishment, except in Yunus in His saying - the Exalted -: {and they run with them with a good wind} [Yunus: 22], and this is the majority of its occurrence in speech.' End quote (2). Ibn Atiyyah and others used as evidence the hadith: (Oh Allah, make it winds and do not make it a wind), but this argumentation is not valid due to the lack of proven authenticity of this hadith from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. As for Al-Samin, he did not agree with Ibn Atiyyah in what he went towards, refuting him with the difference of the Reciters (Qurra') in eleven places, and that is one of the aspects of Al-Samin's attention to the Readings, where he uses them as evidence to refute some opinions or support them. Then Al-Samin said: 'Rather, what is said is: The plural form did not come with punishment at all; as for the singular, it came in both, and for that reason, peace be upon him, singled it out in his supplication using the plural form.' End quote (3). In this issue, there is detail, and there is some discussion regarding the speech of both Ibn Atiyyah and Al-Samin.
foot_note:
1. See: Tafsir al-Samarqandi (1: 110), Tafsir Ibn Furak (1: 199), Tafsir al-Mawardi (4: 319), Tafsir al-Qurtubi (2: 198), Al-Burhan fi 'Ulum al-Quran by al-Zarkashi (4: 9).
2. Al-Muharrar al-Wajiz (1: 233).
3. Al-Durr al-Masun (2: 207).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Syntax: Collection and Study
text: First: The difference between (the wind) and (the winds): (The wind) in the singular denotes the genus, and in the plural (the winds) because they vary in courses and benefits. Thus, in mercy, it is called (winds); due to their multiplicity, for they are the South, the North, and the East (Saba) winds. As for the wind of punishment, it is one, intense, with cohesive parts as if it were a single body (1). Al-Qurtubi said: 'Whoever made the wind singular, it is because it is a noun for the genus indicating the few and the many, and whoever made it plural, it is because of the difference of directions from which the winds blow.' End quote (2). Ibn al-Qayyim said: 'Allah - Glory be to Him - informs about the winds of mercy in the plural form due to the difference of their benefits and what results from them; so a wind stirs the clouds, a wind pollinates them, a wind carries them on its back, and a wind nourishes the plants. Since the winds are different in their blowing directions and natures, He made for every wind a counterpart wind to break its intensity and sharpness, so its softness and mercy remain; thus, the winds of mercy are multiple. As for the wind of punishment, it is a single wind sent from one face to destroy what it is sent to destroy, so no other wind stands against it to break its intensity and repel its sharpness; rather, it is like a mighty army that nothing can resist; it destroys everything it comes upon.' End quote (3).
foot_note:
1. book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Syntax: Collection and Study
text: Second: Regarding the rule being predominant: Everyone who established that rule indicated that it is predominant and not absolute. They made an exception for what came in His saying: {It is He who enables you to travel on land and sea until, when you are in ships and they run with them with a good wind}... [Yunus: 22], where the wind appeared here in the singular within the context of mercy. They mentioned the reason for singling out the wind in this position, stating that it was singular here in relation to the ships; because the wind for moving ships is only one and continuous. Then it was described as 'good', so the commonality between it and the wind of punishment was removed (1). Ibn al-Qayyim said: 'Reflect on how this is consistent except in His saying in Surah Yunus: {It is He who enables you to travel on land and sea until, when you are in ships and they run with them with a good wind and they rejoice therein, there comes to them a stormy wind} [Yunus: 22]. So He mentioned the wind of mercy (the good one) in the singular wording; because the completion of mercy there is only achieved by the unity of the wind, not its variation; for the ship does not sail except with one wind from one direction. If the winds vary against it, collide, and oppose each other, it is a cause for destruction. Thus, what is required there is one wind, not winds. He emphasized this meaning by describing it as good; to repel the illusion that it might be a stormy wind; rather, it is one of the things to be rejoiced in due to its goodness.' End quote (2).

2. Bada'i' al-Fawa'id (1: 118).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Quranic Syntax: Collection and Study
text: Third: Discussion of the statements of Ibn Atiyyah and Al-Samin, and the preference: As for the statement of Ibn Atiyyah and those who agreed with him: even if it were correct that this rule is predominant, that is from their reasoning (ijtihad) and opinion; as for their argumentation with the hadith, it is not valid. Likewise, Abu Ja'far al-Nahhas refuted those who argued with that hadith, stating it is weak and has no basis (1). As for Al-Samin's rectification upon Ibn Atiyyah that what he said is refuted by the difference of the Reciters: Indeed, Ibn Atiyyah followed up by mentioning the difference of the Reciters regarding this word immediately after his statement, where he said: 'As for the Seven Reciters, they differed; Nafi' read (the winds - *al-riyah*) in twelve places: Here, and in Al-A'raf: {He sends the winds} [Al-A'raf: 57], and in Ibrahim: {the winds blow strongly with it} [Ibrahim: 18], and in Al-Hijr: {the winds as fertilizers} [Al-Hijr: 22], and in Al-Kahf: {the winds disperse it} [Al-Kahf: 45], and in Al-Furqan: {He sent the winds} [Al-Furqan: 48], and in An-Naml: {And He who sends the winds} [An-Naml: 63], and in Ar-Rum: {And of His signs is that He sends the winds as bringers of good tidings} [Ar-Rum: 46], {Allah is the One who sends the winds, so they stir up clouds} [Ar-Rum: 48], and in Fatir: {And Allah is the One who sent the winds} [Fatir: 9], and in Al-Jathiyah: {and the directing of the winds} [Al-Jathiyah: 5], and in Ha-Mim 'Ain-Sin-Qaf: {He stills the winds} [Ash-Shura: 33]. Abu 'Amr, 'Asim, and Ibn 'Amir read two of these positions in the singular: in Ibrahim and in Ha-Mim 'Ain-Sin-Qaf, while they read the rest like the reading of Nafi'.
foot_note: 1. See: Ma'ani al-Quran (5: 34).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: And Ibn Kathir read it in the plural form in five places: Here [Al-Baqarah], in Al-Hijr, in Al-Kahf, in Ar-Rum [the first instance], and in Al-Jathiyah, and the rest of what is in the Qur'an he read in the singular. Hamza read it in the plural in two places: In Al-Furqan and in Ar-Rum [the first instance], and he read the rest of what is in the Qur'an in the singular. Al-Kisa'i read like Hamza and added to it in Al-Hijr: {the fertilizing winds} [Al-Hijr: 22]. And they did not differ in the singular form for what does not have Alif and Lam (1)." End quote (2). Ibn Atiyyah is objected to for preferring the plural reading (Al-Riyah) over the singular reading (Al-Rih) - which is a sound and established reading - relying on that rule he mentioned! Where he said: "The plural reading is more appropriate (awjah); because the custom of 'wind' (Rih) whenever it appeared in the Qur'an in the singular form is that it is for punishment." End quote (3). Such preference between sound readings is not appropriate. Al-Alusi said: "In Ibn Atiyyah's words there is negligence of the interpretation by which the two readings agree... and it is not permissible to say regarding that reading that it is more appropriate than the other reading while both are Mutawatir (mass transmitted)." End quote (4).

2. Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (1: 233).
3. Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (4: 213).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: As for what Al-Samin and Al-Farra (1) before him said, that the winds in plural form did not come with punishment at all, while the singular came in the context of both mercy and punishment: this statement is more accurate than the previous one, but it is invalidated by the reading of Abu Ja'far: (qasifan min al-riyah) (2) [Al-Isra: 69] in the plural form in the context of punishment. The correct view is that the statement that 'wind' comes singular with punishment and plural with mercy cannot be established even as a general rule; given that the difference among the ten readers regarding this word was not in few places but in more than eleven places. And we should not establish a rule in the wording of the Qur'an relying on some sound readings to the exclusion of others. It is more correct to restrict this rule to the reading of Hafs alone without generalization. So it is said: According to the reading of Hafs: whatever came of the word (Rih) singular is in the context of punishment, and whatever came plural is in the context of mercy, except for what came in the verse of Yunus: {and they sailed with them with a fair wind} [Yunus: 22], and that singular form came for a reason and wisdom - previously mentioned. Note that there are places where this word appeared singular and plural in contexts other than mercy and punishment, such as the context of parables, as in His saying: {And present to them the example of the life of this world, [its being] like rain which We send down from the sky, and the vegetation of the earth mingles with it and [then] it becomes dry remnants, scattered by the winds} [Al-Kahf: 45], and His saying: {and he who associates with Allah - it is as though he had fallen from the sky and was snatched by the birds or the wind carried him down into a remote place} [Al-Hajj: 31]. * * *
foot_note:
1. See: Ma'ani Al-Qur'an (2: 269).
2. Abu Ja'far read it in the plural: (Al-Riyah), and the rest read it in the singular: (Al-Rih), and both readings are sound. See: Tafsir Al-Qurtubi (10: 293), Tafsir Abi Hayyan (7: 83), Al-Nashr fi Al-Qira'at Al-'Ashr by Ibn Al-Jazari (2: 223).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: [2]: Ibn Atiyyah said in his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {And a faction of the People of the Scripture said [to each other], "Believe in that which was revealed to the believers at the beginning of the day and reject it at its end that perhaps they will abandon their religion (72) And do not trust except those who follow your religion." Say, "Indeed, the [true] guidance is the guidance of Allah" - [do not trust] that anyone be given [knowledge] like what you were given or that they would argue with you before your Lord. Say, "Indeed, [all] bounty is in the hand of Allah - He grants it to whom He wills. And Allah is All-Encompassing and Wise." (73)} [Ali 'Imran: 72 - 73]: "Allah - the Exalted - mentioned about this faction of the People of the Scripture that they said: {And do not trust except those who follow your religion}, and there is no disagreement among the people of interpretation that this saying is from the speech of the faction." End quote (1). And Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "They differed regarding the sentence from His saying: {And do not trust (believe)}: Is it from the speech of the faction or from the speech of Allah - the Exalted -, meaning that Allah - the Exalted - addressed the believers with it to strengthen their hearts and calm their fear; so that they do not doubt when the Jews confuse them and falsify things? Ibn Atiyyah reported consensus from the people of interpretation that it is from the speech of the faction, and this is not correct due to what people have reported of disagreement." End quote (2).
foot_note:
1. Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (1: 454).
2. Al-Durr Al-Masun (3: 256).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Study of the Rectification: The exegetes differed regarding His saying: {And do not trust except those who follow your religion}: Is it from the speech of the faction, or an address from Allah - the Exalted - to the believers? The majority went to the view that it is from the saying of the faction (1). Then they differed in detailing this saying; some said: It is the saying of the leaders of the Jews and their rabbis to the lower class among them (2), and others said: It is the saying of the Jews of Khaybar to the Jews of Medina (3). Al-Tabari said: "He - Majestic is His praise - means by that: And do not believe except one who follows your religion and is a Jew. And this is information from Allah about the saying of the faction who said to their brothers from the Jews: {Believe in that which was revealed to the believers at the beginning of the day}." End quote (4). And Al-Fakhr Al-Razi said: "The meaning is: And do not believe (trust) except a prophet who confirms the laws of the Torah, but as for one who comes changing anything of the rulings of the Torah, do not believe him." End quote (5).

1. 3. See: Tafsir Al-Qur'an Al-Aziz by Ibn Abi Zamanin (1: 296), Tafsir Al-Mawardi (1: 401), Tafsir Al-Qurtubi (4: 112).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: And Al-Shawkani said regarding His saying: {And do not trust except those who follow your religion}: "This is from the speech of the Jews to one another, meaning: The leaders said that to the lower class: Do not believe with a true belief except one who follows your religion from the people of the creed you are upon. As for others who have embraced Islam, show them deception at the beginning of the day and reject it at its end; so that they may be seduced." End quote (1). Ibn Atiyyah reported the consensus of the exegetes that this is from the speech of the faction (2), and Al-Samin objected to him saying: "And it is not correct; due to what people have reported of disagreement." End quote (3). Ibn Atiyyah was not alone in reporting consensus on that; Al-Fakhr Al-Razi agreed with him (4), and others (5). Al-Fakhr Al-Razi said: "The exegetes agreed that this is from the rest of the speech of the Jews." End quote (6). Al-Tabari preferred that everything in the verse is a report from Allah about the saying of the faction except His saying: {Say, "Indeed, the [true] guidance is the guidance of Allah"}, and he said: "And we chose that over other opinions we mentioned; because it is the most correct in meaning, the best in alignment with the meaning of the speech of the Arabs, and the most consistent with...
foot_note:

2. See: Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (1: 454).
3. Al-Durr Al-Masun (3: 256).
4. See: Tafsir Al-Fakhr Al-Razi (8: 259).
5. See: Tafsir Al-Naysaburi (2: 187).
6. Tafsir Al-Fakhr Al-Razi (8: 259).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: ...the structure and context of the speech. Anything other than that is an extraction far from correctness involving severe forcing of the speech." End quote (1). Some exegetes (2) mentioned that His saying: {And do not trust except those who follow your religion} is an address from Allah to the believers, not a narration about the Jews. Then they mentioned several aspects in its interpretation: The first: That the meaning is: And do not trust except one who follows the religion of Islam, and this would be a clarification that this Sharia is the most complete of Sharias. The second: That this is an encouragement to ally with the believers, and a prohibition against mixing with the disbelievers, like: ... {And do not incline toward those who do wrong} [Hud: 113]. The third: That it contains, along with the previous meaning, an encouragement for the believer not to accompany one whose path is not his path (3). The fourth: That this is an address from Allah to the believers; to strengthen their hearts and calm their fear; so that they do not doubt when the Jews engage in deception and raising doubts (4).
foot_note:
1. Tafsir Al-Tabari (6: 516).
2. This opinion was reported by a number of exegetes from others without attribution. See: Tafsir Al-Raghib Al-Isfahani (2: 647), Tafsir Abi Hayyan (3: 212), Al-Durr Al-Masun (3: 256), Tafsir Al-Alusi (2: 212).
3. See: Tafsir Al-Raghib Al-Isfahani (2: 647).
4. See: Al-Durr Al-Masun (3: 256).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: The fifth: That the meaning is: Do not disclose the secrets of the Truth except to its people, and do not acknowledge the meanings of the reality to those veiled from the people, lest they attack you and intend to shed your blood (1). All these aspects are forced and not suitable to the context. Therefore: The opinion of the majority is the preferred one, and attributing His saying: {And do not trust except those who follow your religion} to the speech of the faction is what agrees with the interpretation of the Salaf (2), and is suitable to the context of the verses. As for the consensus reported by Ibn Atiyyah, it occurred among the early exegetes; for they mentioned only one opinion. As for some later scholars who mentioned the other probability, that it is an address from Allah to the believers, they did not prefer this opinion nor did they attribute it to a specific scholar. * * *
foot_note:

2. Those of the Salaf who interpreted the verse attributed His saying: (And do not trust except those who follow your religion) to the speech of the Jews. Among those who said this: Qatadah, Al-Hasan, Ibn Zaid, Al-Rabi', and Al-Suddi. See: Tafsir Al-Tabari (6: 511), Tafsir Ibn Al-Mundhir (1: 253), Tafsir Ibn Abi Hatim (2: 680), Tafsir Al-Mawardi (1: 401), Al-Durr Al-Manthur by Al-Suyuti (2: 241).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: [3]: Ibn Atiyyah said upon his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {Have they not seen how many generations We destroyed before them which We had established upon the earth as We have not established you? And We sent [rain from] the sky upon them in showers and made rivers flow beneath them; then We destroyed them for their sins and produced after them a generation of others.} [Al-An'am: 6]: "And 'Al-Qarn' (generation) is the nation associated in a period of time. From it is his saying, peace be upon him: (The best of people are my generation [Qarni]) the Hadith (1). And people differed regarding the duration of the 'Qarn', how much is it? The majority is that it is a hundred years... and it was said: The Qarn is eighty years, and it was said: seventy, and it was said: sixty...". Until he said: "And all this is weak, and these are classes/layers (Tabaqat) and not generations (Qurun). The Qarn is only that there be the death of the elders and then the birth of the children, and that appears from His saying - the Exalted -: {and produced after them a generation of others}." End quote (2). And Al-Samin Al-Halabi said regarding the meaning of 'Al-Qarn': "The apparent meaning is that it is the people, because it is mostly applied to them, and dominance indicates originality usually. And Ibn Atiyyah said: 'The Qarn is that there be the death of the elders and the birth of the children, and that appears from His saying - the Exalted -: {and produced after them a generation of others}' End quote, so he made it a meaning [abstract concept], and it is not clear." End quote (3). Study of the Rectification:
foot_note:
1. Agreed upon: Narrated by Al-Bukhari in his Sahih (5: 2) Book of Virtues, Chapter: Virtues of the Companions of the Prophet PBUH, Hadith (3650), and Muslim in his Sahih (4: 1964) Book of Virtues of the Companions, Chapter: Virtue of the Companions then those who follow them, Hadith (2535).
2. Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (2: 269).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: The scholars' opinions regarding the intended meaning of 'Al-Qarn' varied, and all their sayings fall under two main meanings: The first: That 'Al-Qarn' refers to the people or the nation of humans in a period of time, whether the period is short or long. This was said by: Al-Tabari (1), Al-Zajjaj (2), Al-Wahidi (3), Al-Raghib (4), Al-Fakhr Al-Razi (5), Al-Qurtubi (6), Al-Samin Al-Halabi (7), and others (8). Al-Zajjaj said: "Al-Qarn are the people of a period in which there was a prophet or in which there was a class of people of knowledge, whether the years were few or many. The evidence for this is the saying of the Prophet, peace be upon him: (The best of you is my generation [Qarni]) (9)." End quote (10). And Al-Raghib Al-Isfahani said: "Al-Qarn: The people associated in one time." End quote (11).

2. See: Ma'ani Al-Qur'an wa I'rabuhu (2: 229).

4. See: Al-Mufradat, entry: Qarn (1: 667).
5. See: Tafsir Al-Fakhr Al-Razi (12: 484).
6. See: Tafsir Al-Qurtubi (6: 391).
7. See: Al-Durr Al-Masun (4: 540).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Al-Fakhr Al-Razi said: "The closest view is that it is not determined by a specific time in which increase or decrease does not occur, but the intended meaning is the people of every era." End quote (1). The second: That 'Al-Qarn' is a period of time, and they differed in defining this period. The majority said: A hundred years. And it was said: A hundred and twenty years, and it was said: eighty, and it was said: seventy, and it was said: sixty, and it was said: forty, and it was said: thirty, and it was said: twenty (2). Ibn Atiyyah weakened those opinions regarding defining the duration of the Qarn, and said that the Qarn is by the death of the elders and the birth of the children (3). Al-Samin rectified him on that; stating that what he went to is not clear (4). The Preferred View: That 'Al-Qarn' in the Qur'an refers to the people or the nation of humans; they were named so due to their association (iqtiran) in a period of time.
foot_note:
1. Tafsir Al-Fakhr Al-Razi (12: 484).
2. See: Tafsir Al-Qur'an Al-Aziz by Ibn Abi Zamanin (2: 59), Al-Hidayah ila Bulugh Al-Nihayah by Makki bin Abi Talib (3: 1962), Zad Al-Masir fi 'Ilm Al-Tafsir by Ibn Al-Jawzi (2: 9), Tafsir Al-Baydawi (2: 154).
3. See: Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (2: 269).
4. See: Al-Durr Al-Masun (4: 540).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Among those who preferred this meaning are: Al-Zajjaj (1), Al-Fakhr Al-Razi (2), Al-Qurtubi (3), Al-Samin (4), and Al-Alusi (5). As for what Ibn Atiyyah said, that the 'Qarn' (generation) is defined by the death of elders and the birth of children, using as evidence {and produced after them a generation of others}: this does not support his view. The 'production' (Insha') in {and produced} does not refer to the death of elders and birth of children; because that is a continuous matter among humans and contains no lesson or threat. Rather, the lesson lies in Allah destroying a people and then creating another people after them, containing both young and old, just as He established Quraysh in the dwellings of Jurhum, and as He established Thamud after 'Aad (6). So what appears is that the meaning of destroying a 'Qarn' is: the destruction of a nation among nations, who lived for a time wherein the death of elders and birth of children is not a condition, but rather Allah destroys them if He wills, when He wills, even if their elders have not died and their children have not been born. The opinion that 'Qarn' in the verse refers to 'time' is a weak opinion; for destruction does not fall upon time itself but upon the people who are in that time. Those who said it is 'time' were forced to estimate an annexed noun (Mudaf), so the estimation according to them is: 'How many [people of a] generation/time We destroyed before them'. All of this is forced with no need for it.
foot_note:

2. See: Tafsir Al-Fakhr Al-Razi (12: 484).
3. See: Tafsir Al-Qurtubi (6: 391).
4. See: Al-Durr Al-Masun (4: 539).
5. See: Tafsir Al-Alusi (4: 89).
6. See: Al-Tahrir wa Al-Tanwir by Ibn Ashur (7: 140).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Furthermore, Allah - the Exalted - described the 'Qarn' at the end of the verse as {others} (akharina) [plural masculine rational], and this cannot apply to time, but rather to people. Al-Alusi said: "The intended meaning of 'Qarn' here is: The inhabitants, without burdening oneself with estimating an annexed noun or committing a metaphor." End quote (1). As for 'Qarn' in general terminology, it applies to both time and people, and outside of the Qur'an, 'Qarn' is often applied to one hundred years of time (2). * * *
foot_note:

2. This is the opinion of the majority regarding the duration of a Qarn. See: Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (2: 268), Tafsir Al-Qurtubi (6: 391), Tafsir Abi Hayyan (4: 426), Al-Tahrir wa Al-Tanwir by Ibn Ashur (7: 137).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: [4]: Ibn Atiyyah said in his interpretation of His saying - the Exalted -: {[It is He] who has made for you the earth as a bed and inserted therein for you roads and sent down from the sky water. And We produced thereby [various] pairs of diverse plants.} [Taha: 53]: "His saying: {And We produced thereby} (fa-akhrajna bihi) bears the possibility that the speech of Moses ended at His saying: {and sent down from the sky water}, then Allah - the Exalted - connected Moses' speech with His information to Muhammad, peace be upon him - and the creation collectively is intended - [about] these signs being drawn attention to." ... End quote (1).
foot_note: 1. Al-Muharrar Al-Wajiz (4: 48).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: And Al-Samin Al-Halabi said: "His saying: {Who made for you} (Alladhi ja'ala lakum): In this relative pronoun there are two aspects. One of them: That it is a predicate of a hidden subject, or accusative by estimating 'I praise' (amdahu). Under these two estimations, it is from the speech of Allah - the Exalted - not from the speech of Moses. We only needed this because His saying: {And We produced thereby}, and His saying: {Eat and graze your livestock} [Taha: 54], and His saying: {From it We created you} [Taha: 55] up to His saying: {And We certainly showed him} [Taha: 56] cannot possibly be from the speech of Moses; therefore, we made it from the speech of the Creator - the Exalted -." Then he said regarding the second aspect: "And Ibn Atiyyah said: 'The speech of Moses ended at His saying: {and sent down from the sky water}, and His saying: {And We produced} to the end is from the speech of Allah - the Exalted -.' End quote. And in it is far-fetchedness." End quote (1). Study of the Rectification: regarding His saying - the Exalted -: {[It is He] who has made for you the earth as a bed and inserted therein for you roads and sent down from the sky water. And We produced thereby [various] pairs of diverse plants}, the opinions of the exegetes varied; is all of this the completion of Moses' speech, peace be upon him, or does Moses' speech end at a certain point? The exegetes have three main opinions on this: 1 - That the speech of Moses, peace be upon him, ended at His saying: {My Lord neither errs nor forgets} [Taha: 52], and what follows is from the speech of Allah - the Exalted -.
foot_note: 1. Al-Durr Al-Masun (8: 51).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: This was said by: Al-Sam'ani (1), Al-Fakhr Al-Razi (2), Abu Hayyan (3), and others (4). Al-Sam'ani said: "His saying: {[It is He] who has made for you the earth as a bed} is the beginning of speech from Allah." End quote (5). Al-Fakhr Al-Razi said: "The speech of Moses, peace be upon him, ended at His saying: {My Lord neither errs nor forgets}, then the speech of Allah - the Exalted - began from His saying: {[It is He] who has made for you the earth as a bed}." End quote (6). Abu Hayyan said in his preference for this opinion: "We only went to the view that this is from the speech of Allah... - the Exalted -; because of His saying - the Exalted -: {And We produced} and His saying: {Eat and graze your livestock} [Taha: 54], and His saying: {And We certainly showed him} [Taha: 56]." End quote (7). Meaning that this cannot possibly be from the speech of Moses, so they made it from the speech of Allah... Almighty and Majestic.

text: 2 - That the speech of Moses, peace be upon him, ended at His saying: {and sent down from the sky water}, and what follows is from the speech of Allah - the Exalted -. This was said by: Makki bin Abi Talib (1), Ibn Atiyyah (2), and others (3). Makki said: "{And We produced thereby [various] pairs} exited to informing about Allah - Majestic is His mention -, because the speech of Moses with Pharaoh ended at His saying: {and sent down from the sky water}, then Allah - the Exalted - informed about Himself regarding the beautiful creation for His creation in their livelihood and the livelihood of their livestock, so He said: {And We produced thereby}." End quote (4). A number of scholars weakened this aspect, among them: Al-Fakhr Al-Razi (5), Abu Hayyan (6), and Al-Samin Al-Halabi (7); because it is contrary to the apparent meaning, corrupts the structure (Nazm), and misses the rhetorical shift (Iltifat); due to the lack of unity of the speaker (8).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Al-Zamakhshari considered what came in this verse as a case of 'Iltifat' (apostrophe/shift) from the third person to the first person; where he said: "{And We produced} transitioned in it from the wording of the third person to the wording of the obeyed Speaker (First Person), due to what I mentioned of diversification and notifying that He is obeyed, to whose command diverse things submit, and different species yield to His will, nothing is impossible for His volition." End quote (1). Ibn Al-Munayyir discussed this with him, stating that 'Iltifat' is only in the speech of a single speaker directing his speech in various ways, and this is not that. For Allah narrated Moses' saying to Pharaoh: {The knowledge thereof is with my Lord in a record. My Lord neither errs nor forgets} [Taha: 52], then His saying: {[It is He] who has made for you the earth as a bed} up to His saying: {And We produced thereby [various] pairs of diverse plants} is either made to be from the speech of Moses - thus being from the specific speech of royalty (We ordered/We did) - and this is not Iltifat. Or, the speech of Moses ended at His saying: {nor forgets}, then Allah - the Exalted - began describing His Essence, so it is not Iltifat either, but rather a transition from narration to initiating a discourse (2). 3 - That what came in the verse is all from the completion of the speech of Moses, peace be upon him.
foot_note:
1. Tafsir Al-Zamakhshari (3: 68).
2. See: Hashiyat Ibn Al-Munayyir 'ala Tafsir Al-Zamakhshari (3: 68).

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Some scholars mentioned this as a probable aspect, among them: Makki bin Abi Talib (1), and Al-Qurtubi (2). Makki said: "And it was said: It is all from the speech of Moses. Moses informed about himself and those with him regarding agriculture and dealing in tillage, for water is the cause of the plant's emergence and by it, it completed and perfected. And the dealing in tillage for the sons of Adam is by Allah's aid to them and His enabling them to do so, so he informed about himself saying: {And We produced thereby pairs}. And He - the Exalted - has said: {Have you seen that which you sow?} [Al-Waqi'ah: 63], so He attributed the tillage to the creation, while He is the Sower and Grower of the tillage, there is no god but He." End quote (3). This opinion was weakened by: Al-Fakhr Al-Razi (4), Abu Hayyan (5), and others (6); because the verse contains what makes it unlikely to be from the speech of Moses, peace be upon him. Al-Fakhr Al-Razi said: "Because His saying after that: {Eat and graze your livestock. Indeed, in that are signs for those of intelligence (54) From the earth We created you, and into it We will return you, and from it We will extract you another time (55)} [Taha: 54 - 55] is not fitting for Moses... peace be upon him. Also, His saying: {And We produced thereby [various] pairs of diverse plants} [Taha: 53] is not fitting for Moses; because the most that is in Moses' power, peace be upon him, is directing water to irrigate lands, but producing plants...

text: ...with their varying colors and natures is not from Moses, peace be upon him, so it is proven that this is the speech of Allah." End quote (1). Some directed this opinion by saying it is from the speech of Moses - peace be upon him - on the basis that he heard it from Allah Almighty and Majestic and inserted it verbatim into his speech, and thus he said: {for you} (lakum) instead of: {for us} (lana), and this is a type of quotation (2). The preferred view among these opinions: The first opinion, which is that the speech of Moses, peace be upon him, ended at His saying: {My Lord neither errs nor forgets}, and what follows is a new (inceptive) sentence from the speech of Allah - the Exalted -. Making His saying: {[It is He] who has made for you the earth as a bed} from the speech of Moses, and what follows: {And We produced thereby [various] pairs of diverse plants} from the speech of Allah - which is Ibn Atiyyah's opinion - contradicts the apparent meaning (3), and corrupts the structure/organization. For the 'Fa' (So/And) in {And We produced} (fa-akhrajna) connects to what is before it, so it is not permissible to make this the speech of Allah - the Exalted - and make what is before it the speech of Moses, peace be upon him (4).

text: As for making the entire speech the completion of Moses' speech, it is also far-fetched; since the branching out of: {And We produced thereby [various] pairs of diverse plants} [Taha: 53], {From it We created you, and into it We will return you, and from it We will extract you another time} [Taha: 55] does not suit that (1). So the preferred view is that it is from the speech of Allah, not from the speech of Moses. Therefore: Al-Samin's rectification of Ibn Atiyyah is in its place, especially since Ibn Atiyyah sufficed with mentioning that improbable possibility and did not point to the other opinions. * * *

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Conclusion Praise be to Allah who graced me with the completion of this research, and I ask Him - the Exalted - for more of His bounty and success. To proceed: These are the most important results that appeared to me through this research, which are as follows: 1 - The Tafsir of Ibn Atiyyah is one of the primary sources for Al-Samin Al-Halabi in *Al-Durr Al-Masun*. 2 - Al-Samin Al-Halabi's stance towards Ibn Atiyyah is moderate; he rectifies him at times, supports and approves his saying at others, and defends him against those who criticized him at others. 3 - Al-Samin Al-Halabi's independence in opinion from his Sheikh Abu Hayyan despite his frequent quoting from him. Therefore, he defended Ibn Atiyyah frequently against his Sheikh, in addition to his many rectifications of his Sheikh. 4 - The purposes of Al-Samin's rectifications of Ibn Atiyyah varied between weakening and refutation, addition and completion, and pointing to a more appropriate opinion or meaning due to an aspect of weighting. 5 - The topics and purposes of Al-Samin's rectifications of Ibn Atiyyah in Readings (Qira'at) varied as follows: • Defending the reading from the perspective of narration and transmission. • Directing the reading and defending it from the linguistic and grammatical perspective. • Rectifying Ibn Atiyyah regarding his lack of knowledge of some readings. • Rectifying Ibn Atiyyah regarding the meanings of readings. 6 - Al-Samin's adherence to the traditional methodology (Athari) in defending sound readings and refuting those who criticized them. He believes that transmission, if authentic, is not opposed by linguistic or grammatical analogy. 7 - Al-Samin Al-Halabi's care in directing Quranic readings, both sound (Sahih) and anomalous (Shadh), defending them, and responding to their critics, especially those who attacked them for contradicting grammatical schools.

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: 8 - The topics of Al-Samin's rectifications of Ibn Atiyyah in linguistic interpretation were numerous, and most of them were in the syntax of the Qur'an (I'rab). 9 - Ibn Atiyyah reported consensus on many issues in his Tafsir, among which were issues where consensus did not occur. Therefore, Al-Samin rectified him on some of what he claimed consensus on. 10 - Al-Samin's rectifications of Ibn Atiyyah are of high scientific value, especially rectifications in linguistic interpretation and Qur'anic syntax. This research was concerned with studying the issues related to rectifications and weighting among them. Many of those issues had not been previously studied or weighted, so I strove and preferred what appeared to me to be the correct view, relying on the rules of weighting in Tafsir and Quranic studies generally, and in linguistic interpretation and Qur'anic syntax specifically. 11 - The reasons for Al-Samin's rectifications of Ibn Atiyyah in Qur'anic syntax varied, including: • Weakness of Ibn Atiyyah's opinion or its far-fetchedness from the perspective of meaning, as Al-Samin leans towards meaning even if it contradicts grammatical structure. • Ibn Atiyyah's syntax contradicting the apparent meaning and claiming advancement and delay (in word order), and deletion and estimation. • His contradiction of the stronger and more famous syntactic aspect. 12 - Al-Samin was not concerned with interpretation by narration (Athar) or interpretation by opinion (Ra'y), which is the reason for the scarcity of his rectifications of Ibn Atiyyah in interpretation by opinion. 13 - Al-Samin omitted mentioning the evidence and reasoning in a number of his rectifications of Ibn Atiyyah, such as sufficing with saying: "It is questionable", or "It contains far-fetchedness" (1). Among the topics I see worthy of research: 1 - The stance of Ibn Atiyyah, Abu Hayyan, and Al-Samin towards sound and anomalous readings: A comparative study. 2 - The efforts of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in defending and directing Quranic readings. 3 - The rectifications of Abu Hayyan on Ibn Atiyyah: Collection and study. I ask Allah - the Exalted - to make this research beneficial, and to place it in the scale of my good deeds on the Day I meet Him. And I ask Him - the Exalted - to complete His blessing upon me. And my final call is that praise be to Allah, Lord of the worlds.

book_title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study
text: Thesis Abstract * Thesis Title: The Rectifications of Al-Samin Al-Halabi in Al-Durr Al-Masun upon Ibn Atiyyah in Readings, Interpretation, and Syntax of the Qur'an: Collection and Study. * Level: Master's. * Researcher: Hanadi bint Abdul Aziz bin Ahmed Al-Musa. * Supervisor: Dr. Nour Muhammad Ali. This research was concerned with collecting Al-Samin Al-Halabi's rectifications of Ibn Atiyyah, studying them comparatively, and preferring what appears to be the correct view, while explaining the reason for the preference. * Research Plan: The research was divided into an introduction, a preface, three chapters, and a conclusion. - Introduction: Includes: Importance of the subject and reasons for its selection, research objectives, research limits, previous studies, research plan, and research methodology. - Preface: Contains three sections: Section One: The meaning of rectification (Istidrak), its purposes, and its types. Contains two demands: Demand One: Meaning of rectification and its purposes. Demand Two: Types of rectifications. Section Two: Introduction to Ibn Atiyyah and Al-Samin Al-Halabi and their books in Tafsir. Contains two demands: Demand One: Introduction to Ibn Atiyyah and his book in Tafsir. Demand Two: Introduction to Al-Samin Al-Halabi and his book in Tafsir. Section Three: Al-Samin Al-Halabi's stance in *Al-Durr Al-Masun* towards Ibn Atiyyah's Tafsir. Chapter One: Al-Samin Al-Halabi's rectifications of Ibn Atiyyah in Readings (Qira'at). Chapter Two: His rectifications in Linguistic Interpretation and Qur'anic Syntax. Contains two sections: Section One: His rectifications in Linguistic Interpretation. Section Two: His rectifications in Qur'anic Syntax. Chapter Three: His rectifications in Interpretation by Opinion (Tafsir bi-al-Ra'y). - Conclusion: Contains the most prominent results of the research. - Technical Indices of the research. Through this research, a number of results were reached, including: 1 - Al-Samin's independence in opinion from his Sheikh Abu Hayyan, thus he defended Ibn Atiyyah frequently against his Sheikh, in addition to his many rectifications of his Sheikh. 2 - Al-Samin Al-Halabi's care in directing Quranic readings, both sound and anomalous, defending them, and responding to their critics. 3 - The multiplicity of Al-Samin's rectification topics on Ibn Atiyyah in linguistic interpretation, most of which were in Qur'anic syntax. The researcher hopes to have presented in this research what benefits students and researchers in the field of Quranic studies.
